My particular order consisted of a medium rare patty served with aged cheddar, Benton's bacon (very good), and ketchup served on an artisan bun.  Basically, it was a gussied up bacon cheeseburger, but it was a rather tasty one.  My major complaint is that I wish the actual meat itself exhibited more flavor.  Having said that, the burger was cooked properly and the flavors worked well together.  I ordered some wilted spinach on the side (mediocre) and truffle fries.  Let's talk about those truffle fries for a bit.  I know more people are apparently into the sweet potato fries here, but I think they are missing the boat.  Burger Up's truffle tries have pleasant aroma, taste great, and are the perfect texture for soaking up oil.  If you are on a diet, it is true you should skip these delightful fries.  But if that were the case, why are you at a burger joint in the first place?  Seriously, if you get nothing else out of my review, please do yourself a favor and order the truffle fries.  

Burger Up also boast an interesting beer menu with semi-obscure breweries from the Deep South included in the list.  I tried a pecan-infused amber from Mississippi - not bad.  I could imagine Burger Up could be a decent place to drink for a bit after eating.  

If I attended Vanderbilt, I would probably go here on a moderately frequent basis.  If you want a change from the dive bar hamburger, Burger Up is a decent change of pace.

3.50 stars.  I was told to go here for the shrimp and grillades (grits) and fried chicken, but I ended up loving the gumbo more than anything.  Located in Mid-City, Li'l Dizzy's is a cozy diner serving up an all you can eat breakfast/lunch consisting of fried chicken, trout, shrimp creole, rice & beans, grits, gumbo, omelettes made to order, fruit, and maybe a few other items as well.  It was all pretty standard until I reached the gumbo.  

Li'l Dizzy's gumbo is heavenly.  They don't hold back on either the sausage or the seafood as you have generous cuts of andouille sausage and crab legs in the wonderfully thick dark brown soup.  They got the flavor so perfect I felt no need to add any tabasco to my order.  I'd definitely come back here for the gumbo.  

Overall, you have plenty of options for breakfast/lunch in this city, and Li'l Dizzy's is a good one if you are in Mid-City.  It's a great option if you just want a cup of gumbo.

Favorite happy hour spot in SB.

Brings out all the best people for all your favorite games.

And no, not a typo, they have ping pong AND beer pong.  The bartenders are great and every one there is having a really good time.

It may help that the pitchers of beer are such a great deal.

Great pub. packed on a Friday but not so much you couldn't order a drink quickly. Great specials, solid mixed drinks, and a shocking palatable "AMF". Definitely a good place to bring a small group of drunken revelers.

if you visiting Indy, you have a few options: the backyard BBQ and pool party, the downtown scene, or the college-bar-esque atmosphere that is Broad Ripple.*

Monkey's Tale is right in the middle, has great karaoke outside, a huge deck area, cheap drinks (on par for Indy but for those of us accustomed to LA, NYC, SF, and/or Miami, you wouldn't be surprised to hear that it had one friend HUGGING a waitress thinking she'd significantly discounted our tab)

The clientele are pretty solid, so much so that one turned out to be a bartender at a place nearby which resulted in a lock-in and lots of complimentary drinks.

Would I go back? Absolutely.

*note: many locals will slur "broad ripple" (two words) into one gelatinous multisyllabic blurb that almost sounds like the name of a terrible strip club, but it's two words and in fact a rather innocent sounding Midwestern-type name.

There is no party quiet like the Brass-a-holics at Blue Nile on a Saturday night.

Truly the brass band for the 21st century.  I was blown away, never stopped dancing, and even got their card from the manager.

This is a band you'd fly out for a wedding or birthday.

Blue Nile is solid and worth the cover. drinks are cheap, plenty of room to move, great crowd. I have many favorites in Frenchmen (dba, spotted cat, etc.) but Blue Nile is in the top two without a doubt.

if a place offers a "drink for free" option for anyone brave enough to walk in naked (and remain that way), you pretty much know what you are getting into.

but late night, this place, if you can get there, is a blast.

If you hate American coffee (especially Starbucks) but shy away from gut-scortching Italian espresso, this place is for you.  If I lived in Philly, this place alone would convert me back to being a coffee drinker.

it's kind of like getting hooked on Motrin 800's...  
giving them up because you just we're "feeling it" any more...
and then having someone walk in and hand you a Percocet 10/350.

(I hurt myself a lot.  that was the best analogy I could come up with)

Just calling it what it is, Tonic is like fishing a koi pond with a shrimping net. If you don't catch something, your net must have some serious holes in it. 

Great music. Lots of people. Lots of space outside (Perhaps a little cramped at times on the dance floor, but nothing to complain about at all) 

The service is quick (it helps to bring people who work next door and at surrounding bars and restaurants) and you won't go home disappointed.

Not to be missed.

Definitely get there early for batting practice, and for those Tony Luke cheese steaks (the line behind us hit over 60 people, and it was still 90 minutes til the Nat'l Anthem).  Mine is Whiz, Wit and a side of the Broccoli Rabe.

The Schmidter is disgustingly good (just don't ask what's actually IN this sandwich) and they have Blue Moon over there and a short line.

Definitely worth the money for the Diamond Club.  behind the plate, comfortable seats, great (and relatively cheep) bar inside, great food, and access to all the fun stuff like the Hall of Fame on the 2nd level.

if you're a baseball fan, or like history, definitely check it out (they have an original 1889 scorecard).

Jersey Shore meets Reno. 

Surprisingly fun and great dancing (the band was going off, great dancing, strong drinks).

Some interesting people watching too.

As for the food, skip it. tried a few apps friends ordered and no one was enjoying them (they actually screwed up fried calamari)
always a stop on my Reno pub and bar crawl.  always.

Started at the bar while they set up the table at the restaurant. 

Sure, we could have waited around, but we would have missed out on the live country music, dancing, stiff drinks and the smell of amazing homemade chili (behind the bar). 

I ordered the baby-back ribs per the recommendation of the waiter and I was very impressed. Also had a bit of the duck which was equally good. 

Great service and great appetizers (got the platter/sampler). Definitely bring your appetite though. they don't skimp on the portions. 

Looking forward to coming back soon.

No question this place has some incredible rolls and sashimi.  Definitely the place you go for the creative and unorthodox (not for the same-old-same-old sushi).  

there are 200 items on the menu and I've only had the pleasure of 10 of them.  but as I return, I will expand this review (for now, anything with habanero sauce is to die for and the baked green lip mussels are killer...but be careful, they come in groups  of five so I hope you know how to share "awesomeness").

god bless my girlfriend for introducing me to this place.  can't wait to go back for the oysters (which, fyi, can run out if you get there too late!)

I've apparently been missing out on an entire dimension of what it means to be an American.

"Thank you" to the 100th Anniversary of the Indy 500 for getting me up to speed (at around 230 mph).

Not only is this a blast to go to the night before (the Speedway gas station and liquor store across the street are by far the biggest party i could ever imagine at a gas station) but the event itself is ridiculous, regardless of where you sit.

Courtesy of some amazing friends, we watched 50 laps from the first row facing the pits (bag or Church's Chicken in one hand, Jeremiah Weed cans in the other), the last 30 from the first row the press box, Box 8, and got a first class tour of the infield (ps: the snake pit in turn 3 is unfortunately no longer what it once was) in between.

never have a seen such debauchery and fun WITHOUT people causing a problem. heck, even with ridiculous traffic, i never heard a car horn outside. Yeah, the Midwest is in a class all it's own.

as for getting there, DO NOT take the interstate. find a local who knows the back roads and you will get there in minutes as opposed to hours.

Will I be back? heck yeah. See you all next Memorial Day weekend.

the Kamehameha nachos are possibly the best nachos I've ever had.

dear lord.

can be a bit of wait with a group but WELL worth it.

i don't know anyone in our group who didn't walk away stuffed.

this is a HAPPY HOUR review only.

After a long day of baseball at the beach, we ordered every thing from the happy hour menu (or just about).  From the mahi mahi tacos to the ahi poke and about a dozen oyster shooters, everything was great.  No complaints. 

Not a place to go if you are looking for a happy hour "scene" (definitely an older crowd) which is why we picked this place for food, and not state street.

I still can't understand the appeal. 

The TV's are horribly placed so more than likely, you will be directly under your team's broadcast (or in a blind-spot). 

For as cute as the hostesses are (for the most part), the service is unsurprisingly poor. 

I'd tell you what we think of the host (dude), but I'm a good Christian. 

And the place smells horrible. So you have to sit outside. Except there is a wait and/or you have to order food and your whole party must be there, even if you have a party of three at a four person table and someone calls you last minute because they got off work early and wants to meet up.

Unaccustomed to free parking at a hotel, I was impressed that they offered it. Even more impressive is the lobby. It's funky, clean and modern, yet it's still somehow inviting and warm. The rooms are fairly standard with nice touches like pretty reliable wi-fi, robes, tea, and a mini fridge with complimentary water.

I do have a couple of questions. One, what's with the bathroom door? Perhaps it's is just the room I stayed in, but the last thing I want to do is to wake up staring at the toilet. Yes, closing the pocket door to the loo will take care of that, but come on, that didn't come up at all during the design phase? And two - perhaps I'm tech challenged (having never owned a satellite TV) but does the "high tech" remote need to be more frustrating than setting the time on a 1990 VCR? Heed my warning: if you channel surf to high or too low you might wind up on a "games" station - exit - nowhere! Or you'll be in music central - again with no exit in sight. I just want to watch Law and Order gosh darn it ;p

Next time I'm going to work my darnedest to get a room on a higher level. In a flat town, the last thing you want to be looking at is someone else's roof.

This is my favorite live music venue in NOLA - a must for visitors seeking lively jazz. 

They offer two full bars, a few water stations when you tire from dancing, bar seats, a kickin' a/c, wood floors that feel like they're about to cave any second from all the dancing, AWESOME live jazz and a great crowd. It's definitley not your beligerant French Quarter Street crowd. It's more of the 30- to 40-somethings. 

This area is poppin', and I rec making a night of it on Frenchman Street. You can dart right next door to Blue Nile (a reggae bar), The Spotted Cat Music Club, Yuki Izakaya and others... 

There's a cover, but cute girls take note: flirt and bargain with the door fella and you just might get in for free or a discount. I don't mind paying cover, especially when there's live music but they do pass around a giant tip bucket MANY times over and it gets annoying, especially when you pay the full cover price and are drinking like a fish.

Yum! Talk about a really lovely margarita. A peach margarita made from FRESH PEACHES FROM THE FARMERS MARKET. 

My colleague Julie P also had a finely crafted drink. Scotch, whiskey, I can't remember, but it had a zing of yumminess which was perfect after a hot day of attempted scooter touring.

Do give Burger Up a try. The name had me thinking it was some burger diner, but that's not the case. It's a modern/industrial cafe with uber fresh food and drinks.

Let's start with the good. Location, location, location. It's in the thick of things in the HB hood. They've got a great patio with prime people watching. There's also parking! Unfortch, perhaps that's all that this resto/bar is counting on. 

I wasn't in the mood to eat, but with the lovely weather and a welcoming patio, the day called for a margarita. They featured a pomegranate margarita, and at $8.50, I thought it would be a stellar, finely crafted, high-quality marg. NO. Even when I asked our server if it had any artificial flavoring or sweeteners, she said no. "Good," I thought. Well it came in a tiny, tiny glass - not even a margarita glass - and had no hint of lime, tequila or pomegranate. It looked and tasted like a vodka and watered down cranberry. For $8.50 - methinks not! 

Service was okay, but it took a turn for the worst in the end. My tab was fine, so I won't get into that, but l'd expect a better handling of the sitch from management. I too, have worked in a restaurant.

5-stars at the chance to once again cheer on the oilers. Being from Houston, I haven't done that since '96!

The most lovely, bodacious and sweet Jennie M - Community Manager for Yelp Edmonton - scooped me up from the airport and surprised me with tickets to my first NHL game ever. I've been to many Houston Aeros and peewee games, but this was an experience. My highlights?

1. Dem hockey dudes are HOT. Who ever thought a mouth of missing teeth would make a girl swoon?
2. Friendly fans. The Oilers were playing the Boston Bruins that night (2/18), and from what I hear about NHL games, the rink isn't the only place where you'll see people throwing a few punches. But Oilers fans are redic friendly. A packed stadium and no drunken buffoons, no fights, no curse words. Fans were civilized. 
3. No one stole my jacket when I left it in my seat! What? I was surprised when Jennie M left her jacket at her seat, and was worried. "This is Canada. People don't do stuff like that." So after the 2nd period, I tried it, and I'll be damned - my jacket was still there when we returned. Crazy. I know. 
4, Rumor has it that people are calling the team the "Spoilers," because they're going to spoil other NHL teams from making the playoffs. And they didn't disappoint. The game went into OT and later resulted in a shoot out where they beat the Bruins 4-3.

So it's the day of NYE and just about every restaurant in the French Quarter has a line of 20 people out the door. Lucky for us, we came across Desire at just the right hour because we were immediately seated - almost window-side - in a packed house. 

With 127 reviews and counting, let me break it down for you...

Start with oystas! The raw oysters were incredibly fresh, chilled, and served with plenty of lemon. And they their house-made cocktail sauce has strong bite - or should I say a giant smack? ...because that was spice-ay! 

We also got the barbecue oysters. They're fried, glazed in a wonderfully sweet and smokey barbecue sauce, sitting over individual shells and topped with crumbled bleu cheese. I didn't snap any pics, but you gotta check out this photo snapped by another yelper... http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/JvawJ9bSr22xn4R9oLvl_w?select=VL23qeOnZHumSnISqQ0uXw

You can't get wrong with the gumbo, with its rich, thick roux. Probably the best I've had in a while. I also ordered the crawfish ettoufee. it was good, but I had plate envy for my friend's shrimp and grits. 

The bloody mary I ordered was alright. Not the best. It was a tad too thick and had the consistency of ketchup. The flavor and spiciness were there, but I should have ordered another shot of Tito's and thrown in some more Worcestershire to thin it out. 

Service was great. I appreciate how it was so busy, and yet our server kept reminding us to "take our time" and "enjoy your food." Love the Big Easy mentality. 

I'll totes come back. But probably stick with a dozen or two oysters and a nice cold beer.

I can spend hours upon hours at this backyard wine bar. In fact, I did. 

Walk in to the front of house wine retail store to pick out your favorite bottle of red, wine, rose, champs or beer - along with any snacks - and pay. Then head on back to grab your wine glasses, buckets o' ice, water (you'll need to hydrate if you're gonna camp out for hours), and snag a table!

:: Live music is offered all day, every day. 
:: There is a menu of food - like a fantastic cheese plate and other light bites.
:: Above the wine retail shack is a second story bar with hard liquor.
:: Tip your musicians!  
:: Enjoy the laid-back backyard atmosphere, cool tunes, great vibe, fun people watching.

Cafeteria + Carbs ...I couldn't be happier. 

Growing up in Houston, we have Cleberne's Cafeteria. But folks in this small town have Gray Brothers Cafeteria -- and I might be a bit jelly. 

Apparently at GBC, it's all about the pies. And y proudly display them at the front of the cafeteria line. It's a reminder to always eat your dessert first. Or at least leave enough room for dessert. 

The entrees include everything from fried chicken, fish, roast beef, even chicken and noodles (which appears to be a fan favorite on Yelp). Sides -- so many sides. 

The cafeteria has been around for decades. It fills up for lunch and dinner. A good time to dine is between those hours. Arrive hungry and leave with pie!

I think Joi B said it perfectly: "I've found a hotel that has it all." It's true.

Friendly, affordable, trendy, easy check-in, comfortable rooms, great lighting in the restrooms for proper makeup application, cozy beds, amazing rain shower, the softest hotel towels, a complimentary wine hour in the lobby, espresso machines in the hallway, turn down service - yes, turndown services offering warm cookies, bottled water, tidying up of the rooms. They're pet-friendly, they have a giant steamer (upon request); I actually kept it in my room for the full five days. 

The entire staff was extremely accommodating - this entire staff deserves a hospitality reward: valet, house keeping, concierge, front desk

The only cons:
This hotel is a freakin' ice box. Not bad when it's 99 degrees outside, but hanging out in the lobby for wine hour, in the restaurant for lunch or the conference rooms (the absolute worst of it), you're gonna freeze your nalgas off. 

I rec, I rec, I rec. I'll be back on my next trip to Nashy - which I hope is soon!!!

When you walk in, this place has the best aroma of oregano, basil, tomato sauce and other delicious Italian flavors, herbs and spices just brewin' in the air. It's a little taste of what's to come. 

My friends and I couldn't decided, so we mixed and matched two of their pizzas, and they even let you do halfsies. My half was vegetarian, but I added spinach and garlic (it's pressed garlic, so it's super strong). My favorite part of the meal was the crust - it was buttery, soft yet crunchy. I always eat my pizza crust first - "backwards" as some may say - and Ponzo's pizza crust reminded me why I do that ... it's the best part!

We also shared an order of their pizza rolls - now those, I really enjoyed. They're more dough than anything, and if you're a carb freak like me, it's perfect. Especially since the pizza itself is too cheesy (I know, there really isn't such a thing, until you have way too much cheese on your 'za.) The pizza rolls are akin to a pizza kolache - just order it and enjoy. Also get a cannoli, and share that bad boy, because Ponzo's are huge. 

More things to note:
+ Everything is made fresh, so your order will take some time. 
+ The bar next door - Dog House Tavern - allows outside food, so oder from Ponzo's and they'll even bring it right over. 
+ ...Or, you can just sit outside Ponzo's shared patio and order a drink from the bar. 
+ They deliver. http://www.ponzos.com/delivery_area.html
+ There's parking. 

I look forward to trying their famous lasagna and other Italian eats!

Octavia Books is perfection in an indie bookstore! I think that I could happily live here. I don't take up much space, I promise!

You've got the charming environs with lots of natural light. You've got helpful personnel who are clearly passionate about books. You've got events/readings by local and touring authors. You've got support for the indie book publishers (my friend did a reading here a couple years back and she was published on the tiniest of presses). You've got good selection and good organization.  You've got actual *books* with that good new book smell. You've got actual pages and hard covers and stuff.

I know that it's so easy to just "buy it on Amazon," add it to your kindle or IPad, but let's indie bookstores from extinction, please.

I love this little yoga mecca, and if it were closer to where I live, I'd be back and forth between here and Life Yoga.

I've been to two classes here so far, both in the first floor studio, which is spacious, cool, and has a good vibe all around. The upstairs studio, which I couldn't resist taking a peak at is incredible because it's all open, full of natural light and they even do acro yoga up there with aerial silks. 

It's like one big house of yoga up in here on Canal Street. Can't miss the brightly colored happy house. Oh and it's across the street from an abandoned building and the cutest tortie kitty who likes to hang out in the ditch. Only in New Orleans...

One thing I really appreciate is that both teachers I've had offered an opt out on being touched with oils during shavasana, so I'm assuming it's a studio policy. I can't tell you how much I appreciate that. For years, I've been in classes where I hear the teacher going around the room and it ruins my shavasana because I'm stressing out as I wait for them to reach me. I don't like to be touched by strangers, especially my face and head. So imagine trying to deep relax when your skin is crawling. It's nice to know that this studio takes it into consideration and now I know I must not be the only one out there!

Why, hello, there, Pelican Bay, newest restaurant on Elysian Fields, purveyor of the absolute best frozen daiquiris in the city, not to mention fresh & delicious food prepared & served with much love. Check me out - FTR (First To Review) and first to set a 5-star precedence, I'm sure.

Stupid me, I didn't bring an appetite, just a thirst for a piña colada because I knew here they have it in the machine so I wouldn't tempt the stink eye from a bartender (I was that bartender once, I admit). Here, you can order any kind of frozen concoction you want because they have a wall of frozen drink machines glorious churning up the colorful sweet stuff. You might feel like a kid at buffet where you can mix & match Pepsi and Mt. Dew and even Dr. Pepper (I was that child once). They have all these varieties and then will do something outrageous like a Piña Colada/Hypnotiq parfait. I stuck to the classic piña and wow, it even tasted like it wasn't filled with that obvious artificial flavor that some daiquiri places typically use (Gene's version is not drinkable, I'm sorry). It's true that I normally shun the sweet boozy stuff but there's something about a hot New Orleans day and the way these days practically beg for frozen cocktails. I'm a believer now. And this is where I'll be getting my fix. Sunday fundays, here's looking at you! 

Despite not bringing an appetite, I wanted to try their veg black beans (perfection-- just the right texture and seasoning) and oh, I can never say no to homemade tortilla chips. So, yes, I ate. It's kind of impossible not to at Pelican Bay. Know that if you're a vegetarian there are options for you (and how cool is it that they have a separate fryer for veggies?) and they note what isn't vegan on the menu, too. When asked by chef/owner Tanzanika what they could do to make the menu more veg-friendly, I suggested having some tofu options, maybe (I just love tofu. I know it's crazy). She laughed but seems like she's open to the idea. It's not even really necessary and if you're open to dairy, they have pizzas that look really great, too. Their emphasis is on FRESH food and yes, they shop daily. My guy had a burger that he said tastes just like "Mom's burger," which for him is a big compliment (for me, not so much. My mom's burgers possibly turned me off meat forever. Please don't tell her I mentioned it, K?)

Service is fantastic from the moment you open the door and are warmly welcomed. Our waiter couldn't be sweeter or more attentive and a special shout out to bartendress extraordinaire, Paris!

It's a slice of pure Southern comfort, friends. Get thee here immediately.

PS. There can't be a better place in the city to watch Saints games and other sporting events. TVs galore!

Vegan vogs alert!

What can I say? I love John Fluevog *long time*! I have dozens of pairs and still have my first pair from 20-odd years ago (they are a square toe boot with Chanel-inspired quilted tops). Thanks to my born-again vegan status three years ago, though, I crossed leather off my list forevermore and although he has been known to have a vegan shoe or two in his repertoire, that stopped a while back. Ages ago, I used to justify buying leather shoes and honestly, there weren't many affordable quality non leather options out there. Not to mention the fact that I have weird small feet that are also wide, have very high arches and an annoyingly high instep. Many shoes just do not work for my feet. Especially cheap ones (ie typical non leather shoes that you might find at Payless, Target etc).
#excuses

So yes. I was buying vogs like nobody's business because when they work for my feet, they really are pure bliss. They are gorgeous/quirky/cool and wearable. Then there are the outrageous super high ones that turn heads (the Malibu. I wore these to MOMS one year and I may have been sobbing in pain by the end of the night, but damn, I looked good). 

The other day an email arrived from John Fluevog. Angels sang. Cartoon birds landed on my shoulders. The bright purple stretchy velvet over the knee boots, aka "The Munchies" are in fact vegan! I called the local store and was informed that they have them in stock. Ten minutes later, I arrived, tried on my usual size 6, though because they are pointy toed, I expected I'd need to go up a size. The 6 fit perfectly and because they are stretchy, they can accommodate a variety of calves; skinny to muscled to those with some heft. These boots are perfect for Mardi Gras... and for Prince tributes. 

JF, thank you for making my dreams come true. Please continue making vegan vogs for those of us who live your motto, "Life is too short to wear boring shoes."

Let it be known that I'm notoriously more stingy with my stars when it comes to hotels. I mean, I gave the W three stars and I'm sticking to it! It's just that I've stayed in all kinds of hotels pretty much my entire life, and I do mean those ranging from budget family joints like Days Inn to luxury hotels like the Hyatt, to smaller, cooler boutique hotels like Hotel on Rivington and now the Moonrise.

I'll be honest with you, the amenities aren't quite as great as those at the W, and so normally I'd give the Moonrise a solid 3 stars (A-OK doesn't mean average in hotel stars, believe me). The Moonrise gets an extra star for the vintage moon photos that are just about everywhere in the hotel. I think decor-wise, Moonrise is my favorite, beating out even the Hotel On Rivingon's sleek rock and roll blood red/black decor! I just love the theme to death!!  There are the cute touches like the voice in the elevator making it seem like you're taking off/landing, the way that it always feels like nighttime is falling in the public parts of the hotel, the stationary, pens, all of it. LOVE.

That said, they don't replenish your products (H20, which I may like even more than Bliss' shower gel, shampoo and conditioner...Bliss wins for that facial wash, however), the way the W does. Oh well, not really a huge deal, and I guess I don't blame them. My room was spotless, extremely cozy and the bed was really luxe with loads of pillows. Temperature in the room was also perfect. 

The gym was sufficient for a traveling morning workout. Three elliptical machines, three treadmills and three stationery bikes. The strengthening equipment left a bit more to be desired (no free weights and just one weight machine in the place that shares two sets of the same weights, so essentially only two people can work out on half the equipment at the same time). Again, not a big deal. I was thrilled by the lounge outside of it that allowed for working stations overlooking the main lobby. All so very well-appointed.

Courtesy of the staff was adequate. I had an annoying check-in experience that I'm too weary to even talk about. Nothing major. Front desk staff was courteous (especially the gal working there in the evening). 

Not sure what was up with the cleaning staff. I had this one very eager dude wanting a greeting early in the morning and did not *get* that all I was able to utter was "good morning." I hate being rude, but uh, it was early, I hadn't had much sleep and I just wanted to get to the effing gym. I stepped onto the elevator feeling guilty about not being more pleasant.  I really hope that guy wasn't cleaning my room. I do have issues with male housekeeping staff. The very idea of it just creeps me out, especially when traveling alone.

Noise, well, I'll be honest, there was a morning when people were talking way too much in the hall (step to the elevator, please!) and there was a night that I just couldn't sleep due to the crowd spilling out into the street (apparently the lobby has that disco after hours thing going on that the W has) and what was more annoying was the asshole in the room next to me who banged on the wall to indicate that I was talking too loudly on Skype. F-You. It wasn't even 11pm. I'm hoping that the revelers kept his ass awake at 2am like they did me. Misery loves company. Bwahahahahah

They drew me with that couture frock in the display window. It's a strapless number, with my favorite construction in fashion: the bustle. If I had a spare chunk of change, it would be in my closet right now.

There isn't much to this end at Posh, though. Think more along the lines of labels that have clothes made in China (I know, I know... it's a lost cause to complain). That said, if you can get past this, they have a well-arranged delightful array of clothing to suit just about any style, with a concentration on young and trendy... and a leaning towards slightly conservative (nothing that I'd call head turners, besides that piece in the window). Perfect stuff for work, too. Then there's the shoes and accessories. I could easily spend an hour in here.

Also, I have to mention that the sales staff is incredibly nice! One guy even complimented me on my style (nice to hear on a day when you feel like you look kind of meh). 

Another star for the sales. Head to the back and be prepared to have your mind blown a bit with the sheer volume of items. They have tons of dresses, tops and bottoms, all arranged by color and the walls are lined with shoes that have major mark downs.

Their Pimm's Cup... shockingly good! And I was mesmerized by skee ball here. That's a remarkable thing for me to admit.

They have cocktails. They have an array of bar games. They have comfy places to sit. I sure as hell wouldn't classify The Other Bar as a dive, but it appears most yelpers do, so we'll leave it at that.

Note: the bartender served my boyfriend an unchilled shot of vodka. If that would have happened before I ordered a drink, I probably wouldn't have ordered anything. I just can't imagine any bartender in their right mind serving a warm shot of vodka.

While not a destination bar (I live on the other side of town), The Other Bar provides a great option if I'm on Freret and not in a Cure kinda mood.

I am completely obsessed with the soy candles Arbor House makes! Originally I had gone in for some of the Bougie Scents candles that I thought they carried. Walking into the lush n' lovely shop filled with greens and blooms, you're hit immediately with the luscious scent of burning candles After speaking to the extremely nice guy behind the operation, I learned that they now pour their own candles. In addition to that, they make soaps and lotions in the same scents. 

I purchased the following scents: gardenia (this has a really intense scent that makes you feel like you're in a tropical forest full of these intoxicating blooms), All That Jazz (their signature scene of jasmine and lemon grass-- it's absolutely heavenly!) and fig (a little more subtle, but still amazing). It's a good thing that they have a recycling program because I'm getting all three of these candles refilled as soon as they run out. I think gardenia is my favorite, with All That Jazz a very close second. I've never been all that happy with floral candles because they seem almost artificial. Not sure what magic they have going on up in here, but the candles smell like the most intense varieties of blooms and it makes me happy just walking into a room where I have one burning. Typically high quality candles of this size run you upwards of 40 dollars, but Arbor House charges you about half that for one of their masterpieces.

It's just not fair to leave them at three stars when I've been back a couple times over the years and had pretty great experiences, especially as they've expanded on their vegan options.

It was after 10 on a Saturday. Happy hour was a distant memory. I considered my meager options within a city where nightlife and eating are mutually exclusive and remembered Juan's. Lifesaver.

Their guac is legit outstanding and chips are paper thin and so crispy. We arrived hangry and devoured the basked in less than five minutes. Paired with a frozen marg with sangria floater and hanger turned to bliss in as much time. By the time the tofu tacos arrived, I decided my night couldn't get any better.

Our server was awesome. I've got to say, service at both locations is always excellent and pretty standout for a casual punk rock joint like this. 

Kudos for Juan's staying open an hour past the typical NOLA 10pm closing on Fridays and Saturdays (way to keep people drunk, New Orleans) and having decent vegan options.

I encountered the motherload of all things awesome and Asian here the other day. WoWowoW. Groceries were made, oh yes.

The produce section is enough to make me weep. I mean, 1.19 ea. for young coconuts that run you three times at that Whole Paycheck? There's an entire freezer section of exotic fruits, like bread fruit and duriyan (one day), if you can't find what you're looking for. I picked up a couple packages of frozen lotus root just cuz I love it and have never seen anywhere in a grocery store. 

If, like me, you're a saucy girl or guy, you may lose yourself in the hot sauce aisle. Dozens of varieties beyond sambal, Sri Racha and the like. Soy sauce... are you kidding? I've never seen so many different varieties. Although I tend not to buy premade curries and the like, there is scores of these too. 

There was something I was hoping to find: I would sell my soul to find bean curd skin, aka, yuba, and sadly was not able to find it the other day, but I'm sure it has to be somewhere here. If you're a fan of gluten and soy meats, you'll find an aisle devoted to this stuff (it's dried and you add water). Personally, I was more taken by the varieties of tofu in the fridge area. Mucho miso paste varieties right over there, too. Again, insanely cheap compared to WF. 

I'll be back soon and report more on this grocery paradise.

I've been a fan of Zotz since it was in its original location across from R Bar, what was it, 7 years ago.

Punk rock coffee joint at its finest, tasty as hell, environment right up my alley, tasty baked goods, too (vegan choices, too!). The kind of place you can walk in at any hour and get what you need (in my case, a high voltage caffeine joit).

Oh yeah!

Why I'd opt to go to Rouses over Whole Foods:

1. It's Louisiana-owned
2. They have Cajun hot nuts
3. Related to the above, they have an array of other NOLA specialty items (tourists, buy your foodie souvenirs here rather than the FQ)
4.They play New Orleans music rather than hippy dippy crap
5. Their employees are nice without making you feel like you've committed a sin by asking for plastic (to be fair, the cashiers at WF aren't nearly as self-righteous as the floor staff who seem like they'd spit on you if you ask for something that is against WF puredom, like artificial sweetener. Not that I'd ever ask for it, but a friend once had the audacity to do so and was met with a lecture).
6. Kick ass olive bar
7. They just have a lot more grocery items, and more affordable options at that
8. Not everything has to be gourmet specialty foods and products. They have those, but sometimes you want a bag of Zapps chips or a harsh cleaning product for eff's sake!
9. Nowhere nearly as pretentious (for example, you probably don't notice, but WF has plenty of produce that's from Mexico, California and other places).  
10. Aeroponic rooftop garden! How cool is that?
11. Phenomenal booze/wine/beer selection

Issues with this particular Rouses that would have me head to WF instead:

1. The oils area is confusing not only to shoppers but to employees as well. I had three different employees attempt to find me a vessel in which to pour truffle oil from the jug thingamajig and no one could help me. Not their fault as apparently they had just changed all that around, but no one clued the staff in. 
2. There's just not enough organic produce. It would be ideal as well, if the organic stuff wasn't all mixed in with the other stuff.
3. Not enough produce in general (uh, dino kale shouldn't be that rare).
4. Lack of gourmet whole bean coffee


Numbers 2-4 have double weight, as I'm all about the organic produce selection. A fine whole bean coffee i(extremely dark roast that I grind myself) is what gets me through a morning. I realize not everyone is as particular as me, but there you have it. Supermarket shopping is painful enough, I'd rather not have to go to more than one store per week.

Other things to note:

-gourmet and deli sections in this Rouses is really outstanding and similar to WF. I didn't check out the prepared food section too much, so I can't report on that just yet. 
-the staff really did go out of their way to find me an oil vessel. 
-that wine selection blows WF's out of the water

Expect review updates!

Give me liberty or give me death! Ok, so that's a bit dramatic and unnecessary. But I take black bean burgers very seriously and Liberty's Kitchen's black bean burgers are in the top 5 BBBs that I have ever had. 

I wasn't expecting this. I expected decent, but my mind was blown! Liberty's Kitchen's BBB is homemade, has an almost fluffy texture, and it's not trying to be "meat" -- this is just the patty which I would have gladly eaten on its own. They make it even better by piling on just the right amount of guacamole, and thinly sliced tomatoes & cheese. Get the cowboy caviar on the side- it's scrumptious. I could eat an entire bowl of the stuff. I'm just going to call it cowgirl caviar henceforth. And I might be inspired to ride a horse across the desert just to get more of it.

Thank god that's unnecessary. Though there is the parking situation (don't even think about parking in the lot. You'll be towed, according to those signs that point blank state, "NO LIBERTY KITCHEN CUSTOMERS." Jesus. Can't we all get along? I wish I could give you solutions but I lucked out with parking right out front.

My lunch for less than 10 bucks kept me full for the entire afternoon and into the evening. 

And the kids that work here are super cool, too. Love what this place is all about.

Sometimes, when all is right in a restaurant, you need to grant it "infinite stardom" and perhaps even yelp about your subsequent visits.

My second visit to Maurepas Foods had me trying a new cocktail, a Chameleon.  As I recite its contents, be prepared to drool: ginger limoncello, cucumber, grapefruit and the wide glass is rimmed with smoked salt. The result is just about indescribable (even for me), but if you're a fan of the Salty Dog, this is a creative and delicious take on the classic, making it perhaps one of the best drinks I have ever had.

Although I almost ordered the same thing as I had the last time, I had faith in the fact that trying something new would yield most positive results. So! The Brussels Sprouts can be made vegetarian (vegan, in fact) and I'm never one to pass up Brussels Sprouts. You get a huge portion of these caramelized cabbage babies. Delish! I also loved the orecchiette, small pasta pillows tossed with pesto sauce and haloumi, a slightly salty Middle Eastern cheese, topped with a sweet balsamic carrot garnish and shredded crunchy kale.  We're talking serious mouthgasm time.

We had a different server this visit and he was just as fantastic as Danielle, the gal we had last time. I'm not sure if it's how management trains the staff or just that they attract these fine folks to represent their restaurant but however it goes, I think you can just expect to be taken care of very well here.

I realize my last review had me professing my deep love to Maurepas on Valentines Day. I think it's appropriate at this time to propose a long time commitment.

I don't know what it was this weekend, but I could not tolerate most bars I went into because of the overwhelming cloud of dirty ashtray that hit me as soon as I crossed the threshold. Wait, I do know what it was this weekend: I had a shitty head cold. That said, 700 Club only added to my misery and although the crowd seemed friendly and fun enough, I just wanted to get outta there! Cucumber gimlets to go, please! 

I will say this really isn't my type of bar due to the huge TVs that dominate the space. Bonus points for the fellas... nice to be a gal in the midst of a boys' club with nary a lame pick-up line.

Verdict on the gimlet: nice cucumber scent/flavor, but a little too much Roses lime juice.

Props for the cheap-a$$ prices on food and drinks. Props for the tasty margaritas, chips and salsa. Props for the cool staff who are pretty damn nice and are at the top of their game. Props for the guac.

Juan's is a really fun place and no doubt I'll give it another go. Just wish my veg burrito had more flavor and more recognizable vegetables rather than muddy mush wrapped in a giant tortilla. An instance where I ate 1/4 of it, took home the leftovers and threw them out a week later. I'm bad with leftovers. Really bad, but I typically don't have any when eating a burrito, because I can't control myself around them. I go into a Mexican restaurant resigned to the inevitable burrito baby belly thing, but it didn't happen here for me.

In honor of Valentine's Day, I'm going to offer up my deep, deep love for a new restaurant. 

Maurepas sits on a corner in the Bywater and looks unassuming from the outside. The inside is open, airy, has lots of windows, and if this were 1955, I'd expect a good blue plate special. Not to stay it's diner-like. For some reason, I want to say "lodge with an edge." 

The staff is completely on point from the moment you are greeted at the door. Danielle, our server, was one of the most knowledgeable servers I've had in a while. You can tell that she works there because she wants to, not because she has to. She asked us if this was our first time, which it was, and explained with enthusiasm that they make almost everything in house, using whatever they can from local purveyors. I ordered a Bloody Mary, figuring it had to be top notch there and oh yes, it was. There was a hint of an usual spice in there (I'm thinking allspice) that didn't overpower it, but made it extra tasty. I believe they pickle their own green beans too, which may be the reason I was tasting the all spice. If the Bloody Mary is the most complex cocktail, then the bartenders at Maurepas are surely at Mensa level. 

The menu is divided into 2 sections grains, vegetables, and starch and then meat and fish. Note that several of the dishes may be in the first category but are not vegetarian, however, Danielle offered up suggestions and said they'd alter things to make them so.  

The soba noodles in hot broth (made from andouille, but you can get it made with veg-based broth) was just what I needed on this frigid day. It's served up with tofu on the side that might have been flash fried, not sure, but I liked what they did with it. The root vegetable gratin was thoroughly delectable, too.

 It took every ounce of control to not order one of the insanely amazing sounding desserts. Something to look forward to next time. I didn't want to, you know, "rush things." Oh screw it... I am in utter love with Maurepas and want to marry it and have its babies.

"Fly me to the moon(rise)
Let me swing among those stars.."

My second stay here and I think this is one of my favorite hotels in the country. That's saying a lot as I'm notoriously picky about hotels (see my hotels list).

The front desk staff is beyond helpful, welcoming and friendly. I love that they seem to love St. Louis so much and want to point you in the right direction for sightseeing and restaurants. I love that concierge is the "Master of your every desire." Come on!! Genius! 

That bed is seriously the most comfortable bed I have ever slept in in mah life! I found myself thinking that I could live in such a bed. 

That rain shower is the stuff dreams are made of. And H2O products rock (I'm so finding that salt shower gel online and buying it).

And those vintage moon photos everywhere... the cherry on top!!

For this price point, the Moonrise has achieved "as good as it gets" status in my opinion. I recommend it to all who travel to St. Louis. 

Note to self: return when the weather is most conducive to rooftop bar dwelling!!

Just a really quickish update to reflect the following: St. Lawrence has become my favorite place to stop in for a drink and late night snacks in the upper Quarter. It started to become a downright habit this past summer on those steamy hot Sunday Fundays that demanded a frozen daiquiri. Although I maintain that sugary drinks are among the worst things I can put in my body, sometimes you just have to... Especially on a day with 100% humidity. Being that they make theirs in-house rather than pour crap out of a plastic bottle with a list of ingredients that include an array of poisonous flavoring and HFCS, St. Lawrence is going to give you your very best frozen daiquiri option in the Quarter! 

I love the Pimm's Cup daiquiri and just recently became enamoured with the holiday special, pumpkin. A place in the upper FQ that cares enough about their customers that they craft frozen daiquiris speaks volumes (let's face it, a fair portion of their customer base stroll in with their giant plastic tumblers of the shit from Bourbon St so you'd think they wouldn't know any better anyway) and St. Lawrence has a devoted crowd of locals to show for it.

Oh and everyone walking in the door is treated extremely well. The waitstaff and bartenders are among the friendliest in town and hell, you might even start chatting up one of the cooks while you're at it.

I just really love this place.

With all these check-ins (and being declared the duchess, sorry, Scott S, muahahahahahha) you'd think I'd write a review already...

I'll be honest. It's taken me quite a while to warm up to Gym Matrix because I'm used to more of a "health club" atmosphere... with crap I never used, granted. Like a sauna, steam room, indoor/outdoor pools, massage etc. etc. But those things were there if I wanted them. And decent yoga classes. And spinning (I miss these and I can't deny that once I move, I'll just join the New Orleans Athletic Club). Hell, the last club I belonged to had several bars in it, too. And that is most definitely not part of the Gym Matrix business model.

But I can't fault them that. For what I'm paying for, a basic gym with cardio that is made up of 4 elliptical, 4 treadmills, 1 stairclimber and 2 reclined cycles, it's worth it, in my opinion. There are decent weight machines and plenty of free weights (I do wish they had one of those pull up machines that has counter weights so that I could continue to work on my goal of doing a damn pull-up). The staff here are all extremely nice and helpful. You don't get any training pressure, either, which is nice. It's also not ever crowded. They get points, rather stars, for all of that. I think of it as a bigger hotel or apartment gym. I just take yoga in other places.

It is what it is. And it's open 24-hours.

It's been about 5 years since I last reviewed Swan River Yoga and although regretfully I can't add stars (I would, if Yelp had a 6, 7, or heck, even 10 star system), I just want to show them more love.

In the years since my last review, I've moved a couple times and was super close to Wild Lotus in the Marigny. Walking to yoga is of course ideal, and Wild Lotus is also a phenomenal experience, so I moved my practice over entirely to there. A couple years, a lapse in practice - I'm living a half hour from civilization- and I started up again at Swan River back in May. It's just been idyllic! I love this studio, with its enormous room upstairs with tons of natural light and air. I love that they burn incense, making for the good smells! I love the morning/afternoon vegan cafe downstairs that makes some of the best cold brew in the city, along with delicious plant-based options (and sinful baked goods that everyone needs once in a while). I love the teachers, especially Michelle and Keith. They both make yoga so approachable that I'd happily bring anyone new to yoga to one of their classes. Love love love. 

One thing that makes this studio unique is the "Assist" cards (at least I've never seen those at any other studio I've practiced at). If you're not feeling like having the teacher do hands-on assists any given day (or time during the class), you turn the card over. There's also the option for no touching during Savasana. 

Their schedule is especially appealing to me, as I live a half hour to 40 min in traffic from Downtown. Those mid and late afternoon classes work for me, but there's also morning and evening classes if that works better for people with more conventional schedules. 

Having two yoga studios that you love in town is priceless! I'm so glad to be practicing on the regular again at Swan River.

I've been a long time fan of dba in NY (and just recently went to their location in Williamsburg). In fact it was my bar of choice when I worked right across the street (at another bar, go figure). The Frenchman location has all that the NY location has but ups the ante quite a bit. There's live music and a cozier vibe (I'm particularly fond of the window booths in the second room... great for crazy sidewalk watchin').

You probably don't need me to remark on the most impressive selection of beers by the bottle and on tap. I'm going to anyway, of course and let's consider the spirits, while we're at it (I'm not a beer drinker, but appreciate that they have Ace Pear in the bottle). Awe-inspiring spirit selection, actually. They have an entire gin *department* if you will, rather than the usual Sapphire and Tanqueray (and Hendrick's if you're lucky). If you're a whiskey/bourbon drinker, you'll be in heaven. If you're a beer drinker, you'll be in heaven. If you love to drink, you'll be in heaven. You get the picture, surely.

The other night I stuck to plain old vodka sodas for some stupid reason, but sometimes I feel overwhelmed when presented with too many choices. Here's to you... and my return soon!

This parade is long, full o' throws, full o' cool floats (this year designed after streets/alleys/places of interest in NOLA) and full o' good will (the parade route is made so they pass by over a dozen organizations for people with disabilities/illnesses). Favorite throw was the blingy medallion beads. Love that the 610 Stompers are a part of it because they crack me up. Less thrilled with what seemed like more boom box pop music than brass bands.

I think this parade has convinced me, however, that I need to maybe not live on a parade route next year. So many people set up shop on "my" front lawn (if I owned this house, you can bet on it that I'd construct a fence) and left tons of trash including a tarp behind. Then there was the dude who brought a GAS GRILL and ran a picnic (he did not know anyone who lived here) for his family. His kids kept running up like roaches on my front porch to grab anything they could find. Actually, so did he. I know, I know, it's Mardi Gras, but... let's just say that if they had some manners, I wouldn't really care.  His kids and the kids with the family who set up their ladders on the front lawn started throwing beads, footballs etc back and forth with the revelers who live upstairs. After all the parades were over and everyone was drunk, for a grand finale, one of the fathers got into a fight with the a guy upstairs on the balcony and charged into the building to kick his ass. Quite a ruckus indeed.

But it's not Thoth's fault. Great parade.

The more I practice at Swan River, the more I am thinking that I'm actually going to start going out of my way to practice more here, despite other more conveniently located yoga studios.

The reasons:

1. Classes here are 90 minutes long which allows for good warm ups and even singing/chanting, which is a pretty nice aspect of yoga that I enjoy occasionally.

2. Both rooms are spacious. Extremely spacious. Upstairs has the added bonus of crazy high ceilings that make you feel like you're practicing in a temple. Really lovely.

3. The rooms are at a comfortable temperature. Read: not stifling hot. I've never liked hot yoga or Bikrim, but at least when studios advertise that the class is such, I know to avoid it. There are a few studios and teachers in town who don't advertise their class as hot yoga, yet shut off a/c and fans on mid summer days. I understand when they don't want a room to be cold, don't get me wrong. And I prefer windows open/fans on most days-- just not in July/August usually!

4. Lots of props.

5. A unique array of classes (check out all those descriptions!)

and most important (and related to #2):

You will not be on top of the person next to you. You know what this means? You will not smack into them nor get kicked in the head. And in general, I am not a fan of someone else sweating on my space either, thank you very much. I appreciate the generous amount of space at Swan River!

Students here range from beginner to advanced and classes are marked as such. I love Sunday eve's Jivamukti class with Keith. She is awesome. And I'm not just saying that because we did a ton of heart openers last night because those are my favorites :)

I have come to know and love a lot of yoga classes in New Orleans over the past 9 months or so and in most cases that is due to the teachers. In Swan River's case, it's due to both the space and the teachers.

Win!

I've long admired the Hotel Mazarin for its picturesque courtyard because I'm often in the adjoining wine bar, the exquisite Patrick's Bar Vin. I've spend many an idyllic afternoon/evening here. I've also booked several of my colleagues at the Mazarin when they've come to New Orleans and heard good things from them (as recently as January 2015).

So when looking to book a hotel for a work conference 10 people I was leading, Hotel Mazarin was at the top of my list. And when you realize that in other local hotels you're probably going to get that New Orleans jenk known as "charm"  for a similar price, I will absolutely recommend Hotel Mazarin for being immaculate (with one tiny exception in my bathroom, but I'm insane), amenities (almost Westin-quality beds, flatscreen TVs), and the restrained modern baroque decor (gold fixtures, marble floors). If you're a breakfast-lover, you cannot beat that deluxe complimentary breakfast (eggs & bacon, pastry, toast, cereal, juices). Seriously, I've stayed in New Orleans hotels with TVs straight out of the 90s, ancient (as in, not antique) beds, dated decor and questionable levels of cleanliness. I won't name names (search my reviews if you must). But Hotel Mazarin boasts higher standards. 

That said, my colleagues and I had some issues during our stay last month that should be noted. 

-multiple reports of the front desk/reception staff being aloof and often downright surly (unacceptable and so not typical of the superb hospitality that is the custom of New Orleans. I'm honestly scratching my head over this one). One of my people was reprimanded for putting a room card/key in her wallet when she came down to report that her keys weren't working (she never put it in her wallet but even if she had?!) When she explained that she had done no such thing, the response from the desk was an eye roll. Another colleague called the desk to report that his room was noisy. With a week of late nights and early mornings ahead of him, he thought he could request a quieter room. He was informed that he was in a quiet room. That's it. No apologies or explanations. I can write more, but in the interest of space, I leave it at these two instances. 

However, all of the other hotel staff were great, from management to catering (special props to the lovely Mary who took care of our conference room. She is a gem!) Everyone in the breakfast room and in catering were ALL so lovely and friendly (everyone says good morning and the catering manager walked around talking to everyone, making sure they were having a great stay). 

-the showers are extremely tricky to work and some of us didn't have anything hotter than lukewarm water. This is horrible to deal with first thing in the morning on one of the coldest weeks in New Orleans. I live here and I know the city's water pressure leaves a lot to be desired, especially in old French Quarter buildings, but this isn't OK in a hotel. Apparently there was some trick to get it to work and I can't even tell you what that is, because it's really *that* tricky. There should be instructions posted, unless this was a fluke with half of my colleagues' rooms. 

-catering: although the food is good, it's extremely overpriced for what you get. You are not allowed to bring in outside food, so if you're using their conference room you're going to have to use these services. I know this is common practice in hotel conference rooms, so although I won't fault them for this, next year I'll try and find an alternative.

Related to this: when setting up my catering order, I specified that three of my group had dietary restrictions/extreme food allergies. For the very expensive muffaletta sandwiches, I thought they'd at least offer a GF bread option for one or two of them for my G/F colleague, but no. Second, I was told the king cake would be nut free and it was not. Suddenly I saw one of my colleagues leaving the room in the middle of a session and I later learned that he had to go up to his room and take an emergency Benadryl. If he hadn't, he likely would have needed to go to the hospital, for his nut allergy is that extreme. If I put on my request that at least one dessert should be nut free and the only other dessert item is pralines, the cooks should pay attention and not put nuts on the king cake. Pretty simple. Attention to detail is crucial. Again, when you're paying extremely high prices for catering, high expectations should be met.

I would still recommend Hotel Mazarin thanks to its amazing location for visitors to our city, as well as the nice perks, including two comped drinks at the fabulous 21st Amendment Bar. Plus it's just nicer all around than other FQ hotels in this price range.

The simply-named Tavern offers up some mighty simple comfort food pleasures (White Trash hash, anyone?) and elevated junk food game bites. 

That said, I'm not sure this is quite the weekend brunch place for me, due to the TVs providing all of the background noise. I'm not a fan of big TVs blaring games -- to me, this is the worst kind of ambiance. BUT... for those of you seeking a place to watch local sports and cheer on with a crowd, Tavern is the spot for you, especially if your tastes are a bit more high brow than your typical nachos. I mean, they have nachos, but Tavern's come with pistachio and goat cheese. Nice! 

I'd easily return on a non game day (or even to sit on the shaded side patio) for more of that White Trash Hash. Think tater tot casserole. I mean, really. Goodbye hangover. The egg white omelet I had was kinda blah, as the tomatoes made it seem extra watery.The "Wicked" Bloody Mary was hardly wicked, more like gentle, despite the vodka being infused with pickled things that you'd hope for on your glass. They don't automatically garnish the way you'd think. Or at least the way a New Orleanian would think. I mean... just a lime? Nu uh. Our very lovely server came out with some olives for us, which was nice. But a Bloody without beaucoup d' garnish is a naked Mary, indeed.

Extra props for three bottles of hot sauces on the table, marked X, XX and XXX. Go for the orangey habanero, as it's the tastiest of the bunch (it might be the XX). Don't be fooled by the warnings. They are there for the bland American palate.

It seems that true vintage shops are themselves becoming a thing of the past. Where there were once specific streets or neighborhoods that were known to be great for vintage shopping in any given city, that's no longer the case in cities like New Orleans or New York. I look at the 50+ dresses that are in my closet, mainly from the 20s through the early 60s. It's discouraging to note that even though I don't really even wear them anymore, they are slowly but surely disintegrating (especially my 1920s and 30s numbers). What was once a fine silk frock is now reduced to spiderweb thread-bare on the seams, shoulders and anywhere there's the slightest bit of friction. Evil moths have attacked cashmere sweaters (they sure do have good taste, as they leave alone the cheap cotton numbers) leaving them beyond repair.

But I don't mean to depress you. There's Blue Dream, restoring my faith in vintage. I looked through well-kept racks of dresses, men's shirts, jeans and accessories and was quite impressed. The prices are reasonable and the quality is excellent. I get the feeling they carefully choose each garment they sell, perhaps at estate sales where a dress might have lovingly been looked after, stored in cedar and out of the sunlight. 

Best of all, and I kind of don't want to reveal this lest you come and snatch them all up for yourselves, but they have quite the selection of old Nola postcards, most with original quaint writing on the back!!! I'm a bit of a collector. It gives me great joy to read what people wrote about their vacations. My favorite one is addressed to a "Dear Ingrid" in Chicago and the sender notes, "It's lovely here, but give me good old Illinois any day!" Clearly this person is both in love with their home and a bit touched for how could anyone prefer freezing cold Illinois to the lush, romantic cityscape of New Orleans?

The Tiki gods have answered my prayers! New Orleans now has a fabulous Tiki bar, with just the right dark Polynesian atmosphere that's straight outta Trader Vics circa 1965. My mom would always regale me with stories about her times at Hawaii Kai in Manhattan in the 60s. As a child, I'd cherish our annual trips to Mai Kai in Fort Lauderdale (which still exists, apparently!) Fun fact: About 5 years ago, I was a featured bartender in Inked Magazine where I talk about making Tiki drinks (you can see the photo in my profile), as I worked in a Tiki bar in NYC (Waikiki Wally's RIP).

So, yeah. I'm a lover all things Tiki, though I have to admit, I hate loathe and despise sweet drinks for obvious reasons, but hell, it's a Yelp review so I'll just come out and say it: usually sweet drinks mask cheap liquor. Usually sweet drinks are meant for people who aren't drinkers and can't stand the taste of alcohol. And last but certainly not least, sweet drinks mean for inevitable hangover. I pride myself on being a veteran drinker and at most, get one hangover a year. In fact, my year anniversary of my last hangover is coming up. July 4. 

The fabulous thing is, Tiki Tolteca offers up *craft* Tiki drinks. Yes, you're reading that correctly. Look at my menu photos that detail the ingredients! They even offer up little stories with each drink. Their cocktails don't only feature rum, but such lovely spirits as my beloved Mezcal, and my much less beloved caçaca. I settled on a Hemingway Daiquiri, which is frozen and perfect because it's not a fruit daiquiri, so not filled with artificial nonsense, just lime, rum, & maraschino liqueur. And potent, seeing as I was feeling a nice buzz after two.

They also have a menu feature small plates with a tropical flavor. DO NOT PASS UP THAT CHOCOLATE TRUFFLE DESSERT. The Tiki gods command it, too. Seriously. It really is the stuff of the gods. Chocolate, coconut, banana sauce... 'scuse me while I talk in tongues. I look forward to going back and trying the sweet corn tamales (vegetarian!). No crab rangoons, though, thankfully (created at Don the Beachcomber and now for some reason is expected on any given Chinese restaurant menu for some perplexing reason).

Oh!! Be sure and order a High Life, if you're so inclined, so you can get the full bottle service experience. This is no joke. They serve it in Champagne glasses and ice your bottle. Luckily my drinking partners indulged so I didn't have to.

More fun trivia. You may see in my profile that my current (and forever) crush is Howard Hughes. Apparently there's a tale of him drinking one too many zombies at Don the Beachcomber and then killed a pedestrian with his car. Bad Howie!! I hope it's not true. But yeah, beware the ENTIRE ZOMBIE MENU (seriously. TIki Tolteca has an entire zombie menu!!)

What's next Tiki Tolteca? Maybe scheduled thunderstorms over a lagoon a la San Francisco's Tonga Room?

Give me a bottle of red wine and a backyard, throw in some good company and/or good music and I really can't really be much happier. Hello, Bacchanal!

Oh, but there's more! See, what you're doing is buying the bottle at the price you'd get it at the wine shop (essentially because you *are* at a wine shop), so there's no bar/lounge mark up, then hitting up their glorious back garden space, filled with trees, fairy lights and all kinds of magic. And wait... there's more! They have a fridge with cheese wedges, and you pick one or more out, bring it up to the counter to pay and within minutes, they'll whisk a huge cheese plate to your table that's overloaded with toast, some fruit and nuts. 

In the days of super lounges and other such nonsense when you're paying high covers and then $$ drinks as well, it's kind of hard to believe Bacchanal can be so generous. Maybe it's due to the city of New Orleans honoring the spirit of Bacchus on a regular basis? The god is giving back...

Kinda makes me want to move in... or next door or even upstairs. I won't complain about the live music, either...

I've gotta be honest. I'm slowly but surely losing my love for United. Sure, you get all the charm of the ladies answering the phone, not to mention, the usually AWESOME, friendly and efficient drivers.

But... I've had a couple terrible experiences recently that have me calling White Fleet, instead. 

During Mardi Gras, a United driver picked up three girls with suitcases he found on a corner in the CBD as he was driving me home from the Bywater. I didn't complain b/c, well, it was during Mardi Gras and that's probably enough said.

BUT... he dropped them off in the LGD on the way to my apartment Uptown, and then he charged ME for the extra passengers. WTF? I called and lodged a complaint because I stupidly didn't feel like arguing (also, I felt sorry for him, like a dumbass, because he was talking about putting kids through college and being broke and... well, it was Mardi Gras, LOL). I've come to find out that THAT waste of time lodging the complaint was not worth the inconvenience and money I was out.

Other issue with United: the last few times I was going to the aiport, I had no cash and apparently barely any drivers accept CCs so I was waiting at the very least a half hour and almost an *hour* once for a cab to pull up.

So, White Fleet it is from now on. Just the way it goes....

Thanks for the reminder, Yelp! I love Fair Grinds, yet I apparently never wrote them a review. So here's the five star review they've been missing for almost 2 years now. 

First a mention on how they are one of the only coffeehouses in NOLA that's dedicated to fair trade coffees and all of their tea is organic. That the tea is organic is a huge deal as I recently learned non-organic teas are ridden with pesticides. Not that I'm such a big tea drinker, but in September-October I'm all about dirty chai and by "dirty" that means a shot of espresso, not a spray of pesticides! Thankfully they make their own chai and hooray for it not being overly sweetened like that stuff from the box.  They have almond milk in addition to soy, so you don't have to worry about GMO-ridden lattes!

I haven't tried their baked goods, all of which look delectable, but I had lunch once, some kind of vegetarian sandwich that I can't recall other than the fact that it was quite good. If you're in the mood for lunch, be aware that they stop serving it around 2. Bagels and pastries are available all the time, though!

Fair Grinds is small and cozy and a traditional coffeehouse in that it's more reminiscent of being in a real house than a sterile storefront/corporate coffee bar. They have community-based activities like Kundalini Yoga weekly and various performances. The staff is so very kind and accommodating and I just love that side verdant patio that's off to the side. It's the kind of place I can easily lose hours in good conversation or a book. But typically I'm working on my laptop, so to that end, you don't have to go crazy scoping out an outlet. Internet works just fine every time I've been there. 

I have some great coffeehouses in my area, but none of them "have it all" like Fair Grinds. The fact that I actually get in my car and drive the 15 minutes or so that it takes to get here speaks volumes, doesn't it?

It's fun up in here!

A night here will include any of the following:

-karaoke (not my thing, but it's fun to watch your friends get up there and rock it)
-drinks, cheap 'n strong
-running into your neighbors from way across town (testament to a bar's greatness- getting people away from the bars in their own hood)
-friendly greetings from the regulars sitting at the bar. They may have seen it all, but they do make you feel like you're special walking in there. I judge a good bar by its regulars.

The good thing about the karaoke is that there is no host (it's all done fair and square by computer). Seriously, there's nothing like an annoying karaoke fluffer. I don't want to see some professional singer up there hogging up every other song just to keep people there waiting and drinking. And I definitely don't need a snotty KJ. Not that they all are but once in San Fran a large group of us were banned from the karaoke list because of the KJ's control issues. Really, should karaoke be so ridden with rules and egos? I think not. 

I may have left on the early side the last time I was there, but I have a strong feeling the place only gets more interesting as the night goes on.

I came to St. Louis expecting to try  *St. Louis style* pizza, which I only learned was an actual style of its own about a year ago. Yes, I had been living under a NYC rock. I mean, stone. A pizza stone.

I had been told St. Louis style pizza featured some kind of cheese known as Provel. Actually, I had been told by someone who is not from the area that it was Provolone, but I was quickly corrected by Abby S, that Provel and Provolone are two different things. Intrigued, but not without some trepidation, I figured, sure, I'll try St. Louis style pizza! Across the street from the hotel to Pi, we went.

Only, Pi is *anti* Provel, as it turns out (their t-shirts proudly indicate this). Instead, Pi is known for its cornmeal crust and although it is "deep dish," it's heavy on the sauce (*not* heavy on the cheese). Now *that* is my kind of pie. FYI they also have thin crust if that is your thing. Typically, that is my thing, but when in St. Louis, one should do as the St. Louans (is that what they're called?) do. Although, I think St. Louis pizzas are traditionally cracker crust. Ah, there I go again. ANYWAY...

It was a beautiful spring day on Wednesday, so we sat outside and were immediately taken care of by our friendly waiter who brought us water and drinks (really good house iced tea that is infused with some kind of blossom). We were warned that the deep dish pizzas take 35 minutes to prepare, which was fine with us.

It was worth the wait. Holy delish, batgirl! I ordered kalamata olives and mushrooms on mine and the sauce to cheese ratio was just perfect. I love the sauce! Chunky tomato, not sweet. Mmmmmm mmmm good. And that crust was just awesome. If polenta were a crust, well, there ya go! I just love the combination of cornmeal and tomato sauce. It wasn't tough, like i expected. Oh yes, I'm a fan!

We were there for a pretty long time and our waiter kept checking back on us, refilled our drinks without interrupting our meeting and finally, it was time for a limoncello cocktail. Oh wow! 

Now, where to get St. Louis style pizza that isn't traditionally St. Louis style, but *Pi* style pizza in Kansas City?

How to review such an iconic establishment? I've been to events here on two recent occasions: a burlesque show and a concert.

The nitty gritty:
-good sightlines
-good sound
-kick ass, fast and efficient bartenders (I've been to enough venues where they can't manage the crowds, or maybe they choose to be slow because the crowd is so anonymous to them).
-part of me wants to just live in those little houses that flock either side of the stage.

If you're "hungry like the wolf" (sorry, I had to go there), pop in next door for what smelled like good, greasy bar food (I did not indulge). It's also a good spot for a breather, as there are seats. The main venue doesn't have as much as a banquet. 

Side note: Doesn't "Howlin' Wolf" sound like something out of the gay animal kingdom?

Really, unless you're a Mormon, how can you *not* adore a festival that celebrates all things cocktail? If people into the intricacies of flavor, texture and ingredients of food are "foodies," what would you call the same types of people who are into cocktails and booze? New Orleanians.

Hence, this festival makes the most sense coming out of New Orleans and it's been a slow, steady explosion. I don't need to give you the history, though. I'm just going to give you my take on it.

I'll give my only criticism here and as you can see from my 5 stars, it certainly didn't ruin my experience. It does bear mentioning. Check-ins on the first day closed at 6pm. I arrived at 6:10 due to crazy traffic due to Obama being in town thus causing a regular 30 minute trip to take over an hour. Although the staff was still in the reception room, they refused to check me in. I think check-in should close a lot later than 6pm, after all, the opening bashes were all going on that night and without your tickets, you can't get in to them (or so I thought. Luckily I was able to get into both Better with Age and the Absolut opening party with my assistant's tickets since she had her media badge). Besides, with people coming in from all over at all times *and* it being that it's in a hotel, next year it would be nice to see extended check-in times.

That aside, I thoroughly enjoyed my lost week, I mean, incredibly fun-filled week at TOTC. From the volunteer staff who checked you in at each event and seminar (all of them incredibly nice) to the tasting rooms to the hotels and other types of event venues, all I can say is that I was left thoroughly impressed. There was just so much going on, it's impossible to catch everything. I paced myself rather well (time for a pat on the back). 

And that L'agniappe Lounge. WOW!!! This room, I believe, is only for media and other sponsors, but holy crap. All of the brands and sponsors left swag, product and other fun materials (favorite had to be the moleskine notebooks thanks to Tanqueray or Hennessey-- it's tastefully embossed into the cover). OH!! And the bottles of shrubs and bitters!!!! I also now have an entire bar of tiny bottles (there were regular bottles, too, but I didn't take any due to not wanting to carry them around). Boozers, you will feel like a kid in a candy shop in that room! Incredible. 

My favorite events were Better with Age and the Absolut bash (I mean... they had SNOW pumped into the room!). The Diageo Happy Hour was fun because of the people I was with, however the food left a lot to be desired (do not bring a bread bowl around to hundreds of people to dip their hands into. Whose idea was that??)
... not to mention that although there were master mixologists at the bars, they had to make due with the ingredients that were given to them (kind of like the "Chopped" for bartenders). I definitely preferred the vodka cocktails to any others.

While the booze flowed freely, my tip to attendees is to make sure and pack some energy bars because this event is not about food, so don't expect any. Plan accordingly! Also next year, I plan to stay in a hotel so I can stumble to/from events (and leave all the goodies I pick up along the way in my room). 

Note: I did not attend any of the Spirited Dinners this year.

Ever get overwhelmed by ostalgie? "Of course you can't, Joi, you grew up in the ol' US of A, safely thousands of miles away from the Eastern block, while your relatives were surviving the aftermath of a cold Prague Spring.

But, but... I totally *get it* just like I may be prone to yearn for times of the plague and consumption and I wasn't around for those either. 

Pravda offers up the Soviet chic in droves and I love every ounce of this place, from the dark red furnishings and communist chic (reminds me of KGB Bar, or perhaps a club car on the Orient Express) to the DJ nights to the lovely courtyard. 

I didn't look at (or see) a cocktail menu, but we came here for a decent selection of absinthe and Pravda did not disappoint. The bartender didn't do the lighting the sugar cube on fire BS that some do, a surefire way to wreck a good louche! Be aware, a decent absinthe will cost you 17-20 dollars, which I think is a bit much, but a little goes a long way. Just be lucid enough to avoid that Lucid crap (their absinthe is infused instead of distilled) and you'll be fine.
