I only tasted the chips with pimento cheese, but a perusal of the menu reveals that there's lots of good going on there. It's an inspired menu, with comfort favorites, as well as creative takes on such favorites. I did hear people going on about the special of the day (duck, so obviously I can't comment on that). There are at least two vegetarian options besides salads and apps, including a sloppy joe. 

Then there's the extremely nice and as of yet, non-jaded staff. Our bartendress was extremely nice and came and checked on us regularly. We arrived hella early, so we were the only ones in there. Nice that no one forgot about us (far more common than you'd expect and I can totally understand, having worked in the industry for so long) and went the extra distance to be friendly, while not overly attentive. It's a delicate balance, folks.

This is a pretty straightforward review (what? no stories?), but I'm sure I'll be back so I can embellish upon things...

A bearable bar smack dab in the middle of Bourbon Street? I've found it in Funky Pirate. Not only bearable, but a good place to catch some good blues acts that play on the regular (Big Al, and the trio that plays on Sunday late afternoons), cuz it's intimate and what's more, no cover, just a drink minimum (one. One?! Yes, one.) The Bloody Marys are as decent as you're going to get in just about any New Orleans bar and all drinks are just 2 bucks more for a double. Can't argue with that, right? Even during Mardi Gras, this place was a refuge from what was going on outside on Rue Bourbon. 

Do check out the sweet little courtyard in the back, which affords you to still hear the music and enjoy the (sort of) fresh air (if such a thing is possible in the FQ).

The eternal (yelper) question: Does this- insert iconic establishment- even need another review, when they already have X hundred reviews? To this I say, uh, yeah they do. You can never have too many positive reviews. Plus I look at it as a note to myself upon returning (ie, see my note below).

Yo Mama's is one of those places that was always on my itinerary when I'd visit NOLA. Truthfully, though, once I moved here, I have not been back since yesterday. And I also had only drank here, back in the days before they even had veggie burgers. 

So, it had been a long day of drinking and no eating. A parade day... By 6, or was it 7 or 8pm, I was really feeling it. I hate being hungry in the French Quarter because I don't have tons of options here (that aren't dress-up places, that is). I remembered Yo Mama's famed burger list and immediately was craving some crazy veggie burger piled high with whatever other crazy concoction they could come up with and insisted we make an immediate beeline (er, crooked, inebriated beeline). My friends and I were relieved to find an empty booth and slid on in. I love the atmosphere here-- just a cozy FQ bar with all kinds of characters hanging around. I remembered the bartenders always being pretty damn nice and that still holds true. You might have to wait a bit for service, but that's how it goes and it's never too long. The bartender also waits the tables. Something to keep in mind. 

While the veggie burger here isn't anything special, the way it's dressed up makes a plain girl into a vixen. And that giant baked potato is her perfect not-to-be ignored accessory (you can get these all dressed up too, if you'd like!) I had the Mexican version with salsa, avocado and jalapeños. While I agreed to have it dressed, I think next time I'll have them leave off the mayo because it didn't go with the salsa at all (that's my note to self, in case you were wondering). The baked potato is perfect, by the way. 

Drinks are cheap and good. I'm glad that I have another go-to for a cheap, casual and quick meal when crawling the Quarter.

A cobbler saved a life recently. That of one of my favorite purses.

Out on a day of shopping/sightseeing far from our hotel, the zipper on my purse became stuck thanks to a bunch of stray frayed bits of material. I thought I was doomed to having my purse tucked under my arm all day so that my wallet and phone didn't fall out...then I walked by this place and almost screamed with joy (again with the hyperbole). I walked in and it was like walking into my grandpa's basement (he was a wizard with shoes). Every inch was CRAMMED with shoes, cobbler flotsam & jetsam and family photographs. I knew I had found the right place to save my purse's life.

Sure enough, the friendly cobbler was able to fix the zipper in minutes. In addition, he showed me a neat trick: the way to get rid of those positively evil stray frays is to light 'em on fire! For real! They shrivel up and disappear, not unlike the feet of the Wicked Witch of the East when Dorothy takes the red shoes from her after she kills her with her house.

Just to be clear, I look at mani/pedis as necessary evils. I dislike having to take the time out of my day to get them done and in New Orleans, that always means for me having to go to one of the places I like Uptown, which is too much of a trek (crossing Canal. Dealing with traffic and road blocks and schools letting out) and even more time out of the day. I'm limited on time, can you tell? Cue the stress. Is it really worth it? All I need do is look at my hands and feet. Sigh.

Don't tell me to just relax and enjoy it! I don't relax because I'm too busy being neurotic about someone touching my feet and kneading them to the point of serious foot cramps if I don't catch them in time. And after paying all that $ for manis/pedis, I inevitably wreck the polish because I can't take the damn time to just sit without touching my phone, moving, etc. I am the WORST customer.

But yesterday, I was kind of the best customer at Nail Spa 27! I've found my quick and easy, no hassles salon, friends. First good sign: easy parking right out front. Second, a mostly empty salon around noon on a weekday, so no wait! Third, a friendly greeting right when I walked in. Fourth, a wall of cool colors. And... best of all??? They did my hands and feet at the same time! And it was so fast, I had time to sit there and wait for that shit to dry! They have gel, but I've sworn off gel b/c it truly was destroying my nails (naturally I cannot resist peeling that stuff off).

The salon is not much to look at and I really don't care because efficiency and speed are all I care about when having to endure mani/pedis. Both nail techs were nice, didn't try to torture me with massage, and when I asked for a second coat on my hands, it was not big deal. Again, it was such a quick, thorough job, I couldn't stop thinking that I'm now going to be a 2X a month regular!

And the price is right. No, these aren't New York or Chicago cheap deals (none to be had in NOLA), but 34 plus a generous tip. I'm down with that!

This. This is why St. Louis is known for barbecue.

For starters, Bogart's makes some of the best ribs I've ever had. They are properly cooked, porky as hell (in the best way), and if I had been smart enough to order a full slab, I would've eaten until I was very, very ill. 

As it is, a half slab of ribs is a solid meal, and Bogart's offers the generous and astonishingly sweet deal of adding a 1/4 lb. of any meat on for just a few bucks. Forgive my saying so, but if you don't add on at least some burnt ends, you're a goddamned fool. 

The burnt ends are the most delicious meat candy you've ever been lucky enough to put in your mouth, and walking out of here without any is the worst mistake you've made since the 90s.*

I'm of the opinion that neither the burnt ends nor the ribs need anything else, but Bogart's offers up several sauces for your use. Of the four, the Sweet Maegan Ann is my favorite, with its sweet molassesy goodness mixing in very well with pulled pork (which does need something else). My wife is a very saucy lass, and she threw the Voodoo and the Vinegar in there as well. 

As always, sides are an afterthought to meat, and Bogart's could honestly serve slaps to my face along with those ribs and I'd still come back for more. Thankfully for my already misshapen face, they've got a delicious deviled egg potato salad, some nice pickles, beans, and slaw instead. 

To sum up: 

Come here. Get ribs, burnt ends and some sides (more than you think you need of everything). Eat all of this food on the picnic tables outside. Listen to the blues covers coming out of the speakers. Enjoy the beautiful day and our place atop the food chain, because at one point in human history we were just gnawing on berries and sticks. And barbecue is better than that. 
_____________

*Don't think we don't remember that summer.

12 Facts About Snake & Jake's. It's Christmas [Club Lounge], after all.

1. It is the best dive bar in existence.*
2. It has the best dive bar name in existence. 
3. You drink for free if you are naked.
4. I've only seen guys take advantage of this.
5. It isn't pretty.**
6. I don't know if I've ever been there before 3 am.
7. It embodies that saying, "Nothing good happens after 2 am."
8. Don't leave with anyone you meet here. 
9. Your decision-making skills are impaired. 
10. They probably have a gun.
11. Nobody will ever see you again.
12. This is New Orleans, and I love it.
____________

*Undisputed, now that Mars Bar is no more.
**I suppose this depends on your taste.

The Good.

-There's a very decent hoagie shop.
-I'm a sucker for high ceilings. 
-There's always places to sit. 
-It's better than Penn Station* in almost every way.
-The bathrooms are surprisingly not that filthy. 
-Free wi/fi.

The Bad.

-There are no late night food options except for McDonald's.
-I broke my three year streak of not eating McDonald's.
-It costs more to get a bacon, egg and cheese than it does to get a platter of eggs, bacon, homefries and toast. That's not right.
-The place that serves fried chicken, meatloaf etc. puts all that food out on the hot plates at like 9:30 am. Which scares me. 

The Ugly.

-Eagles fans.
-Phillies fans. 
-Me.
__________

*NY Penn. You couldn't pay me to get off in Newark to see what that station looks like.

The dulce de leche gelato is absolutely fantastic, except when paired with Brooklyn Brown Ale.

The cones are nice, but not as amazing as you would think, considering that they are handmade in France and smuggled into the US by pre-pubescent teens that are summarily executed if even one cone is cracked.*

There is nothing emasculating about having another man buy you ice cream. Especially if you call him Daddy for the rest of the day. I swear. 
__________

*I may have made part of this up.

Upset that the line for Acme is around the block? Your charbroiled oyster fix can be had right here in the middle of the French market. 

If you don't mind ruining your shirt and/or you are more coordinated than I am, the crawfish are big and beautiful and $10 a pound. Grab a tray, post up at one of the tables and get in there. Don't forget to suck the heads.

Bourbon Street, when you look beneath the surface, can be pretty depressing. It stinks of desperation. And vomit. 

But if you drink a couple hand grenades, you're quickly rendered incapable of seeing anything beyond the surface. Sometimes you're incapable of seeing anything at all. 

And you're ready to have a good time. For pretty cheap.

I wish I could tell you about the sandwiches, or the selection of snacks, but I don't know anything about that. 

What I know is that I promised to provide ice for a party nearby (a necessity for any party, and something that will get you in just about anywhere), and I was late and frantic.

Olde City may not pick up the phone...ever, but they sell ice for $2.50/bag, they have plenty of it, they are conveniently located, and the guy at the counter seemed nice enough as I ran in, grabbed ice, and threw money at him. 

Thanks to them, I have not been disowned by my family.

I can't say for sure why we chose to spend our afternoon at Winners and not Losers when we all know where my friends and I stand. However, with some folks (not me) it's probably difficult to diagnose the full extent of their problems with a cursory glance, so they let us inside anyway.

In any case, Winners might look like your average sports bar, but they did have complimentary bail bonds koozies, picklebacks, buckets of six Bud LIghts for $12, and the sweetest bartenders around. 

And although the food is just your standard fried fare, the cook will gladly give you handful of flour as long assure him that you just want to slap your friend in the face with it.

My train arrived at 30th Street Station on a Sunday afternoon; I needed a late lunch, and Bridgewater's fit the bill. 

Normally, I would order their burger and never look back. Unfortunately, my girlfriend recently accused me of eating four burgers a week, which is completely absurd. OK, so MAYBE I had already eaten three that week, but I would NEVER eat four. What sort of glutton eats four burgers a week? 

In any case, since I would rather be unhappy than allow her to be right, I went with the crabcake sandwich on the bartender's recommendation. When it finally arrived, the accompanying sweet potato fries were barely cooked, but the sandwich itself tasted pretty good. The crabcake fell apart (as crabcakes are wont to do), but I bet they make a good burger, which I'll have to come back and try when I haven't reached my weekly quota.

Now, Bridgewater's doesn't look like much. The food is a little better than decent, and their flatscreens could use some updating to HD (you want to be able to see the pain on Favre's face). But this is the best train station bar in existence, and I'll tell you why: their beer selection is shockingly awesome. You'd never expect to find so many great beers available in a train station. It's even updated seasonally. Right now, they have all sorts of Christmas ales.

If they would only stay open a bit later, I can guarantee I'd have a pint here before every train back to NYC.

Forget cowboying up. Personally, I prefer to burger up before I do anything at all, and that certainly includes before consuming prodigious amounts of bourbon. 

I'm not sure there's a better choice for a gigantic group of dudes to have dinner. We were seated in the outdoor patio under a few heat lamps, and the staff here handled us like pros: offering advice when it was needed (which included when to urinate outdoors), kept the alcohol flowing,* and brought us plate after plate of excellent eats. 

We started with the habanero wings (not as hot as you'd think, but fantastic), fried pickles, fried mushrooms and more. They've got some great sauces, which I always appreciate: the blue cheese dressing was legit, the honey mustard fantastic, and the homemade Jack Daniels ketchup good on everything, especially the motherfucking TRUFFLE FRIES. With sliced parmesan on top, those things rocked, and the sweet potato and the house fries were nothing to sneeze at either. 

And of course, we ate burgers. Grassfed, juicy burgers. Cooked correctly, well-proportioned to the bun, and flavorful. Not the best I've ever had by any means, but damn good nonetheless. Our waiter made no bones about the fact that the Woodstock was the move, but I must say the pimento cheese option was no slouch. Having tasted both, I'd be hard-pressed to pick between the two. 

Basically, Burger Up held up their end of the bargain: If you put a dish in the name of your restaurant, it has to be good. And it was. 
_________

*Be warned. If you ask for a double bourbon on the rocks, you are basically going to get a pint glass of bourbon. Two in, I was a mess.

Cocktails and Dreams, Flanagan's isn't...and for that we can all be grateful. Of course, I can't promise you that Tom Cruise won't recite inane poems from atop the bar when you come in, but it hasn't happened for me yet.

This is one of the best bars in the Quarter precisely because you'd never know you're a few blocks from Bourbon, and as such they aren't trying to completely rip you off with their prices. The bartenders are good people with heavy hands, and the low-key crowd is always a winner; whether local or out-of-towner, everyone's trying to have a good time, and that's how it should be.

Oftentimes, the first thing I do on a NOLA morning is find a good bloody mary to wander around with, and Flanagan's makes my new favorite bloody in a city full of fantastic bloodys. It's like drinking meat in a glass. In the best way (as if that could be a bad thing). 

"Days get shorter and shorter, nights longer and longer, before you know it, your life is just one long night with a few comatose daylight hours."

He might've been talking about New Orleans.

A charming bar with undeniable character, Pravda specializes in absinthe and vodka. After a stint in Amsterdam, we decided to stick to the latter which is more than enough to sustain your buzz before you stumble home in the AM. 

The real prize here is the bathroom, where there is unfailingly a roach waiting for you, and at least once, a phone number scrawled on the wall requesting a picture of your genitals.

There are a lot of bars on Bourbon St. that can give you the same things you can get here: live music, cheap drinks, aggressive shot girls, grimy everything.

While I do love at least 50% of those things, I'm not a fan of this bar in particular. 

I'm pretty sure they can't be blamed for the fact that my wife's wallet was stolen out of her purse that was hanging on her shoulder (but that did happen inside their doors). However, they can be blamed that they wouldn't give a visibly overserved girl water, instead demanding she buy a bottle of it. 

I'll find my aggressive shot girls and grimy everything elsewhere.

Nothing but good things to say here.

We got a great rate via Priceline, the bed was comfortable, and the towels were huge and fluffy. No problems.

Also, I forgot toothpaste, so I called the front desk. They answered "Hello Mr. Peter!" I love that. They sent it up right away, along with a little bottle of Scope and a mini-toothbrush.

And I think we must have stumbled on some sort of convention, because they were giving out sandwiches downstairs. I skipped those because I had to go get myself a cheesesteak, but I did grab some hot chocolate, complete with white chocolate shavings, mini-marshmallows, cinnamon and whipped cream. Fantastic.

I knew it was going to be a great place to stay when we pulled up and there was a man in a wife beater using a nail clipper to trim his calluses on the front sidewalk.

Unfortunately, that usually rock-solid indicator of quality was a bit off. 

I was surprised that a man like that would stay in a place where the beds are so uncomfortable, the shower is so unimpressive, and the hairdryer is so useless (so says my wife). I do appreciate the risqué touch of the full wall mirrors behind the bed, but the horrible lighting and the general appearance of her husband turned my wife off to the point that it was a futile design choice.

What especially galls me, though, is the blatant favoritism. The room my in-laws booked contained a fridge; where am I supposed to put the leftover wings I definitely should not have ordered on the drive down? Where is my fridge, Microtel? And while my wife's towel was shabby at best, it was downright luxurious compared to the scratchy, threadbare napkin that I was forced to dry my body with. 

This inequity cannot stand. 

At least Tina, at the front desk, was nice. And the room rates are affordable, because you get what you pay for.

There are really only two things you have to do in Philly:

1. Shake your head in disgust at all the Phillies/Eagles fans. 
2. Eat a cheesesteak.

I had #1 well in hand, so that left only the cheesesteak. Fate (or Miriam) brought us to Tony Luke Jr's. The place is spartan; a counter, tables and chairs. No decorations. This is a place to eat meat and cheese, and nothing else.

I recalled seeing an episode of Bobby Flay's Throwdown (see below for rant) with Tony Luke, and I remembered that their specialty is the broccoli rabe they toss on top of their signature steak. So I went for the steak w/ greens, and asked them to throw some whiz on it too. 

The bread was fresh and tasty, the steak plentiful and juicy, and the greens definitely added a nice garlicky flavor. This wasn't the best cheesesteak I've ever had, but it was pretty damn good. And big; at the end of the meal, my companions were debating whether or not to bring the rest of their sandwiches with us. They asked me what I was going to do with mine. 

Bitch, please. I ate that shit. 

***

Throwdown Rant: Sure, the premise is cool; challenge people to see if you can beat them at their specialty. Competition breeds excellence. But why is deception necessary? Why does the Food Network have to lie say they are doing this whole showcase on them because they make the best cheesesteaks (for instance) around? 

Because then, when fuckin' Bobby shows up and ruins the whole thing, half these people look like they want to cry. They were so jazzed up at being chosen, at being recognized for their excellence in a particular area of cooking...and then they see Bobby's smug face and they realize they've been sandbagged.

These people are proud of what they do, and instead of being celebrated (as they originally believed), suddenly they have to go up against some d-bag who has been preparing for this for who knows how long, and has the benefit of picking out a ton of gourmet ingredients that could never be used on an everyday basis because it would cut into their profit margins. It shatters them. Fuck Bobby Flay. I want to see him lose every time.

At least once in their life, everyone should partake in the pleasure that is a jazz brunch.

While Muriel's might not serve the best food in the French Quarter, their brunch is an experience anyone with a soul will enjoy. After all, this might be the only time in your life that it's acceptable to eat veal, or a pork chop, or pecan-crusted drum first thing in the morning. 

My alligator hash and her andouille omelette were solid, if a bit overpriced. (Don't be frightened by the gator; it's in tasty sausage form, and you wouldn't know what it was if they didn't tell you.) The flavors were good, but the eggs (poached and scrambled) were overcooked. 

But although I might not revisit either of our entrees, I would GLADLY start any day with Muriel's Bloody Mary and the ridiculously rich crawfish and goat cheese crepes. That's the move here. 

The band starts the party and keeps it going, and in between songs you'll see that they are not only talented performers, but genuinely good guys as well. Not realizing my absolute ineptitude with all instruments, the leader asked if I wanted to sit in on bass. I declined, but offered him some of my Bloody Mary. Now we are best friends forever and ever. 

And ever.

I'll say it: I'd switch teams for John Besh. 

Restaurant August was already among my favorite restaurants in the nation, and Luke is a casual alternative that offers up an entirely different but equally tasty view into New Orleans food. 

For one thing -- and let's be serious: probably the most important thing -- they make an EXCELLENT burger. It is massive (and shareable according to some), covered in caramelized onions, Allan Benton's bacon, caramelized and Emmenthaler Swiss cheese. And although the brioche bun stands up well, it's unavoidably messy when cooked to a juicy medium rare. Our bartender friend informed us that this particular burger was chosen as 8th in the nation; I'm not sure by whom, but I'm not mad I got it, just mad I'm not on the committee. 

The shrimp and grits are also apparently a specialty of the house. We were told that they do them a bit differently than most places; as far as I can tell, they just cook the shrimp perfectly, and make the sauce good enough to drink. 

I was a bit disappointed that the fries were cooked past crispy into crunchy territory, but the lady on my left loved them all the same. For me though, the only downsides were said fries and the fact that their bloody mary is merely a mix (although I do like the Gator Blood), and they don't provide a spicy bean. Sacrilegious, I know, but give them a chance to make it up to you with the food.

Welcome to The Hutton, the Unofficial Bachelor/ette Party Hotel of Nashville.

At least that how it seemed. On our own mission of mayhem, we ran into large group after large group of folks also there to celebrate a friend's impending doom...nuptials. I meant nuptials. 

But I can't blame any of them for choosing the Hutton, because as far as I can tell, this is the best hotel in all of Nashville. All right, this might be the only hotel I've hit up in town,* but I have absolutely no complaints and I'm not sure how it could've been better.** Basically though, they've got everything I want:

-Free, fast wireless. Without even the hassle of a username/password.
-Clean, well-appointed rooms with outlets everywhere.
-The most comfortable of beds.
-A modern, gorgeous bathroom with every amenity.
-A friendly, courteous staff that was on top of our every need, and didn't even stop the 3:30 am Natty Ice chugging contest that took place on the front steps.***

Well, almost everything. They didn't let me extend my checkout time past noon. But I can't really blame them; I would've wanted us out as fast as possible too.
____________

*The filthy fleabags I slept in during college visits do not count as hotels. 
**Unless they could somehow find the hundreds of dollars that seem to have gone missing from my bank account at some point over the weekend.
***Although, several people who shall remain nameless would've sincerely appreciated it the following morning if the contest HAD been stopped.

Haha, I totally forgotten that I had eaten here. Sometimes when you're bored in Truckee the next biggest place for things to do is unfortunately Reno. Sometimes you get caught up with people with not so ordinary lives and they restart their future in less glamorous ways. I never was able to track that person again, but this was one of the stops I made to find them. Had decent solid meal but still It's Olive Garden. Nothing to write home about!

Where are you going to go to get a solid sandwich while rocking out to Pentagram? Yellow Sub of course! It's seems to draw the alternative crowd and it's full of crazy things seemingly stacked throughout the years? Creepy baby dolls? A pic of young Selma Blair? The logo of Buena Vista the bar with the great Irish Coffee in SF? It's all here. Capocollo and provolone for the win. Oh and rock out too.

Maybe one of the more interesting businesses in one of the strangest strip malls Ive ever seen. Walking in it looks like a fast food place. Milk tea on one side and food on the other. THere are lcd screens above that highlight both generic and Taiwanese specific fare. If not for a friend's rec, we wouldnt have known what to go for or that this place existed. Got the stinky tofu, Taiwanese sausage, beef tendon in chili oil, pork belly bun and green onion pancakes. The pancakes were under cooked but the tofu, tendon and sausage were good. Pork bun was ok. Service is what you'd expect and they were efficient but not too talkative. I guess for Reno this is pretty good.

I used to go to the Truckee one a while back but that's gotten really popular and crowded. Cool to find they opened up one in Reno too. Got a pretty solid iced tea after they couldnt make an iced con panna (even though it says any espresso drink iced). All the workers seem to be young and female. Actually most of the clientele too. The link to the pizza place next door and the cool industrial patio area to the south makes it good for hanging outside. It does get a bit toasty inside as one of the baristas declared as she was pouring.

Similar to my beloved Dutch Bros, a drive through caffeine vendor. The girls working are similarly attractive though not as uber friendly. Their specialty hazelnut coffee is quite good. They also give out a chocolate covered coffee bean with the order. The whole poor coffee convenience thing is being turned on it's head as now you can get better coffee from a kiosk than some cafe's now

Id been to the coffee shop next door a year ago and recently the desire for wings and pizza hit. Ao we dropped in for a few bites. Angey pig which had a load of pork and the baked wings were the fare. Pepperoni, salami, bacon, sausage goodness. The one problem was the outer crust was good but the center was a tad soft in the center. I think the cooking style has to adjust for this i think. Aside from that it's a solid pie and wings. Next time i try the hidden pig which has a garlic sauce instead

Wow people really be hatin on the Steak and Shake. I have a friend from Indiana that doesnt shut up about this place having grown up with it. So when driving through town we had to check it. Didnt realize it was a sit doen style place, though they do have a drive through. Double bacon steakburger, fries and an orange cream shake. Burger was actually pretty darn good as was the shake. Fries were decent but not killer. Servers seem to all be young women while the cooks were all guys. Interesting. Anyways for a fast food joint it's pretty decent.

Holy Moly,. Did Cabela's and Sports Authority have a baby with an amusement park? That is what Scheels is. Lots of sporting goods stuff throughout and then the crazy hunting stuff upstairs. The giant hill of taxidermy is crazy next to a hanging airplane. But then there's more. A ferris wheel! this place is just nutz!

I had no idea Grimaldi's was so open across the country. I always envisioned it as a small place under the Brooklyn bridge. Guess they're all over the place. I did not envision them being in Sparks NV! It's large and very un NYC I have to say. But the pizza was actually pretty solid. Pepperoni, sausage, and black olive. Crust is nice and thin and has a good crunch/chew factor. Not quite the same as my old upper west side go to (replete with two old Italian American dudes) but still solid. I like that they've simulated the old brick oven with the flapping door and such. It's just crazy big with lots of seating which is the opposite of the counter only standing room that Im used to in NY

The Hub has become my coffee of choice in Reno. I've been to the midtown locale and really loved that one too. Though this one is way more spacious, has a great design and it's next to the river and thsoe huge-mungous houses on the hill. Got their Toddy cold brew iced coffee. So damn good. The quote of the day came from my friend who when seeing the new Strada they had yelling" NO WAY!!!" and then running over to practically pet it. Not only great coffee a humorous outcome too.

'evs.

The scorpion bowl tasted more like a candy bowl filled with cough-syrup flavoring; the two actual gummy worms didn't help. Though you get to keep the giant glass, allowing you to wave it around downtown Reno like you're decreeing something important, it's not worth the effort or the sugar-induced hangover the next day. The appetizer platter was bland at best, and all these goodies will cost you approximately 1.5 arms and half a leg.

There were good things about Fireside, though none of them had anything to do with the products we paid for. It was intimate, good for chatting, good for couples and/or small groups. It has a fire pit in a pool of water, and fairly comfortable couches to lounge on. It's also in the fabulous Peppermill hotel, where you could enjoy a lengthy seizure from all the mirrors and interior neon.

Nice place for a quiet chat and a drink, but bring your credit card and keep the drinks simple.

We had another restaurant in mind on Frenchmen St. After a so-so vibe at the place we were considering -- I honestly don't remember its name -- we bailed and went with a recommendation from the bartender (bah-tenduh) at Hermes Bar at Antoine's.

The place was pretty low-maintenance with a lot of cool-looking servers in hats. It seemed like a mix of tourists and locals.

Since we never got the hang of ordering properly -- us Californians are used to smaller portions -- we asked for an ungodly amount of food. An enormous basket of fried okra, fried chicken, mustard greens, collared greens, mashed potatoes, and cornbread. Though the fried okra was pretty good (also seems hard to mess this up), and the sides were fantastic, the fried chicken stood out for me. That batter is insane. We didn't talk the whole way through the meal: a sign of a good one! Pralines to go made my day later on.

I'd love to spend more time on Frenchmen St. -- for food, music, and bars -- next time we're in town. Nicely out of the way from Bourbon Street madness.

Def a must see if you like old churches. The lawn across the street from the church is pretty. We did find girls in bikinis sunbathing too. uhmmm.. weird... 

Moving on....

I liked the rose garden area with the stations of the cross.

I didn't do the tour.. but yes; they have a tour.

The church is pink and HUGE from the outside.

My boyfriend did a very good job picking this place for our first breakfast place during my trip to see him in August.
I loooved the vibe....

It's very movie-ish. I felt like my boyfriend and i were the only "tourists" in the restaurant...

I did enjoy my food... and my boyfriend did too...

They do have a variety of selection to choose from...

Loved the quesadilla.....
Loved the pancake....

Great coffee taste...

Quality is So there... But why only 2 stars? READ on...

I had the almond milk latte and it was good.

The butterscotch cookie was intensely satisfying as well...

But..what's up with the cashier??? Minus 1 star for a rude male (or in between) cashier.
He calls me and my husband over and asks us for our order.. and in the middle of my order; he gets in a conversation with another customer..and lets me repeat my order? oh hell no.
My husband asked if he could get a latte. Male(or in between) cashier asked if chocolate or vanilla.. My husband said chocolate... and he said.. so you want a mocha... He said it in a condescending tone... He might have just left it as how he said it at first. chocolate latte. easy. less confusing. 

My husband got our table while i went to use the restroom...
I came back and saw my husband sitting with a plastic cup of his iced drink and a paper cup of my hot drink.
We were sitting in and why is it that we didn't get a REAL cup like everyone else?
Why did that cashier assume we were to get our orders to go?

I'd think because Santa Barbara is like a tourist spot... they shouldn't be rude to tourists who live in cities with the best coffee EVER. (i miss you Philz Coffee).

Ambiance is Great... it's just full of students and their macbook pros sippin on teas. (FYI. i just read how one coffee shop shut down their wifi and their sales went up! because people who actually pay have a place for them to sit... not with students being there for hours and hours just having one of the cheapest drinks they offer.)

-1 star for not having a trash bin in each stall in the bathroom.
hello. not everything is flushable like the plastic part of a tampon.

GREAT COFFEE.
UNFRIENDLY and RUDE CASHIER.

Total Vibe Killer.

I observed every single person working at that bar. all of them seem to take their job way too seriously.. no personalities shine here.

Do Not Recommend unless you want to feel agitated to punch someone in the face.

I love the fresh steaks here. Nothing beats a huge  cut of the delmonico. The thick-cut smoked bacon is also incredibly flavorful. I'm almost glad that this is far from home. Otherwise I'd be buying stock in plavix and lipitor.

The coffee is definitely weak but the breakfast sandwiches are pretty good.  I definitely appreciate that they use shaved deli ham rather than a single slice of a ham-like meat.  The bagels are on the small side but fresh with a nice shell and soft interior.  I was disappointed that they didn't have any asiago bagels though.

Yum!  That's the only word that comes to mind when you have a bite of the vegan chocolate chip cookie.  Usually, vegan cookies tend to be bland and dry but not here.  It was soft, chocolatey, and delicious.  Minus 1 star for the hefty $3 price tag, though.

Serious staff attitude problem here.  I almost considered conducting a study on the number of eye rolls it takes to complete a transaction.  The weekend staff are horrible and I had to wait for 17 minutes at the register to pay for a belt because there wasn't anyone at the counter.  Even after the cashier arrived, she exuded such an air of affected ennui and practically snapped the amount I owed while throwing the item almost angrily into a bag.  I' sorry if you abhor your job but that is no excuse for treating customers poorly.  I also noticed that other customers were getting impatient waiting for their shoes and just for someone to be at the register/counter to help them pay for their items.  The weekday staff is a lot more efficient and friendly, especially the day manager who is simply a sweetheart.  It's just the Sunday staff here that are certainly yelp-worthy, to say the very least.  They do have some cute accessories so I will continue to stop in every once in a while but never again on a Sunday.  The experience here definitely takes the term "customer service" (or lack thereof) to a new level.  1 star for the experience today.

The brisket is a bit on the tough side but the broth is very flavorful and the meatballs nicely seasoned.  Plus they give you a generous serving of meat.  The summer rolls are good but very much on par with those at every other Vietnamese restaurant.  The service is what sets them apart.  They are just so nice and attentive here!  I was accustomed to the south Philly service level and it's a complete 180 degrees from that.  Even when we order takeout, our bags are handed over with a smile and double check to make sure that we have whatever extra sauces, utensils, etc we need.  Love it!  Plus it's only 10 min away.

This is my favorite Panera location in the area.  It's a bit smaller than the Norristown and Conshohocken branches but the cafe is cleaner and the service is A LOT friendlier and more efficient.  Plus, they always have most of the menu in stock (every kind of bagel), unlike the Norristown location.  The hazelnut coffee here is also slightly darker.

I love the salads here.  They are absolutely amazing and very easy to become addicted to.  I love the curry chicken an the apple and grape chicken, which is slightly reminiscent of a waldorf but creamier and crunchier.  The seafood salad is very fresh and not overwhelming with mayo (it's always a delicate balance).  The breakfast and paninies here are superb, as well.  I like the chicen caprice with basil and mozzarella; it's freshly tasted with a hint of butter spread without tasting greasy in the slightest.  They also allow you to make healthy substitutions like egg whites.  And instead of artery-clogging chips and fries, they give you pasta and potato salad; my cholesterol and doctor are very grateful.  Do your tastebuds and health a favor and get dinner to go or lunch here.

This is a decent Irish pub with okay food and drinks.  The wings are good but didn't blow me away.  Curly fries were decent but my reuben was a bit tough and started falling apart about 1/3 of the way through.  At least the Yuengling made me feel better about my maimed and dying sandwich.  I might consider coming back but only if it's unarguably convenient.

This is a pretty decent sushi place with some nice appetizers.  The sashimi ceviche is a good dish to start with 9I could probably polish off at least 2 plates by myself) and the king crab dumplings are great with the wasabi soy dipping sauce.  This is also the only place in Phila that I have had them.  The symphony is also a good option and the presentation is great; it's literally a tower of seafood goodness.  The rest of the menu is decent, not spectacular, but I do fully appreciate the live scallops sashimi, which I get every time I'm here.  The rolls are pretty standard and portions are okay but not great for the prices.  Service has always been pretty friendly and efficient, but nothing to rave about.  A good solid choice for sushi.

The brunch here is fantastic.  The highlights:

1.  apple-smoked turkey bacon (flavorful and lean - definitely not as greasy as your everyday bacon yet it is still crispy and tasty)
2. quiche lorraine (fluffly and light with a flaky, buttery crust and just the right amount of gruyere)
3. omelette station (need I say more?  they have every imaginable topping for a great made-to-order creation.  try one with a combination of spinach, fontina, and mushrooms)
4. carved lamb with rosemary and mint (tender and flavorful but it was well-done and I tend to like my meat a little on the raw side.  It was still delicious, all the same, and I went back for a second serving...because being pig-like is excusable at a holiday brunch)
5. chicken in bechamel (very juicy, tender breast in a buttery sauce that doesn't taste heavy - pretty good although it wasn't my favorite)
6. salmon with baby shrimp (the addition of the tiny shrimp was ingenious and really added a welcome twist to any otherwise good, but kinda overly prevalent dish - the sauce was buttery and flavorful)
7. lox and cold cuts (your typical display - not bad but not very memorable either)
8. clam chowder (edible but kinda bland)
9. challah french toast (okay but not as good as Sam's or Sabrina's, by a long shot; it wasn't very thick and a bit overcooked)

They also have a waffle station and your typical breads, toppings, fruits, and sides.  The range of dishes and offerings never ceases to astound me and it's always rather overwhelming.  I would advise looking everything over before deciding on what to try since there is always more than you can physically eat in 1 meal, even if it is breakfast and lunch combined.  Service was great and my coffee cup was never empty.  To be completely honest, Thayer's "famous" brunch was not as fantastic as the brunch here.  It would be 5 stars, for sure, if they improve their french toast and imported actual NYC bagels (I can dream, can't I?)/
Closed.

I came here for the garlic soy crispy fried wings and made sure to call in my order, which made the process flow much more smoothly.  My chicken was ready when I arrived and it was crispy, juicy, tender, and perfectly salty-sweet.  The key is to place your order 15 min before you expect to get there and your takeout will be hot and ready-to-go.  Honestly, you won't find a better place to get Bonchon-like chicken in the area.  That crispy skin comes from the chicken being double fried and will easily derail any New Year's resolution to stay away from fried food on the first bite.  The wings are small, though, so an order won't kill a diet.  Plus, it's super close to home, which gives it an additional convenience factor

Really loving the $6.99-7.99 trio special right now.  My tarragon chicken salad on a pretzel bagel was full of almonds, red onions, chicken, and craisins in a savory, creamy blend; the pretzel bagel itself tasted like a soft pretzel with a nice crispy shell.  The clam chowder was decent but didn't really stand out from the versions at Au Bon Pain or Panera; it was very hot though so kudos for that.  The combo also came with a medium drink, too, which was definitely an added plus since that alone will cost you over $2 at Panera's.  Overall, service was fast and friendly and I had a very filling and good meal for about $8, which is almost unheard of these days.  Will be back to try the smoked salmon cali roll sandwich, which has smoke salmon, avocado, and wasabi cream cheese; it sounds quite interesting.  Anyhow, will update once I try that but definitely stop in and grab a trio if you want a fast, filling, and very inexpensive meal that isn't from your local BK or Wendy's or McDonald's.

That's it.  I'm going on a one-day diet tomorrow because I believe that I ate my weight...times 3 probably in meat.  That being said, it was worth it.  I had the picanha (had the light seasoning and it was very flavorful), alcatra (top sirloin - tender and marinated nicely), fraldinha (bottom sirloin - very robust with nice marbling), costela (beef ribs!  so tender and juicy), and bacon-wrapped chicken (not as amazing as the steak but still very good and well-seasoned).  My favorite has to be the picanha.  I'm a steak person and this was an amazing steak.

The salad bar was massive and had lox and prosciutto, along with marinated/grilled vegetables.  Every dish was fresh and carefully prepared (not like they just threw everything together into a mixing bowl).  The accompanying cheese bread and garlic mashed potatoes complemented the meats quite well.

i managed to fit in the flan for dessert and was very pleased with the creaminess (I will eat sweetened condensed milk from the can so I was happy).  Of course, then I was faced with the problem of having to walk to retrieve my car, even though it was only to the valet.  Somehow everything seems so far away when you are stuffed and required to move.  Overall, this was a great dinner.  I'll just have to remember to follow etiquette governances that stipulate that it is not ladylike to gorge on huge, albeit delicious, slabs of meat.  And there will be a next time.  Just as soon as I recover from tonight.  

Oh, and the valet parking makes driving painless.  Service was also great and our drinks were refilled continuously.

I love this location because the service is unsurpassed, it's newly rennovated, and they have a great selection of designer bags and shoes.  The manager is the sweetest woman ever and she was extremely helpful in addressing a not-so-easily-fixed situation.  Most of the staff are great and they have a great Lily Pulitzer section for the prepster in you.  If you, like me, are a shoe fiend, then you will definitely appreciate the stock of vintage and limited-edition Manolos, Pradas, and Salvatore Ferragamos.

The essentials:

Stoltzfus: yummy, fresh, soft, homemade pretzels and whoopie pies (get the classic chocolate)
Ultimate Bake Shoppe: chocolate chip biscottis (need I say more?)
Di Bruno: um, kinda speaks for itself but for constiency's sake, all things cheese
Seafood Market: fresh lump crabmeat and fresh fish (love the salmon and seabass) 
Sushi Sei: fresh, made-to-order sushi rolls (love the dragon and salmon avocado - much much better than anything from the supermarket and on par with Sushiland - just without the baked lion king roll)
Saxby: yes. it's a chain but the caffeine will give you the energy to carry all of your many purchases at the market...and you will end up buying a lot in spite of your best efforts to resist

That's definitely reason enough to get it...ASAP.

We came for brunch and were seated by the window on the wooden benches on top of the gravel, which was great, especially since it was no beautiful outside and we had a prime view.  Service was very attentive, prompt, and friendly, and the food itself was phenomenal!  We wanted to order everything but decided on a smaller selection due to stomach size constraints.  They were also great about separating items since one of my friends had some food allergies.  We had:

1. smoked salmon with egg salad and creme fraiche on toasted thick bread: Pretty good although the salmon was very salty by itself.  The combo of bread, creme, and salmon together was perfect, though.
2. potatoes bravas: The tried-and-true classic and yes, we ended up ordering seconds.
3. mixto cheese plate of truffled lavender and honey, fig and dried cherry, and pistachio: Fantastic, especially the truffled lavender and honey, which was the unanimous favorite.
4. lemon ricotta blueberry pancakes: Great but the creme fraiche makes all the difference.  Without it, the pancakes are just solid.
5. black cod: Okay, this was TINY but INCREDIBLE!  The fish was buttery, silky, and melted on your tongue.  I could eat this for days.  And you might want to get 2 orders...per person...minimum.
6. chorizo: Very flavorful and grilled to perfection.
7. chorizo with roasted potatoes and poached egg: This was a great rendition of a standard breakfast classic.  Mix it up bibimbap style!
8. grilled mixed mushrooms: Buttery and decadent.  A must-try for vegetarians.
9. chocolate cake with pistachio ice cream:  This was delish but to be honest, there was only a faint hint of pistachio flavor in the ice cream.
10. caramel flan topped with candied cherries and pear pieces: This was a very good custard but I felt that the additional candied fruit toppings made it overly sweet.  It actually would have been perfect on its own.

As expected, Garces delivers.  Make sure that you make reservations as the wait can be long on weekends but the ambiance is great so it isn't a bad thing to have to wait by the bar for a little while.

The food here is pretty good and the service is excellent.  The chicken tikka is seasoned nicely and the meat is baked to the perfect degree of tenderness.  The chilly chicken can be made very spicy, should you ask, and is probably my favorite dish here.  The chicken korma is a little bland but still edible.  The naan is always fresh out of the oven and deliciously butteryl I just wish that they had more varieties.  The service is great and the lunch buffet is a fantastic value since it also includes a mango lassi.  If you're in the area around lunchtime, definitely stop by.  Oh and they have discounts for dinner and takeout.

This is fast food at its best.  The variety of toppings (like mushrooms, peppers, onions, etc) catapults this chain to the top of the fast food heap.  The plain burgers are already pretty good, but once you add grilled mushrooms, onions, and cheese, they are excellent.  Eat your heart out BK and McDonalds.  Next time I'm in the mood for a fast food burger, I'm heading here.

The happy hour here is fantastic.  

The food highlights:
1.  Short rib sliders are served with a great onion jam on a buttery, lightly toasted roll.  The meat is flavorful but can be a little on the dry side.  Solid 3 stars. $3
2.  Raisin pecan bread with gorgonzola fondue is simply delicious.  It's a great combination of sweet, savory, and creamy flavors with a nutty crunch.  4 stars.  $3
3.  Poutine fries were delicious.  They come with a savory, rich gravy and fresh cheese curds.  While they are not as great as the ones found in say, Montreal, they are flavorful, crispy, and very very good for the area.  I have yet to find another restaurant in the vicinity with these fries.  4 stars.  $4

As you can see, the prices are almost unheard of so you can literally get everything on the happy hour menu and still have change left to spare for a nice glass of wine (recommend the sauvignon blanc and chardonnay, both of which are also half price).

Plus, you CANNOT beat the ambiance.  Who doesn't love a stroll through Renoir's Boaring Party masterpiece followed by a fantastic meal comprised of French cuisine-inspired small plates and French wine?

The cupcakes here are addictive.  Seriously.  My friend literally had to slap my hand from reaching for my third one, after which I most likely growled (kinda) at him.  I love the plain, classic chocolate, but the red velvet is also delicious.  The cake is very rich and moist.  Their cookies are very good, as well (love the chocolate chip walnut).  Okay, it's tomorrow so it's time to eat the cupcake that I was prevented from consuming yesterday.

Yum!  I finally got around to getting the carnitas burrito and was very happy with it. I had it with the saffron rice, pinto beans, cheese, guacamole, sour cream, onions, corn, and BBQ sauce. It was huge and the flavors meshed together quite well. All for just $5.78. I'll be back tomorrow to try the barbacoa. The carnita itself was very tender but a little bland. Not to worry though because the other ingredients and sauces definitely help to rectify that.

This is one of my favorite vegetarian restaurants in Philadelphia, for sure.  The food is fantastic and perfect for sharing.  We had the following:
1. marinated beets - flavorful and dressed with an apple vinaigrette served with a side of creamy panna cotta
2. charred Caesar salad - your classic Caesar but with charred romaine, which gave it a slightly smokey flavor.  A nice twist.
3. wild mushroom and barley on toast - flavorful with a touch of garlic and thyme on toast
4. chickpea fries - very innovative use of chickpeas and very tasty with a touch of garlic seasoning
5. roasted Brussels sprouts - classic and simple with perfectly roasted, buttery Brussels sprouts sprinkled with bread crumbs
6. Bouillabaisse - made with tofu in a slightly spicy saffron and tomato broth and served in a delicate papillotte shell.  Definitely recommend trying.
7. Buccatini and "meatballs" - absolutely fantastic with a spicy fra diavolo sauce.  I am not a vegetarian and would order this over the meat-based version.

Service was great and  the ambiance is very classy and cozy, with small tables and dim lighting.  A great setting for a date!

We came for lunch today and it's still a solid option, if you are looking to stuff yourself with passable sushi.  If you are a sushi connoisseur, head to Bluefin.  The other dishes were okay, but a bit on the greasy side, although I did like the sashimi salad.  They do have tuna sushi but no eel or macarel during lunch.  The rolls are decent, and I would definitely recommend those over the cold salads.  Noboru makes a better and less oily sashimi salad.  It is not as busy here as it was a few years ago but it's a decent lunch option ($17+ tax and tip on Mon-Fri).

You can get diner food here.  The menu is pretty extensive but the food itself isn't that great.  That being said, the service is friendly and the prices are good.  I would probably head to one of the Main Line diners instead but if you're starving and across the street, then it is worth stopping by for your favorite breakfast dish.

This is in the old Sushikazu location next to Rita's and they do have pretty good Korean fried chicken wings.  The fried wings have a crispy skin with just a thin layer of breading with a very juicy interior; we got an order of the garlic-soy, which came glazed with a  sauce is simultaneously sweet and salty.  While the sauce was tasty, the highlight was definitely the crispy skin.  It's not as great as BonChon but pretty good for Blue Bell, PA.  They also have sushi rolls but I don't know if I would get my sushi here; I would rather just stick to the fried chicken wings.  Service was on the slow side but the food was worth it.  Each bite was a nice combination of crunchy-savory-sweetness.  If you want a Federal Donuts-like experience with an Asian twist, head next door to Suzy Jo and pick up a couple of glazed donuts.

Came here to grab 2 sandwiches and decided on the chicken salad on croissant with havarti.  The sandwiches were tasty and the accompanying potato salad was creamy with just a touch of dill (only ~$8 for the combo, which has the sandwich, salad, choc. chip cookie, and a soda).  They were also made very quickly, which was much appreciated since I was in a hurry.  We have also ordered our holiday hams here, and they have always been fantastic.

I didn't feel that this place lived up to the hype.  The food was good but not amazing.  We shared the pork belly buns (um, like ribs chopped and stuffed into plain bao) and peruvian ceviche (this was the highlight of the meal - perfectly fresh, creamy, and accented with sweet potato) for the appetizer course.  I got the parihuela, which I suppose is the Latin version of bouilliabaise (w/saffron,, of course).  It was decent but a tad on the bland side.  I sampled the smoked sirloin, which was better, with a delicious miso butter.  It was also generously sized.  The lychee sangria added a nice touch to the meal.  Overall, a decent experience but nothing spectacular.

I love the Farmer's Daughter, and the prix fixe menu is solid and  quite reasonably priced.  It has almost become a family tradition to grab a weekly dinner here, partly because it's right next door and partly because we always have a nice experience here.  I wanted something savory so it was the roasted half chicken for me with the reliable grilled romaine and olive bread.  The chicken was tender and nicely seasoned with a coating of herbs in a garlicky jus; it came with a delicious scalloped potato tart and a carrot puree (okay, not a fan of carrots, in general, so I very "chivalrously" offered it to my father who happily finished it).  The garlic jus gave the dish an extra flavor boost, which I liked a lot since the roast chicken dish is a rather uniform and ubiquitous one.  The side of mushrooms was a nice touch too.  Definitely better than the typical mashed potatoes and green beans sides.  Dad's butternut squash ravioli was also great and the brown butter sauce was rich and flavorful.  It's a great fall dish and on my radar for the next visit, for sure.  For dessert, we split the chocolate pot de creme and bread pudding.   And by split, I mean that I gave him 1 bite of the pot de creme.  The bread pudding was good but I liked the chocolate pot de creme more, probably because of the hazelnuts and hazelnut cookie.  Service was great, as always, and our french press coffee was delish.  Will be back nect week to report on my own order of the ravioli.

It's better than Ramen Boy but still not quite Ippudo, by a long shot.  The Terakawa broth was just slightly greasy but it was very rich and decently flavored, so I can imagine that it would be good on a cold winter day.  It came with roast pork, seaweed, bamboo shoots, woodear mushrooms, scallions, and half a marinated egg, which, to me, stole the show.  The noodles themselves were decent, as was the pork, but the egg had that wonderful sweet, well-marinated flavor and a semi-soft yolk.  Next time, I'm skipping the pork and getting a whole egg instead, although you do have the option of adding an extra half for $1.  The takoyaki were pretty good, with perfectly crispy outsides and soft, flavorful interiors..  In fact, I liked them more than I liked the actual ramen, ironically enough.  Service was fast and friendly and it's a good place to grab a bowl of ramen or takoyaki.  It's not Ippudo, but for Philly, it's good enough.

A decent Asian restaurant with just about every variation, including Chinese, Thai, Japanese, and Malaysian.  It's surprisingly decent with the typical Americanized Chinese fare, all at very reasonable prices for Rittenhouse.  My Buddhist Delight and beef chow fun were solid, and not overly salty, although the portions are on the small side, compared to Square on Square.  Service was good, and I really liked that their green tea is actually brewed from tea leaves and not tea bags.

AMAZING unbreaded veal schnitzel!  The creamy mushroom sauce is delish and wonderful when mixed with the spatzle and roasted Brussels sprouts.  The pan seared duck breast with the red wine reduction, cherries, and baked cabbage is also superb.  Be sure to add a side of the potato pancakes with chive sour cream and applesauce and a pretzel.  Absolutely one of my new favs in Philly!  BTW - the service is very helpful, friendly, and FAST.  They are always more than happy to bring you a sample of any brews as well.

Great crab wings and steamed crabs. Get the mid/large at $3 each. They are huge and very fresh. The crab cakes are pretty good, as is the crab Mac and cheese. The seafood salad was the only subpar item I had. They also have pints of soup. The clam chowder was decent but not as good as the ones that I have had in Boston; it was creamy but just slightly on the bland side. It did have a generous serving of clams though. This place does resemble an actual shack to call and get your order to go. Nt a sit down restaurant but you'll avoid making a public spectacle  of yourself by eating the crabs at home where you can be as messy as you want. And as a side note, the wins are addictive. They are incredibly well seasoned without being overly spicy.

Solid fries with a good selection of dipping sauces from cheddar to sriracha to BBQ.  They are very greasy, though, so it's not for the light of appetite!  The shakes here are very good, as well and I was quite happy with my toasted marshmallow shake.  Prices are reasonable and it's a nice treat for a day hanging out in Rittenhouse Square.

I love the turkey on challah. The meat is shaved and not overly salty; the bread is soft inside with a great crust. Plus the portion of meat is very generous. Prices are very good and the service fantastic. If you need catering trays, the assorted sandwiches option is inexpensive and will feed 10+ easily.

This is a great hotel with excellent service.  The penthouse suites are quite luxurious and they also have ballrooms that are nice for hosting dinner parties, etc.  The staff is very friendly and responsive to any requests.  Definitely recommend if you're staying overnight in Philly.

You have to take the time to look around but they have a great selection of designer bags and shoes.  Everything is in excellent condition and prices are amazing.  It's also a good place to find that perfect piece of vintage jewelry to complete an outfit.

This is the place for a brunch with a view.  Nothing beats a lazy weekend meal here overlooking Rittenhouse.  The quiche lorraine is great, but my personal favorite has to be the steak and eggs.  The mornay sauce is delicious and meat is cooked to perfection.  Plus, the portion isn't so massively huge that you will run the risk of suffering from a cardiac arrest.  For those of us who have to watch our cholesterol, the egg white gruyere omlette is a great option.  Healthy and flavorful.  The service is impeccable, although a bit slow, and the ambiance definitely resembles that of a Parisian cafe.

My neighbors get a huge pig here every year for their pig roast and it's always delicious.  You can probably feed everyone, plus have leftovers, within a 2 block radius for $200.  And they give you plenty of gravy.

They were open yesterday in the midst of the maelstrom, so dad and I stopped in to grab a few dishes.  We weren't that hungry but just wanted to get out of the house due to cabin fever so it was the lunch specials for us.  I had the chicken with cashews, which came with a very generous serving of chicken and cashews; the sauce was flavorful yet not oily at all.  They also used chicken chunks rather than slices, which was a nice plus.  Dad liked his doubled-cooked shredded pork with five spice tofu, but did comment that E Mei's version is more flavorful; I tasted a bite and found the actual pork to be a bit tough and the tofu a bit bland, although it was certainly better than anything that we would have gotten from any other Chinese place in KoP.  We also got an order of the spicy shredded beef with peppers.  This was good, but there were only a few shreds of peppers.  I'm not complaining, though, since they compensated for the lack of peppers with a plethora of meat.  It came to about $30, for all three, which isn't bad.  the lunch specials are around $8 each, and come with soup.  I highly advise getting the wonton soup.  The portions are generous, too, and a lunch special can easily last 2 meals since they give you a pint of rice.  Pretty solid.

Attended a seminar here and the event facility itself was decent although the temperature was either too hot or too cold.  The hotel itself seemed rather cramped and a bit disorganized in its layout (bathrooms on alternate floors, towel carts in the middle of practically every hallway).  The attached parking lot is a nightmare, though.  It is 5 stories of narrow spots and narrower navigation lanes, which basically turns the experience into a nightmare on Elm St.  The location is nice (right in Midtown) but the venue is almost subpar.

I have to admit that the concept of all-you-can-eat sushi and sashimi terrified me initially.  I mean, how fresh can the fish be if it's put out and left under heat lamps?  Clearly, I was misguided, at least for this place.

For about $35-37/person (including tax and tip) for dinner, you get to eat your heart's desire of sushi, hibachi, sashimi, and other hot dishes, in addition to the ubiquitous crab legs.  The sushi isn't exactly Bluefin quality but you get to try some many more varieties and the chef is always more than happy to make a roll for you, should you ask.  My dad, being scared to death of raw fish and apparently allergic to anything that is green or seafood-related, loves the udon station and hibachi grill, where he will typically pack away twice his body weight in meat and noodles (and believe me, that's not a very trivial amount).  The hot entrees are pretty good, as are the cold salads.  They have a dessert bar with green tea ice cream, but I have to confess that I rarely take advantage of it except for maybe a minuscule dish of ice cream because I'm so stuffed with fish and crab by then that they would have needed to pull me out on a stretcher had I chosen to indulge further.  Come on people, this is a buffet so what else am I supposed to do besides stuff myself?  I mean, the ambiance is okay but that's not why I go there.

Love the ice cream and the staff here BUT the owner can come off as very brusque and even curt to the point of rudeness.  I asked for a lid for my parfait and he basically huffed and walked away.  The poor guy at the counter apologized and very kindly went to get me a lid and bag.  So in summation: everything is great...except for the owner who needs a lesson in customer service.  4 stars for the food but 0 for the owner so updating to a 2 overall.

The hibachi is okay but the chef there was incredibly nice, efficient, and friendly.  I asked him to go easy on the oil and he actually cleaned and scraped down the grill for me!  That's called service.  The teriyaki seasoning was also very good, and a concoction that he created in the cooking process, which was certainly taster than anything premade.  I was pretty happy with my udon, veggies, chicken, shrimp, surimi, and beef stir-fry, although I did wish that they had tofu, crawfish, broccoli, and mussels.  The sushi bar had a great cold calamari salad that was literally just tender, seasoned calamari.  It was delish!  And quite fresh.  The rolls were pretty standard but the futomaki was well made, as was the dragon.  No eel or salmon sushi during lunch but the albacore sushi was buttery and fresh.  The seaweed salad was pretty standard and everything was extremely organized with an open, clean sushi bar.  The other dishes were solid, including the bamboo leaf wrapped glutinous rice dumplings, honey-roasted chicken, and honey-roasted whole bass.  Our waitress was very sweet and attentive and checked in on our tea, plates, etc. every 5-10 minutes.  Desserts were okay and they had the usual frozen yogurt and toppings.  It was pretty quiet at lunch but the place itself was probably the cleanest that I have ever seen a Chinese buffet be.  The food is not as amazing as King's but it's only $7.25 for a lunch that includes the made-to-order hibachi, which makes it a great lunch option.  It's a solid 3 stars but I will add an extra for the service and hibachi chef.

I love the crabmeat eggs benedict here.  It's the perfect Sunday morning brunch meal.  I am also a fan of their fluffy chocolate chip pancakes and omelettes (try it with either the lox or peepers and cheese).  And don't leave without getting the hash browns!  You would be doing your mouth a huge disservice.  Service is always fast and friendly, although it can get crowded at peak times.

It's a small Au Bon Pain branch but the service is friendly and they do have all of the essentials, such as bagels, croissants, salads, and sandwiches, for the same prices at any other location.  While you can't order accustom sandwich or salad, there are enough choices here that you will find something.  All I can say is that my Thai chicken salad was infinitely healtheir and better tasting than anything offered on the plane, and, for this, I was extremely thankful. This is the location in the F terminal near US Air.
The owner actually told a bunch of the customers to limit the number of crab legs that they got.  Um, isn't this a buffet.  Sushi is barely edible.

My vegan friend and I came across this cute cafe in our hunt for a lunch spot.  My Americano was great but the highlight was definitely the vegan cookie that was dessert.  It was chewy and delicious.  My mozzarella and basil panini was tasty but not amazing; I would have preferred a more flavorful spread.  The ambiance is eclectic and artsy.  Perfect for a leisurely-paced lunch!

They have breakfast sandwiches all day so that makes me happy.  Because some days you just want a bacon, egg, and cheese for lunch, or in my case, second lunch (yes, I was probably a merry and/or pippin-like hobbit with a similar appetite in a former lifetime).  While I still like to head to Lenny's for my hoagies and roast pork, this is a solid option for breakfast.  Rolls are fresh and soft, prices are good, and service is fast.

They also do takeout sushi, which really isn't that great of a value in comparison to the AYCE option, BUT I was able to get unagi sushi for about $1 a piece.  The unagi was pretty fresh and tender, and the portion was generous (not paper thin).  Not bad if you want a lot of sushi and a good variety (you can probablyy taste 10 different rolls/sushi for $10) at a great price, but don't have the time to sit down and dine in.  The AYCE option at lunch (~$16) is still the best deal here but the takeout isn't bad and the sheer volume of diners, especially during peak meal times, ensures that the sushi and rolls are fresh.

Update to previous review:

New owners = better seafood.  They now have an ample quantity of dungenness crabs but the sushi is definitely subpar.  Service is very attentive and they clear plates quickly.  Also, print out the 20% off coupons from bluegingerbuffet.com.  Not a bad meal for under $10 for dinner (including tax, not tip).

The sweet potato fries are pretty good but the burgers are a bit on the dry side.  The duck pot pie sounds er interesting but I have yet to muster the courage to try it.  For now I will just stick with the fries and get my burger elsewhere.

This is halfway between a cafeteria and a sit-down restaurant.  There is decent seating and your food is brought out to your table but you order and pay at the counter.  There should probably be a sign stipulating that all orders are taken at the register otherwise they might wonder why there are customers sitting at tables looking around with confused looks.

Foodwise, this was just okay.  I got the chicken taouk platter, which came with salad, rice, pita, grilled vegetables, and 1 kebab for ~$13, including tax.  The chicken was adequately spiced but could have used a bit more sauce.  The rice was topped with some almonds, and was pretty good.  Salad was very bland and tasted like it had merely been spritzed with a tiny amount of lemon juice and olive oil and a scattering of spices - definitely could have used more of actual dressing.  The pita was...well, a pita, although I think that it would have gone nicely with some hummus.  The portion size is pretty small, and probably wouldn't have filled anyone besides me up.  Maybe if they added a kebab?

The restaurant itself is very clean, with an open kitchen, and the overall experience was adequate for a quick, inexpensive lunch place.  It's good for those of you searching for a traditional, middle eastern lunch without any twists.

Okay, this is an edit after just dining there tonight:

They have snow crab legs now, along with sauteed dungeness crab and mussels, which is a major plus in my book.  The sauteed crab was pretty good imitation of the ginger and scallion style crab you would get in Chinatown, except with less starch, which is a good thing.  Still missing the crayfish, though.  The sushi is still pretty much the same as before, but the seafood is definitely better.  Thus, I'm upgrading to 3.5 stars.  If you're in the area, it's worth it to stop by, especially since they still have the 20% discount.  I would do so on a weekend night, because that seems to be when they bring out the best dishes. 

Original:
 
This used to be Star East Buffet, but reopened about 2 weeks ago.  What can I say?  It's your typical Chinese buffet, but without snow crab legs, at least on the night that I went.  They do offer steamed sea bass, which was quite deliciously flavored with ginger, scallion, soy, and sesame oil.   The sushi wasn't too good, and they had a very limited offering of nigiri, sadly.  I was able to request a spicy tuna roll, though.  The salmon wasn't the freshest, either.  There is a small hibachi station next to the sushi arena, and you can get a custom-made stir fry, but honestly, if you want a REAL stir-fry go to International Buffet in Bustleton, not here.  The salad buffet was very clean, and they do offer a generous variety of cold salads, including pasta and chicken based ones.  Probably my favorite item was shrimp dumplings, although only a few are brought out every 15-20 min.  In terms of the hot entrees, they are your typical take-out dishes, and none truly stood out in either direction.  The crystal dumplings filled with mung bean custard were amazing - you have to try them!  I'll probably head back and get a box of those to go.  

Overall, not somewhere I would go to, save in forced situations.   The prices are a bit cheaper than King Buffet, but it is not its competition, by any stretch.  They were offering a 20% discount, and have ads in Clipper.  The owners have another buffet (Jim's in North Wales), which does offer snow crab legs at the same price.  If you're in the area, head to King's, where you can happily eat your weight (or double) in crab legs, nigiri, and oysters.

Lunch: 6.99
             3.99/lb
Dinner: 10.99 M-Th
              11.99 F-Sun
               4.99/lb
               7.99/lb sushi and seafood

When I'm craving a roast beef I always come here.  The food is your typical Arby's but the service is fantastic.  I had to wait maybe 3 min for my sandwiches and was given a complimentary beverage and profuse apologies for the wait.  Furthermore, the cashiers here are very pleasant and always certain to ask if I need any extra condiments, which is more than I can say for most other fast food places.

The baristas here are great and it's definitely a great spot for people-watching on South Street if you are able to grab a window table/seat.  It's always busy but the service is very friendly and I have yet to receive an incorrect order.  Plus, they also have the Evolution Sweet Greens juice, which I haven't been able to find elsewhere.

We usually head to Ekta but decided to finally try its basically next door competitor.  We had the malai chciken tikka, which was marinated in a sour cream-like sauce and grilled; the meat was a bit on the dry side but very flavorful.  The chicken tikka masala is my usual benchmark, and I found it to be good here, but I prefer the  sauce at Ekta (that's just my own preference so your mileage may vary).  The meat was pretty juicy and full of flavor, so they definitely take the care to marinate, which is essential.  The vegetable samosas were delicious!  The shell was crispy and the potatoes and peas stuffing was spiced perfectly.  These are definitely better here.  We also had the onion naan, which was good but didn't really discriminate itself from the the one at any other Indian place in the area; I did notice that they used red onions so if you are looking for some color in your naan, this may be for you.  Otherwise, there's really nothing special about it.  The staff here are very friendly, and the service is pretty fast.  It is pretty small so I imagine that it can get pretty loud and crowded during peak meal times although it wasn't bad today.  Overall, a decent Indian option on the Main Line.
If you are in the mood for a creamy and savory cold dessert, try the Rosemary Honey Goat Cheese.  It tastes like a fluffy, cold, and milder version of your favorite chevre appetizer.

Decided to give this place another shot...and I was shot down.  I wanted to try the benchmark salmon avocado and spicy tuna.  It took them 20 minutes to make the rolls (4 chefs in the back and it was not busy at all) and they were very sloppily put together.  They were falling apart basically.  The spicy tuna was decent but not memorable and the salmon avocado was not that fresh.  At least it was part of the lunch special and didn't cost an arm and a leg.  The waiter/cashier was pretty nice and had a very cheerful demeanor.  For sushi, I'm heading to Bluefin next time.

The eggs benedict is amazing but really, any of the breakfast dishes are delicious.  After my surgery, my family brought me breakfast from here every day.  Needless to say, breakfast easily became the highlight of the day.  But the eggs benedict and omlettes are probably my favorite, although their pancakes do surpass IHOP's.

This is a diner that rivals Luke's from the Gilmore Girls. Friendly, small, quaint, and just good.  French toast is yummy but I still love my eggs Benedict. It's just not too great for my waistline since I practically live across the street. The constant temptation...

This is very Americanized Chinese but sometimes I do want just that. And that is when I come here for my chicken teriyaki with brown rice. It's filling, fast, and cheap. And honestly, it's pretty good too. I would liken this to five guys, except that it serves Chinese rather than burgers. The sauces are flavorful and the ingredients are fresh. Plus, the veggies are crisp and given in ample amounts.
Expensive limited grocery selection. Head to Assi for a full food court and every sushi ingredient you could ever desire.

This market is small but has all of the essentials covered, in addition to some very tasty baked goods.  Some highlights from this year (opened in May, I think):

Daily Loaf :  organic flaxseeds and whole-grain flour

Marliscious: the pistachio torte cake is 3 fantastics layers of pistachio cake sandwiched between and enrobed in a pistachio-filled cream.  I have not found a pistachio cake anywhere else and this is just delicious.  The Prinzregententorte is amazing to even look at, with 8+ layers of super-thin sponge cake layered with chocolate cream and covered in a thin chocolate coating; it's very good and has just the right amount of sweetness.  She doesn't always have every cake every time, but you can always order a particular flavor.  
 
Farm Fromage: creamy, organic goat cheese - it's delicious paired with a spring mix salad and glazed walnuts.
 
Frecon Farms: hard cider.  need I say more?
 
Jimmies Cupcake Co.: James Taylor/Boston cream cupcake with a custard filling, vanilla cake, and chocolate frosting.  Personally, I just like the names.  Cupcakes taste pretty good, too, but aren't as fantastic as House of Cupcake's in Pton.
 
Livengood Family Farm - grass fed ground sirloin - makes REALLY good, tender burgers
 
MacDougall's Irish Victory Cake: You HAVE to try the sweet butter cake!  It's rich, buttery, and full of simple, delicious goodness.  They have other varieties but this is the traditional tried-and-true, and, in my opinion, the best.

Definitely stop by if you live in the area and don't feel like driving down to Reading or Ardmore for your farmer's market goods.  I only wish that they had more prepared foods and snacks, like sandwiches and roasted meats.
