There was plenty of stuffing, which was moist (dry stuffing is the worst!), and just the right amount of sweet (but not overly so) cranberry sauce, complemented by the creamy mayo.  I also added Provolone, which gave it an extra flavor boost.  The roll was soft and fresh, and a footlong will easily feed 2 or be enough for lunch and dinner.  It was around $10 for a footlong, which isn't bad considering everything that is in the sandwich.  Service was very friendly and fast, too.  If you are out by Exton/West Chester, definitely give this place a try.  I only wish that there was one by home or work.

What can I say?  I'm definitely a snacker who likes to try a bit of everything so this is the perfect place for me...well, in John locke's world.  The concept of small rolls is appealing but the execution was a bit lacking. The rice was pretty dry...not exactly ideal. However, I did like the fact that I got to try 5 rolls rather than just 2. The eagle, new wave, and southern comfort were creative and pretty good.  The salmon avocado was meh but the lobster roll actually contained fresh lobster meat and avocado in a soybean wrap. That was probably one of my favorites and it is relatively hard to find lobster rolls. Service is very slow so that was one of the detractors. A decent place for those of us who want to sample a variety of rolls.

The hoagies here are edible but nothing really special.  They don't compare to Primo's, that's for sure, but are okay if you live across the street and just want a quick, simple bite.  They have a "bistro/cafe" menu but I would stick with the hoagies and the cheesesteaks here.  The fries (both sweet potato and waffle)  are pretty good when hot and fresh from the deep fryer.  Today (and every 3rd Wednesday of the month) was half price Italian hoagie day so I ordered a few for dinner along with a half chicken caesar hoagie and waffle fries.  Overall, the food was good and the price was great.  I would definitely spend the extra $.30 and upgrade to the sesame seeded roll.  The chicken caesar hoagie was full of marinated, grilled chicken and cheese, although they did go a little heavy-handed on the dressing.  If you live in the area, it's a good takeout option.  Plus, they deliver, which is a nice plus.

The testing Zone with breaded chicken, pesto, and mozzarella was solid but a little bland. The end zone with steak, mozzarella, peppers, and onions fared better. The shell is decent without being too doughy which is key in a calzone. they are open pretty late so it's a good option if you're hungry and sick of takeout and typical slices.

The quinoa loaf is a delicious gluten-free option that will satify any bread lover.  Seriously.  It's moist, soft, and flavorful.  Try it with chicken salad made with walnuts and craisins.  It's absolutely yummy and pairs well with the creaminess of the salad.

I came.  I ate. I conquered. The gringo Gordo that is. Yep a 5 lb burrito in 40 minutes. And it was delicious. The meat is fresh and tender, the saffron rice nicely seasoned, and the beans flavorful. If you aren't feeling gluttonous the $5.95 standards are a great deal. They offer more options than Chipotle or qdoba and you get to pick your tortilla flavor too. Owner is very friendly and knows the regulars (there are a lot of them and for good reason). This isn't a typical chain with pre made burritos. Everything is created to order and fresh.  And if you like hot sauce there is an ample supply and good variety.  They also have punch cards and daily specials.  Definitely stop by.

The best lamb chops and gyro in bucks county!  The lamb meat is perfectly seasoned and cooked to a succulent perfection. Many places tend to overcook the gyro meat so that it is too dry. Not here. The Greek salad came with an ample serving of feta. Prices are a bit high but still cheaper than what you would pay for the gas to drive into the city for comparable and slightly better food.

The rococo pizza is very good. The feta added the perfect touch and the crust was flavorful and crispy. If it is your first time here, get the chicken Mykonos, hummus, and a pizza. I can assure you that it will be delicious. The wait can be very long on weekends though.

Decent selection of karaoke songs and pretty spacious private rooms.  We came here after dinner at Penang and definitely liked the setup more than that at Yakitori Boy.  It easily fit all 20 of us and the interactive song selection screen was much easier to use.  The drinks themselves were pretty meh.  The sangria was very sweet and I couldn't taste any of the alcohol, which says a lot since I have a very low tolerance and very high sensitivity.  It was pretty neat, though, that they brought out sparklers with every new bottle of Ketel One.  Our hostess was friendly and helpful, and we did enjoy the ambiance and msuic selection.  The actual club itself is nothing to rave about and the majority of the clientele are 30-35+.  Overall, it's nicer and cleaner than Yakitori Boy, likely because of its younger age.

We decided on a late, casual dinner at the bar tonight, and were pretty happy with the food and service.  My chicken salad sandwich was creamy and full of chicken, craisins and candied pecans, served on toasty, grilled sourdough.  I really liked that it was grilled rather than served cold, like it is at most other places.  The fries were hot and crispy, too.  Dad really liked his lobster roll, which was made with dijon rather than just plain mayo; it did have a nice zest and there was plenty of lobster, too.  It's not served with fries, though (you get chips instead).  We also split the warm pretzel bites with truffle butter, which were good but not as amazing as Frankford's or Brauhaus's, and the crispy and delicious beet and sweet potato chips (better than Terra's!).  Service was great and we had plenty of time to enjoy our Sly Fox pilsners and food.

Yes, you have to call to reserve your dough but the margherita pizza is just amazing and worth the wait and hassle.  The crust is remarkably thin and simultaneously crispy, chewy, and flavorful.  The sauce is flavorful and topped off by the perfect amount of mozzarella and basil.  Love it!  BYOB and bring stuff to do while you wait (that iphone and ipad will definitely come in handy).
I love my meat and I love my potatoes. So I drag my lazy butt to the gym. And it is definitely worth it for a meal here.

Barbacoa is very good and perfectly seasoned.  The tacos aren't as fantastic as Don Memo's but are great for the area.  Guacamole is decent but lacking in flavor.  But I always have mine on a taco with salsa so you can't really tell at that point.  As far as the enchiladas go, nothing beats Vercruzana in South Philly but the chicken mole is pretty good; the meat is tender.  Stop in if you're in West Chester.

We came for a late brunch today and, although this is still one of the best brunch venues in Philadelphia, it does somewhat pale in comparison to Balthazar.  My egg white with ratatouille omelet was very good, with a savory filling and fluffy, buttery egg.  I asked for mixed greens instead of the roasted potatoes, and they came dressed in nice, light lemon and oil vinaigrette.  The steak and eggs plates looked good, but I did notice that they had a tendency to overcook the steak.  Two of my friends asked for medium rare and their steaks looked like they were cooked to a medium well.  Service was solid, although our waitress looked somewhat frantic throughout the meal.  The bread basket is still a tried and true staple, and I would definitely recommend the cranberry walnut bread.  Try it with butter and a smear of the jam!

Sushi isn't bad at all.  I really liked the American Dream with avocado, shrimp tempura and eel and the spicy king crab roll (love the crunch!).  I wouldn't put them on the same par as Bluefin or Ajihei but it's a good option for sushi if you are close by.  They also have Chinese but I have never tried that.  Service was very fast.
Closed

Lamb chops were well seasoned and juicy. I very much enjoyed them. The accompanying potatoes were good but not amazing.  Now on to the pastitsio...  The béchamel sauce was delicious!  It did not overpower the met but complemented it perfectly. The pasta itself was cooked to perfection: neither soggy nor al dente.  The taramasalata caviar was delish and went very well with the pita, which is amazingly fluffy and buttery. Service is fantastic and the owners are very sweet. Be sure to bring along a bottle of red wine if you're getting the lamb. A Shiraz would be perfect.  Prices are slightly high but the food is very redeeming.

It had been a long day so we decided on an impromptu father-daughter dinner night and headed next door to the Farmer's Daughter.  We decided to get the 3-course prix fixe ($35) since that had always been a good sampling option in the past.  I had the grilled romaine (love the hint of parmesan and who knew that grilled lettuce could taste so good?) and crispy skin salmon (loved the crispy, well-seasoned exterior that comes from baking, not pan-frying!) with farro succotash (a nice twist to your typical stuffing/succotash side) and creamed spinach (creamy without being overly heavy like some creamed vegetables dishes can be).  Dad had the same and didn't complain once that he was having fish and veggies and not red meat.  Dessert was the butterscotch pot de creme, which was good but not my favorite - the cinnamon marscarpone was a very different and I'm not sure if I like the combination of butterscotch, cinnamon, and salty nuts.  The bourbon cookie was great though (I actually ate Dad's too; he liked the pot de creme so we traded )!  Service was very friendly and efficient, and they have a great French press coffee (medium and floral-ly).  They have a bar too, and it was pretty busy tonight.  Plus, they have lobster rolls on the bar menu!  We actually got one to go since it has been ages since the two of us have gone to D'Angelo's.  Spilt it between the two of 2 about 5 minutes ago.  Now, that's what I call a good, solid, and very comforting snack.  Yes, it's slightly pricey at $17 but sometimes you just want a lobster roll.

It's definitely a small, rather inconspicuous restaurant in the same shopping center (if you can call it that) as the neighborhood oriental supermarket, but the dishes are great.  The seafood pajeon was served hot and filled with plenty of veggies and seafood, and the soondoobu chigae was flavorful and very spicy .  The banchan dishes were pretty good (although they didn't have the marinated shredded dried squid that I loved so much when I was in DC!) and I really liked the braised lotus root and white daikon kimchi.  The place itself is kinda small but the service is very friendly and prices are fair.  I haven't tried the barbeque here but I would venture that their specialties are actual dishes and not cook-your-own meats.

Sushi here is decent but a little on the pricey side considering that it's not bluefin. The marble roll was the only standout of the bunch but the size was small forgets $16 price tag. The fish was pretty fresh, though. The Korean food is not spectacular but edible enough. The hot stone bibimbap was average, but the bulgogi?  Go to any of the Korean places in nearby blue ell or north wales. You also can't cook at your table,  which to me defeats the purpose of bbq. However, the lunch boxes are usually around $10, which is a pretty good deal considering that you get to pick between sushi, sashimi, maki, teriyaki, BBQ, udon, and bibimbap. If you craving sushi for lunch, stop in and grab the spicy crunchy tuna and 5 piece sushi for $10. Your wallet and stomach will thank me. Dinner?  Head to bluefin or Gaya.

The roast pork here is excellent; it is cooked in spices for hours until the flavors are imbued in the tender meat that almost melts in your mouth.  Get it with provolone and greens.  The other offerings are decent but I only come here for the pork because the area is a bit difficult to travel in, which is the reason why I am subtracting one star.

We haven't dined in yet but stopped in to pick up a few of our benchmarking Sichuan dishes last week.  The tea-smoked duck was okay, but the flavor didn't penetrate all of the meat (especially the thick thigh and breast portions).  The outer surfaces were very flavorful, though.  Definitely better than the duck that you can get at any other Chinese restaurant in the KoP area (it's a sparse picking since you're left with China King/House/Star), but it's not as amazing as New East's (in the NE), which has that authentic pink-ish flesh in literally every piece.  The crispy fried fish with pine nuts was good with plenty of seeds and a nice batter; the bass meat was tender yet firm and took on the sweetish sauce nicely.  Not as amazing as Margaret Kuo's but still tasty, all the same.  The dan dan noodles were flavorful with plenty of minced pork although the sauce wasn'treally spicy at all.  E Mei's version is definitely spicier and more authentic with a more generous addition of chili oil.  Overall, it's a good option for Chinese in an area that is severely lacking in even semi-authentic restaurants.  Will return to try the dry-woked dishes before deciding on a final rating but so far, there is potential.

It's still a humble-looking location but the service is fantatic.  They actually cook up the wings when you order them so they are hot, fresh, and sooooo flavorful.  AND they are still good the next day too (heat in oven).  Me?  I had a crabcake tonight (no meat on Fri) that was nicely seasoned and full of fresh, delicious crabmeat.  Just heat it in the oven and you're good to go.  Plus, I have those wings to look forward to tomorrow.

Solid seafood cafe in the French Quarter near Cafe du Monde with fresh crab, fish, and oysters and a very casual atmosphere.  The servers are friendly and helpful, and I was happy with my grilled oysters and etouffee.  It's not a fancy dinner restaurant but great for a quick bite.

It's definitely not Machismo or Chipotle but the staff here are sweet so I do stop in every once in a while.  The chicken bowl here is decent and the free chips and salsa much appreciated.  The meat can just be a bit dry.  Portions are pretty generous though.

This isn't the best Dunkin by a long shot BUT it is the only one in the area that will have a full inventory of bagels even after 6 pm.  And ya know, sometimes you just want a damn bagel with cc for dinner (multigrain por favor) and it is heartbreaking when your Dunkin doesn't have the multigrain.  Service is just ok and they have yet to get my usual order wrong (large iced coffee, half decaf, coconut, skim, half sugar...yes, I am very high maintenance).  The drive-thru is a different story but it's decent if you order inside.

Nothing beats a cherry water ice and pretzel on a sunny Sunday, which is just what we got.  The mini pretzel was fresh and soft in the middle and delicious with a side of honey mustard.  The cherry ice was good but didn't really stand out either way.  About $2.50 for a small ice and mini.  Staff was friendly and they have a nice selection of different mustards.

I love the cashew butter (unsalted por favor!) here, and although I confess to being a diehard Skippy Extra Chunky fan, I do have a weakness for the fresh, chunky, unsalted PB here.  It's literally just full of crunchy peanuts, which I just love. The hazelnut pb is a must-try if you like Nutella; it has a crunchier, more nutty taste and is not as sweet.  Get a loaf of whole grain bread and just slather it on a slice or two for a satisfying snack.  They also have a good selection of dried fruits, although I find that they are on par with the kinds at Trader Joe's and more expensive.  The dried pear is the only fruit that I tend to get here because it's not too tough (Trader Joe's is really almost leathery).  

Since today was national PB & J day, I had to stop in to grab a jar of the chunky unsalted to go with the Smucker's squeezable grape jelly at home.  It was still warm and tasted fantastic when paired with a thin layer of grape jelly and a toasted slice of Arnold's Multi-Grain.  Now that's what I call a yummy dinner in celebration of a true American classic.

I love the sandwiches here, mostly because they are just stuffed with plenty of freshly shaved meat and served on fantastic rolls.  Half of a catering platter sandwich has more meat than perhaps 3 Subway footlongs.  I'm not exaggerating.  My favorite is definitely the turkey and swiss on an egg roll.  The tuna salad wrap isn't bad either.  The roast beef on kaiser really depends on the cut you get in the sandwich; sometimes, it can be a bit on the tough side but other times, it is very tender. The pasta salad is decent (your basic ziti with Italian dressing, feta, tomatoes, and olives) but the garden salad is really nothing more than icebery, tomatoes, and peppers.  I would definitely skip that.  So, come here for the sandwiches and/or catering platters.  It's around $7.50/person so the price is pretty fair for the amount of food you get.

Meh. Why do most restaurants in airports have to be so sucky? This place looks very nice. And the food is alright. It's edible. It's not delicious. But it'll hold you over until you get some place better. The food sounds way better than it really is. Don't let the menu descriptions fool you. However the menu describes it (particularly with regards to dipping sauces, etc.) is not how it'll actually be. The service is subpar at best. You'll be ignored for the most part. And note that the kitchen typically closes at 6:00pm.

Alright, I appreciated their willingness to seat a large group, especially one with 4 kids. But beyond that, it was terrible. The service was alright. The food was horrible. I hadn't eaten all day and was starving, and I couldn't even muddle through more than a couple of bites of the terrible pasta. And I'm a total pasta lover. I don't know how they could've screwed up penne with meat sauce so horribly, but they did. This is definitely not a place I would go back to.

This was an a-ok breakfast spot. It's popular and gets crowded, especially on the weekends. But the wait isn't too bad. It's a small-ish spot with the hostess and waiting area in the middle and then a dining area room on either side. It's like a diner in a grandma's house. Lots of knick knacks and chipped plates and whatnot. It makes it almost charming and kinda cute. The menu had a decent variety. We ordered one of the combos and shared. It's definitely some large portions - by my standards anyways. Everything tasted fine and was filling and entirely eaten. But I wouldn't describe anything as delicious. The service was attentive and friendly. All in all, we had a pleasant experience here and I'd stop by for breakfast again.

This is a decently nice nail salon. I liked how quickly the nail techs worked. However, the tech I had did a somewhat sloppy job. Not terrible, but uneven thickness and filing. Easy location to find with easy parking. Walk-ins ok. Same day appointments are easy.

The good:
- Friendly front desk staff. Felicity in particular was great.
- Nice selection of drinks and snacks for purchase. Way better than just vending machines.
- Close to the stadium and 275.
- Large rooms.
- Comfy linens and pillows.
- Free wifi.
- Decent channel selection.
- Free breakfast every morning.

The bad:
- No much in the way amenities.
- The restaurant in the same parking lot was closed - and it didn't look particularly good anyway.
- Not much in the immediate area other than strip clubs.
- Bathroom amenities lacking.
- The A/C / heat was just one of those below the window fan thingys. In FL in the summer, this just doesn't cut it. Room was always an uncomfy temp and too humid.

Overall, not a bad place to stay. Seemed to have a lot of pre and post cruise-goers. Lots of families and large groups trips. Clean and nice enough.

I will always prefer the original Silver Peak location, but this one is nice too. The ambiance and vibe are nice. There's indoor and outdoor seating. The beer is always excellent. Hint: Get the sampler so you can try all of them! The wings are awesome. Hint: You can get both flavors, so go ahead and get half jalapeno honey and half buffalo. Their buffalo sauce is actually spicy. The jalapeno honey sauce is delicious and unique. They really coat the wings in lots of sauce. And the wings are meaty and good quality with a good crispiness. And the blue cheese and ranch dipping sauces are both high quality. Hint: Be sure to ask for both dipping sauces when placing your order. And, of course, there's the grilled cheese. Seriously like the best grilled cheese you will ever have. Multiple cheeses, cream cheese, avocado, sour dough bread - oh my, it's a taste bud heaven! Service is always good too. So yeah, come eat and drink here!

It was alright. The staff were nice and accommodating, especially considering we were a large group who wanted the TV on convention coverage. And they were really nice about the fact that we showed up minutes before they closed. So 5 stars for all of that.

The food, however, was just mediocre. It was standard Americanized Mexican fare. And the packet of salad dressing was kinda creepy. Between 2 and 3 stars.

So we'll even it all out to 3 stars. It was an alright experience. If you're in the area and hankering for Mexican, why not.

This is a pretty nice hotel. Clean, new-ish looking, quiet, not crowded, comfy bed, decent bathroom, etc. There's no free breakfast. But there is a little counter where you can order some items for any meal. It's in a nice location where you have numerous restaurants, stores, etc. within walking distance or an easy drive. It's also easily drivable to all the various casinos and downtown. So if you're looking to stay somewhere that isn't a smokey casino, this is a nice option.

This is surprisingly a pretty decent hotel. The staff are super nice and friendly. We had a large group staying here with different arrival and departure dates and lots of room changes - and they were awesome at accommodating us.

The rooms are all slightly different. Some of pretty substantial in size. Others feel a tad cramped. Overall, it's all pretty ok. My biggest complaint was the super uncomfy, hard as rocks pillows. I had to make a Target run to buy one it was so bad.

There's free wifi, free breakfast, etc.

If you're in the area, you should feel a-ok staying here.

It's one of the most famous cemeteries and a total NOLA must-do. Pro tip: Go here as part of a tour. Navigating around here unguided leads to aimless wandering and not knowing what you're looking at. A knowledgeable guide will clue you in to the secrets, history, and hidden gems. It's also a great place to try out some artsy photography. This is the place where you'll find Marie Laveau's tomb and her actual hidden tomb, as well as Nicholas Cage's awaiting pyramid tomb.

Sure, I suppose it's a touristy place. But it's in a cool old building and convenient. We opted to sit at the bar. The bartender was friendly and attentive enough. Decent beer offerings. I opted for ordering the red beans and rice. I found it enjoyable and with just the right amount of spice. While Yelpers may argue over the authenticity of the food, it seemed authentic enough. And we didn't have bad service or feel overrun with tourists.

I don't know how I always wind up in this CVS when I am Reno, but for whatever reason, I do. And this is seriously the creepiest CVS I've ever set foot in. It's a total throwback to something out of the late 70s / early 80s - and not in a hip, retro way, but in a scary, horror movie way.

However, all that being said, the pharmacists are really nice and efficient. So props for that.

This is one of my favorite places in NOLA. The fish marigny is what I always get. It's breaded fish topped with small shrimp and the most delicious sauce. The cajun shrimp are also great. The menu is plentiful enough for everyone to be able to find something suited to their tastes and/or dietary restrictions. I've been here for business meetings, as part of a large group, and on a date. I've never yet been disappointed. And when you dine in the restaurant, you can hear the jazz from upstairs. It's a great vibe and ambiance. For the last decade, this has been my go-to NOLA spot and it's always fun and tasty.

For my 600th review, I have opted to skip a few New York joints on my recent east coast trip and flash forward over to my super fun and freakin' fantastic Philadelphia food experience at Fogo de Chao.

This is a Brazilian steakhouse that is made for people with huge appetites and zero remorse for eating animals. So with that said, my uncle took my dad and I here for my dad's birthday.

For $55 person, before tax & tip, you get this:

1) A trip to an amazing salad bar that features all kinds of good stuff, namely aged cheese, shitake mushrooms, and some of the best asparaghus you will ever have. But don't spend too much time here as you will not have enough room in your stomach for part 2.

2) An all you can eat meat extravaganza. Flip over your card from "red" to "green" and the meat cutter server guys start to come by with all kinds of Brazilian style meats, such as picanha (top sirlion), bacon wrapped filet mignon (amazing), and the orgasm inducing, beef ancho (prime of rib eye).

FDC also features killer fraldihna (bottom sirloin), yummy costela (ribs), super excellent and fresh cordero (lamb), very juicy and savory frango (chicken), tasty costella de porco , exceptional lombo (pork loin), and above average linguica (sausage). 

If you are a first timer, I suggest asking the servers for small cuts so you can figure out what you like most and request more later. My favorites were the picanha, bacan wrapped filet mignon, beef ancho, cordero, and frango. 

3) Tasty side dishes like garlic mashed potatoes, buttery bread, and caramalized bananas

4) You also receive spectacular service. The guys working that night were friendly, fast, and efficient. One server said:

"Hey, when you aren't taking orders, you have no excuse for screw ups."

Also, the guys are very attentive. I think they heard me say, "happy birthday" to my dad when we first started eating and at the end of the meal, the guys presented my dad with an amazing flan that was on the house.

5) A smile on everyone's face after dinner as they rub their bellies.

So if you have a huge appetite, and are looking for a wonderful meat eating experience, you should head to Fogo de Chao, which has several locations across the United States and Brazil.

Now if only they would open one up in the Bay Area!

Cafe Beignet is like a hot chick with no substance. There's a reason you want to hit on her, stick around for some time, and would call her in the future. But her personality is the reason you may lose her phone number.

When it comes to Cafe Beignet, the live jazz music was the reason I went in, stayed a while, and would come back. But their food is the reason the latter may not happen.

Their typical touristy Cajun food was decent, but it lacked flair, culture, and was far from memorable. In a city like New Orleans, there are so much better options. Unknowing tourists must come here for the awesome vibe which features patio dining and amazing live jazz music in the middle of a classic courtyard.

I loved eating on the courtyard taking the energy of New Orleans in. The entire experience transported me into another world. Unfortunately, the food brought me back to reality.

My recommendation is that you eat somewhere else. Just come here for some dessert, coffee, or a beer. 

In the end, Cafe Beignet truly is like the hot with no substance. That makes it mistress material.

In New Orleans, the legendary Bourbon Street is full of sin. And by sin, I mean vomit, discarded thongs, booze, beads, and boobs.

If you need an escape from the debauchery on Bourbon Street, you should consider stepping into LeBooze. Most of the clientele here is fully clothed, chatting in their deep voices, sipping on scotch, smoking cigars, and showing off a little chest hair. And these are just the women that I am talking about. Kidding.

Kidding aside, the place has a classy feel with dark brown wood furnishings, some big screens, and a very professional and polite staff. My bartender looked like Jon Bon Jovi. Yes, that Jon Bon Jovi. The guy that your wife thinks about whenever she needs to get herself in the mood. You know, in the mood to clean the kitchen.

Anyway, after every round I would buy for my clients, I would say things like...

"Oh! Oh! Drinkin' on a prayer!"

"Your drink is like bad medicine. Bad medicine is what I need!"

"It's my life! It's now or never!"

The bartender was not pleased, but he was a good sport about it. He fueled up my clients, so I could take him to other less than desirable joints on Bourbon Street. 

I heart NOLA.

Food just tastes better in New Orleans. And the food at Popeye's is no exception.

My fries were were crispy, seasoned, and delicious as they should be. And my chicken strips were hot, thick, and juicy. Pretty much just like my...

*Remainder of review censored by the Internet*

Really Diner food.  Good Selection.  Good Service.
I stuck with the burger.  Decent.
My friend had a falafal burger, which she seemed to enjoy, and yet another friend went with the Monte Crisco.  (uneventful)

Service was good, and prompt.  Nice bathrooms.  Ok prices, in $8 for the burger.  Nice outdoor sidewalk seating for the coming warmer weather, in a quaint downtown.

I agree with several other of the reviews that the cannolis are the single best thing here the canolis are great and the cheesecakes are excellent however the price of $4 for single cannoli seems very high to me and higher than New York City. Other than price this is a worthwhile stop.

The last time I went through a drive thru in this neighborhood was probably a Jack in the Box in 1975, while riding in the back seat.  Over multiple days, I recently had an opportunity while visiting Mom, to not only go through the drive thru, but also counter service.  I was surprised that both were equally as speedy and friendly, and they didn't screw up my "no-cheese" order.  Solid,  fast and friendly service.  Good times, but I miss the big clown head.

This dump hasn't changed in years!

That's what's great about it.

Always cool and interesting art work hanging on the walls, usually from the students at PCA around the corner.

Great jukebox,  cheap beer,  tube TV's,  confusing uni-sex bathrooms....what more could you want.

I like the open air feel of this place, as they just leave the door wide open most nights, so it feels like you're drinking in a garage.

Cool place.

Growing up in the Philadelphia area, I used to go to the Christmas Light Show at Wannamker's, narrated by my favorite Philly Sportscaster, Mr. John Facenda. (Wow).

And Wow have things have changed!

Am I really that old?

From being delighted by tungsten light bulbs chasing each other around in colorful circles. (I still kinda get a kick out of that. :) )

To the high definition world of people crawling up walls (see my picture), and the walls transforming, right in front of your eyes.  (and so much more.  Sports, Rocket Ships,  etc. that look so real, you can almost touch them)

Sometimes we wonder, "where is the future?",  "Where are the flying cars?",  "Where is what I see in Minority Report?"

Look here.

The future...
....and the future of America, and Television (because the two seem to be inextricably linked)
are here NOW.

Stop by.   I guarantee you will be impressed.
At least until it's in your living room. :)

Good sports bar.

This is just a good local spot, that is refreshingly diverse, updated and good food and service for the area.

There s a lot of outdoor seating space, some great wooden booths and tables inside, and a nice bar area with high-boy tables, and bar, with a LOT of big screen TV's.

I usually get the crab cake sandwich, which is always good.  I think they serve their sandwiches with a small bag of chips, which is a downer.  Prices are "fairly" reasonable.  Not cheap, but overall this a is a great place for sports, or a decent meal.   Can get a little loud for eating.

Always had an affinity for this train station.

Maybe because I spent 10 yrs in Philly and walk by here many times on my way to university.

Maybe it's from the indelible movie images in "Witness" and "Blow out".

The WW1 statue of an angel carrying a soldier to heaven is really quite striking and the ceiling and lighting, coupled with the ample benches for seating, just make it a good spot to wait for your train.

It seems like food court has some vacancy problems and I notice a longstanding bar that was a nice waiting spot too, is now gone.

Regardless, it is VERY convenient whether coming or going and is nice to admire.

Sort of a must visit place, you know?  It is a beautiful historic thing that re-creates a moment in time that is long gone.  What's more, they don't "create" it... it's obviously re-created, but that's fine.  It's one of the few places that ends up, by default, a nice, normal bar with jazz.  It isn't too gimmicky - and if you can sort of stop wandering about slack jawed, you can go here and have a brilliant time watching ragtime jazz.  Just sit and relax.  Patty O's, The Dungeon, and all the other gimmicky bars can wait.  This is a gimmick I am hip on.

On a Tuesday night, this place is pretty much empty.  

I loved the ambiance and the decor.  It's kind of what I want my future kitchen to look like.  Subway tile.  Exposed brick wall.  Old school Edison light bulbs.  Kind of industrial, but warm.  I love it.

Good selection of drinks.  I'm always a fan of milk stouts, so the Milk Man was a plus for me.

The food was decent - I had the tri tip salad.  Portions were quite large, I don't think I finished it.

The service was good.

Overall, we had a positive experience.

I'm a little surprised for the poor reviews here!  Of course if you are comparing this hotel to an Omni or Hyatt, it's definitely nothing to call home about, but for a 3-star hotel comparable to a La Quinta or Best Western, it's really not bad!

The lobby smelled and looked like they just recently underwent a remodel.  My flight landed at 1am, and I was still able to check-in without any issues.

My room was quite pleasant.  I liked the floor to ceiling windows.  Again, it smelled like fresh paint, the bed was comfy, and the bathroom was clean and looked new.   I wasn't crazy about the lighting (LED lights make bedrooms feel cold!), and it took a while for the hot water to come on for my shower.  Other than that, I had a pretty pleasant stay.   

The front desk staff were friendly.  It's in a convenient location with an easy walking distance to the French Quarter and CBD.  Overall, if you're just looking for a no-fuss hotel, the Blake Hotel ain't bad at all!

If you're looking for a nice break from all the heavy Southern food in NOLA, Two Chicks Cafe is your place to rejuvenate with fresh juices, smoothies, and delicious breakfast food items that are perfectly portioned.  Our trip to New Orleans was a food-centric ordeal, so we wanted to start the morning off light.  The Chia Pudding totally called to this Southern California girl's heart.  It wasn't too sweet, and the fresh blueberries gave the pudding a nice balance.  They can get a bit overboard with the walnuts, but I still really enjoyed it.

The Belt Eggwich was also perfect.  Good portion size.  Not too heavy and greasy.  Goes very well with Louisiana hot sauce!

Lastly, I would also recommend the Blue Chick Smoothie if you're one to love acai and smoothie bowls.  On a hot and humid day, this smoothie totally hits the spot.

If you're staying near the Convention Center, Two Chicks Cafe is super convenient.  The line can get pretty long, but it moved quickly.  The service was friendly and quick too.  Overall, I would definitely come back here for a quick and casual breakfast/lunch.

First and foremost, I want to say the service here was excellent.  With a group of 9 girls who may have had 1 drink too many, I know taking care of us was not the easiest task.  On top of that, we also had a show to catch.   Our server(s) were on top of it!  Quick, friendly, attentive, and overall we just had a very positive experience.

Coupled with excellent service, the food was also delicious.  We ordered:

Stuffed P&J Oysters (broiled) 
Raw Oysters
Hot Buttered Crawfish 
Crispy Brussels Sprouts
Fresh Gulf Puppy Drum (white fish)
Shrimp & Grits
Shrimp & Crawfish Etouffee with pasta

I think my favorite item might have been the etouffee with pasta.  There was a ton of crawfish and shrimp, and it was bursting with flavor.  Of course, needless to say the Shrimp & Grits are delicious too.  Oh, and so was the Hot Buttered Crawfish (if you can't tell, I LOVE shrimp and crawfish!).  I don't think you can go wrong with any items with shrimp and crawfish.  How many more times can Cecilia say shrimp and crawfish?!

Yes, I would highly recommend enjoying a dining experience at Luke!  Stellar service, delicious food, beautiful and classy space, it's a win all around!

(Review for the donuts only)

Donuts always have a special place in my heart.  It was Memorial Day weekend, and it was FREAKIN hot and humid.  We were on a self guided tour through the Garden District when we stumbled upon District Donuts.  What a godsend!  1) Air conditioning - YAY!!!!! 2) Donuts - double YAY!!!!!!! I loved the concept of a slider bar AND donuts.  Plus, it was stupid hot outside, so we needed a break too.  

We ordered the Coconut Mango (my favorite), Chocolate Glazed, and Carrot Cake donuts.  They do have some unique and interesting flavors, and from the looks of the other pictures on Yelp, it appears they rotate their flavors pretty often too.  The donuts were light and fluffy, and did I mention they are huge?  Out of the three that we ordered, the Coconut Mango was my favorite.  The cream filling wasn't too sweet, which is perfect for me.  

I do love the space.  Exposed brick walls, kinda industrial looking.  Seating is pretty limited, but since most people are just eating a donut or burgers, the turnover was pretty quick.      

Overall, I think this was a great find!

Mediocre vegan desserts, but not a lot of competition in the city to get better. Granted, these treats are vegan+, I've had far tastier and fulfilling vegan treats at the Whole Foods in Portland, OR. I really want to love this place and tell you it's totally amazing and life changing, but I've done my vegan dessert due diligence of tasting and can't vouch for these. Doesn't mean I won't keep trying. I will try the tomato pie like Sarah F. says is delish and try some more. But for now, SF you're A-Ok.

My favorite craft brewery in PA! Whenever out of towners come to visit, Prism is the place I show 'em. It's full of wonder and mystic - located in a more industrial part of town - you are wondering where the hell you're going and if you'll ever make it back. Once you're inside, you might never want to leave. Incredibly creative beers - from the Love is EVOL (with jalapenos and strawberries) to the Bitto Honey - IPA brewed with honey. The place reminds me of a place I'd find in Oregon. Low profile, awesome beer, friendly and generally staff and patrons. Prism is the place to be!

After leaving Springfield, MO, one of our most favorite cities on the Route 66 cross-country road trip, we stopped in St. Louis, MO for a round of golf (I sort of caddy for the husband) and lunch. It was about 3pm when we finally had lunch so starving was on the menu. I read good word about Blues Cities Deli keyword searching "lunch in St. Louis" and further checked superior ratings by populus vote.  Even at 3pm, St. Louisians were still coming in for lunch, with patrons scattered in tables outside late-lunching away.

I was in the mood for something vegetarian, so I ordered the Panino Fresco ($5.75) which contained about $6 worth of mozzarella. The muffuletta olive mix provided a sharp tang against the creamy, mild mozz. The slightly toasted bun was chewy and soft, yet provided enough structure to hold the giant slab of cheese and scoop of olive mix together. I adored this sandwich!

My husb got the Chicken Shack Ranch ( $5.95) with Applewood smoked pulled chicken, bacon, provo, lettuce, tomato and buttermilk ranch dressing. I looked down and then up and it was gone. Just destroyed.

Chips: Never seen before chips! Wondering what Wisconsin cheddar in chip form tastes like, no more. Nothing special in the end - just artificial tasting cheese powder is all. 

Soda: Found some interesting sodas - how can you resist a Santa Claus root beer and a cow drinking straight from an orange?

Dessert: I was feeling like something sweet, so splurged with a chocolate chip cookie which I ate on the road. It was not anything special, but hit the spot in terms of that chocolate chip cooking feigning feeling. 

Overall, Blues City Deli was a fantastic lunch spot and definite bang for your buck.

Having lived in cities that define themselves by their d-nuts (Portland, LA - proud to be Dunkin' Free) and now Philly with their Feds, I have become an expert in the field of Expectation Management. What is said about the cities "Best Donuts" might just be a mouthful of overtly sugary wreckage. 

Federal keeps it consistent. The same block of dough for every doughnut. You decide whether this is boring or not. I will tell you that they have nailed this dough. It's what cake doughnuts should be - a slightly airy crumb bite that gives you the false impression you could eat 6 and still not be full. The coatings and icings get all the jazzing up, which is fun. Adventurous flavors like watermelon cucumber lime and strawberry ginger icing or sugar coatings - lavender sugar? Yes!

While I wouldn't break my neck or stand in line for more than 10 minutes for some Federal Donuts, I could eat one every other day and be very happy (and without rotting teef). they are delicious and are best in class for cake doughnuts. 

Good stuff on the d'nuts Philly. I like your style.

This is solid Thai food where you wouldn't expect it. The pad see ew and crying tiger salad are where it's at. Skip the pad thai and the curries. Focus on the wide noodles. Drunken noodles are also worth noting. Everyone on yelp that reviews Nadia Thai seems to like them, but the pad see ew will call to you: it combines the perfect amount of broc, protein (tofu for me), egg and savory-yet slightly sweet sauce to create an alluring and comforting wellness in your pie hole. I've never had a finer made Crying Tiger Salad - strategic ingredient chopping so every bite redeems the glory of all flavors of the Crying Tiger. No lazy chef bones here.

It was wheely fun! 

I am not a beach person at all- and when my friends wanted to go biking down the beach, i thought i would probably sit this one out. I thought maybe riding tandem with dude would be fun, but i was scared of toppling over! THEN- we saw a bike that seated four people strolling down the street!!!
Next thing we knew, we shelled out 38 bucks for two hours for the four of us, to ride this bike "car" called a Surrey. 20 bucks per couple was not bad in my opinion to ride a few miles around the beach! You just had to becareful of all the bikers, rollerbladers and the traffic surrounding the area. But there's many places on the bike path where u cruise through with a nice relaxing view. At the time that we went, it can get pretty chilly with the wind blowing from your biking- so bring a sweater and also water cuz it's a pretty good work out! (there's a basket on the front of the bike where u can store purses etc). We saw some families have about 5-6 people on these bikes! There's two wheels and everyone has pedals u can choose to do, but only the driver has control of the steering. 

Other options: Single (two people) Surreys
Choppers and regular two wheel bikes.

Didn't get to have the whole experience as we popped in here to kill some time before dinner and they were closing in 10 minutes at 5pm. The gentleman at the desk was more than happy to let us scope the place out and didn't make us feel unwelcome for showing up so close to closing.
The interior is pretty cool to check out and see the old courtrooms, beautiful architecture and the relaxing lawn area outside. Didn't get to go to the clock tower which will give u a great view of city for FREE!. Next time!!!

Such a cute stop on State Street by Macys! Tons of affordable baubles such as cute rings, hair accesories and i found cupcake and hamburger necklaces! http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/AYSZCdB7oUiKMaOy0yud6g?select=XPbBmk-Mu2gx0jyVW_QvdQ

*i love yelper anne marie p's perfect description that this is a Claires on crack!http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/AYSZCdB7oUiKMaOy0yud6g?select=RFtz6rAlfQlX_erXcohcDQ

I came here at the recommendation of the front desk at the hotel I was stay at. I was definitely not disappointed. The food was really inexpensive, and the waitress was soooooooo nice and helpful. I didn't have to wait very long and everything tasted great.

Dang! another car rental review. 

Booked a mid-size car so I can get access to the executive emerald aisle. The car selection wasn't great but I was able to get an SUV. checkout process was a breeze. The car ran very well, and did not give me any issues. The return process was a bit convoluted, and I did have to wait a bit as the staff were not very fast. 

Location of this place is weird, google maps had trouble finding it, and I had to circle the airport twice to get here.

Was staying at the Peppermill and too lazy/too drunk to drive my pretty behind anywhere to feed myself. This place is right across the street - v convenient. 

I ordered the Broccoli Beef combo meal which includes a bowl of soup, 1 egg roll, and rice...huge portions... ALL for $5!!! Now, that's a deal!!! Dani's wallet gives 2 thumbs and 2 toes up!

To add to my last review: 
- Heated pool and awesome gym facilities! 
- Large hot tub inside the rooms
- flat screen TV in room and in bathroom - so you can watch Snooki do her thing while bathing 

Lovely!

Stayed in the Tuscany tower, which is suppose to be THE place to be in Reno. Decor is very nice, room was very spacious, bed was very comfortable and the 3 pools on the property are very very nice. The fitness room had brand-spankin new machines with individual TV screens and they provide you with headsets. 

Dani's complaints:
1. holes on my bed-sheets, yes, only I would notice 
2. pool-side bar opens at 11am, wtf? I need my drink at 9am in the morning when I wake up!! Minus 1 star.

Usual Whole Foods experience: great choice and delicious food along with friendly and inquisitive staff.  Was with a large group so I couldn't stay and linger, but it was well worth stopping by, even though it's out in the burbs as opposed to being centrally located in Nashville.  Be aware that the health food products like whey protein, etc., are located across the street at a separate "Whole Body" store.

The hotel would have easily had 4 stars had there not been ants in my room, crawling all over my lamp.  The front desk gave me a Starbucks gift card on my way out when I pointed it out in the morning (I had to deal with the ants myself the night before - too tired/too late to call housekeeping to do something I could have done myself).  I have a feeling, from how well-run the rest of the hotel was, that this was a fluke...but a fluke nevertheless.

The lobby is absolutely lovely and beautiful, and was part of the George Clooney "Up in the Air" movie.

This was one of the places I stayed when I first visited St. Louis.  It's got a convenient shuttle to the airport that departs whenever you want it to and at a regular time during rush times.

The Fox Theater was almost bulldozed less than a generation ago.  Leon and Mary Strauss kindly undertook a massive and expensive renovation (http://www.fabulousfox.com/theatre_restoration.aspx) and preserved a St. Louis landmark.

The Fox is designed in a "Byzantine-Siamese" style and was part of a Grand Avenue at the turn of the century that featured all sorts of theaters for movies and vaudeville.  The Fox was one of the first theaters that showed "talkies" and is so magnificent that if it were to be built today, estimates range in the hundreds of millions for construction.

Tours are given on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays at 10:30am, and believe it or not, the tour will last for 90 minutes!  I recommend the Saturday one as that is when you will likely here the grand Wurlitzer organ under the stage rock the house.  Stan Kann used to be the one playing that organ back in the day...he's no longer with us. (http://www.fabulousfox.com/StanKann.aspx)

I took the tour on a Thursday, learned a lot about a St. Louis landmark, went backstage where many St. Louis natives have never even gone, and got to experience the beauty of this theater, which is designed, in its reaching towards a lovely ball chandelier, to look like a giant tent (continuing the Siamese theme).  It costs $5, or $3 with your student ID (I'm going to miss busting that one out). 

Here are some pictures that I took:

http://www.facebook.com/media/set/fbx/?set=a.2015045492755.120798.1142340120&l=01992796c5

I've stayed here on 3 separate occasions and it's a very fine hotel.

You have Ruth's Chris for the steak lovers, Red for the trendy types, Brewhouse for those who want a gastropub or just want to watch the game.  Morning?  Don't worry, there's a Starbucks!

Valet is only $5 more than garage parking, and frankly, with this location, you gotta expect to pay a premium for parking.  At a hotel this nice, across the street from the Old Courthouse and Arch, you can't expect the "low price leader."

Yes, I don't like the nickel-and-dime aspect of paying for wi-fi, but I think this probably speaks to the Hyatt's convention and business traffic.  They know they can get away with it, so they do.  If you really need internet, walk to Bread Co.  It's a few minutes away and free there.

Rooms are clean and for the conferences, both big and small that I attended here, the meeting rooms were vast, spacious, well-appointed, and set-up just as ordered.  

I think this is a great spot to treat yourself if you live out in West County - walk to the game and come back to hang out after knocking a few down at Paddy O's.  Not paying for the DUI might be worth the cost of the room :-)

Wei Hong, yet another jewel on the treasure that is South Grand, is to me, the best Chinese place in St. Louis.

Not only are the dishes authentic, but they also have baked goods and bbq pork and roast duck that you can carry out!  For those of us raised near ethnic supermarkets and shops, having Wei Hong across the street from Jay Intl Market gives you access to 65-75% of the things you are looking for when living in Asia, and that's really cool.

If you really like Chinese food (and no, if you eat a lot of Orange Chicken, Broccoli/Beef, and crab rangoon, I'm not talking to you.  That would be like saying that liking Taco Bell meant you liked Mexican food.  Kinda, but not really) this is the place for you.

As I've mentioned in other reviews of Asian places, "American style" customer service is very rare in an authentic place.  Indeed, there's probably an inverse proportion - the ruder the staff is, the better the food might be.  Every now and then you run into an Asian or ethnic place where the service is awesome and the food is awesome.  For me, when I go for great ethnic food the service is really secondary.

Yes, I know it's a chain, but it serves up some good food.  Not only that, I was able to place an order for 14 enchiladas and tacos without a credit card and when I showed up when I said I would everything was boxed and bagged for me, and everyone enjoyed the food.

Had a chance to do the Brewery tour!  Very informative, got a chance to learn a bit about brewing history in St. Louis, and got a much smaller, scaled down, more personal version of the A-B tour.  

Oh, and at the end, you're going to get a minimum of 5 pours of samples.  I was driving, so I had to leave it to my friend to do the drinking for both of us.

Tours are Fri-Sun, from 12-5, every hour on the hour...be there 15 minutes ahead of time and wear close-toed shoes (if you forget, there's a bunch of crocs there for you, but it's like bowling shoes, you know? :-)  Oh, and of course the tours are free.

The A-B tour is mandatory for anyone who likes beer, even if you're a snob and only drink craft beers.  One has to concede that without the big dog pushing the market on the "quantity" side, there's not the luxury of creating the "quality" side and I think that craft brewers all over St. Louis and all over America are riding on the wave of beer popularity pushed by A-B and its brands, which, unlike many other breweries, survived the insane Puritan madness known as Prohibition.

You're going to do a fair amount of walking.  You're going to go into warm areas and cold areas.  You're going to see Clydesdales.  You're going to be with a lot of other people.  You're going to get to drink two beers at the end.  You'll get to see the history behind what was an American institution until InBev bought it some years ago now.  Don't miss it.

Was taken here by friends.  Definitely try the brisket nachos!  Also a great patio out back when the weather is nice.  

You will need to park ages away, though, as there's almost no ready parking around there.  The earlier you go, the less likely the cuts and dishes you want will be sold out (it happens regularly!).

Graduation week continues...brought my parents and my baby sister, and had a wonderful late afternoon lunch.  Around 2:30 on a drizzly day, you're going to have a restaurant to yourself.

I had the pineapple seafood fried rice (sorry, I don't recall the Thai name) on a 3 out of 5 scale of spice (you can order anywhere from 1-5).

Loved the dessert....sticky rice and sliced mango and also got the fried banana fritters with ice cream and drizzled honey.

Great Thai food doesn't need an English-speaking server.  You can point (even, when in my case, the server didn't even understand the properly pronounced Thai names).

My date and I experienced fast service, great food, and a not-crowded atmosphere.  Hard to miss with the food offered on South Grand.  This was just Exhibit #2,732 for anyone who doesn't already know about this street of ethnic food delight in the Lou.

I enjoyed my stay here, as I always do (this is my 4th or 5th time here).  I'm really pleased that they've also upgraded some of the bathroom fixtures in the rooms and made their keys RFID - i.e. you can't demagnetize them with your phone any more.  Major kudos!

So how did they lose a star?  One reason only: Parking.  I think this continues to be a problem for this property as it grows in popularity, but it's a problem.  I pulled in around 10pm at night, gave my name, and went upstairs thinking that I could call from my room and start leisurely walking down.

When I woke up in the morning, the parking cost wasn't on my bill.  I called the Front Desk.  "Hey, can you add parking and then transfer me to the parking garage?"  "Sure sir, but may I ask, does it say 'P1' on your ticket?"  I looked down.  Sure enough a "P1" had been scribbled and circled on my valet ticket.  "Yes," I said, wondering if I had won a prize.  I hadn't.  "That means you'll have to come down to get your car in line."  $26 for valet means I can't call down - and that I wasn't even told or given the option to get the more expensive one that means I can call down and not wait?

Figure it out guys, but boo on this visit.

Not as great as World's Fair, but is drive-through, and is going to have a lot more in selection at any given time of the day.

Cash only.

I loved reading from one of the other reviewers that she wanted her "St. Louis Merit Badge" now that she had been to Ted Drewes.  Of course it's a landmark.  Of course it's listed in every guidebook about St. Louis.  And of course she deserves her merit badge.  I mean, so do I. :-)

The way it's set up, with the multiple windows, handwritten menus, tschotchke for sale, I'm so reminded of stopping at ice cream shops in Cape Cod.  High school kids spending all summer serving ice cream to the rest of us.

She held my M&M concrete upside down to show me it wasn't going to spill.  I then had to take a picture of it myself:

http://www.facebook.com/photo.php?pid=2642977&l=718e6a3819&id=1142340120

Pretty cool.  And Delicious.  Head down there and earn your own merit badge :-)

Conveniently located near any of the delicious restaurants on South Grand.

Great gelateria.  That's really enough.

Huge, huge facility out in the burbs.  Plenty of parking, instant smell of hops when you walk in the door.

There's a dining area, a gift shop, and then a bar/live music area.  Older (older than 35) crowd, but still a fun vibe.

So many beers on tap, really cheap.

If you like beer, I think this might be one of the top 3 places in town to go to.
Decent bar to get away to or to pregame at before eating on South Grand.  Cosy, intimate, not trendy and knows it.  Decent bar service.

I try to explain to people all the time why it is I so love my alma mater.  

I came here as a transfer student in an MBA program, so I was only there for one year, but wow, I really fell for this school.  We have a world-class, beautiful campus, with two wonderful museums you should check out - the St. Louis U. Museum of Art and the historic Samuel Cupples House.

We have an amazingly beautiful college chapel and a group of students dedicated to service.  

We have world-class faculty and students from all around the world who come to study here.

And, at least in the business school, at the John Cook School of Business, we have an amazing place to study, meet in groups, and go to class.

I'm deeply grateful for my second degree from a Jesuit University.

This company is known as "Bread Co" in St Louis, and "Panera" everywhere else, but the standard is the same: clean tables, free internet, staff that won't hassle you if you while away an afternoon in leisure or at work after only having bought a tea, really great pastries, and good soups/sandwiches/salads.

The college church of SLU is very beautiful, mostly because it was designed before the catastrophe that was Vatican II, in which all churches were deigned to be ugly going forward.

The church is in the Gothic style, with very detailed and lovely stained glass windows, and marble altar pieces.

Mostly deserted and quiet during daytime hours.  Stop in and look around or sit down and have some moments of silence or reflection or prayer.

At least one of my yelp friends had a bad review of this place so I'm going to preface by saying this review is solely for the late night drink scene...

I haven't really made it out to Clayton in my too-short one year stay in the Lou (alas, I'm moving back to KC in August) but I was glad I made it out to Cafe Napoli for late night drinks.  Large patio/al fresco area, decent drinks and food, and the people-watching...great.

Oh, and if you want to see the phenomenon of hot Wash U girls (or those masquerading as such) throwing themselves at older men, you can get that here.  It's worth a drink or two itself.  And for us men, it makes us look forward to getting older :-)

They are open late and have a late night menu if you miss the dinner cutoff around 1030pm/11pm or so.  Great service and cool environment.  Don't be thrown by the address.  It's located inside the hotel, and you should be able to get your valet parking comp'ed.

About an hour ago, I received the fastest food service I've ever received, ever in my life from a sit-down restaurant.

I've been to Sen-Thai before, which is why I was very comfortable coming back.  It's within walking distance of tons of places in downtown, the decor is modern, and the staff is friendly.

I ordered the "Pad Chestnut" which had raisins, cashews, green peppers, onions, and beef stir-fryed and served with jasmine rice.  This was brought to me maybe 4 minutes after my date and I had started in on the spring rolls.  I was totally shocked, not only by the speed of the service, but the great taste of the meal.

Not the most attentive service, but you're there for the food, so don't worry about it.

So my rule is that if I want to give .5 stars, I round down.  I do not give the benefit of the doubt when it comes to restaurants.

The waitstaff was aloof and inattentive, and neither my nor my date's meal were particularly memorable.  I ordered some Chili Mac and it wasn't wonderful, though they do have a great beer selection and this "Ghost Wing" level of spice that is above "Stupid Hot" (yes, that's what it's called) on the menu.  Eating all of the wings means you don't have to pay for the order, you get a t-shirt, and you get a photo on the Wall of Flame, also known as the "Wall of Chodes."

Don't bother...there are other places on Delmar that will be a better spend of your time and money.
Good family restaurant,  different type of Mexican food pretty solid, good food. The service is pretty good but at the end of the day it is still a mom-and-pop hole-in-the-wall Mexican spot

Wow! What did we stumble upon post our dinner at Acme oyster house. This spectacular bar with so much rhythm and jive that I could just spend all night listening to the world class Jazz here! Yes the cocktails are amazing too! We were lucky to find a table n just enjoy a magical night! A must visit recommend if you are in town! Check out my pictures for more Deets on the amazing decor and how this cozy bar gives you everything you need to spend a perfect jazz night in the big easy!

Hubby is alum from UFA and we were visiting my cousin who is studying at the university and we were looking for an upscale dinner restaurant. Luckily for us we could get a last min reservation eventhough it was the 2nd Sat of the month when there is a local fair in downtown.

 Loved everything about this place
- Drinks:Sonoran Gimlet- magical potion that hits the right notes if you like a tequila based coctail made with finesse. They are strong
Bourbourn and Tepache-my whiskey loving hubby couldnt have enough of it ;)
Boca Del Rio: need an acquired taste for it,very strong but may not appeal to everyone

-Appetizers: Ceviche: Perfect!
Complimentary Chips and Salsa- super yumm, know when to stop or you will miss the main course
Tacos- Amongst the 5 of us we had Nopalaes, Rajas,Carnitas,Pescado and Lengua- you get 2 types per plate and all of them were delish and well made
Main Course:Chile Relano and Chile Nogada- both perfectly presented, served and cooked :)
Dessert: OMG, best tres leches ever presented beautifully in a Mason jar..yumm yumm

Overall, a memorable family dinner. Can't wait to come back for another meal!

After reading about Woodside in GOURMET Magazine I decided it sounded worth the two hour drive to Delaware. Thankfully, I am not alone in my willingness to drive long distances for the prospect of amazing ice cream. With a three car caravan in place we decided to make a day of it, stopping first outside Baltimore at G&M for crab cakes and then heading on to Woodside for ice cream. As soon as we pulled onto the road that Woodside Farm sits on I was sure the drive had been worth it. The trees, the cooler-than-DC weather, the pastoral scene with the grazing cows - this was definitely what I'd envisioned.

We were welcomed warmly by friendly ice cream scoopers Karla, Bridget, Meghann and Sandra who upon finding out we had driven all the way from DC for their ice cream agreed to allow us unlimited tastings. If you know yelpers, you know we took advantage of their generosity tasting cake batter, motor oil, orange honey blossom, butter brickle, chocolate thunder and more! Let's just say I feel very qualified to write this review with so many samples!

In the end I got two cones. I took things slow starting with a scoop of chocolate peanut butter on a sugar cone. It was the perfect balance of chocolate and peanut butter and in my opinion a must try for anyone who loves this combination. I then went back for mango sorbet, coconut and banana on a waffle cone. That might've been a bit overkill in retrospect but hey - we'd driven over 100 miles to get there!

Woodside Farm is an ideal en route stop on your way from Washington, DC to New York as it's right on the way. The gals at the counter are real sweethearts, there's plenty of picnic tables outside to sit at and the rock road fudge makes a fabulous take-home gift.

For one night, this hotel worked for us. That and my doppelganger got it on Priceline for a mere 100 bucks at the weekend so how can I really complain?

The location meant easy access to restaurants and bars.

The outdated decor was rather hideous and there was no free wifi.

I vastly prefer the Hyatt Regency Philadelphia at Penn's Landing which is just a short trot across the 95 from the Sheraton Society Hill.

Let's say you're in the mood for a nice, summery beer (Dogfish Head Festina Peche, perhaps?) al fresco but still need to get a bit o' work done. Such was the case this week when we arrived at Tria. The kind staff set us up at two tables on the sidewalk, conveniently positioned next to an outlet to keep our laptops juiced.

Snack-wise, you cannot go wrong ordering the Parmesan olive oil potato chips. I can't wait to return and sample more of the menu!

If you love to eat and drink outside, Tria is an ideal spot.

Drastically better than New York's Penn Station, here are some reasons I like Philadelphia's 30th Street Station:

- Plenty of wooden benches to sit on
- Soaring ceilings 
- Art deco decor
- Tasty hoagies
- Easy parking if someone's coming to pick you up
- Rarely, if ever, a long wait for a taxi

"We have a parlor room available - it's about twice the size of an average guestroom but it does not have a bed. I'd be happy to send a roll away for you," said the hotel staff member checking me in at the Hyatt Regency Philadelphia at Penn's Landing. I furrowed my brow and then he offered me his other tantalizing option: a smoking room (WITH a bed.)

I was understandably displeased with both options and let him know. In a lousy attempt to lessen the pain he offered me a voucher for a free breakfast.

I reluctantly took the smoking room and headed upstairs. Once off the elevator on the 7th floor, I was instantly hit with the stench of cigarette smoke. I wanted to gag. I didn't know hotels still had smoking rooms, let alone smoking floors!

As I climbed beneath the covers, the sheets felt like plastic. I wonder if this is a special perk available only to smoking room inhabitants?

I've stayed at the Hyatt Regency Philadelphia at Penn's Landing on numerous occasions. However, on my last two visits the hotel's not been up to snuff: rooms not quite clean (crumbs near the desk), room service trays left outside the room I was checking into (I think that explained the source of the crumbs) and a general feeling that the hotel had let itself go.

And then came last night's two terrible choices: a room without a bed or a room on the smoker's floor; pretty much the last straw for me. One thing's a sure bet, I won't be coming back to the Hyatt Regency Philadelphia at Penn's Landing!

I've stayed now twice at the Hyatt Regency at Penn's Landing. While this hotel's not exactly in the heart of Philadelphia, you can easily walk there from here. And if you're not the walking type, there's always a cab waiting to be beckoned over from the stand across the street.

The rooms are current (no dodgy bed coverings here!), spacious, well insulated from noise and very clean. And snagging a room here for around $100 on Priceline has been a cinch.

The best thing we three did at Vietnam Restaurant was take the advice of yelpers and order the BBQ platter! When it arrived we were overwhelmed by the bounty: crispy spring rolls, beef stuffed grape leaves, chargrilled chicken, grilled meatballs, rice vermicelli, lettuce and rice paper (to wrap it all up in!) They say it serves two - if you plan on ordering other main dishes, it can easily serve four.

For dinner I ordered the chicken pho (my litmus test for Vietnamese food) and the broth (my favorite part) was a bit like bland dishwater. I also wish it had been served in a larger bowl; delivered as it was the soup was sloshing over the side.

Still, I'd return for the BBQ platter any day of the week!

Looking for a beautiful rustic place to have a romantic dinner? Look no further then Cold Spring Tavern. CST is hidden in the mountains about twenty minutes from Santa Barbara. To get there you have to take old highway 154 and then a little windy road called Stage Coach Road. The restaurant is nestled in the mountain side and is shaded by huge trees. You can't even see the place from the highway. CST actually consists of two buildings. One is a restaurant and the other is a small bar. CST looks like an old log cabin inside and out. The inside has lots of little tables that are lit by candle light, two fireplaces, and lots of old pictures on the walls. 

The food here is great. They serve quite a few different types of meat. Anything from steak to pork ribs to venison and even buffalo. They also have an amazing chili. I always get the sampler which will let you try three small bowls of their great tasting chilis. My favorite thing on the menu though is an appetizer. It is the mushroom caps filled with venison. The way the venison and the mushroom taste when combined is fantastic. 

The best day of the week to go though is on Sundays. On Sunday they have a guy come down and set up a BBQ outside the restaurant and serve up the world best tri-tip sandwiches. The chef is a big friendly guy who has been doing this BBQ every Sunday for as far back as I can remember. His sandwiches are too die for. The best thing is that he is not stingy when it comes to the meat. He packs those rolls full of the juiciest tri-tip you will ever taste. To put on the sandwich he has three different types of condiments. The first is salsa, the second is a great tasting sweet BBQ sauce and the third is an amazing apple horseradish. 

The service here is stellar. The people who work in the restaurant are all really nice. On Sundays when the BBQ is going on the place will get really crowded. Mostly by bikers and tourist. If you're a fan of motorcycles then I would recommend going down one Sunday. You will see all makes and models of different bikes. Also on Sundays they have bands play outside of the bar for you to enjoy will you eat your tri-tip sandwiches. 

The restaurant itself is a little pricy but well worth the money for the experience you are sure to have. On Sundays the tri-tip sandwiches are seven dollars a piece but more then likely you will end up spending fourteen bucks because they are so good you will want to have another.

"They smile in your face, all the time trying to take your place..the back-stabbers..."


After leaving my 'give a damn' at the California border, Daisy and  made it as far as Tucson before stopping  for our first overnight stop.   I know Motel  6's take pets so we stopped  and checked in.   A friend of mine is from Tucson  and now I see why she got the hell out.  This location has quite the ick factor.  The room was good enough for an overnight stay, but I not sleep well for getting up peep my ride with  all of my stuff in it.   It was covered up with a black blanket and you could not see anything through the tinted windows, but I was taking no chances.  In addition, Daisy kept growling and barking at anyone who passed our door.   
After a restless night for both of us,  I got into a cold shower as the water would not get hot.  WTF!   We packed up our overnight bag and got on the Interstate for our next leg of the trip.  

Weird kinda night but at least I was heading further away from back- stabbing bitches.

"...fish don't fry in the kitchen...beans don't burn on the grill
'took a whole lotta tryin' just to get up that hill
Now we're up in the big league, getting our turn at bat
As long we live, it's you and me baby
And nothing wrong with that...."


Aaaah yes... that theme song from The Jeffersons.  It's time for a bitch to careen like a magic carpet on her second wind. Heading into a quieter, older woman kinda life, I can begin to live my retirement dreams.  The excitement about this venture is unexplainable. 
However my huge kitchen complete with a pizza oven, huge yard with tress in a city that is also country....I've  taken to the sky on a natural high.

www.Pods.com

I got too much to think about.  What to move? What to sell? What to giveaway?  Should I have a yard sale?  The Recycler?  The Penny Saver.   Of course that's for shit I want to get rid of.   For the stuff that is headed to Georgia, other than me and Daisy....it's Pods.

Pods is a moving and storage company, for which if you got the cash...they store, they move it for you.  I'm not trying to pull a U-haul trailer or drive a U-haul to the ATL.  The shit I decide to move; business, studio and photography equipment, my bars, and  some other keepers.  The rest is for sale BABY!  Art, furniture, fixtures...and kinds of shit. 

And I'm gonna be a tote-bag, glass ware, art selling bitch this summer,  as Pods ain't cheap.  I may have to pare it down.  But my estimate to store and ship my shit  to the ATL is gonna be somewhere around 8 grand.  And that's for the stuff I want to keep

Letting them worry about getting it to me....priceless.  

I will have to post an update once I am happily romping through 'Hotlanta" , but hey....I'll be Yelping from the ATL!  How cool is THAT??!!

Five stars because if works like they say they it does, it makes it one less thing to worry about.

Awesome dive bar with cheap, tasty food. Great place for out of towers to catch a glimpse of old school Nashville. 

I came by this bar after checking out a few other spots and this was the highlight of the evening. We had cheap, tasty food (including a MASSIVE burrito) and the drinks were cheap and tasty too.

It's a total dive but in the best way. The people were cool, the music was great, the bar was clean... What more could one ask for? I will always stop at this bar whenever I'm back in Nashville.

The queso is a must-have!

Visiting Nashville with some friends who live there, I was really hoping for a tour of great local establishments. I knew I struck gold when we showed up at San Antonino Taco Co. Even just walking up onto the massive outdoor patio I knew this place was going to be great.

See, in Seattle there are few places where you can eat outside because it rains so much that an outdoor deck area is wasted space 9 months out of the year. I fell in love with the fact that you could choose to eat inside or out, and both spaces were equally large. I imagined late nights here in the summer, loud people, big meals, and tons of fun. 

Then I fell in love all over again with their cute ordering system. There's a long hall where people line up to place orders. Sort of like Customs at the airport, you're outfitted with a paper menu and a mini pencil so you can input your order and just walk it up to the counter when you're ready. No more standing in line behind people who don't know what they're doing! (Which would have been me.) Instead I got to take a ton of time looking over the menu and thinking up a million different lunch options for myself without wasting anyone else's time.

Once I decided on some soft and hard shell tacos, my friend insisted we get sweet teas and queso. Queso isn't a "thing" anywhere I've lived so I was totally down. Sweet tea sounded like a good idea but "sweet' didn't begin to explain just *HOW* insanely sweet this stuff would be. But from what I understand it's super authentic. So I drank mine and enjoyed it for the tourist factor.

The tacos were great, the queso was outstanding and the whole experience was a ton of fun. I don't think I could have said I saw any of Nashville if I hadn't stopped in here at least once to eat. In fact, I'm certain I can't come back without going here to eat again!

Jamie W. and I were way too cheap to stay in this elaborate Vegas-Strip-level resort when we took a quick trip to Nashville recently. However, that didn't mean we weren't above being among the throngs of plebeians who traipsed through what is apparently the largest non-gaming hotel in the continental U.S. Yep, no slot machines, no green felt tables, no Keno light-up boards. Yet, the indoor atrium felt so Bellagio, so Venetian, so Paris that we felt we might as well be in Vegas (photo: http://bit.ly/2v5NGVf). It's just that without the gambling and with the Disney-like decor, it was all kinda boring. The boat rides weren't operating when we were there, and we are so not water park people. BTW, the trick to avoid the exorbitant $30 parking fee was to park in the outer reaches of the Opry Mills shopping center lot and walk over. It was a bit of a hike but hey, I said we were cheap.

RELATED - Collection of Tennessee sights and eateries that I've tried and reviewed: bit.ly/2v22KmG

Jamie W. and I never did take that cemetery tour we heard so much about when we were in New Orleans earlier this month, but we wanted a bit of exposure to the voodoo culture that appears alive and well in the French Quarter....at least for ignorant tourists like me. We saw the voodoo museum on the next block, but this one spoke to us a bit more. You enter a very thin doorway (our first punishment, I guess) and come upon a dark, heavily stocked store full of gris-gris bags and voodoo dolls of all shapes and sizes. The juju guardian dolls are the freakiest ones (see photos).

I was kinda bummed to find out it's been a myth to stick pins in a voodoo doll and expect to cause pain for whomever the doll is supposed to represent. I immediately canceled my bulk order just after I finished itemizing my inventory of everyone I hated in high school. It was payback for unwanted Facebook invitations. But I did find out that to stop a voodoo spell being placed upon you, you need to acquire some bristles from a pig cooked at a voodoo ritual, tie the bristles into a bundle and carry them on you at all times. Had I known. Fun store. It's definitely worth a browse as you're strolling the quarter.

OK, this was cool. I was in Philadelphia just for the day on business and walking in my monkey suit with a colleague into the Comcast Center for an appointment. It turns out we were a bit early, so he excused himself to make a few calls. I was left to wait in the Winter Garden lobby. Lo and behold, I saw a huge widescreen that just blew me away. Oh the glory of high definition resolution.

It turns out to be the largest four-millimeter LED screen in the world. Stretching 83.3 feet wide and 25.4 feet high, the 2,100 square-foot video wall conforms with the tall doorways to the elevators and shows some sensational images - just about anything from a montage of Philadelphia to the expanding universe - all produced specifically for this venue. You really have to see it to believe it. Take a look at the photo gallery to get some idea. Or better yet, how about this video clip...
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WSRcDrCse7c

I think this eclectically upscale hotel should probably win some Art Deco-stylized loving cup for Best Repurpose of a Historical Building Into a High-End Hotel.
