It was formerly the Lafayette Building, an 11-story office building built in 1906 and left vacant for several years due to the recession until the ever-resourceful Kimpton Hotel chain gave it a complete makeover inside. On the corner of 5th and Chestnut, It's right across the street from both Independence Hall and the Liberty Bell, so you may want to pimp out your powdered wig and practice your minuet moves. Alas, I wasn't there for any patriotic pleasures.

I was there for work and could merely enjoy the holiday card scene of Independence Hall outside my window (photo: http://bit.ly/U8kGYg). As it turned out, that was just fine because the room was a Deluxe One Bedroom Suite that was priced at an astonishingly low $171 on a wintry weeknight in January. Although the interior styling points to a historic restoration, the colors and patterns applied are bold and contemporary (photo: http://bit.ly/1o1OvUV). Look at the gigantic floral designs on the carpet, the Revolutionary War-era wall treatments (photo: http://bit.ly/T8ZEbh), the hard geometry of the shelving units and occasional tables, and the words of wisdom stenciled in the closet (photo: http://bit.ly/1kDxzhQ)

Your eye then gets drawn to the bright yellow doors (photo: http://bit.ly/1l1ZpsJ), the shiny mauve armoire housing the TV set (photo: http://bit.ly/1wYu3bL), the uniform iron-gate pattern of the wallpaper, and the lamp with the greyhound sitting dutifully at the base (photo: http://bit.ly/1nJxZeM). The standalone spa tub and deluxe shower are enough to lull you into a transcendental state (photo: http://bit.ly/1hu4MSF). There's also the Red Owl Tavern downstairs and a rooftop lounge. In fact, there's even a free hosted wine bar between 5 and 6 PM every day. Because of its unique location, the only downside to the Monaco is that any other dining or libation destination will require you take a cab. Otherwise this hotel is a genuine knockout.

After 2 straight days of non-stop cheese steaks, we finally took a break and ordered out from Linda Jean's Grille. A buddy of mine lives around here and highly recommended their roast pork sandwich and I must say, it did not disappoint.

Their roast pork is very juicy and tender. We took this go and ate this in the dark while watching a movie on our portable projector during the snow storm. The bread was good, this sandwich included some veggies in the sandwich, chips on the side, and small container of the juices from the roast pork. Dump that juice over your sandwich, it will give it even more flavor and you'll find yourself wolfing down this sandwich within seconds. The best part about this sandwich, it's not too oily or greasy.

Verdict - We definitely enjoyed it. From the reviews I've read, they seem to make a lot of other goods things. My friend ordered their pulled pork sandwich before and said it wasn't as good as the roast pork. For the price, the roast pork sandwich is pretty legit. It's good bite if you grow sick of the Philly cheese steaks that are available all around town.

This Costco is huge. There's even a big display of outdoor patio furniture in the center of the store. Everything is so neat and clean in this one. The food court even serves French fries. I've never seen fries in any Costco in New York. I do have one problem and it's the people who serves samples. They're really mean and moody. I tend to forget that in PA, they don't sell beer or alcohol in their supermarkets or 7-11. You have to goto a distributer for alcohol. I simply asked one lady employee where the beer section was and she berated my ear about how Costco across America will never have alcohol on their shelves. I then tried explaining to her that in New York, our Costco does sell beer and Costco in Taiwan sells both beer and hard liquor. She looked at me as if I didn't spoke a word of English to her and continued to lecture me about how there's no alcohol in every Costco. At this point, I simply don't care anymore about what she has to say. She's obviously never been anywhere else other than this boring town.

We attended Calvary Church this week for a graduation ceremony for Westminster Seminary graduates. This is by far the nicest and biggest church I've ever been to in my life. The parking lot is huge and as you enter through the auditorium entrance, you'll come across a massive cafeteria and lounge area. The seats are comfortable and the ushers were really friendly.

A wee bit pricey for the portions they serve. I come to Beck's for their gator gumbo over jambalaya. The whole thing is just so savory and the spices are just right. It's not overly spicy and not too salty as well. It's a great meal. The gator is in a sausage form. All chopped up into the gumbo. During this visit, I had to order their pasta. Chicken alfredo, for my 2 year old son. It was alright. The whole pasta tasted a bit dry. It's something I wouldn't get twice.

Verdict - Gator gumbo, end of story.

I don't stay in hotels very often, but I must say my experience at The Windsor Suites was a positive one. I really loved the location of this hotel. It was walking distance to nearly everything Philly had to offer. We're pretty much in between the Philadelphia Museum of Art and the Reading Terminal. So you can walk one direction towards the Museum  and go through Ben Franklin Parkway and through the Rodin Museum and near towards Eastern State Penitentiary or towards Reading Terminal which will lead you close to the Liberty Bell and other touristy sites.

Upon arrival, we had the valet take our car. They offer a in and out service which was very convenient for us. It allowed us to take the car out at night and see some the sites and hit up Pat's Steaks. The checking in process here is a breeze. The concierge was really friendly and helpful. There were a few things I disliked about the hotel. One would have to be their elevators. They have 3 elevators but they were all so slow! My second was their bathroom. The toilet seat was loose and the sink counter and cabinet below was dirty. I had to wipe everything down with disinfectant wipes. Everything else was pretty spot on. The beds were a bit small but it was bearable. The rooftop pool was nothing luxurious but for what it is, it worked. It wasn't crowded, they had fresh towels on hand and plenty of seating. Beverages weren't allowed at the pool site. The views were pretty nice.

Verdict - I would definitely come back to Windsor Suites if I were to visit Philly again in the future. I would just suggest to the management and housekeeping to make sure the toilet seats are on tight so that they don't wobble or break loose every time you sit down. And I hope in the future, the dust and dirt that was all over the sink cabinet would be gone. The value and price you pay is definitely worth it since you're getting a suite. Kitchen is kinda small, water and coffee are complimentary but I wouldn't recommend using their coffee machine. It is filthy! We ran water through it, and the hot water it produced was utterly disgusting! The closets were plentiful spacious. Our view was okay, 10th floor view of other high rise buildings. I wish we had a view of the other side that overlooks Ben Franklin Parkway. Everything about Windsor Suites gets an A except for their cleanliness. If the room was completely spotless, huge A all the way.

Friendly service but they're really slow. The selection of flowers here are minimal and they're expensive. It's a big shop but its filled with junk. It doesn't quite feel like a flower shop to me. Sure, it's suppose to be a gift shop at the same time but unfortunately, the gifts here are gifts that nobody wants. They're tacky and outdated. The nursery section is depressing. Many of their plants look very dead and dried out. I would not recommend this shop for graduation simply because their flowers are just way too overpriced. For the amount that we've paid, we could of gotten something much nicer elsewhere. This spot just happened to be the closest flower shop to the graduation ceremony.

The Gator Gumbo was the highlight of my day upon my visit to Reading Terminal. Just to make a clear note, I did not research on what's good and what to avoid at Reading Terminal before my trip. The only spot I was aware of was Bassetts. 

As I wandered around the terminal aisles, I saw a sign that said "Cajun". I immediately speed walked my way over and peaked through their menu and saw some gator. I never had any kind of gumbo in my life, nor have I had gator. I figured, this would be the right place and time to try. 1 order of gator gumbo over rice and it was by far one of the tastiest things I've ever tasted in my life.

The gator meat. I'm not 100% sure if it's actually gator but it tasted darn good. It seemed like they made gator sausages out of them and chopped them into pieces and cooked them in the gumbo. The cajun spices in the gumbo was magnificent. It was not flamethrower spicy, it had a nice kick and it went down just fine with the white rice. It was absolutely delicious and I regret not ordering a second bowl.

Verdict - Something this good is worth trying. Some may be discouraged because of the gator meat but trust me, just pretend you didn't hear the word "gator" and you'll love it. After trying other vendors in Reading Terminal, when it comes to hot food, I choose Beck's Cajun Cafe over everything else I've tried. The gumbo was served in the right temperature and the service was outstanding.

I've been to Mojito Cuba Caribe twice, both times under different ownership. The first time was under a funny dude name Mickey. He was great and had wonderful stories to tell. The food then is a different story. Portions were a tad bit small for the prices they charged. I came back last week with family and under the new owners, the food has improved drastically in my opinion.

We started off with some mango mojitos and beers. They have a few select IPA's on special and their mango mojitos were amazing. We ordered a sizzling grilled chicken fajita and Pan de Lechon which consist of roast pork, mojo cilantro mayonnaise and grilled onions on pressed Cuban bread. The roast pork sandwich was very juicy and tender. The cilantro mayonnaise along with the onions went really well on that toasty Cuban bread. As for the fajitas, they sure came out sizzling. Many other patrons ordered it because it smelled so good whenever the waiter passed by with it. It was really worth it. Served with grilled onions, bell peppers, rice and beans, guacamole, sour cream and warm tortillas. It was very filling and one of these best things to eat in all of Main Street in New Hope.

Verdict - Mojito Cuba Caribe is a nice cozy fancy little joint. There's outdoor seating and the service here does not disappoint. I miss the Mick but the food under the current owners is way better than before. Everything is speedier and tastier. Job well done!

Beck's Cajun Cafe has become my favorite spot in all of Reading Terminal. I've grown to like Beck's even more than DiNic's famous roast pork sandwich. Don't get me wrong DiNic's is still on my favorite list, just Beck's has been my top goto spot whenever I'm in Philly.

The gator gumbo in my opinion is always a must. Don't think too much about the gator. It's more like a pork sausage if anything since it does contain pork. But the gumbo itself is savory and full of robust flavors mixed with plain rice or jambalaya, it's a delicious combination.

I ordered just a gator sausage on a stick. It seemed pretty good because my dad hogged it! Guy didn't even share one piece. He kept dunking the sausage into their mustard and finished it within seconds so it must be good.

The train wreck po'boy was a first for me. Prior to this visit, we've only come to Beck's for their gator gumbo and fried Mac and cheese. I wanted something different this time so I gave the po'boy a shot and it did not disappoint. The hoagie for one was probably a better hoagie than most sandwiches spots I've been to in Philly. The taste and juiciness of the meat and ingredients inside was like an explosive orgasm in your mouth. It's not a sandwich that you need to rush and eat before it gets cold. Take your time with this one because it likes it slow. Comparing this sandwich to DiNic's, you have to rush to eat the roast pork sandwich at DiNic's because that sandwich taste like crap when it gets cold and dried up.

Verdict - It's probably no secret to folks who goto Reading Terminal regularly. Beck's has to be one of the best spots to eat in this place. The Cajun flavors here are just spot on and reminds you of New Orleans. Whether you been there or not, this is a taste of New Orleans and a must try for those who like like Cajun spices.

Came into this ballpark during a Phillies off day. My friend is a die hard Phillies fan forced me to come with him to the ballpark before we head back to New York. We circled around the stadium and took some photos with the Mike Schmidt statue. We went inside the team store and luckily the stadium was opened to a class trip. The funny part about this whole thing was my friend and his father were wearing suits while I dressed casually walking around with my camera. The students from the field trip thought I was some Japanese or Korean import and the two men in suits following me were my agents and translator giving me a tour of the stadium. It was quite hilarious. I casually walked into the stadium along with the class without any personnel noticing. I got a good look of the field and the view was quite nice. I personally like Citi Field much better but Citizens Bank Park is a fine ballpark too. There's much less advertisement. It's a clean and simple looking ballpark.

I love the ambiance but I don't love the service nor their menu. I get the whole "shorter menu" but a short menu doesn't mean your portions have to come so small. Was the food good? Yeah... but was it filling? Hell no!

I certainly enjoyed my time here, mingling with the owner, sippin on alcohol and munching on their small dishes. My main issue was their portions and they took way too long to come out.

Verdict - I'll come back another time just for drinks at the bar. I would avoid dining in due to the small portions.

Close enough to the action in the French Quarter but far enough from the Bourbon Street debauchery.  Won't beat a Kimpton hotel but it was a wonderful stay nonetheless.  [Original Visit: November 13, 2011]

The "original" loses its lackluster when there are so many other "franchises" along the block.  Yes, liquid pixie stick is the best way to describe it.  So long as you follow the one-and-done philosophy, you'll make it alive out of Bourbon Street without gagging - too much.  [Last Visit: November 11, 2011]

Jeb's Open Face Biscuit Sandwich.

Oh man.  This stuff is the best.  Gravy.  Fried egg.  It doesn't matter that they use a fake veggie patty instead of a sausage patty.  That just means that you can order two and feel good about eating "healthy."  And it's not just some ordinary toast, muffin, or toast but slices of soft and crispy challah toast.  This is breakfast comfort food at near perfection.

And like everybody else says, "Yeah, it's cash only but the prices are so reasonable, that's it's worth the "inconvenience."  Screw mileage points, I'd rather another entree at Honey's.

[Last Visit: November 2014]

West Chester is a quaint little town with a vintage feel.  Limoncello continues with that image.  Had a business lunch and partook in their buffet.  The selections are ample (5 pizzas, one pasta, 3 meats, and a full compliment salad bar) and the lines may seem crowded at times.  But the food is excellent and worth at least one visit.  [Original Visit: March 4, 2011]

Normally I would find a Ferris wheel structure at the State and County fairs, carnivals and amusement parks. But I never would imagine seeing the rotating big wheel ride inside a sporting good store. 

Indeed this is one at one of the largest and newest sporting good stores in the West coast (opened in 2008). The 300,000k square foot sporting good store carries "Everything" for all serious and casual athletes. The sporting good store is bigger than many Costco's and some warehouses. "Yeah, that big!"

The main floor has your typical athletic apparels and shoes, ski and snowboard apparatus and equipments. For sports fan, the store carries a large selection of gears of your favorite sports team. The bike shop carries road and mountain bikes from Trek (my favorite brand). 

The second floor has gym equipments, hiking needs, fishing and hunting needs including rifles and handguns, paint ball accessories, golf and tennis needs and soccer apparels including all the participating countries from the FIFA World Cup of 2010. There are other fun things to do including a video game simulator for NASCAR, a mini course for driving golf balls and putting, a real firearm shooting range. 

So if you're tired and need a break from walking around the giant sporting good store or you're just hungry and/or thirsty, there is also a café on the second floor serving Starbucks coffee and ice cream among the treats.  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/HF8gKF3UDiSc94YWd03kkw?select=kQ-fbCizWh3Lt4qSLKODWA

And in between the giant store is the aforementioned Ferris Wheel: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/HF8gKF3UDiSc94YWd03kkw?select=GQEwLCMVgxM-ACcF1VisAw

The expert and well-trained staff are well dressed with a tie and a dress shirt. 

The only item I bought was the Los Angeles Clipper's tee from Blake Griffin for $25.00. Despite being a Golden State Warrior's fan, I still enjoy watching NBA including Griffin's dazzling dunks every night. 

Even if you're not sport's fan, there are many things to do for all people and all ages.

The store is clearly one of the biggest sporting-good stores in the West Coast and obviously in the Legend outlet.

Do people still go to libraries anymore?

This downtown library, which is located south of Virginia Street, reminds me of the Main Library in San Francisco. Except the hours are not as great with unusual closing days on Fridays and Saturdays.

Probably lack of financial support from the state of Nevada cause the partial hours. 

Just like the old days, many locals come here to read the periodicals, do homework and researches, use the computer, or just want to avoid the casinos. 

I was here to use one of the thirty library's computer. I spilled my latte on my laptop. So I was just here to check on my necessities on the computer. Reserving a computer was not necessary since one lady was ahead of me. The wait took 10 minutes and I was on that filthy computer for 30 minutes.

For a chained-restaurant, I have always enjoyed Claim Jumper's huge portions and unique homemade desserts. No matter which locations I have visited and dined, the results have always been a positive one. 

I have been to this location many times when I lived in Reno for a while. And this location has never disappointed me.  My latest visit was a dessert treat after my questionable Vietnamese meal. I was also conferring myself for my dinner.  Boy, did I make a wrong decision. 

Nevertheless, I was here for dessert. I had the Salted Caramel Mud pie. For $8.99, I get a mountain scoop of Dulce de Leche ice cream in a crushed pretzel crust with a drizzle of warm caramel sauce. What you get is a mixture of the creamy homemade ice cream with the salty pretzel base as the crust. This is one of the restaurant's famous desserts. And this one is a hearty and yummy one too. 

Don't forget to grab a hand full of root beer hard candy after you are done. They are refreshing too.

I took the RTC #1 line to the end and the bus took me at the Meadowland Mall. 

A very big mall with Macy's, JC Penney, Sears and Sport's Authority as the anchor stores and same stores you see at any mall:
Foot Locker, Cinnabon, Victoria Secrets, Bath and Body Works and yes, the Disney Store to name a few. 

The mall's Border's Express is bigger than some of the other Border's I've visited.

The University of Nevada Reno store is also in the mall. Students gets 20% off any purchase.

The food court comprises with Orange Julius/DQ, Hot Dog on a stick, Sbarro, McDonalds, Flaming Wok and of course Starbucks to name a few. 

I didn't come to the mall to eat mall food. I decided to get ahead start on my Holiday-shopping for my family. 

I got something sexy from Victoria Secrets for wife to wear and to steam my glasses for the holidays. 

I bought my son a kid's jersey from the Kid's Foot Locker. 

Finally, my daughter recently picked up the game of Chess, and she is good too, by kicking my ass several times. Like dad, she likes the Peanuts too. So I went to Games Galore store to buy the Peanut's cute Chess set. 
http://static.px.yelp.com/photo/8gqlr7-onYFrmTVvga_gag/l

A typical mall with the same stores/outlet you see everywhere.

We drove to the city of Reno to see Aaron Kwok in Concert at this newly remodeled facility. Wife always obtained the news about these Hong-Kong entertainers coming to the US to do a performance from friends and other sources, and miraculously obtain tickets to all these musical events. The tickets were purchased in many places in San Francisco's Chinatown or other larger Metropolitan cities that has a Chinatown. This facility holds nearly 5,000 spectators, who try their best to rock the whole city of Reno down. 

Aaron Kwok along with Andy Lau, Leon Lai and Jacky Cheung (Matt's fav singer) formed Hong Kong's Cantopop  version of the "4-Kings" were the most popular foursome for all Cantonese and Mandarin fans from the 1980's- the mid 1990's. In current time, they are still popular, although they haven't done much in Hong Kong's pop cultures and being overmatched by new breeds taking over the music and entertainment scene. 

When they were in their prime, Matt listened to each of their musics and owned many of their "now" classic CD's in the 90's where they dominated the Hong Kong entertainment industry with their silky smooth voices that attracts many listeners of all ages from the Chinese communities  in all globe around the world. Ever since Matt got married and older, he haven't followed much, but wife still keeps up with the current events in the Hong Kong's entertainment. Wife still listen to musics from Hong Kong, (both Mandarin and Cantonese) while Matt listens to Jay-Z, 50-cent, 2Pac... "WEST-SIDE!"

Wife spent $125.00 dollars (the cheapest and lowest price)each for us, to watch a great 2-hour show performed by Mr. Kwok. Mr. Kwok would sing many of his current & greatest hits that Matt and wifey listened and grew up on. Some of the missy fans including wife bought nice bouquet of flowers and other gifts for Mr. Kwok and whenever he would sing a slow song, he would invite the girls upstage, hand him the gifts and give each girls including wife a hug and peck on the cheek. He did dance with a few of them, but not wifey, who was heartbroken and disappointed, but still she did hugged the man of the night.

From a Giant's fan: 

Ha-Ha, Ha-Ha!

Can you resign Jayson Werth? He's "Werth" a lot of money!

Ha-Ha, Ha-Ha!

And the dynasty is over for you guys!

Ha-Ha, Ha-Ha!

I better shut-up or else Chase Utley will come after me!

Ha-Ha, Ha-Ha!

Yeah, right!

I've rented kayaks all over California and Hawaii, and they all typically charge you at least $25/hour and up.

SEA Landing: $15 for 3 hours...unheard of!!!!! That's a deal!!!! :D

The caveats? There's no lesson, but ocean kayaking in sit-on-top kayaks is pretty self explanatory.  

Staff is friendly, but no service.  You just go up to the desk, pay, get a seat back and lifevest, and then you walk down to the dock where you grab your kayak, set the seat, and pull it into the water yourself.  But if you've never kayaked before and/or are out of shape, I can see this being a problem, though I would assume one of the staff would help you if you asked. 

There's one 2 Star Yelp review because one Yelper got pissed that they don't allow dogs...I love dogs and own a dog, but personally I would rather not get my hands, legs, or butt on doggie pee or dried poop.

Santa Barbara doesn't offer affordable lodgings...Castillo Inn is probably as cheap as it gets!  We paid $199 for Saturday night, which is good for Santa Barbara.  The word "Inn" might be perfect...this is a one story glorified motel.     I was amused seeing the parking lot full of Porsches, Mercedes, BMWs, and Lexuses...and our Subaru!  

PROS: 
-Clean spacious room and bathroom, but...
-Almost on the beach! 
-Quiet at night
-Free parking
-Quick drive to State Street
-Good Value

CONS:
-Clean room, but had a musty smell that took a couple hours of open windows to remove.  Could be the beach location bringing in a lot of moisture.  
-Few restaurant choices in walking distance, and they are expensive
-LOUD in the mornings! Since its a one story building, you'll hear the voices and cars of all the early bird tourists and maids chatting away.  

4.5 Stars...good place overall, though its hard to be romantic here.

"FARM FRESH PORK RIB CHOPS"..."PASSOVER FAVORITES"

Schnuck's management needs to educate themselves on basic Jewish beliefs(see my photo). 

I'm not an expert myself, but I do know that pork isn't exactly a "Passover Favorite",or ever for that matter.

My great friend and I went for lunch July 21. We always get the same server, and she is delightful.

He got a burger. Special was pork steak, which comes with a salad and two sides. I could not resist. I got Biggie's White French dressing, broccoli and broccoli.

He liked his burger. It came with fries. And he took half his meal home.

The salad was rather large, full of crisp vegetables, and the White French dressing was fabulous. I ate the whole thing, which can kinda put a damper on the appetite.

The pork steak took up the entire dinner plate. The broccoli and broccoli was brought out in a huge vegetable serving dish. I started laughing, and she said, "Well, you asked for it." Yes, I did.

The broccoli was beautifully bright green, tender-crisp and delicious. It had a tad of butter on it. The pork steak was thick with not-too-much barbeque sauce, very little fat, tender and porkalicious.

I took home more than half of both.

BUT, it was Thursday -- FRIED CHICKEN DAY!! Because the chicken takes 30 minutes, I put in my order for a take-home when we ordered our lunches.

Our server suggested I skip the salad, because it doesn't travel well, so I got broccoli, broccoli and pasta with white sauce.

The chicken (half a chicken -- four pieces) was delightfully crisp, well-cooked and well-seasoned. The broccoli and broccoli was the same -- perfect. I gave the pasta with white sauce to my oldest son.

I sure got my greens that day.

And I got all this food for a tad over $26. SCORE!!

The office had a working lunch, so ordered in using 569.DINE. I don't know what they pack the food in, but it's always delivered with the hot stuff hot and the cold stuff cold. Man, does that work.

There were five of us, and I couldn't keep track of everybody's food, but it was gobbled up heartily.

Here's what I saw around the table: two large house salads that were huge (and they were ordered as sides), fried fish sandwich, Dagwood, cheese quesadilla.

I got a small house salad that was still massive. It was fresh and crunchy with beautiful, crisp cucumber slices and diced tomato. The bleu cheese dressing was tasty. I also got the original hamburger with Cheddar. I ditched the bun, but it looked rather fresh. The burger came with lettuce, tomato and onion; I used all of that. Even though the burger was flavorful, it was a bit dry. They didn't ask how I wanted it prepared, a shortcoming in my book.

But the pickle was delicious and tangy!

Ordering from Market Pub House worked for our group, because of the variety of offerings. There was something on the menu for everyone.

What a gorgeous array of offerings. The chill case is full of beautifully decorated cakes, mini cakes and tarts that are absolute perfect works of art.

The "fruit cakes" were cakes that were covered with gorgeously glazed fruit -- kiwi, strawberries, blueberries and other fruits. So, they're not what you would think of as Aunt Sally's nasty Christmas "fruit cake."

Another display case had incredibly thick pieces of French toast, and lots of thick, fried doughut-looking things.

Korean pancake samples were available. How delicious! Quite sweet.

Cookies and other assorted treats were prepackaged in small see-through and resealable bags along the wall. So many choices.

We got cheese cookies, almond crisps, tomato paste cookies, a butter cream bun, Korean pancakes, honey cookies, a peanut butter bun and mocha bread.

Everything was delicious; most weren't overly sweet. The Korean pancake was the sweetest with a filling of sugary-mapley goo.

The office went today for a celebration lunch. We'd all reviewed the menu, but noted there's an $8 lunch buffet.

This joint amazes me. It's all made from salvaged things -- from the brick parking lot to the entry doors to the booths, the restaurant floor, all the tables, all the woodwork . . . well, you get the idea. It's just beautiful!

Upon entry, they sent us to a table, took drink orders and told us to help ourselves to the buffet. We inquired if menu ordering was available. Yes. We decided to scope out the buffet first, and decided there were plenty of tasty-looking offerings to forgo the menu.

One small table offered pizza -- at least six different varieties during the time we were there (kind of a while) and double-mushroom soup.

The table where you get your utensils and plates also offered bread and butter, and slices of sub sandwich.

The first buffet section offered all cold vegetarian items: potato salad, two pasta salads, a green salad with two dressings, cole slaw, beets, an olive bowl (complete with pits), and grilled vegetables (winter squash, zucchini, eggplant, a couple others).

The second section was hot food: steamed vegetables, vegetable pasta, beef stew and baked chicken.

Desserts were on another couple tables: red velvet cake, separate cream cheese frosting for the cake, Dad's cookies (nice local support) -- four varieties that I could see -- and oranges.

Everybody loved all the foods they chose. Among our group, I think everything was sampled, except maybe not the cole slaw.

The mushroom soup was the hands-down table favorite all the way around. It was absolutely divine.

I also got a bunch of olives . . . many different kinds, which also included pickled celery and carrots; baked chicken (flavorful and juicy); beets (just plain old beets -- lucious); beef stew, hearty with a great broth and tasty vegetables; a couple kinds of pizza (one had bacon, one was more like a Margherita with roasted garlic).

There was garlic galore in many of the dishes. That was more than A-OK with all of us. I think we all believe garlic is its own food group.

There were starlight mints at the hostess station, so you could nab a few on the way out! Just speaking to the garlic element.

Lunch is served 11 a.m.-2 p.m. Tuesday through Friday -- buffet or menu. Dinner is menu-only 5 p.m.-9 p.m. Tuesday through Thursday, and until 10 p.m. Friday and Saturday. Closed Sunday and Monday.

Our service was fabulous on the drink refills. And our server was incredibly knowledgeable of the origins of the salvaged materials that made this place. Unique!!

The floor of this place is amazing. I want it in my kitchen!

Had to get a rental, 'cause my son's car was crashed. It was Sunday, but this Enterprise was close, and I was hoping it would be open. No such luck.

Checked two other Enterprise locations on Manchester Road, and they were all closed on Sunday.

Sunday night I went online to reserve a car for Monday. No such luck. Monday was Labor Day. But I still put in the reservation.

Next try. 8 a.m. Tuesday. Arrived. Checked in. Paperwork intact. Printed. Done. Drove off in a Dodge Avenger very expediently. Not a bad car.

I specified my reservation to September 30, anticipating major repairs. So Enterprise froze nearly $650 on my credit card for that time period of rental.

I get it.

Well, good comes with bad. The car was totaled (bad) very quickly (good). We got another car (good and bad), and were able to return the rental after only three days (good).

How does that balance out?

Clerk was stupendous on the return. Reviewed the car quickly. I paid up, and went back to West County Honda to pick up the replacement car.

Can't have two drivers with three cars.

They do a good job, and always very friendly!

Two co-workers and I came in for a quick lunch, and we barely fit into the door because of the length of the line. But it moved rapidly.

There are probably 10 "classic" sandwiches available, as well as a "create your own sandwich" option ($6.99) combining meat (many options, including two types of chicken salad, tuna salad and egg salad), cheese (5 choices) and bread (7 options). And there were options for children: PB&J, grilled cheese, hot dog -- all $4.99.

For $2.50 extra, you can get a combo by adding a side and beverage to your sandwich. The sides were chips (Route 11 brand), mustard potato salad, dilled red-skin potato salad, vinegar and oil cole slaw, macaroni and cheese salad, pasta salad, hummus with flatbread, Caesar salad, side salad, and fruit salad.

Aside from fountain drinks, there were lots of bottled beverages.

There were two soup options today: black bean with feta and basil tomato.

We all got the corned beef Reuben, $7.59 (also choice of pastrami). With a fountain drink (Diet Dr Pepper, YIPPEE!!), mine was $10.10. The sandwich was chocked full of lucious corned beef. There was plenty of sauerkraut, minimal Swiss, enough 1,000-island dressing, and the grilled marble rye was tasty.

I got a to-go vessel for half of my sandwich.

And the pickle, which I ate first, was stupendous!

Miller's Crossing is in what's lovingly called Hog Hollow. It's on the south side of Olive probably halfway between 141 and where Olive veers south to eventually  turn into Clarkson Road at I-64. It's in a center that also houses the Hog Hollow Gallery.

I've been here five or six times. Mostly in the dining room, but a couple times in the bar -- at the bar for drinks, and at a high-top for a quick sandwich and a good conversation.

The bartendress is so personable and friendly. Talkative if you want.

Reuben is HUGE and flavorful full of house-smoked corned beef and comes with A-OK  fries. Half comes home with me.

The Cobb salad is quite good. I always have bleu cheese dressing on this salad. Again, half comes home.

Other favorites: clam chowder, Irish stew, chili, fish and chips. I've also had a lovely fish dinner, which I think was grouper.

Service has always been attentive, friendly and spot-on.

There's a nice outdoor eating area facing the parking lot and a bit beyond that, Olive.

My girlfriend and I have found this AMC theatre rather equidistant from our homes, so when we are catching a matinee, we go here. And we did that today to see "Spy."

Usually we eat lunch at Sweet Tomatoes before a 1 p.m. matinee, so I was disappointed to learn that Sweet Tomatoes had closed. We had to find another lunch spot.

The ticket window area is HOT and seems to be not well-ventilated. So if there's a long line to buy tickets, you're going to break a sweat. That didn't happen today, because there was nobody ahead of us in the line.

The matinee still costs $5, but now they add tax.

The ticket-taker guy was extremely friendly and directed us to the appropriate theatre.

I was raised to NOT get concessions at the movies, and I still don't ever do that. My girlfriend got a small bottled water, and it cost almost as much as the movie.

The restrooms are still spotless, BUT they now have automatic towel dispensing. However, the toilets seem to be miscalibrated and flush while you're still using the facilities, giving you kind of a bidet situation. Rather unpleasant.

The seats in the theatre are comfortable. Cupholders are big enough. Again, we sat in the first row of tiered seats, so we had the railing for our feet.

I really like this theatre, and it works so well for my girlfriend and me.

McAlister's has an incredibly extensive menu: appetizers, children's meals, soup, entrée salads, hot sandwiches, cold sandwiches, classic sandwiches, potatoes, pasta, desserts.

Yesterday was my first visit to a McAlister's. I was impressed with the cleanliness, the ordering process and the friendliness of the teammates. Erin took my order: a bowl of autumn squash soup and water ($5.73).

There were five soups available: autumn squash, broccoli cheddar, chicken tortilla, potato and French onion.

The soup is either butternut or acorn squash, includes cinnamon, cardamom, rosemary and maple. There's a swirl of sour cream and roasted pecan bits on top.

A teammate came by and replenished my water. That was kind.

The soup was fabulous. Luxurious texture. Sour cream and pecans were a perfect addition. The taste was rich and squashy -- YUM!!

After lunch at Filomena's May 27 with my great friend, we meandered down Manchester Road to Saint Louis Frozen Custard Factory. Neither of us had patronized this sweet facility.

Four flavors of custard were available: vanilla, chocolate, salted caramel and one I forgot.

Lots of toppings were available, as well as DIY flavors, if you wanted to begin with a vanilla base.

We both opted for a large salted caramel concrete for $6 and change.

It was 20 ounces (small compared to others, IMO). Not too salted, and not too caramel AT ALL.

And the worst part . . . it had tiny crystals of ice galore -- throughout the whole darned thing. Not something I've ever encountered with a concrete. It was icky crunch.

So, NO -- not smooth, not tasty, not refreshing.

The office went for a celebration lunch. Our vegetarian dining partner was unable to attend, so we ordered her lunch to-go. Timing worked out perfectly.

Chips and salsa were really good. Chips were warm and salty. Salsa had some chipotle smoke, which was nice. Not too much onion or any other overwhelming ingredient. A good blend.

We ordered the Queso Chipotle Dip ($6.99) -- Blended cheeses with chipotle en adobo. You could add chorizo for an additional $1.99. We didn't do that.

It was a nice-sized portion for the three of us. Came with a spoon, the only spoon on the table -- which was helpful, 'cause it was a bit runny for chip-dipping. But it had a good flavor. We ended mixing the queso with the salsa, and got a good combo for the chips.

Entrees ordered were:
Tuna Tacos ($14.99) -- Spice-crusted ahi, blended cheeses, pineapple slaw and mango habanero salsa. He chose flour rather than corn tortillas. Came with a bed of red chile rice topped with black beans that had a splash of queso fresco. He said the sweetness was nice, and he ate everything on his plate.

Chicken and Roasted Corn Enchiladas ($11.49) -- Red chile chicken, roasted corn, onions, blended cheeses topped with sliced avocado, pico de gallo and sitting in blackened tomatillo salsa. This came with the same rice/black bean side. Something here was a bit too spicy for her, making her nose run, and she didn't like it. We figured it was the blackened tomatillo salsa.

I got Shrimp Tacos ($9.99) -- Marinated grilled shrimp with jalapeno bacon, blended cheeses, cilantro and mango habanero salsa. Flour, rather than corn, tortillas. Same rice/black bean side.

The rice/black bean combo was bland and boring. A rather small portion. In fact, all portions were rather small for the prices. Two of us added salsa to the rice/black bean combo, and that helped.

The shrimp tacos were OK. I guess it was the mango habanero salsa that gave them a full overall sweet flavor. I do not like that in an entree. I ate one. Took everything else home. Don't know that I'll revisit that.

In my to-go bag -- everything rcyclable -- and in that for our vegetarian dining partner, they included a bag of chips and a container of salsa. Nice touch.

Service was good. Beverages were replenished regularly.

On Super Bowl evening, we were the only patrons in the house. Specials were chicken fried steak, chicken fried chicken and tomato-basil soup.

We shared an order of fried shrimp that came with a lovely ketchup-horseradish sauce.

She got a pulled pork sandwich and fries. I got a Reuben with cottage cheese.

Both sandwiches were tasty. The Reuben was stacked with corned beef and plenty of sauerkraut.

Service was A-OK. I had a hefty to-go vessel for another meal.

My decaf Highlander Grog was fabulous and served in a massive cup that had to be 20 ounces. My college chum got an English Mint tea, which she enjoyed immensely.

I saw other patrons having bagels and flavored cream cheese; and waffles with fresh berries and whipped cream. Lots of singles reading and online.

Not too crowded at 9:30 a.m. Saturday.

When I take a trek to Main Street St. Charles, we always go before the stores open, get a parking spot on Main Street, then get a pick-me-up at Picasso's until the stores open.

This is a beautiful equation. But I think a lot of other people have the same equation, and this place isn't all that large. Sometimes the order line is out the door. It moves, though. Then you must fret about getting a place to sit.

I always get a wonderful decaf. My shopping/excursion partner gets a hot cocoa or tea, sometimes a muffin or scone.

All the tables are painted with fun scenes, and there's always good people-watching to be had!

This joint is amazing. Hand-crafted spices everywhere with so many options, a cook could get dizzy. Aside from the norm of spices, there's available beef stock mix (powder), chicken stock and all manner of spices not available at the normal grocery store.

It's a tight, quaint store that packs a whollop in every corner and space available.Look everywhere!! There are seasonal spreaders and placemats! Lots of fabulous finds!!

Lots of dip blends (all you have do to is add the sour cream or mayo), pie and dessert makings, Paula Deen offerings and Bad Byron's Butt Rub!! Vidalia Onion dressings for salads; Wind & Willow soup mixes; and lots of rib, pork and beef sauces and marinades.

Their trick is: almost everything is available to sample.There are pretzel sticks everywhere (and graham cracker pieces for the sweet ones) to sample the dips, sauces, dressings and marinades.

The more you sample, the more you buy!

The office ordered in for a working lunch using 569.dine. There were 5 of us, and the orders around the table were:

Hawaiian pizza and small salad ($10.49 for the small pizza) -- she absolutely LOVED the pizza -- pineapple, ham and bacon. The salad was a lovely mix of fresh, crisp greens. No iceberg here.

Mushroom and tomato pizza and small salad ($11.07 for the small pizza with two toppings) -- she LOVED her pizza, too, and added a few more tomatoes. The pizza was truly brimming with lovely cheese.

Tiger Tamer ($8.99) -- grilled chicken breast topped with sautéed mushrooms and Swiss cheese. It came with fries that spread a massive aroma throughout our meeting room -- in a good way.

Blackened Tuna ($8.99)  -- 6oz. tuna fillet with lemon dill aioli. This sandwich came with fries, too. He liked it, but was disappointed he didn't get lettuce, tomato and onion for the sandwich.

I got the the Chef Salad ($9.99) -- Mixed greens, turkey, ham, black olive, tomato, green pepper, carrot, onion, crouton and cheddar cheese. I ditched the croutons and added grilled chicken for $2. AND they chopped up the chicken to truly blend into the salad. The green pepper was a nice and very tasty addition. I got bleu cheese dressing, and they sent two containers. YIPPEE!!

This salad was pretty darned massive and lasted two meals. It was soooo good. And lasted well to the second meal.

This was a successful delivery order. Makes me want to go to the restaurant. Not all do.

My girlfriend and I came for lunch in late February. The dining rooms were full, so we sat at an elevated booth in the bar. Karla was our delightful server.

The oil/balsamic mix served with the bread was mostly balsamic and ruined the bread. We should have known from the color. it was hideous.

We shared a caprese salad (heirloom tomato, crudo, buratta, olive oil, aged balsamic) for $6 each. They got the olive oil/balsamic balance correct on this salad. It was good. But $12 for a salad?

She got a veal dish. I got the shortrib papardelle ($15) with cipollini onions and roasted mushroom sauce.

Her veal dish was a mess on a plate. There were two veal cutlets. One was breaded and had sauce. The other veal cutlet wasn't breaded and had no sauce. Who sends this type of disaster out of the kitchen?

And these cutlets were sitting on a meager bed of pasta. Come on. Pasta is cheap. Could you not have given AT LEAST a reasonable amount of pasta?

Top this off with: she said the veal was not good: immemorable was the word she used. Flavorless. But she did like the pasta, the two strings she got.

On a higher note, my paperdelle was quite nice. A hearty dish. A few forkfuls will do it. So, I took a lot home. And it served for two more meals.

I hated that my girlfriend's dish was a flavorless disaster, But I liked my dish. So I'm going to cut in the middle with three stars.

This took me a long time to figure out. I liked my dish so much, and she got the bad one. I've been on the other side of this many times.

Thursday night, the high school girlfriends decided on a holiday celebration! Had a great table in the front window. The place is kinda small. There's a nice patio out back with 8 tables of four and a big fireplace.

Kristin was our fantastic server. Bottled water served immediately!

All were left to their own beverages, calculated beautifully by Kristin on separate tabs!

Food we shared --
Ernesto's flatbread ($9) -- figs, prosciutto, goat cheese and arugula with a balsamic reduction
cheese and charcuterie (choice of 3 for $10) -- she chose brie, bleu and a summer sausage from Washington, Missouri
Grilled cheese ($9) -- cut appropriately for the five of us; wild mushrooms, prairie breeze English cheddar cheese, black truffle fontina and white truffle oil
beef carpaccio ($12) -- served with aoli, ground mustard sauce, capers, arugula and a basket of flatbread with small baguette slices
Mushroom flatbread

We ordered all at the same time, but Kristin timed them a little differently, so first out were three, then two. It was a beautiful orchestration.

This was incredible food! Everything was delicious. Two standouts were the grilled cheese and the carpaccio (melt in your mouth).

Then we got more: another grilled cheese, a cuban, and the chicken and bacon flatbread. Again, more outstanding food. That cuban was amazingly delicious.

What a great evening! The restroom was holiday decorated, too!!

This is a most delightful coffee shop to patronize before the shops on Main Street in Old St. Charles open. My college chum and I always arrive a tad early to get in a good coffee here in this lovely shop.

This morning, I got a 16-ounce, quite tasty decaf  Highlander Grog in a gorgeous mug. My college chum got a beautiful skim-milk hot chocolate -- skip the whipped cream.

We found a sunny table for enjoying out liquid wares. They do offer plenty of enticing scones and croissants, as well as breakfast sandwiches. Lunch is served, too.

It's been a long time since I've been here.

The curtains haven't changed. I don't know if they've been washed.

I went in with my girlfriend who religiously gets 3 bagettes (These things are 32 inches long.) every couple weeks. She cuts each one into fourths, so she's got 12 days of bread for meals.

There were cookies available, probably 12 types. They looked good, but there were many display cases empty. Probably due to the time of day we were there -- after noon.

But it seems they cater to the sandwich-for-lunch crowd with fountain sodas and bagged chips.

Not what I remembered.

A girlfriend and I went for a matinee Wednesday.

It cost $5.

I had a gift card.

There was a small line at the ticket-buying queue. There was only one open, but there was no need for more. It moved quickly.

She was friendly and asked (as I'm sure all good ticket-sellers do) if I was an AMC Stubs member. I absent-mindedly said, "Yes," but then needed to recant, 'cause I don't even know what that is. And she thought that was funny.

The ticket-taker woman was incredibly enthusiastic and so friendly. She directed appropriately to the correct theatre for the movie we'd purchased.

Concessions are concessions. My girlfriend got a bottle of water. I watched.

The restrooms were SPOTLESS. And HUGE. Automatic everything, except towel dispensing.

The theatre was fine-sized. Lots of handicapped accessible seating in front, which I applaud.

The seats were comfortable for this 2.5-hour movie. For that amount of time, you have to move your seat around a little bit in the seat provided. It worked.

And since we were in the first row of the tiered seats, we had a railing to use to uplift our feet without interfering with other viewers.

Of which there were only four.

"The office" -- the four of us -- has been to Biggie's for lunch many, many times. It's always spectacular, and the service is spot-on.

Last visit was Friday. And we actually got a parking spot in the small lot behind the restaurant.

This isn't a fancy place. When you walk in, you're in the bar. But the hostess is right there to seat you.

This visit one of the walls in the dining room was rather yucked up. Maybe they had lots of inquiries, because they had hand-written signs taped to the wall that read: Remodeling. Pretty funny!!

We almost always order off the dinner menu: steak. Yes, steak!!

It had been a while since our last visit, and we were all anxious to dive into BEEF!! Our vegetarian dining friend was not with us this trip.

#1 got the strip steak with broccoli and bleu cheese dressing on the salad.

#2 got the sirloin steak with baked potato and asked for thousand island dressing on the salad. Not available. She offered white french on the side as a replacement -- a perfect solution in case he didn't like it.

I got the filet with broccoli and bleu cheese dressing.

The salad is served on a lipped plate, so you don't lose your salad upon tossing. The homemade bleu cheese dressing was divine. The salad crisp and fresh. #2 liked the white french, and we all had a taste, proclaiming it delicious.

Talking stopped when the steaks arrived. Moans, groans. NO SHARING!! #2's baked potato was half the size of a football, and it came with sour cream.

These steaks were so perfectly cooked, beefy flavorfulness and seasoned with Biggie's special garlic butter. Absolutely delicious!

The bread was soft and fresh with a crispy sesame seed crust. Yummy!

Service was impeccable. She returned to the table many times for beverage refills and to see how we liked the food, including a special trip about that white french dressing that #2 got.

#1 and I had to-go vessels of both steak and broccoli. Another meal!

It dubs itself a "Premium Burger Joint." I got a steakhouse burger ($6.95), herbed garlic fries ($1.95) and a beer ($2.75). I probably should have built my own burger, but it was entirely too confusing to make all the selections on my first visit.

The burger was maybe 1/3 pound. I got it cooked medium-well, which is what they suggested, and it's still got pink in the middle. Iceberg lettuce, gorgonzola, tomato, "special" sauce (some mayo/ketchup mix) and onion straws. The bun was Dave's special bun, a caraway seed bun, almost tasting like pumpernickle.

You order at the counter, they give you a number. You take a seat, and they bring your food when it's ready. I was there early, and there was just one other person in the place besides the employees.

In the dining area, there are booths, tables and high-tops. I sat at a high-top. Probably too close to the door, because I was freezing the whole time. There was music in the background, and a television on mute.

The fries were a huge order with mozzarella sprinkled on top. It was just starting to melt, so only the fries on the top got the cheese. They were tasty.

I cut the burger in half and still had to squash it to fit into my mouth. It was a kinda sloppy bite.

I ate half the burger and half the fries, so had another meal for the next day.

There's also a punch card. Buy seven entrees, and the eighth is free.

The restaurant is in the Bellerive Shopping Center just a little west of Olive and Mason, right next to Schnuck's.

I went in for lunch after running errands.

Remembering the fries are from a frozen bag of crinkle-cuts, I skipped those.

Just got a Vienna dog (mustard only) and a gyro.

The Vienna dog was in a soft bun that was covered with poppy seeds. I detest poppy seeds. So, I just ate the dog that had plenty of mustard.

The gyro was full of lettuce, tomato, great lamb, feta and tzatziki. I ditched the pita and ate the innards, which were fine.

I had a lovely breakfast at the bar. NOTE: On Saturday and Sunday, they serve ONLY breakfast until noon.

I stopped in last Saturday about 11:15 a.m. expecting to get an early lunch while running errands. I sat at the bar, ordered a beverage, then was offered a menu, which I accepted, then found out that breakfast was all that was available.

And I was eyeing the hamburgers, because they have cottage cheese as a side!

Well, that was OK. I ordered a three-egg omelet with sausage (patty, not link), mushrooms and Monterey jack cheese. It came with hash browns that were crispy and choice of toast (I chose wheat.). $8.99.

You get three additions to your omelet, and the choices available besides what I got were: bacon, green pepper, four of five kinds of cheese, tomatoes and onions.

I was reading my book. Not too many patrons were there . . . a couple guys at the bar. Two televisions tuned to different sporting events (no volume). It was quite pleasant.

The omelet was wonderful, and full of sausage and mushrooms, covered with cheese. The hash browns were crispy. Even the toast was good, and the wheat had a good nutty taste.

This place is large. There are 10 stools at the bar, as well as six 4-person tables, one 4-person hightop and four 4-person booths, each lit by a colorful tiffany shade. Lots of wood and warmth.  There's a lovely fireplace and mantle (looks like it came from an old house) in the bar, and the bar itself is beautiful dark wood.

The separate dining room has 11 or 12 4-person booths, and about eight 4-person tables.

While I was dining, a few folks came in and left when they found out only breakfast was available. Monday through Friday there's a $5 hamburger special until 3 p.m. I can't speak to the value or taste there -- just mentioning it.

I chatted a bit with the very personable bartendress, and she indicated they have A LOT of regulars. Most of the folks who came in she knew by name, as did one of the servers!

I was there more than two hours, had a great meal, chatted merrily with bartendress and other patrons and left with a beautiful to-go vessel full of another meal.

We went for "Happy Hour," which really doesn't exist at Tavolo V. But this was the reqeusted venue.

We shared three appetizers:
Roasted cauliflower with lemon, garlic and parmigiano ($7)
Brussels sprouts oven-roasted with cipollini onions, pancetta and shaved parmigiano ($8)
Grilled zucchini with lemon zest, parmigiano and extra virgin olive oil ($6)

All three appetizers were good-tasting, but those crazy brussels sprouts were the hit! I don't like brussels sprouts. If I'd had them like this before, I would have been a fan a long time ago.

The zucchini was sliced into the thinnest of ribbons and displayed beautifully on the plate. But just eating zucchini didn't quite hit the taste meter.

The cauliflower had the additional taste of being roasted, but it wasn't QUITE roasted enough. It was tasty, though.

The three of us split the appetizers and paid for our own beverages. Service was, as always, attentive and ultra-friendly.

I can't say this was our greatest trip. I think "Happy Hour" needs specials.

I've been to Maggiano's for numerous lunches, including two that were group lunches in a private room -- where you get two salads/appetizers, three entrees and two desserts. For these group lunches, the food has always been spectacular and quite varied, with attentive service.

Wednesday, a group of 8 went for a birthday celebration. Our server was efficient, friendly and very knowledgeable of the menu.

Three of our group got the $12.95 order one pasta, and the chef throws in another that they pack up for you to take home. There are about 8 pasta dishes available for this special. One got lasagna and spaghetti/meatballs. I don't know what the others got. But overall, I was unimpressed with the pasta offerings for this special.

Another diner and I got soup and salad: Maggiano's chopped salad and chicken-potato soup. Diner next to me got chopped salad and an entree.

When the salads came out, they came out in shifts. First was a chopped salad in a big bowl, which three of us ordered. The woman across from me (we both ordered the soup and sandwich) got THAT chopped salad. Then two other chopped salads came out -- smaller and on little platters. OOPS!! We were supposed to get the smaller salads. The diner next to me was supposed to get the regular-sized chopped salad.

Our server identified the mistake, asked if diner had eaten the salad (no), then moved it from one diner to another. I thought that was icky! No, she didn't eat it, but maybe she sneezed on it!

The chopped salad was fine, but not as good as I remember it in past visits.

The chicken-potato soup was a cup. It was fine, too.

So, now we're ready for our checks . . . all separate. No problem. But because of the size of our party, they add an 18% gratuity. I had already calculated what I was going to tip, but when I saw that they added 18% already, I left it at that. It was less than what I was going to tip.

I don't cotton to any restaurant automatically adding a gratuity for a large party (usually anything 6 and up). I know most of them do it, but I don't have to like it!

Our birthday celebrant got a lovely dish of ice cream and plenty of crescent shortbread cookies with lemon frosting to pass around.

The office went today for a birthday celebration. We got the $8 lunch buffet.

 The regular foods were there (see previous review).

The soup today was tomato florentine. I didn't taste it.

In the hot section today, I tried all four offerings: mixed vegetables (not like from a frozen bag in the grocery store), vegetable pasta, chicken marsala and baked chicken.

The vegetables were wonderful: carrots, cauliflower, winter squash and zucchini. Nothing overcooked. Nothing undercooked. They must be cooked separately.

The vegetable pasta was rotini, winter squash and broccoli in a tasty tomato sauce.

The chicken marsala had a lovey sauce. The chicken was moist and delicious.

The baked chicken was its regular fabulosity. Fall off the bone but not overcooked and wonderfully moist.

The cold offerings were the same, but I still needed to have some: olives and beets this time.

Pizza available was a pepperoni and a supreme vegetable (black olives, red onion, mushrooms and broccoli). Great offerings.

Wonderful service on beverage refills and removal of plates already spent. It's a buffet for lunch.

And I still want that floor in my kitchen!

Last visit was Thursday, I went on Yelp to check in, and got a 1/2 off appetizer coupon. WHAT A DEAL!!!

I've been back a number of times. We sit in the same rounded booth, and always have fabulous and friendly service.

More lately we've gotten the chicken wings naked with a side of ranch dressing, and they're just absolutely fabulous. Really large, meaty wings with crispy, crunchy crust!

P.S. It was called an appitizer, so somebody needs to learn how to spell-check -- or learn how to spell. BUT kudos for the half-off special!

Went today for a short happy hour. Sat at the bar . . . bartenders extremely friendly and helpful. $2 bottles, $3 16-ounce drafts. And we were gladly provided water that was refilled generously.

My friend didn't know which beer she wanted, so samples were gladly provided until she found one she liked (took three tries). I had my regular.

Split an order of Market Nachos -- steak (choice of chicken, steak, pork or vegetarian) for $7. Quite tasty. Very filling! Two of us couldn't finish the order.

Ambiance is fine. Some pretty loud heavy metal music for a while, then morphed into "Tie a Yellow Ribbon." Didn't quite get the statement.

Lots of TVs, nearly every one tuned to a different station. Take your pick!

The menu aggravates me, though: Wings don't even come with Ranch or Bleu cheese dressing . . . costs $.50 extra. Cheeseburger comes with cheese, natch . . . unless you want feta or Bleu, which costs $.50 extra. Taco doesn't come with sour cream . . . costs $.50 extra.

This is what I call the "Bleu cheese is extra" syndrome. It's boring and chintzy!

I believe this is the oldest Sam's of Sam's in the St. Louis area. And it looks it.

But bargains are down every aisle, especially if you're shopping for a family, including the four-footers. And clerks are friendly and helpful!

I've been in here so many times for the past 30 years, and I've probably bought from most departments, except jewelry and bedding.

My most recent trip was being in the area and needing gas. I hauled in there. Found a pump. Got gas for $3.45.

I was so proud.

Until I pulled out onto Manchester Road and saw the Circle K just down the street was also offering gas for $3.45. Whoops!!

But it's usually cheaper at Sam's. I have to remember to go.

I went yesterday for lunch: "Dining Out for Komen." Three Kings was one of just two restaurants in The Loop donating during lunch. And Three Kings was donating 25%, a very generous contribution. Hats off for that!

The Yelp check-in bonus of 1/2 off an appetizer is still in effect! I think this is the third time I've used it.

So, I got the chicken wings ($9.99, but they were half price) naked with both ranch and bleu cheese dippers. It comes with a couple substantial pieces of celery, which were terrific.

My dining partner got the Beer-Battered Fried Cod Sandwich ($9.99) -- Comes on a French baguette with American cheese, lettuce, tomato, red onion and lemon tartar sauce.

She had her choice of sides: natural cut fries, sweet potato fries, vegetable of the day or small house salad. There were at least three vegetables offered, which was really nice. She chose asparagus.

What a great lunch and fabulous service from Alexis. I took half my wings home for a light dinner. And finished my dining partner's asparagus. Wowee, was that asparagus tasty, seasoned so well and cooked perfectly.

And she liked her fish sandwich.

I've had nothing but spectacular food at Three Kings. And never gotten anything but stellar, friendly, attentive and enthusiastic service.

And if you've got a St. Louis Originals card, be sure to use it to get points on your account. It's a free sign-up, and points accumulate quickly, if you remember to use the card, 'cause nobody ever asks you: http://saintlouisoriginals.com/

Went . . . closer to home . . . for dinner, after having been to the Soulard location numerous times for lunch and enjoyed it thoroughly.

Terribly disappointing related to service (two women, what, you think we won't tip! Or drink enough!) Well, actually, we didn't drink much. Was that part of it?! Very small table.

Slow service, grudging service. Food was not remarkable.

Prices were way above what's going on at the Soulard location. What, you think we've got money trees growing out here?!

At lunchtime, we had a devil of a time finding a parking spot within walking distance. The parking behind all the shops in the strip was overflowing with folks double-parked and blocking others. ICK!

You order as soon as you walk in, so know what you want or don't get in line. Then find a seat. When your order is ready, they call your name, and you pay where you pick up your food.

I got a little paper boat of homemade pickles that were spectacular and supremely crunchy. When we sat down, a guy brought us our own crock of pickles, so I had a bunch more.

We both got the Rachel ($8.50) -- hot pastrami with sauerkraut, homemade Russian dressing and Swiss grilled on rye (It's a Reuben, except with pastrami instead of corned beef.); and fresh iced tea. Beverage refills are available at the counter.

And we both got a little paper boat of sauerkraut (ask at the counter) to add to the sandwich, but I just ate mine as a side.

The sandwich tasted great and was extremely filling. But the bottom piece of bread got really soggy. Was that grease or butter or meat juice? I don't know!

I didn't want to eat the whole sandwich, 'cause I was full, but a carryout wasn't going to travel well at all, so I ate the whole thing. And wasn't hungry for the remainder of the day. Truly, I went to bed without dinner!!

On the way out, I got a carryout pound of corned beef for $10.99, a special price for either corned beef or pastrami when you get it carryout after your meal. That was tasty meat!

The place is well-stocked with all manner of cosmetics, hair care products, grooming basics, plus there's a salon.

Went Saturday and was clearly lost wandering around the store looking for what I needed. Couldn't find it. Walked, walked, wandered, wandered. Nobody offered to help me, until I was about ready to walk out.

As it turned out, I was standing right by the display of the item I needed, so she didn't have to help that much. But I told her exactly what I needed, she retrieved it, and I checked out pronto adding this purchase to my Ulta Club membership.

Customer service at the store in the bottoms is MUCH better!!!

Last Friday we had a work outing (celebrating 11.11.11) that  began at 3 p.m. We consumed the entire joint with our group of 60+.

What a fun place. And little. Eight lanes, auto-scoring (thankfully) -- although we did have a discussion of who learned in high school to score bowling -- EEK!!.

Plenty of music and other messages across the front of the lanes.

Barmistress was cordial, another server/don't really know what his role was -- was much more friendly and smiley.

Lightweight balls were in abundance and well-marked, so that was extremely helpful.

When I got shoes, my size was translated verbally into a male size, so I guess the shoes are unigender.

The food was catered from Blueberry Hill, so I guess it doesn't count for the review. It was OK with plenty of variety. I didn't try lots of things.

We had a glorious time, but I'm not sure if it was due to Pin-Up Bowl or the work crowd!!

New location. I went today to check it out.

It's clean, well-lit and signage is well-viewable. Many sales associates are on the floor. I was greeted upon arrival, and numerous associates asked if I needed assistance.

Everything was all fine and good, until I got to checkout.

A woman was checking out, and asked how to use a particular item she was buying. That wasn't the cashier's fault, but the explanation went on and on.

Then, the cashier decided to do an upsell of some associated item that she would "swear on." And was it a Chatty Cathy sales pitch!

Now, five people were standing in line to check out. I was #2. #1 turned around and looked at me. We shared "The Look." No other cashiers came to operate another register.

I left the line, returned my would-be three purchases to their respective homes, and walked out.

As I walked out, I turned at looked at #1. We were both laughing, and upsell was continuing.

There's nothing wrong with upsell. We can all spot it, and we expect it. BUT PLEASE don't do it at checkout. Do it on the floor.

Office birthday lunch celebration, AND we had a coupon for 20% off our meal that we printed from Ari's website.

You cannot miss this place. It's BLUE inside and out. We were welcomed warmly and seated near the front picture window. The place looks pretty small.

We all got the gyro plate -- an open-faced version of a gyro. The website says that gives you more meal, but I'm not so sure.

Choices of potatoes were fries or Greek potatoes. Two got the Greek potatoes, which were jazzed up with red and yellow peppers, and kalamata olives. I got the fries, which were quite good.

We all enjoyed the open-faced gyro. It was tasty with appropriately proportioned ingredients. The pita was cut into triangles, so you could use it as a scoop. That worked quite well.

The birthday girl got a surprise dessert: Galaktobureko -- a lemon custard pie with phyllo dough crust drizzled with honey. Man, was that piece of pie huge!! And she said it was good.

Service was extremely attentive, albeit a bit slow, but I think it was the kitchen that was the hold-up.

~ 1 p.m. March 24, Miss C. and I arrived for a light lunch.

Our server was friendly and served water right away.

We shared:
Pate Plate ($11.99) -- Goose liver pâté with truffles served with crostinis dried cranberries, apricots and cornichons

Brie Plate ($11.99) -- Served with crostinis, dried fruit and nuts

Both plates were good, and the combos with each were rather impeccable. I'd say somebody put some exemplary thought into what morsels would best accompany each plate.

I took home some of both plates, which served as an even lighter dinner.

Miss C. and I ventured here for a libation after lunch November 9.

GEAR UP YOUR OLFACTORIES . . . the smell of fresh-popped popcorn will overcome you. It's divine.

But we refrained, as we'd just had lunch.

Miss C. knew exactly what tap she wanted. I was unsure. She said her choice was kinda hoppy. I've had kinda hoppy and thought that would be OK, but asked for a taste.

The bartendress was more than happy to give me a taste. Um . . . just a little too hoppy for me.

She suggested something with an undertone of citrus. And that worked.

We sat at the bar for a while, then ventured outside through the big game room to a quite large and lovely patio privately fenced. Tables, chairs -- a great place to commune in good weather. But it was a cold day, so we didn't stay outside long.

And as soon as you walk back in, there it is . . . the smell of fresh-popped popcorn luring you. Again, we refrained.

Nice people, good people. Great service. I'm gonna get that popcorn!

The office went again, sans the vegetarian. We all got the strip steak . . . lucious steak, a little fatty on the outer rims, but isn't that what gives it flavor? The outside grill crustiness was divine, and the steaks were all done beautifully medium rare!!

Salads were great . . .various dressings: creamy Italian, bleu cheese and the Biggie's White French (similar to Thousand Island).

Sides: baked potato with sour cream was a massive missile of carbs, which he loved; I got lots of broccoli perfectly cooked, can't remember the other diner's side.

I got a to-go vessel of the fried chicken dinner: $10 for half a chicken, and I got two sides instead of a side and a salad -- at the recommendation of our server. Evidently, Thursday and Sunday are fried chicken days! And I had that lovely specimen for dinner!!! Sadly, though, it was underseasoned . . . so, while crunchy and juicy, it was rather bland.

Beyond that, I had a wonderful to-go vessel of half of my broccoli and more than half of my steak for another day! That salad was filling. Not to mention the bread!

And I must mention that everybody is so nice here! Greeting you! Happy you're there! Fabulous service! Saying goodbye and come again! It's nice to know your patronage is appreciated!

Had to go for a gyro. When you walk in, the menu is over the ordering window. If I hadn't known they offered gyros, I would have NEVER seen it on the menu. There's so much about the Vienna beef hot dog and other sandwiches.

They have a separate Mediterranean menu off to the side over the chill-case, and no gyro there, either, just dipping sauces. I don't get that. If you're so famous for gyros and other Greek/Mediterranean fare, why not make it more accessible and visible??

There was one single diner, a family of probably six or seven, a single behind me in line and while I was waiting for my takeout, a family of four came in. Pretty hoppin' for Mother's Day, considering the size of the place!

The place is really small -- two one-person hightops and maybe four or five other tables. It's cramped. I would not eat in. No need. Just take it home.

Also got Baba Gannouj for $2.99 (doesn't come with ANY dippers, which I found out when I got home, so I used celery) and a small fries (which some on Yelp had acclaimed), which was a really large bag, seasoning showing on the fries but not on the palette.

And I watched the cook open a bag of frozen crinkle-cut fries and dump them in the fryer. So much for hand-cut fries. That aside, I did eat them all. Boo-hoo on me!

The gyro was spectacularly huge with lots of very tasty meat, onion, tomato, lettuce and tzatziki sauce. I asked for feta to be added -- I just think that goes on a gyro.

I would have liked more tomato and more onion, but everybody has their own taste. It was a really good gyro.

The Baba Gannouj was a large serving presented beautifully with paprika sprinkled atop and sprigs of (I don't know what green thing -- but it was pretty) in the center. Great garlic taste.

The gyro lasted two meals. I still have more than half of the Baba Gannouj in the fridge. A bargain all the way around.

This is a lovely establishment right on the corner of Skinker and Delmar. We got carryout pastries.

Our server at the display case was very attentive and friendly.

There were lots of flavors of cannolis and two flavors of cassata cake (mocha checkerboard and strawberry), cheesecake, cookies, cakes, fruit tarts and many other luscious-looking pastries. Hot and cold beverages, and gelato.

My girlfriend got a piece of sugar-free cheesecake and a piece of the mocha checkerboard cassata cake.

I got three cookies: a chocolate-dipped Italian spritz, a strawberry thumbprint and a shortbread.

All the cookies are $9/pound, so mine were all weighed together and cost $2.50.

On the way out, we snagged a couple samples. One was the mocha checkerboard cassata cake. It was delicious.

My cookies were delicious and not too sweet. Very full of butter and richness.

I cut them in half to make them last longer.

This restaurant is HUGE, spannning four floors, and there's outdoor seating on every level. It's bright and cheery with plenty of windows affording a view of Main Street and the river.

I've never had a club sandwich. Got one today ($9.49), and it was fabulous!

Turkey, ham, prime rib, bacon, Cheddar, Monterey Jack, Swiss, tomato and lettuce on toasted white. I got the mayo on the side. What got me to order this sandwich was the addition of prime rib and three different cheeses!! It was intriguing.

I opted for fries as the side, and they were fabulous crispy, crunchy -- not limp and lame.

The pickle spear was huge, fresh and crunchy dillness!!

My college chum got the same thing, and we both enjoyed a diet cola to go along with lunch.

Now I see why there are toothpicks in this sandwich. It's soooo thick, that's the only way to hold it together. And it's a challenge to get it in the mouth. But it was delicious with such fresh and tasty ingredients!

Service was good and timed well. I had a to-go vessel of half my sandwich and 2/3 of the fries.

There are two things I don't understand about a club sandwich:
Why the extra piece of bread?
Why do these rather mundane ingredients taste so good together?

I bought two Voice Daily Deals for We Do That. Three hours of house-cleaning services. The first Saturday we had scheduled (which was in May), they didn't show up, and I sat around all day waiting for them. Boo-hiss! When I called Monday, they said I wasn't on the schedule.

We rescheduleld for another Saturday (in June). They called three times that morning to confirm the appointment. Why do you have to do that?

Three people came for one hour. They cleaned two floors.

When it was time for them to leave, they told me there was a $15 upcharge for them to come on Saturday, because people "volunteer" to work on Saturday. Surprise!!

Upon inspection, I found dust absolutely everywhere. They didn't even mop the kitchen floor -- just swept it. And they didn't vacuum the steps to the second floor.

With that deceit and poor performance, I chose to not use my second coupon.

So I lost on this one.

And I'll be wary of future coupons related to services. And certainly wouldn't buy two!!

I've used ANCO for 28 years. Not often, thank goodness.

But they've always been reliable, trustworthy and knowledgeable.

I called yesterday, December 1, kinda late in the afternoon. It wasn't an emergency, so I didn't need overnight or weekend service. But they said I could get service Saturday, which is today. Wowee!

The battery in my garage-door opener was depleted and making insipid yet piercing BEEPS. This is continual. It happened before -- in 2012.

This is IN THE GARAGE. I can hear the beeps in the house. You can only go so far with this situation without pulling a Jack Nicholson.

IMO, you need the battery. It's there so you can use your garage door when the electricity's out. I went through this conversation in 2012 with Greg.

Today, Greg came again.

I got a call ~8 a.m. giving me an 11 a.m.-1 p.m. window. Very tight. Very good and very much appreciated.

And Greg called after his previous appointment to say he was on his way.

Greg arrived ~11:15 a.m., and we had the same conversation about the need for the battery. I opted to get a new battery . . . my luck being the electricity would go out tonight right when I want to go to the grocery.

He totally understood and proceeded to replace the battery.

THEN I mentioned how the two light bulbs quit working after a few ups and downs of the garage door. I'm thinking it's vibration that loosens them, and then they don't come on. And Greg confirmed that is the problem.

Greg had tips on this conundrum. He asked me how tightly I tighten them. I said loosely. He said tighten them as tightly as you can. Wear a glove, in case the bulb breaks. THAT'S how tightly to screw in the bulbs.

He took out my bulbs, filed them (to get back down to the core), used a screwdriver in the socket -- yes, electricity was turned off -- to reduce debris and then blew into the sockets to get rid of the detritus.

BINGO!!!!! Both lights worked.

Greg knows of what he speaks.

I got a new battery. I got big tips from Greg re the lightbulbs. $199. Check this one off the list, and I don't have to pull a Jack Nicholson.

Went for brunch -- well, we thought it was brunch, but it was really breakfast.

Nothing exceptional on the menu, except it said "Eggs and Style," for which I brought out my pen and corrected the menu -- and shared the pen with my dining partner to do the same.

Now, I know I can use some additional style, but I didn't think it was coming with breakfast, so I figured it was a typo.

And that's what we both got  . . . Eggs and Style. Comes with breakfast potatoes and toast.

She got scrambled. I got easy over. And that's what I called it. Our server grinned at me slyly. I didn't get it.

So when he left, I asked my dining partner what the deal was, and she said, "You ordered over easy eggs easy over." Dunce. I've never had over easy eggs before (clearly), just thought I'd try them.
