They were good. The toast was hot -- some nice, nutty wheat bread. We were both served our own butter and grape jelly. Both of us just used the butter.

She liked her scrambled eggs. They looked fresh and fluffy.

The potatoes were a medium dice, no crunchies, a few pieces of both red and green pepper. I should have asked for crispy.

Service was absolutely perfect. Breakfast was fine, but at $15 (including tip), it seemed high.

Eau seems to have two restaurants. One for breakfast and dinner. A separate one for lunch. That's the way our server explained it to us. Just a tad confusing.

Miss C., her friend and I went for an after-wedding brunch Sunday, sponsored by friends of the groom. Signage helped us know where to go as soon as we walked into the lobby of the hotel. That was incredibly helpful.

The room was spectacular. The food was great. Fresh fruit (grapes, strawberries, pineapple, cantaloupe, maybe some honeydew), wonderful scrambled eggs that were still moist and topped with parsley and red (roasted red peppers?) so they didn't look so yellow.

Bacon perfectly cooked ultra-crispy yum. Sausage links I didn't try. Waffles I didn't try. Many, many muffins and croissants and Danish I didn't try -- they were all beautiful. Bagels, cream cheese in many varieties.

Grapefruit juice. BINGO!! Orange juice, cranberry juice.

What was so spectacular -- besides the food I got ('cause I got the food in the buffet that I wanted) -- was the service.

Making sure we had coffee and juice at the table, clearing plates, bringing a glass of ice. Filling waters. Checking all the time to ensure we were getting what we wanted and needed. Incredibly polite. Coffee service was important, 'cause I believe we emptied the carafe at the table pretty quickly.

And it was great to talk with more of the wedding guests after such a spectacular event Saturday.

My college chum and I went for lunch the last day of September.

This place is a total workaurant. You order at the counter.

They give you a large, laminated playing deck card. I got the queen of hearts. She got the nine of diamonds. This is totally random and does not reflect the order of the orders. It could just as well have been numbers or Monopoly properties.

We both ordered the same thing: Custom Cobb Salad ($7.50) with turkey (from the Café Salad section). Other protein choices were ham or tuna.

This came in a massive bowl with mixed greens, sliced hard-boiled eggs, tomatoes, avocado slices, black olives and bleu cheese crumbles with their homemade ranch dressing.

This was a tremendous salad with such fresh, abundant ingredients; and they all shone and worked perfectly together.

The dressing was on the side, you could use as much or as little as you desired.

I needed another napkin, so I had to go back up to the now-forming line and interrupt JUST to get another napkin.

When we were finished, I needed a to-go vessel for half of my salad. So again, I went to interrupt the order line to ask for a receptacle.

You have to bus your own table, including separating, utensils from bowls from trash from recyclables. That's a lot of work. I do that at home, and do not expect to have to do that in a restaurant.

Not to mention that if you're separating utensils from a half-eaten bowl of food, that's a pretty icky task to have to perform in a restaurant.

I would suggest their business model is just a tad flawed, especially considering there were only three people working, including managing the drive-through. And they were interrupted two times by me for a napkin and a to-go vessel, which they easily could have had out in help-yourself areas.

I don't know about this place. The salad was stupendous. Maybe drive-through is my answer.

A few weeks ago, Dierberg's had the yellow dot sale again. A variety of meats and poultry are packaged and marked with a yellow dot. Each package is $5, regardless of what the label says.

You have to buy three.

I got boneless pork chops, chicken thighs, split chicken breasts, a whole chicken, ground round, beef patties, beef stew meat and pork tenderloin.

Completing my grocery list, I went to checkout (where there was no wait), and saved $89, nearly 42 percent.

I don't know how often Dierberg's has the yellow dot sale, but I'm cashing in on it every time it occurs.

They got this lunch thing DOWN with the blue plate lunch. No menu. Everybody gets the same thing. Just sit down and eat.

I went Wednesday for bacon-wrapped meatloaf with Pappy's BBQ reduction, glazed carrots and mashed potatoes. It comes with salad and iced tea for $10.

I arrived first and was invited to sit anywhere, so I chose a little table for two. Dish towels serve as napkins. There's no decorating in this place, the tables are rather close to each other, and it's a really small place.

Jennifer was our server. She brought water right away. We both got the unsweetened iced tea, which was delicious and refreshing.

The spinach salad was great and accompanied by pickled cucumber, red onion, radish and hard-boiled egg. The dressing was good. It came with a huge cracker thingy that was actually quite tasty with a good crunch.

The meatloaf was rich-tasting meatiness topped with onion straws. Yes, the meatloaf was wrapped in bacon, but I think there were bacon crumbles on top, too.

The carrots were fresh and glazed with honey and butter. Cooked perfectly.

The mashed potatoes had little yummy lumps. I think there was a lot of butter in there.

My dining partner couldn't eat the carrots, because the glaze was too sugary, so I got hers.

And because of that, I needed a to-go vessel for the carrots, a large dollop of potatoes and three bites of meatloaf. It served as a great breakfast the next morning.

One of my sons loves this place, so I get to sample the wares.

Overall, I would say the quesadillas are much more quesadilla and much less filling. I prefer more filling, yet it's all still tasty.

The size of these quesadillas is monumental! I'd say one could serve at least two people!

I've sampled:

The St. Louis ($7.49) -- Parmesan tomato sauce, pepperoni, Italian sausage, provel and Mozzarella cheeses on a tomato-basil tortilla.

The Texas ($7.49) -- Home-made smoky sweet barbeque sauce, red onions, grilled chicken, thick-cut bacon, cheddar and monterey jack cheeses on a flour tortilla.

The Italian ($7.49) --  Parmesan tomato sauce, red onions, red and green peppers, provel and Mozzarella cheeses on a tomato-basil tortilla.

The Parma ($7.49) -- Parmesan tomato sauce, grilled chicken, provel and Mozzarella cheeses on a flour tortilla.

The Bleachers 'Chos ($6.99) are really the king! Yea, I know, it's just nachos. But the four-cheese queso is stupendously fabulous, and I could drink it by the gallon!

Also, as others have said: after 8 p.m., everything's $5.

The office was celebrating a birthday on Monday. We chose THIS Dewey's, because of the  convenience of a parking lot . . . and closeness to the office.

Oh, my, I haven't been here enough. I forgot how divine the Dewey's salads and pizzas are.

With the four of us, we split the "regular" sized salads and split pizzas.

I was on the split of the Harvest salad ($7.95 for the regular): field greens with figs, chopped applewood bacon, roasted pumpkin seeds and boursin cheese with apple cider vinaigrette.

This is a monumental salad and could easily serve three or maybe even four, since you're going to eat pizza, too.

When I was done with my half of the salad, I was stuffed . . . BUT I wasn't letting anything stay on the plate, it was so delicious! The figs were plentiful, bacon, too. Boursin cheese was overall adequate but in proportion, a little skimpy.

On the pizzas: two split the caprese and Hawaiian -- both looked ridiculously fresh and lucious, and were declared delicious.

My pizza partner and I split the 17-inch Bronx Bomber ($20.45): red sauce, Mozzarella, pepperoni, sausage (sliced), mushrooms, onions, green peppers, black olives. Toppings, sauce and crust (good, yeasty dough) were deliriously in perfect proportion, with generous toppings.

This is just divine salad and pizza. Service was top-notch, too!

We got in yesterday, arrived a tad early for lunch and had no trouble getting a table in the front window. I noticed there's no salt or pepper on the tables.

I got grilled cheese ($10) -- Sharp white Cheddar, Fontina, mushrooms, truffle and arugula with homemade chips. Both the sandwich and the chips were a little greasy. Together, it was too much grease for one sitting, so I took more than half of both home.

My dining companion got the cheeseburger ($12) -- Missouri grass-fed beef, roasted garlic aoli, bacon, Cheddar and a fried egg. He subbed a fresh spinach salad for the slde, and asked for no bacon on the cheeseburger. That burger looked fabulous.

Service was great. I wish the water they served was a little chilled; it was tepid.

I had a 10% off coupon to use before the end of the month, so went in yesterday and tried:
red velvet cake
pecan praline
chocolate
cake batter
cookies 'n creme

No toppings. Weighed in at $3.90. And I was so excited about my coupon, I forgot to present my yogoluv membership card to get credit for this purchase. Dang bang!

All the flavors were just delicious, but the pecan praline was a special delight. You could taste pecan, but there were no pieces of pecan in it, so whatever magic they work on this stuff . . . is successful.

The chocolate, too, is especially rich and deep . . . quite a feat, I think, with frozen yogurt.

Went with girlfriends for happy hour in the bar.

They have in the bar (durirng happy hour) one- or two-bite hors d'oeuvres for 75 cents to $2. Marvelous concept!

I had a fried oyster, grilled shrimp with aoli, stuffed mushroom, pork and veal meatball, trout-stuffed red pepper with onion and caper, pickle/olive/cheese skewer, pureed asparagus on bread with crabmeat, mussels, and bacon-wrapped dates with cabreles cheese.

For all of this, it was $7.

They were all fabulously tasteful, and really made a total meal for me. I would, however, omit the pickle/olive/cheese skewer, as they were as-is, not treated in any way. Just disappointing. And the pickle was a mini sweet gerghkin. Rather boring. I'd also give a pass to the pureed asparagus on bread with crabmeat, simply because the menu didn't say pureed (so that texture was an unwelcomed surprise) and the crabmeat was quite sparse.

There are beer specials and drink specials during happy hour, as well -- as one might expect!

It was a great outing with good friends, fabulous food and a great server who helped us through the whole mass of options!

A group of 9 met for lunch August 26. HS friends. We were relegated to a back room with no one around. THAT WAS A GOOD THING. We had our own private room. And we did a lot of laughing and a lot of talking.

Trish was our incredible server, and she had another server at her shoulder. He was always smiling. And he helped a lot.

I made the reservation, specifying that we needed separate checks and that I was paying for the "man of celebration's" meal. I double-clarified both points with Trish. She got it, and she was unfazed. These people have nerves of steel.

It went like clockwork. They got in cadence with our program. We were slow, steady and smooth.

A lot of salads were ordered and enjoyed.

I got a cheeseburger (Cheddar, no bun), double pickles, tomato, lettuce and onion. Southern green beans as a side. I don't know what's so Southern about these green beans. But they were flatter and longer. And bacon was involved. Bingo!

An incredibly juicy medium cheeseburger , , , really good. Beef flavor, tender. I want another one.

Trish took pictures of our group, which are now on Facebook.

I took half my burger home, and I drank 17 glasses of water. Gol, I had to drive home. Come on.

This is really in an old house. The house was built in 1859, and was the first home to be listed on the Chesterfield Historic Register.

You can figure out which room was the family room, the dining room, the sunporch and the kitchen on the first floor. Upstairs are bedrooms and a couple bathrooms that have been repurposed.

One of the bathrooms was full of children's toys, plush animals, pull-toys and the like.

This is folk art, Early American, colonial, Americana -- whatever you want to call it, but you get the idea.

Offerings include scarves, candles (both artificial and real), soaps, quilts, pillows, pottery, linens, placemats, rag rugs and many other soft items.

Some of the real candles had spot-on smells, like oatmeal-raisin cookie, Santa cookie crumbles, lavender, sugar cookie. The soaps smelled fabulous, too: oatmeal, lavender and numerous others.

And they had hogwash soap, which is an all-natural stain-remover. A perfect offering, for being in Hog Hollow.

Lots of furniture.

Earrings and other jewelry that were quite inviting.

Many hand-crafted decorations. Metal works and wood works of pigs, cows and other barnyard animals. Hand-made dolls. American flags everywhere in many varieties and displayed in artwork, on dolls, framed and other permutations.

Many primitive artwork framed originals, some going for upwards of $300.

On the second floor there are three large rooms, including a 10% off sale room. Here, we found Christmas ornaments and decorations (some metal, some cloth), braided rag rugs, lighted branches to create your own wonderland and many other decorative things.

In the kitchen we were generously offered a cappuccino, but we declined, since we'd just had lunch.

The kitchen held beautiful little appetizer forks and spoons; silicon lid covers in many sizes; Wind & Willow soup, dip, salsa, cheeseball and baking mixes; red pepper jelly and green pepper jelly; Texas hot rub; and a colander that works for draining as well as steaming. I was a bit intrigued by that. I believe I was silicon.

A great lot of quality offerings.

My girlfriend and I just had a delightful lunch.

Lunch specials are $9.95, which includes an appetizer, an entrée and a beverage.

Our server was friendly and knowledgeable, and he gave us plenty of time to decide. There were many choices.

She got arancini, spinach ravioli and iced tea. And she ordered a dinner-sized portion of baked cannelloni to take home for dinner.

I got phyllo cigars, chicken madeira and Diet Coke.

Beverage refills were spot-on throughout our meal.

When the appetizers came out, they were fresh out of the fryer -- hot, but not killer hot. The arancini were sitting on a tomato-cheese sauce. The phyllo cigars were served with a tomato-based sauce.

We shared, so I got an arancini, and she got 1-1/2 phyllo cigars. They were both tremendously flavorful and full-bodied. The phyllo cigars were stuffed with dill feta. Besides risotto, the arancini were filled with gorgonzola and steak.

Our entrees were equally impressive, but less eaten. We were both kinda full -- not stuffed, but comfortable.

I took two bites of my tender chicken, which had a tomato and mushroom sauce, and two bites of zucchini (cut on the bias rather thickly to maintain its integrity) beautifully sautéed to the point of lovely browned crispness.

She took two bites of one ravioli, proclaimed it excellent, and we both took home a bunch o' food.

By the time we left, place was pretty filled up . . . just like we were.

Prepare your olfactories for an assault! So much so, I got a sneeze attack. They can't help it. It's a stinky store. You get used to it.

But the wares are astounding. Things I've never seen before. Lip balms, bath bombs, body butter, creams, soap sticks and soap slabs, pumice-type lotions for the hands and feet (probably too gritty for a facial). Many other skin helpers.

All in different fragrances.

And they've got a testing station for the pumice lotion, so you can see how it works on your hands!!

We must remember the skin is our largest organ, so we have to take care of it!

I went for dinner using a Groupon. Met my college chum early evening with a reservation. Denny was our delightful server. He explained the Groupon, i.e., there are three components: appetizer to share, beverages and entrees. So each has a dollar limit. All were generous.

We got the crab beignets (jumbo lump crab and fontina cheese in puff pastry) served with poblano aioli. The beignets were OK. The aioli had too much bite for me and had a taste of bitter horseradish (And I like horseradish.), so I just skipped that aioli. I would not repeat the beignets.

For entrees, my dining partner got the Pappardelle (grilled tenderloin with wild mushrooms in a port wine demi cream with goat cheese and radicchio). She ordered the tenderloin to her cook level and asked for the radicchio on the side.

I got the veal shank (16 ounces in pan juice served on wild mushroom polenta with a side of grilled vegetables).

First of all, I needed to understand what my dining partner ordered. I couldn't even pronounce it. She said it was like beef and noodles. OK, I can work with that.

Crap in a handbag, when those entrees came out, we were both in meat heaven. Such generous portions. Such beautiful food. OK. Got that down. How does it taste?

I've never had a veal shank, just thought it would be time to do that before I get dentures. Sumptuous meat flavor, tender, juicy, delicious. The wild mushroom polenta was underneath absorbing all that rich and tasty pan juice. It was spectacularly creamy with wonderful Earthy mushroom flavor.

The grilled vegetables were winter squash, zucchini, onion and tomatoes. They were so good and fresh, grilled beautifully. Nicely seasoned.

Dining partner's Pappardelle looked absolutely fabulous and enough to serve a third-world country. I don't know what the noodles were (this is listed as a pasta dish), but they were hearty and stood up well to the tenderloin. She loved it!

We also got their crazy bread basket that makes carbs grow on your eyelids. Pretzel rolls!! So irresistible. What we did not eat, I took home.

This was a true dining experience. Very different from the lunch I've had here previously, but circumstances need to be considered.

We both had hefty to-go vessels. And it was a lovely evening of catching up with my college chum and her daughter's up-coming wedding.

I'd repeat this in a New York second.

And, thanks, Denny, for your stupendous service!!

BTW, there are two things now that I've never had in my life, but I had at Frontenac Grill: French Dip and Veal Shank. Should we now be related??!

Needed tags for my 3. Pick them up at check-out, then go to the kiosk to engrave. An interesting laser process, but you're in control all the way. Just have to get used to it.

Also, I needed a  backpack for my rescue dog, who likes to get out ALL THE TIME. He weighs 9 pounds. I'm fenced. Nonetheless, he finds incredible ways to get out.

So I got him a backpack and found the largest squeaky balls that fit into the backpack to give him more girth.

At checkout, the clerk started to take the balls out of the backpack, and I yelled, "No! I just got them to fit!" He got it, and scanned them.

They haven't left the "Outward Hound" backpack since! And Thomas Raymond hasn't gotten out!!! The whole point!

Tonight for dinner. First time at any Pi for dinner. Upon arrival, 6 p.m., told of a 10-minute wait. It was less than that.

I was the only diner who had ever been to pi, so I had a lot of 'splainin' to do! I told all what salads and pies I'd had and how we shared large pies, then left everyone to their own devices.

I got the small blt salad ($6), as did my niece -- Romaine, red onion, banana peppers, bacon, cherry tomatoes, parmesan cheese, with peppercorn ranch dressing. Her husband got the small caprese ($6) -- fresh mozzarella with sliced campari tomatoes and fresh basil, drizzled with EVOO and balsamic vinegar. My sister got the small pi'oneer ($6) -- Romaine, Volpi salami, cherry tomatoes, artichoke hearts and kalamata olives with house-made creamy italian.

EVERYBODY stopped talking to devour these lucious salads. Ryan exclaimed enthusiastically to the freshness of the ingredients in the caprese, and I think he won that salad war. That caprese looked divine!

Katie and Ryan decided on the large deep-dish south side classico ($22) - mozzarella, sausage, mushrooms, green bell peppers and onions. Server asked if they wanted sauce, because the thin-crust doesn't have sauce. This being deep-dish, she suggested sauce. And she recommended the red sauce, so that's how they went. What's interesting is the sauce is ON TOP of the toppings.

My sister and I shared the large thin-crust east loop ($21) - mozzarella, pesto, chicken, mushrooms and onions.

Again, chatting stopped upon pie delivery. Everyone was astounded at the combination of tastes on these pies, including me, since I'd not had the east loop. That pesto was a major flavor success.

Service and delivery were deliriously beautiful, thanks to cheery and helpful Jona.

And diet Dr Pepper was available! Cheers for that!

Parking was situational, but traveling west on Delmar just before the Pageant, I espied a spot on the other side, so pulled an awesome U-ie in the middle of Delmar, stopping traffic just briefly. Then corked my minivan into a parallel spot the size of a VW. Got major props for that from everyone. Yea me!

When we left, the place was packed with waiters . . . and I mean PACKED! Glad we went early.

Lunch on Saturday offers two options: the regular menu or the brunch menu.

Our foursome was seated right away. The place was jumpin'.

Two of our group ordered brunch. Two ordered lunch.

#1 and #2 got the Eggs Your Way ( $7) -- Two eggs cooked your way with breakfast potatoes and a buttered biscuit. One got scrambled. One got over-medium. Both plates looked delicious and a hearty portion.

#3 got Grilled Portobello -- ($9.50) -- With provolone, spinach, roasted garlic-green olive mayo on a wheat bun. Comes with a side of grain blend, but she asked to sub sauteed spinach, and was easily accommodated.

I got the Bratwurst Burger ($12) -- Grilled bratwurst patty, sauerkraut and swiss on a toasted pretzel bun. Comes with potato salad.

I wasn't going to get this until I saw that the bratwurst was a patty. I generally don't care for link things.

This sandwich was totally Reuben-esque and just delightfully tasty. Very good bratwurst flavor. I ditched the bun and knife-and-forked it.

The potato salad (something I usually don't care much for) was equally tasty. It was very well-seasoned and made with new potatoes, which are much more flavorful than white potatoes. There might have been some dill in it, and I'm a fan of that.

Everybody enjoyed their food. Service was good.

It was pretty awkward to split the check four ways, when two were paying with cash and two were using plastic. We had to help on that, because our server couldn't match up the dishes with the money or the plastic. Totally understandable. He didn't know who we were. But it took a while.

And I had a recyclable to-go vessel of another meal: half my burger and half my potato salad.

Wowee!! Didn't know it was there. Right in the stripmall with Book Rack. Opens at 11 a.m.

My dealings with Book Rack completed, I moseyed on down. They've been open as Stoogez since December 2015, per Cassie. It used to be Island Bar.

It's a bar. Themed after The Three Stooges, with a reel playing and sayings everywhere (as in Nyuk), as well as Moe, Larry and Curly statues on display. What fun!

Cassie was the attentive and friendly bartendress. I asked about a particular libation, and got olives with it!

I was the only one there for a while, so we had a lovely conversation. Then others came. And they're regulars. I was the odd man out.

So, I introduced myself to everybody and in so doing, found many connections, lots related to armed services.

Incredibly nice folks behind the bar (Cassie) and in front of the bar, who included me in their conversation, and were regular people.

Nice to find regular, friendly people. And good libations.

I just had all hairs cut two doors down, and it was nearing on 2 p.m. I'd had no breakfast or lunch, and I was salivating.

Nobody in the house, 'cause it was after lunch hour.

Counter guy recommended (since I've never been) a small square pizza. It's an 8x10. That sounded pretty small to me. One topping was allowed (unless you wanted to pay extra, and I didn't), and I chose Italian sausage.

So I got it, with a major beverage, my choosing of Diet Coke.

I sat at a table reading my book, really not too worried about time. I refilled my soda. The pizza came out.
 
It was piping hot right out of the oven. Sizzling, actually. Cut into six pieces. This is kind of a deep dishy kind of pizza.

It was sooo good. I ate two pieces after it got to a temperature that wouldn't burn my mouth.

The Mozz was a-plenty, the Italian sausage was full of fennel.

I took 2/3 of it home for two more meals. The pizza cost $6.

I got a carryout of the family size pizza (16 inches), half sausage and half pepperoni, both sides with extra cheese.

This was a great pizza, good balance of sauce. Generous toppings -- both for the pepperoni and for the sausage. Nice fennel flavor in the sausage. The extra cheese was lucious.

On another carryout trip I got the Chicken Parmesan dinner ($10.99) for my son (they forgot to give me the salad), and the Club Salad ($8.49) for me -- bacon, cheese, tomatoes, grilled chicken, and I asked for them to add black olives.

I loved my salad. But my son didn't like the chicken parmesan sauce. It was a huge serving, and the chicken portion was generous, but there was a lot of spaghetti, so he wouldn't eat it. And the breadstick was too garlicky.

I'd give 4 stars, except for the forgotten salad (Man, that just irks me that I haven't learned YET to check the order before I leave a restaurant.), and the disliked sauce and breadstick.

I've used these guys for 12 years. They're nice folks.

They do great grass-cutting, trimming, edging, and they blow the sidewalks and driveway clean.

I started with them because a neighbor used them, and I thought they could just take care of two lawns in one trip.

And because my back lawn is so steep, I couldn't mow it going up and down, sideways or diagonally.

Prices haven't gone up too much over the years. And they're reasonable.

Also, if it's a dry period and the grass hasn't grown much from one week to the next, I get a pass.

They offer a lot of other services, such as fertilizing, seeding, aerating and all that other lawn stuff.

Lucky me . . . somehow I've always been on the schedule for a Friday mow, so the lawn looks great for the weekend!

My girlfriend and I went for lunch. It was nice to pull into a parking lot instead of battling the hooey going on on Delmar, with many parking meters out of commission.

Service was good. Chips and salsa came out as soon as we arrived. The chips were hot, the salsa was good, and we each got our own bowls for salsa, so double-dipping was allowed. And the salsa was in a little carafe to replenish our own personal supply of salsa.

I got a steak fajita quesadilla ($8.50) -- grilled cheese quesadilla filled with steak, grilled onions, tomatoes and peppers. Served with cold additions of lettuce, guacamole and sour cream.

I added the cold stuff by bites, 'cause I knew I'd be taking home some of this deliciousness.

It was a great dish. Very full-flavored, and everything was cooked perfectly. The lettuce, guac and sour cream made lively additions to each bite.

I forgot what my girlfriend got, but she liked it, and we both took home large to-go vessels, mine lasting two more meals.

Met my college chum for early dinner Friday night. Not too many patrons for the duration of our visit.

Our reception and the service were quite nice throughout. Water refills were always at hand, as was plate-clearing, offering of dessert and delivery of to-go vessels.

We ordered meat samosas for appetizer ($3.95) -- triangular pastry filled with ground beef and spices. Two sauces were served in a condiment caddy -- one green (quite spicy) and one maroon (less spicy).

We selected the samosas for two reasons: description and the order comes with two -- figuring that wouldn't be too much of an appetizer!

These things were huge! Extremely crunchy on the outside and tasty meat/spice soft on the inside. After I tried both sauces, I just ate my samosa naked. It was quite flavorful, and NOT spicy hot.

I would not call the outside a pastry as I know it; I'd call it more like a hush puppy outside (but harder), but not cornmeal like a hush puppy. The menu did not call these deep-fried (as it did for other appetizers), but my guess is they were deep-fried.

Entrees:
Chicken curry ($11.95) -- chicken cooked in tomatoes and spices
Lamb sagwala ($12.95) -- lamb cooked in spinach and herbs

Heat: we were offered a scale of heat beginning with medium, then spicy, very spicy, hot, and on and on.

I opted for medium for the lamb sagwala. She opted for one step above medium for the chicken curry.

She got garlic cheese naan ($4). I got garlic naan ($2.50).

We got a lovely share platter of rice garnished with peas. Great presentation and nice thought to spiffing up the look of a white platter full of white rice.

Our entrees were in individual casserole dishes.

She liked the chicken curry, but said it wasn't as thick as she liked. The taste was fine. But I did notice that it looked a little runny. She loved the garlic cheese naan.

I tried her chicken curry, so I understand about the consistency, but the flavor was delightful, albeit a bit spicy for my palette. But it didn't make me delusional.

The lamb sagwala was spectacular -- thick, lucious, deep flavor, wonderful mixed with some rice, or I could have eaten it by itself.

The garlic naan was the garlickiest I've ever had -- and that's a good thing!

We were both stuffed, and half the food was still sitting on the table. I got it all, since she was eating out all weekend.

So we put our food in the styrofoam containers, wrapped the naan in foil, and I'm trying to open the plastic bag to put it all in. It wasn't happening. The guy who took our orders came by, gently took the plastic bag from my hand, smiled big (which he hadn't done the whole service), and opened that derned think in a New York second. Then he smiled bigger as he put all our containers in the bag and tied it in a knot!!

Yippee!!

I was here this week for lunch. My dining partner was well-greeted by one of the servers. Then I found out she's been there many, many times to enjoy both lunch and dinner.

So, I asked HER for a suggestion from the menu. THE BURGER!

Works for me. We both ordered the steak burger ($9) -- Stuffed with gorgonzola, arugula and balsamic onions. I believe it was a brioche bun.

You could get THE BURGER with fries or a salad. I chose salad. She chose fries.

We opted for a booth, which are so delightful and private. They're totally enclosed on three sides. You slide in, and you're in your own world.

Back to THE BURGER. Quite rare. (They didn't ask about how you wanted it cooked, but I think that's because it's steak.) Full of flavor, really a nice, rich beef taste. I should have ditched the bun. I didn't see the arugula, but the gorgonzola and onions were in perfect proportion with the beef.

The challenge with this rare of a burger is the bun gets soaked with juices when you put any pressure on the sandwich. And you DO have to squash it a bit to get it to fit into your mouth. Or just to cut it. That's when the bun gets in the way and becomes superfluous.

The menu didn't say how big THE BURGER is, but I'd suggest it was into hefty ouncedom.

The salad. Torn romaine (not massive leaves that required cutting), Kalamata olives (sans pits), tomato and cucumber (no seeds) pieces, red onion, and feta. Italian (light?) dressing. So flavorful. So good. I could have eaten a platter of this salad. It was delightful!

The fries. I tried a few of my dining partner's. Flavorful, battered (?), seasoned with something lucious (I'd guess paprika from the look and the taste). They were fabulous and cooked just right -- plenty crispy on the outside, soft and fluffy on the inside.

I took half my burger back to the office and had it as a snack late in the afternoon. As such, it became my dinner.

Service was lovely. We were never wanting for water refills.

I like this place . . . the food, the ambiance, the service, the happy greeting when you walk in the door and the parking lot.

I went to the Weavers' Guild annual sale, where gorgeous handmade wares of all kinds are available. Clothing, scarves, hats, jewelry, raw materials to do your own crafting, Christmas ornaments, bookmarks, potholders, placemats, table runners, decorations of all kinds and more.

There were some weaving demonstrations that were informative and fun to watch.

It's always a great two-day sale usually the end of October or early November. Unique wares and great gifts!

Friday with the office cohorts, like 100 of them. We were in a separate dining room that had two-person booths, four-person booths and tables of six. This wasn't set up for the group . . . it was just a separate room they reserved for us.

It was a buffet.

First up -- salad. Greens of all sorts (I think some of these things are growing in my front yard.) with three dressings that weren't labeled

Second up -- grilled vegetables  . . . broccoli, red peppers, zucchini and yellow squash

Third up -- garlic mashed potatoes

Fourth up -- chicken in white sauce with capers (sparingly IMO)

Fifth up -- penne pasta with sundried tomatoes and little-bitty shrimp

Water glasses at the table. Rolls and butter (margarine, really) at the table.

Beverages offered. I got iced tea. It was colored water -- no taste. Neither water nor iced tea were ever refilled.

Everything came with a straw in it . . . what's with that? I don't like straws. Usually they're optional.

The food:

salad was fine (I still don't know what dressing I put on the greens.)

grilled vegetables were fine

garlic mashed potatoes were good

chicken was tasteless and kinda mushy, some edges were dry and hard; sauce was tasteless; capers were AWOL -- I didn't actually see them until I sat down and INVESTIGATED my food; yeah, they were there, but very sparingly

didn't eat the penne pasta

After so much non-refilling of beverages . . .  water or iced tea . . . it was time to leave. I was so parched, I needed something to drink.

Oh what  . . . on the way out  --  there are desserts?!?!? Who said that? On the buffet table, there were  now chocolate chip cookies and half-brownies.

These should have been served around or something. Nobody knew they were there. I did not partake, as I was on my way out.

My girlfriend and I had lunch August 1. There is a small private lot. And even though the restaurant address is Wydown Boulevard, it faces Westwood Drive, and we turned onto Westwood to access the private lot.

We were the sole diners for a while. James was our attentive and informative server.

There was a chalkboard of (I presume) specials, so we were eyeing that and the menu simultaneously.

We both started with the House Italian salad ($9). It was a good mix of greens, Italian peppers, mozz and a single black olive (with a pit -- just watch out). The house dressing was just perfect for this fresh combo. We were pacing ourselves, so we both had half our salad packaged to take home.

I then had the Italian Divorce Soup ($8) (a special) -- a rich chicken broth with orzo, seasonings and a tukey/chicken meatball, which was huge. Is it similar to Italian Wedding Soup? Don't know. Never had it. But it was tasty, and the meatball was flavorful and juicy. I had half of that packaged to take home.

James was really rollin' with us here, considering what we were ordering.

For entrée, my girlfriend ordered the spaghetti and meatballs. Again, one huge meatball. She chose a beef meatball, which was made with bread crumbs and cheese. Gol, that girl is a masterful spaghetti twirler. This is not a dish I would eat in public. AND, she had the gall to wear a white shirt -- which came out pristine. DANG!

She cut a little piece of meatball to go with every twirl of spaghetti, and enjoyed it immensely. The sauce was tomato-based and well-seasoned.

My entrée was wild mushroom ravioli ($10), served in a shallow bowl (a special). The pasta was in a tomato broth with plentiful mushrooms. The raviolis were large, round and beautifully filled. Everything blended into such tasty bites.

To take home (for dinner), my girlfriend ordered chicken cacciatore (a special), which (she reported) was fabulous.

I ordered, to take home, shrimp alfredo ($24) (a special) -- which was four beautiful, large prawns (tail on) lightly breaded and perfectly cooked to be succulent and tender. The alfredo was a rich cream sauce tossed with wide noodles. It was spectacularly delicious. I cut the tails off, then cut the prawns into bite-sized pieces so as to get some prawn with each forkful of pasta.

She got at least 3 or 4 meals in her to-go vessels. I'd say I had 7 or 8.

It was all spectacular food oh-so thoughtfully composed and prepared.

The place is maybe 10 tables. The look veers to the industrial. It works.

As we were hauling our booty (in large bags) out of the restaurant, a couple guys came out from the kitchen. We had a friendly chat. I'm sure one of them was the masterful head chef.

Got more tastings tonight, as son-who-loves-quesadillas is home for spring break.

The St. Louis ($7.49) -- Parmesan tomato sauce, pepperoni, Italian sausage, provel and Mozzarella cheeses on a tomato-basil tortilla. Quite fine and filling. Had a couple bites.

The American ($8.89) -- Tomato tortilla, covered with Parmesan tomato sauce, pepperoni, bacon, sausage, Cheddar jack and provel. There's something just too sweet about this quesadilla. None of the fillings qualify for sweetness, so it must be the tomato tortilla. I do not like this sweet taste.

And again, that four-cheese queso with fresh chips is irresistible and hauntingly addicting!

I did get a salad that I didn't get to eat tonight, since I was tasting the quesadillas, and I can't wait for this one -- dressing's on the side, so it will save until tomorrow lunch: New Orleans ($7.29) -- blackened grilled chicken, pico de gallo, bacon, blue cheese crumbles and blue cheese dressing.

Here we go for the kicker: The Global Quesadilla has declared quesadillas to be Irish -- so on March 17, EVERY quesadilla, salad and wrap is $5 ALL DAY LONG!!

Thanks, Jakki, for your description of the location, or I would have been somewhere else east and on the north side of Olive!

It's four doors down from my dentist and at the other end of the strip mall from my hairdresser  . . . dangerous territory too close to home! Just across Olive from the Heritage Place Dierberg's.

Tried:
chocolate -- lovely deep flavor

birthday cake -- tasted like birthday cake, yellow cake

cheesecake -- tasted like coconut (same thing happened at FroYo)

no-sugar-added strawberry-banana -- mellow strawberry flavor, no banana taste

no-sugar-added blueberry -- blue-blue-berry-berry loveliness

raspberry -- lucious rich flavor

Same $.40/ounce turned out today -- with tax -- $5.15.

Each one of the machines spit out a little bit of liquid before it got to the yogurt. And the yogurt seemed to come out a little too runny.

But by the time I was finished and went for the weighing, it was all solidified into creamy crystalization. (I understand that's an oxymoron.)

I didn't do toppings, but noticed LOTS and LOTS. And they were very well-labeled.

Many toppings were in containers that would preclude droppings all over the serving area or the floor . . . good thinking . . . sprinkles and crushed cookies, etc., were in pour containers, not in open bins where you have to use a plastic spoon to get your topping.

And I'm now a card-carrying member of the Yogoluver Club!

Should get e-mails about special promotions and at some point get discounts on my mega-purchases!

I've been here five brazillion times. It doesn't matter how long the lines are, there's never a long wait to give your order.

Sometimes I think they've got as many servers inside making your concoction as there are customers.

I usually get a small concrete: chocolate-banana or chocolate-strawberry -- gotta get your fruit, doncha know!

But one time I had a banana split for dinner. Man, was that good!!

Six tips:
1. The incredible queso is: cheddar, Monterey jack, Mozzarella and provel. The chips in generous supply have GOT to be home-made, because they're bumpy, all different shapes and soooo fresh-tasting . . . not like grocery-bought or mass-produced tortilla chips.

2. On the St. Louis quesadilla (parmesan tomato sauce, pepperoni, Italian sausage, provel and Mozzarella): sub a regular flour tortilla instead of the tomato-basil. It's a lot better. The tomato-basil has too much sweetness.

3. Get the paper menu if you're picking up or eating in, because it's chockful of coupons.

4. They've got lots of salads.

5. Right now, they've got a French Dip Quesadilla (roast beef, Mozzarella and provel with a side of hot au jus) for $6. Add peppers and onions for 99 cents.

6. For free chips and queso, text GLOBALQ to 686868

I just needed to find the drive-through drop-off, and it took me two go-rounds to figure out it's ONE box in the middle of the parking area.

Some signage would be helpful, as there are cars parked all around the narrow drive-through lane.

At least there's a back way to get to a light for a left turn onto Brentwood.

The office ordered in using 569.DINE for our monthly department meeting.

Using 569.DINE: there is a $10 food minimum and a $5.50 delivery charge. If your order is more than $30, they automatically add a 10% gratuity. You order from restaurants offering this service based on the ZIP code of your delivery destination.

This has been an incredibly reliable service every time we've used it, and it's been nearly a monthly usage for us.

Today's lunch was just for the four of us -- no guests. Two ordered gyros with the Elleniki salad. One orderd tilapia sandwich. One ordered the strawberry salad.

The gyro ($9) was OK. Not too much meat. Lots and lots of iceberg lettuce. Had to eat it with knife and fork, and the pita was hard (toasted?).

The salad ($8) was lots and lots of greens; and little of the tomato, onion, kalamata olives and feta. The Greek dressing was sparse.

The tilapia sandwich was proclaimed OK. The strawberry salad was full of ripe flavorful berries.

Overall, we were all underwhelmed, but I think the strawberry salad was a hit.

College chum and I went again with a Groupon. Somehow, everything wasn't as spectacular as it was for our last dinner. Denny was our server again. He did a splendid job of reviewing the Groupon components: appetizer to share, beverages and entrees.

We opted for the shrimp scampi for appetizer. We were both concerned that the description made it sound like an entire entree with the shrimp sitting on angel hair pasta. Well, as Denny explained, the pasta was a small bed. But it was still too much pasta for us to eat as an appetizer. The shrimp were well-grilled and butterflied nicely. A good, solid taste.

Entrees:
My dining partner got the Papperdelle again, but asked for the goat cheese on the side and ditched the radicchio.

The sauce was a little skimpy and thin. The grilled tenderloin, while cooked to her specifications, was in really big pieces that had to be cut up. I think if you're serving a dish like that, the meat should be in bite-sized pieces.

BUT, when she added the on-the-side goat cheese, the broth thickened up nicely, and she enjoyed it. Aside from having to cut all the pieces of meat. I don't remember it was like this on our last meal.

I got the grilled Alaskan salmon topped with artichoke, sun-dried tomatoes with a red onion and caper relish. The salmon was grilled well, very tasty and moist. The other components were sporadic with more red onion than either sun-dried tomato or capers. I believe I saw (and ate) one little caper.

My dish came with garlic mashed potatoes or spaghetti (olive oil, red or white sauce -- I chose white) and a zucchini-squash-red onion medley. It's really an entire meal for $19. And it's nice that sides are included (two, to boot) with the entree.

The spaghetti white sauce was flavorful, and the vegetable medley was well-seasoned and not over-cooked.

We did get the lovely bread basket of yeasty, doughy pretzel rolls, which were fabulous. I took two home.

We both left with wonderful to-go vessels. Mine's probably a hefty dinner for tomorrow. Hers is probably a nice-portioned lunch, with a nap après.

What I don't get is how the Groupon is apportioned. We were allowed $13 for an appetizer (ours was $12), $7 apiece for two beverages (which we got) and $23 apiece for entrees.

Her entree cost $18. Mine cost $19. That's $37 for an allowance of $46. So we should have had an extra $10 (add $1 for the appetizer differential).

But when we got an extra glass of wine (not both of us) for $7, it didn't balance against the leftover money from the appetizer and entrees.

It did last time. It didn't this time. I don't understand how it works.

My oldest son and I dropped in here today after a "healthy" Lancia frozen yogurt to watch the Derby.

We both had a draft Bud Light, and we split an order of dry rub chicken wings, celery and bleu cheese dressing on the side.

Quite fine tasting wings. The celery and bleu cheese dressing were lovely.

The beer was cold.

As was the reception.

I met a girlfriend for dinner. I arrived first, and was seated right away. Paul C. was our server.

I had a card for a free appetizer, but it had expired. I asked if they would still honor it. Paul said yes. Good show!

We got beef carpaccio. It was paper-thin sliced meat with capers and mustard aioli. Complemented by nicely dressed field greens. This is an appetizer to share. It was absolutely delicious. My dining partner had never had carpaccio, and she loved it.

We both opted for one of their specials: a 5-ounce fillet with a crab and lobster cake for $26. It came with garlic mashed potatoes, mixed vegetables (broccoli, carrot, red pepper strips and zucchini) and that wonderful parmesan-encrusted tomato that comes with many Brio dishes.

This was a plateful of food. And it was all fabulous. The steak was cooked perfectly (rare to medium-rare). The crab and lobster cake was rich, contained very little filler and sat in a tasty sauce of some type. The potatoes were well-peppered, so they didn't just look like a lump of white on the plate. The vegetables were well-seasoned. And I just love that tomato with its crispy outside and perfectly intact tomato.

The breadbasket at Brio is always inviting with the seeded flatbread triangles and sourdough bread, along with a plate of butter.

Paul was outstanding with his check-ins to ensure all was going well. Waters were refilled any time they got to half-full. And he brought over the dessert offerings. We had to decline.

I had hefty to-go vessels, including the remaining carpaccio, the bread and butter, and half of my meal.

This was stellar from beginning to end.

I go here so often and after work this week was just another trip. But THIS week, Dierberg's has specific meats on special for $5 a package (you have to buy at least 3), no matter what the label says.

So, I set about finding the heaviest packages of ground round, chicken thighs, beef stew meat and boneless pork chops. I saved $31.

The bagging gentleman mentioned that a previous shopper that day got a pork roast for $5 that was labeled $18. Bargains galore!

I must return before this sale is over!

What a lovely restaurant for our office celebration. The adjacent parking lot makes it a breeze to pull right in, instead of having to scout for street parking.

The bar is large with comfortable seating, a nice bar area with televisions and a loft.

We sat in a cozy booth. Service was great and attentive, and our server was quite knowledgeable of the menu items.

The house-made breads and olive oil were tantalizing and were on the verge of filling us up.

We shared an order or arancini: gorgonzola, steak and potato balls served with a roasted tomato marinara ($5) -- it was two large balls . . . lovely and luxurious with a little piece of delicious steak in the middle.

Entrees were: grilled pork chop ($9) and I got the grilled salmon with lemon and capers ($10) . . . I forgot what our other diner got.

The pork chop and the salmon came with a lovely serving of spinach, accompanied by tomato and chunks of garlic. It was delicious. And the salmon was beautifully covered with a generous serving of capers . . . which was wonderful.

After appetizer and salad . . . not to mention the fabulous bread . . . I took more than half of my entree home for another meal. Lucious!

How could you not go again! This time with a 7 p.m. reservation, so not so much rush.

We duplicated the luxurious mushroom and garlic crouquettes, which were still unseemly delicious. And the paella mixta, which was fabulous as well. Added a potato tapas that was immemorable.

Service was impeccable. Attention and interest in what we were wanting to have in both the way of food and experience.

Got some great wine recommendations.

It was glorious!

This is a quick drive-through close to work when dinner is not planned . . . like, when is it ever!?

The drive-through greeters-on-the-speakers are always helpful and cheerful.

I always get the original (not spicy) chicken for the boys. No sides. I'll eat a couple pieces, and it is really good fried chicken.

But they boys declare that Popeye's biscuits beat all. So, the biscuits become the side, the vegetable and the starch.

Last time on the drive-through I added a soda at the window. This is not a good thing to do -- add something at the window. Boy, they just ran with it. Had me pull forward to wait. And I waited a New York second for that soda to come out!

Beautiful!

Parking was ridiculous for the Indie Craft Revolution. I had to park on grass, which is NOT what I wanted to do.

Toured the outside tented booths first. Some pretty tacky stuff. Jewelry not too good-looking. Blocks of homemade soap for $4 . . . whatever.

Inside lots of felt animals, tableclothes, more not good-looking jewelry, some good-looking jewelry (but I wasn't interested), the old lotus blossom bowls in avocado green and burnt orange, stained glass. Lots and lots and lots of stuff.

But I was underwhelmed early. Been before and had better luck.

I'll keep going.

Thanks to Brian M., for this wonderful UYE at a restaurant on the ground floor of a retirement home. Who knew?

The atmosphere is fabulous. Very Chinese (of what I know of it). Warm greetings.

Noah was our server. He's a card. So engaging, so exuberant.

Aaron got a table of crab Rangoon. They were good and served with two sauces: sweet and sour, and hot mustard.

That was perfect for me. I usually mix the two sauces for both crab Rangoon and eggrolls.

For an entrée I got a shrimp-cashew dish that included raw white cabbage and perfectly small diced water chestnuts in a broth, but it could have been a sauce. But it was light. And wonderful.

The cabbage was on the side, so I had to mix it, and it worked.

The shrimp were rather large for this type of dish. Many skimp with a smaller shrimp. These were large, perfectly deveined and perfectly cooked.

Great dinner, great company! Thanks, Aaron, for the crab Rangoon appetizer.

Thanks, Brian M., for organizing this UYE!

I took home a lot of my entrée  . . .  which was good for two more meals. And it was fabulous, 'cause those little small-diced water chestnuts crunch worked so well in heating up in the microwave. And I held the cabbage out so it could still be fresh and crunchy.

What a great place! A group of 12 gathered here to greet a long-time friend while she's in town from Santa Fe for the holidays!

We had great accommodations in the bar with a 5 p.m. reservation. Allison, with whom I'd emailed to make our arrangements, came by to introduce herself, and she was available throughout the evening and checking to see how we were doing. Pat was our fabulous server. Incredible wine and beer selections, including a full bar. And the bartender was serving our group, as well.

I only saw the bar area: a beautiful horseshoe shaped bar with maybe 10 stools and about seven four-seat round bar tables. Exposed brick, lots of woodwork, rustic and casual. Warm and inviting. Holiday-decorated!

We all shared:
Baked Brie ($11.95) -- French brie baked in a puff pastry stuffed with cranberries, orange blossom honey and brown sugar with sea salted pita rounds

Chorizo Sausage Flatbread ($9.95) -- Schubert's chorizo sausage, whole-milk mozzarella cheese, tomato-basil pizza sauce and grated Parmesan

Chicken-Spinach-Feta Flatbread ($10.95) -- Grilled chicken, alfredo sauce, baby spinach, feta, sun-dried tomatoes and grated Parmesan

Mushroom Bruschetta ($8.95) -- Baked artisanal French baguette topped with whipped ricotta and seasonal wild mushrooms sautéed with red wine, and then drizzled with white truffle oil

This food was amazing! The Brie may sound rather goofy, but the sweet with the pucker-making cranberries blended so well!

They took an imprint of everybody's credit card at the beginning, then just kept separate tabs for all. It worked beautifully! Thanks, Allison and The Wine Tap, for making our evening unique, exciting and very special!

Particular reasons for this rating.

We walked in when the kitchen was going to close down in 15 minutes.

We ordered a paella dish that was going to take 25 minutes to make.

We didn't know what we were doing related to small plates, never having been there and coming from a Grizzlies game.

Great wine. Great service. Great accommodations for reorders.

First, we got a bread board of tapenade and soft, deliriously fresh bread. Dang, I made a noise when I ate this. I hope it was a soft and feminine mewl. But this was incredible!! I could bathe in this tapenade! The flavor balance was spot-on, and a perfect beginning to the meal.

The paella was absolutely fabulous with mussels, shrimp, seafood, peas and all accompaniments. Marvelous flavors. Got a bite, and it was a perfect mouthful.

Got a serving of four mushroom and garlic crouquettes that could make you cry. Soooo flavorful and lovely. LOTS of garlic.

Got a serving of four shrimp croquettes that were delightful.

Reordered both croquettes. Had to check if the kitchen was still happenin'. Bingo!! Magic!

Remember what time it is. I'm sure they want to strangle us!

Ordered another glass of wine  . . . let me see if the bar is still open . . . yes, it is.

We were really taking them to task. The patron nobody wants to have.

And then we wanted to take leftovers to-go.

These people and this food were beyond fabulous!

We've decided we'll be back, but not when the kitchen is open for just 15 minutes more.

The food was delirious!

Went for a charity event.

Had trouble finding a 10-pound ball.

Electronic scoring, etc., quite fine. Bowled my usual crappy 135 or thereabouts.

It was a fun and well-organized event. Raffles and all that stuff. I won a bottle of peach schnapps, which I gave away before I left the place.

It's a fine joint. Well-lighted, clean place and clean restrooms. Come on, it's bowling!

Today I got a lunch combo for $5.25. I chose garlic chicken (There are many, many entree choices.), regular rice (Fried rice is also available for no extra charge.) and crab rangoon (Also available are 2 won tons or 1 eggroll.).

This is a small place. Five tables of 4 on both sides up against the walls and four tables of 4 butted together down the middle. Order at the counter.

The crab rangoon was basically sort of acceptable. It got a little wilty from the carryout box and the ride back to the office. Evenso, it wasn't very tasty, and the crab rangoon part was quite small.

The garlic chicken had nice pieces of carrot, zucchini, onion and plenty of chicken. I couldn't taste the garlic much. The sauce was good-tasting. So, this was fine and dandy.

The rice was almost black, and I'm thinking that was from lots of soy sauce. I don't know. It was rather flavorless. But I think rice usually is flavorless. I ditched most of it.

This trip aside, I still want to get that St. Paul sandwich. I haven't had one in YEARS!!

Yesterday for a celebration luncheon. I DID NOT PICK THE PLACE. The requisite four of us.

We had to park 5,000 miles away, because the festival tent was being put up for the celebration of The Repeal of Prohibition. We were met at the front door by 10 port-a-potties (what the plumbing doesn't work?) and a nonpotable water (can't drink it) faucet for handwashing after lavatory duties. EEK!! Not too appetizing.

This time, somehow . . .  I ordered the right things.

I asked our great server Chad about the beer cheese soup vs. the special broccoli and cheese soup. He recommended the latter -- I swear there was chicken in it. Lovely, rich, thick soup with lots of broccoli and great taste. A cup filled me up!

We got a basket of Billy Goat chips with sour cream-onion-horseradish dip to share ($4). Everybody liked the crunchy chips and the beautiful tang of the dip. This was no Lipton's concoction.

#1 got the bacon sandwich ($8) -- Bacon, lettuce and sun-dried tomato aioli served with slaw. She really enjoyed this sandwich, and there was LOTS of bacon on it. The slaw was good, too. She ate half. She also got a small order of macaroni and cheese ($5), which she declared delicious. And took more than half of everything home.

#2 got the tuna reuben ($10) -- Tuna seared rare with honey-wasabi mayo, shredded cabbage and Swiss cheese open -faced on Russian black bread. He enjoyed this, but said it was a stretch to call it a reuben. But he really remarked about the taste of the black bread!

#3 built her own pizza ($11) -- 10-inch Pilsner dough making a beautiful crust topped with mushrooms, sundried tomatoes, house blend cheese and Match (vegetarian sausage with lots of fennel; she gave me a taste, and it tasted exactly like beautifully infused with fennel pork/breakfast sausage!!) She ate maybe two pieces, and took the rest home.

I seemed to be on a carb mission . . . which is totally not my norm. I'm surprised I didn't fall asleep in the car on the way back to the office!

I got a small order of macaroni and cheese, which was absolutely fabulously delicious; and pistachio ravioli ($14) -- Ravioli stuffing of pistachios, sundried tomatoes, goat cheese, roasted garlic and kalamata olives generously covered with a smoked gouda cream sauce and Parmesan cheese. This made me delirious with the perfect combination of flavors of the stuffing  -- the crunch of the pistachios, the creaminess of the goat cheese, the brineyness of the kalamata olives, didn't get much or the tomatoes or garlic -- and the denseness of the ravioli and the richness of the creamy rich sauce. I ate half of one piece. Took the rest home, along with more than half of the macaroni and cheese.

I must say when I ordered the pistachio ravioli, Chad asked if I liked olives . . . since the kalamata olives were the preponderance of the taste. Good call for asking! If you don't LOVE kalamata olives, this dish is not for you.

Our server Chad was generous with checking on food, beverages and clearing plates. It was a small table for all the food I ordered. And he laughed about all the to-go vessels we needed. So friendly and generous! Go, Chad!!

On leaving, our vegetarian dining friend said to me, "Did you notice all your food was the same color?"

I met a couple girlfriends after work last evening. We sat at a high-top in the bar. Got beverages. Julie was our happy server . . . entirely and ever attentive.

One of our threesome was intent on getting something called "Chicken Littles," which are now NOT on the menu --  four sliders of white-meat fried chicken with melted cheese. Comes with lettuce, tomato, white onion and pickles. NOT AVAILABLE!!

Well, our lovely Julie went to ask the chef if this was possible. She was back quickly, saying IT WAS!! So, all three of us ordered Chicken Littles. We also got loaded potato skins and pretzel bites to share.

What a ridiculous feast. Everybody had to-go vessels.

The Chicken Littles ($8.99) came with honey mustard and WARMED barbeque sauce. Two of us asked for Ranch dressing, which was readily provided.

The little sandwiches were absolutely fabulous! The white-meat fried chicken was brimming outside of the bun. And the cheese was beautifully melted. I used the pickles, lettuce, onion and lettuce to complete my Chicken Little. I ate ONE!

Why they aren't on the menu anymore, I will NEVER, NEVER, NEVER know. A couple at the bar asked us what they were. They wanted them, too!!

The loaded potato skins ($7.99) were served with sour cream. Six to the order. We each ate one. Yummy! Really lots of bacon.

The pretzel bites ($6.99) were hot with nice sprinkles of coarse salt and served with a jalapeno cheese dip. This had some heat to it, but not too much. They were great! I don't know how many were in the serving, but they seemed endless!

Happy hour is 3 p.m.-7 p.m. -- quite generous.

And there are Early-Bird specials in the dining room for $8.95.

My to-go vessels were three more meals!

To clarify: This may be the correct address, but it's goofy. This store is at I-270 and Olive.

I've been to Kohl's many, many times. And I always come armed with a coupon and my Kohl's credit card. Sometimes the coupon is 20% off, sometimes it's 30% off. And I head for the sale areas.

This is ONE store where my youngest son can find New Balance shoes for his 4E foot. And jeans, slacks, dress shirts, T-shirts and other apparel.

I've purchased from most departments in this store. It's great for adult clothes, baby clothes, housewares, small appliances, linens, gloves and socks. I've not patronized the jewelry department.

My most recent purchase was for hostess gifts, two from dinnerware and one from glassware. All my purchases were on sale.

#1 was $9.99, a $15 savings

#2 was $13.99, a $21 savings

#3 was $20.99, a $9 savings

With my Kohl's credit card discount and the 30% off coupon, I paid $22.42 and saved $69. I'm ringing that up as a sale.

What I don't like about Kohl's Cash is: When I'm there, I get what I need. If I earn Kohl's Cash, I have nothing else to buy.

I've let some Kohl's Cash lapse (It usually has a pretty quick expiration date -- like within a week.), but I have been "forced" to shop more to use the Kohl's Cash. And that usually ends up as buying something I don't really need or spending more money than I like . . . or both.

Thanks, Sarah S., and Thai Country Café, for another successful International Supper Club outing March 13. It was a large group -- I think about 17.

The table setup was not perfect. They had set aside two large rectangular tables, so we really didn't all eat together.

I got potstickers for an appetizer. Shared. Dang, they were good. The sauce was a little sweeter than what I usually have, but it worked just fine.

Charleen and Ben shared their chicken satay. That peanut sauce was just so fabulous to set off the chicken. Who knew?

Denzel shared his spring rolls. He didn't like them, so he shared them with everybody. I didn't partake.

I got Tom Yum Soup for my entrée. It had some spice to it (that you could see), but, dang, it was really, really good. I'd get that again in a New York second.

It's always fun to get together with Yelpers. Everybody's from a different place, a different scope and experiences.

Paul K. is right. As usual, Sarah S. sets it all up. All we have to do is walk in, sit down and have a great meal.

I took home half of my Tom Yum Soup, which served as a great lunch the next day.

We went for lunch. I didn't even know this place was here . . . it's been here 10 years. Oh, well -- I know now, AND they've got private parking!! Score in Clayton!!

We got a table for four, with just two of us . . . something I do so appreciate. We had our coats, our purses, all of which had their own ZIP codes! Good room.

This is a white linen place, although I did notice a more casual seating of tables in the bar area.

There were a lot of businessmen lunching here. And two large groups in private rooms.

We got water and just stuck with that. Then the bread with black olive tapenade. Absolutely divine. The Italian bread was toasted just right with perfect crunch. The tapenade was oh so tasty!

My dining partner has been here numerous times, so I asked her for a recommendation. She absolutely adores the chicken parmesan, and she recommended the lobster ravioli.

The chicken parmesan was a large piece of chicken perfectly topped with tomato sauce and cheese, then broiled. It came with a couple large potato wedges (grilled?) and a vegetable combination of green beans and carrots. It looked delicious!

I did get the lobster ravioli, and it was really good. Triangle-shaped raviolis in a rich brandy creme sauce. There were some peas and other vegetable additions, such as onion, artichoke and tomato. Plentiful serving.

We both had to-go vessels.

Service was attentive. Waters filled before they were empty.

I've never had a bad experience in this license office.

Yes, sometimes a wait, but it's probably because of the time of month I go. Or the time of day.

They still take numbers here. But they're separated by plate renewal and driver's license.

The clerks are friendly and very knowledgeable of the transaction needed. They ask for the appropriate paperwork and as long as you've got everything in hand, your business needs will be realized within a few minutes.

Today I went in with my novel, ready for a sit. Before I read an entire page, my number was called.

Business was transacted in less than a minute . . . with a smile on both sides.

I barely had time to cram my book back into my purse.

I didn't know exactly what I needed today, so I went in instead of using the drive-through. Everybody inside, from the cashier to the guy packing up my order, was friendly and accommodating.

My son likes the boneless pieces, but I didn't know they are called tenders. So I got him two 5-piece chicken-only meals. I got an 8-piece chicken-only meal, thinking it will last a few meals.

And six biscuits for my son.

As he was packing my chicken, he said they were out of wings, and could I accept thighs. ABSOLUTELY!! So, I got better pieces, IMO.

And now that I'm learning to check the order before leaving, I found only chicken and no biscuits. So, he packed those of up for this hefty bag o' clucks, and I was on my way.

This was entirely too much food. My son can only eat three tenders and two biscuits. Leftovers don't appeal to him.

I ate two pieces of chicken and was stuffed. It was crispy, moist and flavorful chicken.

I'll get a lot less next time.

My son sponsored a church youth group Super Bowl party at our house.

He ordered online well ahead of time. Asked for the delivery to be at 5 p.m.

Right at 5 p.m. eight perfect pizzas were delivered piping hot for a hungry group of teen-agers.

This was so painless, delivery was spot-on and the kids loved the pizza. I had a little, myself, and it was fine and dandy.

Girlfriends for happy hour in the bar tonight. Happy hour goes until 7 p.m. Don't look at the online happy hour menu; it's out of date.

I understand there's a new chef at Modesto: http://blogs.riverfronttimes.com/gutcheck/2012/03/modestos_new_chef_selects_spri.php

There was a mandarin orange sangria special. Not being one for sweet drinks, I asked for a taste. Perfectly accommodated. It was fine and dandy, so I got one.

Other dining partners got the same sangria and a mellow cab.

Our server was fabulous, and water was replenished perfectly!

For food: At happy hour in the bar (ONLY) there are one- or two-bite hors d'oeuvres for 75 cents to $2. We had from the happy hour menu:

grilled shrimp with aoli (perfect)

mussel that had a fabulous lemon-infused breading (I had two; could have had 10)

chicken liver mousse on a toasted baguette (fabulous; I had two)

chickpea puree with Manchego cheese on a toasted baguette (I'd pass on this next time)

bleu-cheese-stuffed Gordal olive (It was hot -- temperature-wise, and I wasn't expecting that; not desirable)

chorizo corn dogs (I didn't try)

Sadly, gone from the happy menu were the stuffed mushrooms, pork and veal meatballs, trout-stuffed red peppers with onion and caper, and bacon-wrapped dates with cabreles cheese.

From the regular menu we got:
Flamenquines de Lomo de Res: grilled beef tenderloin rolls with mushrooms (three to the serving)  $9 -- addicting

lovely ensalada mixta: red onion, almonds, Manchego cheese and fried garlic with sherry vinaigrette (we got the dressing on the side) -- $7 --  that was huge even for three people on a beautiful triangle plate (I could have put it in my purse.)

Papas Rellenas: potato croquettes stuffed with Cabrales cheese, almonds and olives -- $6 -- I'd pass on those next time

We each had one drink, and our total for the three was $67. I guess we ate a lot of food. I was stuffed.

The office for lunch today. Opted out of the lovely Branica salad for minestrone soup. Not the best choice.

The soup had lots of nice vegetables -- zucchini, yellow squash, celery, onion (?) and corn (didn't know there was corn in minestrone soup) -- but the broth was rather lacking in flavor and was clear. No tomato base anywhere.

Entrees were much more successful:
#1 got large spinach salad and subbed Mozzarella for the gorgonzola -- $7.95 -- and a side of roasted vegetables (zucchini and yellow squash with fresh tomato).

#2 got the Branica salad (mixed greens, tomato, onion and Mozzarella with house vinaigrette) -- $3.95 -- and Fettucine Genovesi (sun-dried tomatoes, mushrooms and pinenuts in cream sauce) -- $7.75. The portion was huge. He said he thought maybe they gave him more 'cause he's a tall man.

#3 got the minestrone soup (we critiqued the soup together, and both agreed) and Grigliata Biblico (breaded tilapia topped with tomato tapenade), served with the roasted vegetables and roasted potatoes -- $9.95.

I got the chicken special (chicken topped with three kinds of mushrooms and pinenuts in a lovely, deep mushroom sauce), served with the roasted vegetables and roasted potatoes. Delightful!

I got a little taste of the tilapia, and the fish was moist and flaky. That tomato tapenade was so flavorful with stuffed green olive slices and lovely, briny capers!!

Not many diners, but our service was painfully slow. We just had to wait far too long to order, then progress through the meal to the check to the running of the check. We were there 90 minutes. Our server was extremely soft-spoken. Waters were replenished diligently, but iced tea and soda were not.

The office went for a celebration lunch. The place is all black and red with Sinatra pictures everywhere. There's a glitzy bar in the back with mirrors, rather gawdy. And the bar in front is the longest bar I've ever seen with stools on both sides. It could seat an army.

The menu offers apps, soup, salads, pizza, sandwiches, pasta, salmon, fish tacos, chicken parmagiana. A rather eclectic menu.

Two of us ordered Diet Coke, and our server didn't tell us they carry Pepsi products. Well, it was OK with me, but the other person detests Diet Pepsi, so her beverage had to be changed out.

We got a basket of rolls (We had to ask for the rolls, after we saw other tables getting rolls.), and they were absolutely fantastic. There were yeasty, hot pretzel rolls topped with pretzel salt; and hot, herb rolls -- served with REAL butter.

Two of our group got the Buffalo Chicken Sandwich ($9) -- battered chicken breast, hot sauce, ranch, lettuce and tomato on brioche. They both chose fries as the side. This was A LOT of food! The chicken breast was huge, and the breading was also buffaloed, but not too heavily.

I got the French Dip ($9) -- roast beef covered with four-cheese gratin on French bread with au jus.

I've never had a French Dip before, and this was tasty. Still, I don't quite get why you would want to put bread in juice and sog it all up. But I did it, and the juice was good! The four-cheese gratin didn't add any flavor.

I got cottage cheese as my side, but couldn't help myself and ordered fries, too. Our server described them so beautifully.

The fries were homemade, skin-on and crispy. They were so dark, they almost looked overcooked, but they were perfect! Yum!

Nobody needs that much starch in one meal, but those rolls were so amazing, we just sat there and ate them all!

Then we ate our sandwiches and fries, and rolled back to work.

Two of us had hefty to-go vessels.

Another working lunch for five of us using 569.DINE.

Having learned from our last order, everybody mixed it up with different orders.

#1 got the tomato and feta salad ($7.25) -- tomatoes, feta, Kalamata olives with basil vinaigrette. Everything was separated in the container, which was helpful for her, because she gave me all the Kalamata olives and half of the feta. The proportions were skewed to the feta and away from the tomatoes. She left the meeting hungry!

#2 got eggplant parmesan sandwich. He enjoyed, but could only eat half.

#3 and I got the same thing: traditional gyro salad ($9) -- but from previous experience, we both added: tzatziki, feta and lamb . . . all of which was already on the salad, but in skimpy supply. Adding those ingredients made for a $19 salad. Hmmm!!

Yeah, it was good, PLUS I got the extra feta and Kalamata olives from #1. So, my salad was hefty and lasted two meals.

But why do you have to do that to get a good salad??

The office ordered in using 569.DINE, and delivery was, as usual, beautiful!

There were six of us, so I lost track of what everybody got.

I opted for a different salad this time: the Fagioli (I thought that was soup!) -- cannellini beans, red onions, cherry tomatoes and egg slices ($4.95).

Holy cow. I ate it first, and couldn't eat another thing! It was filling, delicious and a wonderful forkful of surprises every time. Who would have thought this mixture of "stuff" would have made this wonderful salad.

My entree (which had to wait for the next day) was the Grigliata Biblico -- sicilian lightly breaded tilapia topped with tomato tapenade. It was spectacular, even waiting 24 hours. Heated up well in the microwave . . . perhaps a little breading suffering, but the taste was incredible!

Yum!!

I'm stocking up for weekend guests and need lots of deli stuff. My cart was pretty well full by the time I stepped up with my number. I asked recommendations for roast beef, so she gave me samples of two different roast beefs. I selected one.

On to ham -- samples. I was only really considering one, but I got a large sample to make sure that was the ham I wanted.

Then on to the turkey and chicken --  samples and more samples. Of many differentials.

Then on to cheeses -- sampled provolone, colby, mild Cheddar and Swiss. Made two selections.

I have NEVER had so many samples offered, and she really insisted on providing them to be sure I would be happy with my purchases. She was just delightful!!

And I had lunch!

Yesterday for an office birthday celebration. The celebrant gets to choose the restaurant, so we found ourselves again at Dewey's. I think the office is PIZZA CRAZY!

The expanded parking lot is a fabulous bonus for this location. We also make sure to arrive at 11:30 a.m., especially today, it being St. Patrick's Day.

Two of us wanted to get the seasonal Harvest salad. Our server suggested we get one big one to split, it being cheaper. When was the last time that happened to you . . . . server suggesting a less expensive way to go?? But he also explained that the large salad is exactly twice the size of the small salad. We didn't know that. (I overheard him telling another table the exact same thing.) So, that was the way we went, and it worked well.

That salad is just amazing. How people think up these flavor combinations is beyond me! The bite of the cheese with the sweet of the figs and the crunch of the toasted pepitos (pumpkin seeds). Other dining partners got the large House salad and the small Greek salad. Both enjoyed immensely.

Now we had a pizza dilemma. Usually four of us split two large pies. Today one wanted to go rogue and get a calzone. So, our vegetarian dining partner got a small pizza with sundried tomatoes and mushrooms, which she loved.

I split a large pie with the other non-calzone dining partner. It was a seasonal special (Tipitutu, that's not it, but something -- I couldn't even pronounce it when ordering -- just said the seasonal pizza). And it's not on the online menu.

This was knockdown ridiculous pizza with proscuitto, bacon and ham, lucious cheese, toasted sesame seeds, roasted red peppers and snappy banana peppers. Whoever dreamed up this pizza is a genius! I could not stop eating it . . . and the crust . . . well, it's Dewey's crust. Nuff said.

The saltiness of the meats combined beautifully with the cheese, smoothness of the roasted red peppers, the acidity of the banana peppers and the nuttiness of the sesame seeds. Killer, killer pie!

Now to the calzone. She got meatballs, diced tomatoes and mushrooms. I guess cheese is already part of the mix. That dang thing could have served three people. The dough used looked like the pizza crust, which was confirmed upon departure, as we stopped by the pizza-making window and watched the tossing and assembly. She really enjoyed that calzone, eating probably 1/4 of it, so had wonderful, tasty leftovers.

So, as we're leaving, we stopped at the pizza-making window. Watching those talented people toss the pizza was mesmerizing. One tosser saw me watching intently, so he threw a little higher and twirled a little faster. Then looked at me smiling, and I gave him a big thumbs-up! What fun!!

April 4, Miss C. and I met for lunch. She ate from the fabulous and generous breadbasket. I looked at it.

Food selection was rather tough, as there were so many tantalizing dishes.

Sarah was our server, and she was quite friendly and at-the-ready with water refills.

Miss C. got penne a la vodka and added grilled chicken ($21.45).

I got a grilled steak salad (medium rare) ($15.95), which included mixed greens, tomatoes, Gorgonzola, crimini mushrooms and spicy pecans with balsamic dressing. There was also a creamy horseradish served on the side, which was a lovely addition.

We both liked our dishes heartily, and both took a lot home. My take-home lasted two more meals.

I was soooo overwhelmed by the options. There are signs covering most of the windows that present the menu -- in a rather unorganized way -- along with signs telling patrons not to come to the window if you don't know what you want to order. Hello to you, too . . . and you want my money??

I sat in my car for 10 hot minutes reading all the menus before going to the window. Then just said screw it! And ordered what I get other places -- a medium hot fudge-strawberry concrete made with frozen yogurt instead of custard.

It was tasty. But not mind-blowing. More than half of it went into the freezer when I got home. When I got it out hours later, it was an inedible crystallized mess. I've never had that happen with a frozen treat.

I don't know why this is listed as a new business. 

I was here February 18, 2011; and March 17, 2011.
