My reviews are not showing in this new listing (nor are the other 56 reviews from the first listing, http://www.yelp.com/biz/deweys-pizza-saint-louis-2#hrid:oe4bUneD6JQ7QiqyIh0MIA/src:self).

So here is the latest, as written on March 18, 2011 (My review from the first visit must be in Yelp Hell.):

Yesterday for an office birthday celebration. The celebrant gets to choose the restaurant, so we found ourselves again at Dewey's. I think the office is PIZZA CRAZY!

The expanded parking lot is a fabulous bonus for this location. We also make sure to arrive at 11:30 a.m., especially today, it being St. Patrick's Day.

Two of us wanted to get the seasonal Harvest salad. Our server suggested we get one big one to split, it being cheaper. This was knockdown ridiculous pizza with proscuitto, bacon and ham, lucious cheese, toasted sesame seeds, roasted red peppers and snappy banana peppers. Whoever dreamed up this pizza is a genius! I could not stop eating it . . . and the crust . . . well, it's Dewey's crust. Nuff said.

The saltiness of the meats combined beautifully with the cheese, smoothness of the roasted red peppers, the acidity of the banana peppers and the nuttiness of the sesame seeds. Killer, killer pie!

So, as we're leaving, we stopped at the pizza-making window. Watching those talented people toss the pizza was mesmerizing. One tosser saw me watching intently, so he threw a little higher and twirled a little faster. Then looked at me smiling, and I gave him a big thumbs-up! What fun!!

I was in here a few months back, and only found one pair of shoes that worked for me . . . somehow many of my shoes wear out at the same time.

A couple weeks ago, I went back during buy-one/get one half off. This was an epic shoe trek that lasted two hours, and I ended up with four lovely pairs of shoes.

Lots of styles from boots to slippers to running shoes, pumps and flats. And there's a pretty substantial sale rack.

There's a "club," too. Accumulate "points" with your purchases and get discounts. Fine and dandy!

Went with girlfriends who like tea. They had some nice samples that prompted purchases.

The guys working here are very nice and personable.

They put together your purchase in the back -- no pre-packaged stuff, except for a few teas at the counter.

Lots of tea helpers, such as pots, sun-tea brewers, cold brewers and other tea-making necessities.

Yesterday for birthday lunch for somebody at the office. Celebrant always gets to choose the destination. THIS WORKED!

Got the NEW harvest salad of mixed greens, figs, boisin cheese, toasted pumpkin seeds (pepitos),  vinagrette dressing. Lovely salad.

Others at the table and enjoyed: house salad and pepperorn ranch salad.

I split a 17-inch -- my side being the Bronx Bomber: red sauce, Mozzarella, pepperoni, sausage, mushrooms, onions, green peppers and black olives. This is alovely  blend of tastes and quite filling (ate two pieces).

Other side being the Wild Mushroom: olive oil, garlic, Mozzarella-fontina, mushrooms, portobello, oyster mushrooms, shitake mushrooms, capers, roasted red peppers.

I tried half a slice of the wild mushroom, and it was incredible. The cheese blend worked fabulously with the mushrooms and capers. The capers were abundant and large. WooHoo! I'll get that next time.

Other dining partners split a caprise: olive oil, garlic, Mozzarella-fontina, fresh basil, roma tomatoes. One opted for sun-dried tomatoes instead of the romas. All declared it delicious.

All our special requests were accommodated with graciousness. Service was WAAAAAAYY lovely.

We were well-hydrated!

Note expanded parking lot makes for easy parking!

Note also: we arrrived at 11:30 a.m. Not much of a crowd. By noon, the place was packed!!

Great store! Fabulous TPRs (temporary price reductions) that aren't advertised.

This place is by work, so I stop often to get a few things.

Most lately I was on a mission to find fish sauce, and Thai red OR green chili paste for a crockpot recipe.

Found both. I was amazed. There's so much ethnic food there, it could make you delirious!

Produce is lovely . . . needed lots of peppers -- red, yellow, orange and green. They had them all! Figure out if the packaged peppers are a better price for you, depending upon which you need. I found the packaged peppers better for me, when the individuals were 2/$4, and a three-pack was $4.59.

And eggplant!

So many ready-to-serve combined fruit dishes, and lots of ready-made dinners. I got a Brie wheel half off. Lovely specialty cheeses and spreads.

The salad bar is lovely and invigorating freshness, and the ready-made soups are wonderful for a quick lunch!

Oh my goodness. The freshness of the produce!! Taking salad for Easter dinner today, so did my shopping yesterday after work.

Got lettuce of all varieties, radishes, cucumber, mushrooms (many choices), cauliflower, broccoli, zucchini, tomatoes (so many varieties), green onions, carrots, celery and salad dressing all within a few feet of each other.

The bakery section is huge with all sorts of decadent offerings. I just needed bagels, but they were fresh and beautiful!

Schnucks brand soda was 8/$2. How do you beat that? A case for $6.

Schnucks diet sparkling waters in all sorts of flavors were 10/$7 in litre size bottles.

It wasn't too crowded, many checkout lines were open. I was in and out quickly!

I wasn't even trying, and I got 16% off my purchases!

I needed a few things, so stopped in here. Couldn't find the sunscreen, so asked a clerk in cosmetics, and she directed me clearly and in a very friendly manner.

Everything I got was on sale. Distilled water was $1.29 for one gallon or 2/$2, so I got two.

Vitamins were buy 1, get the second at 50% off. Cinnamon was $10.99 for one or 2/$13.99, so I got two.

Sunscreen was 30% off.

Even the 20-ounce sodas were $1.79 for one or 2/$3.

Most of the sales were due to the Balance Rewards program. I earned 5,000 points on this visit, which gives me a $5 savings on the next visit.

At checkout, the clerk (the same clerk I talked with in cosmetics) asked me about the Balance Rewards program. I simply put in my number, and she knew who I was and called me by name throughout the rest of the transaction.

Kudos to Walgreen's for training their clerks to ask all patrons if they're a member of the Balance Rewards program. If they didn't remind me, I'd forget.

She was very friendly and efficient in checkout. Before I could get my credit card out, she had completed the transaction and put all my bagged purchases in the cart, so I could get them to the car.

Overall I saved $25.99, a 27% savings.

On the spur, I asked the clerk if there was a post office close. She said, "Yes, just across the street." She pointed, I looked, and saw the flag and sign. She was great. And I got to the post office.

I went today for lunch. After the dentist, after getting my hair cut and colored, and after selling more stuff at Scotsman's.

It's on Olive. Everything else is on Olive.

I ate in. Not something I usually do at a place like this. But it was 2:30 p.m. for lunch, and not much was happening. And I was hungry. And I had my book.

I got The Med Salad with Grilled Chicken ($9.02 with tax) -- Grilled chicken, romaine, mixed greens, tomato, cucumber, red onion, olives, cavatappi pasta, spicy yogurt dressing and feta.

And I asked them to hold on the cavatappi pasta. I don't need or want pasta in a salad.

I know what you're thinking. Go to a pasta joint that even has "noodles" in its name and don't get pasta. Get a salad.

Call me dumb.

The register at which I ordered, the order-taker was checked out of the machine, so he technically could not take my order. He was required to return my money to me, and I had to checkout at another machine with another person. Hmmm.

You need a doctorate degree to figure these new fandangled soda machines when you're only getting water. I stood in front of the machine a long time figuring it out. At least there was no line behind me. I was tempted to get a diet Dr Pepper.

It was a good salad. The olives didn't have pits, the ingredients were fresh, the chicken was plentiful and small-cut. The feta was grand. Tomatoes were fresh. Cucumber was crunchy.

Now that I see that it's a spicy yogurt dressing, I understand from whence the heat emanated. I couldn't figure it out when I was eating it.

It took me 1.5 hours, but I ate the whole thing.

Dinner tonight. We meant to meet at the bar and have dinner there. But the bar was PACKED at 5:30 p.m. And the lights were so dim I could hardly scan the bar guests to see if my dining partner was there. Finally decided not, and went to sit at the bench in front for arrival. Felt like a refugee . . . not one of the hostess persons said anything to me.

When my dining partner arrived, we decided to take a table, since the restaurant was barely inhabited.

We shared calamari appetizer. It was fine, but there were some huge pieces of intact tentacles in it. Is that normal? Never seen that before. I actually had to spit one huge mass of chunky tentacles into my napkin. I was going to choke on the dang thing. Not a pretty way to take it to infinity and beyond!

We both had the biestecca insalata . . . a wedge ($6). It's always divine, and it's really a meal in itself. Dining partner got a flatbread ($13), of which ate one piece. I got chicken milanese ($21). I totally misread the description. The chicken was breaded (which I hate), and it was sitting on a bed of spaghetti (which I hate). I had one bite, and took the rest home. Somebody will eat it.

During dinner, a bug came crawling across the table on my side. I just watched incredulous of this happening. It took a turn on the white tablecloth towards my dining partner's salad. She swatted at it. It kept going. Disappeared somewhere.

It's amazing two women at a table with a bug didn't jump up screaming and make a scene. Brio should have been grateful to us for that. We informed our server Brad of the event. Some manager came over and apologized. Gave each of us a card for a free appetizer upon next visit . . . NEXT VISIT!!!!!

A more restrained sampling this time weighed in at $3.79 with:
chocolate
no-sugar-added strawberry-banana
no-sugar-added blueberry
pomegranate-raspberry
red velvet cake

They were all quite flavorful and freshly tasty!

There was also:
original tart
mango
blueberry acai
birthday cake
vanilla
cheesecake

The same bazillion toppings.

I whipped out my Yogoluv membership card to get my purchase logged onto my account . . . which will add up to savings at some point in the future.

And the cashier gave me a coupon for 10% off that expires July 31.

I like this place . . . a lot. It seems they are selective with the clothing and other merchandise they accept.

The first couple racks of clothing I viewed were full of women's clothing  --  many with the original tags still on the garments.

There is a men's section (much smaller, but still -- offerings, nonetheless).

Plentiful variety in styles and sizes: pants, blouses, sweaters, T-shirts, outerwear, blazers, skirts, dresses, shoes, purses, satchels.

Also china, everyday dinnerware, serving vessels, salt-and-pepper shakers, coffee carafes.

Infant and child clothing and toys.

The prices I checked were incredibly reasonable.

Proceeds are used by NCJW to support their community service projects helping those in need. A valiant effort.

I LOVE this Dierbergs! It's the only store (including all other groceries) where I can find a four-pound container of nonfat plain yogurt (Cascade Fresh is the brand) and a huge bag of fresh frozen blueberries.

I mix a serving of each with a couple packets of sweetener, let it sit for a bit for the flavors to blend and the blueberries to thaw a little, and have my own frozen yogurt.

And I know EXACTLY what's in it!!

The office had a celebratory lunch and were the first patrons in the door. We got our pick of tables, got lunch menus, beverages, then asked for the dinner menu.

There is a bar here. It has six stools, and it's smack-dab in the traffic way for diners coming in or waiting for a table. Probably not the best design.

Josh was our server, and he gave us the low-down on sustainability, butchering your own meat, local farm to table and all.

Our plan was to sample and share some sides/apps, then have entrees.

We shared:
Crab & Risotto Cakes ($11) --  Lump crab, sweet corn, creamy vegetable slaw and grain mustard mayo
Baked Macaroni & Cheese ($5 for the small) -- served in a cute little lidded cast iron casserole dish
Shrimp & Chips ($11) --  Crispy shrimp with shoestring potatoes and remoulade

Entrees were:
Everybody got The Block Burger ($10) -- ordered medium by all and served on a brioche (?) bun with white Cheddar. Two got lettuce, tomato and onion. I got it naked. Came with garlic aoli fries and pickled vegetables.

The Crab & Risotto Cakes were crispy on the outside and soft yumminess on the inside. The vegetable slaw was a ridiculously fabulous complement to the cakes. The taste was creamy and crunchy of cabbage and carrot.

The macaroni and cheese was creamy and used small shells, a nice pasta for this dish, 'cause the insides of the shells hold the sauce.

The Shrimp & Chips was three perfectly cooked large shrimp of grand fresh flavor. The remoulade was quite tasty. The shoestring potatoes were just a garnish for crunch.

The burgers were quite pink inside for medium and brimming with beefy, juicy flavor. No condiments required, although house-made ketchup and mustard were served in beautiful hammered shot glasses. The fries were skinny (like Steak 'n Shake, but not quite that skinny), and the garlic aoli shone through very well.

One of our group had his whole burger fall apart, bun and all. I think it was because he had lettuce and tomato, and condiments on the burger. Probably too much moisture. Not sure that bun could withstand that.

Salt and pepper were on the table in little bowls with itty-bitty spoons. Trying to put this extremely coarse salt (It was like flakes.) on the fries was impossible, 'cause it didn't stick. And one wrong flick of the spoon would put salt on something you didn't want to salt.

There's nothing wrong with "regular" salt and pepper shakers. I think they've worked for a few years now.

This was a whole lot of food. Two of us had to-go vessels (recyclable). I had 3/4 of my burger and half of my fries for another meal.

And the fries warmed up well the next day, which is rather unusual for fries. They're usually a loss when taken home.

Quite a fine lunch, and our sampling plan worked well!

While I appreciate the local flavor of the farmers market and the bottleworks and brewery . . . and the festivals, this is about the food.

I've been at least four times, hoping the food would either get better or grow on me.

Today at lunch (probably around 2:30 p.m.) we were seated right away, and ordered water, because our server came too soon for us to investigate the beer menu.

BTW, our server was great!

When the water arrived, she suggested a pilsner for me. Miss C. ordered an extra-bitter, which I tasted, and it was bitter, but not extra-bitter. The pilsner was a good call and suited me just fine!

We ordered a $4 basket of Billy Goat chips (which neither of us have ever had), which comes with an onion sour cream dip in which I detected a dollop of horseradish . . . quite tasty. The chips were fine . . . just homemade chips. I make them. Very salty. We chomped on them while perusing the menu.

It took a while to get the food.

I got the $8 brie and turkey panini (sourdough bread) that comes with peach jalapeno preserves and slaw. There were no panini grill/press marks on this, and the bread was mismatched, so it didn't eat well. Tried the preserves on the sandwich, and they were a nice addition, yet somehow not required. The spinach would have been a lovely addition had there been enough of it. I'm not a slaw fan, but this was way under-dressed crispy, crunchy purple and green cabbage with carrots. Better than many I've had.

Miss C. got the $5 small cheese pizza. She said it was fine.

All in all, nothing stellar. How many chances do you give a restaurant? For $35 for a lunch for 2?

As a side note, one of my sons has been for lunch, and got the pulled pork sandwich . . . he couldn't eat it.

Evenso, we took plenty of food home. Don't know if it will be consumed.

On a mission Saturday for Redd's ale (strawberry, apple and green apple) for my oldest son: 26 in September -- of age.

Checked in on Yelp before I went into the store. I got a free "something" from the goody box. Nice surprise.

Walked in, no greetings. I was OMO (on my own). Got a cart. Scanned the aisles. Never been here before.

Had any associate been watching new patrons, they would have seen a deer in the headlights.

This place is called wine and spirits. I was seeking ale. Thinkin', gol, maybe they don't have ale or beer.

Every aisle well-labeled with spirit names. And I saw a big wine section.

But I'm there for something else, not to browse.

Finally, at the end of one sort-of center aisle, I saw a Blue Moon logo. I headed there. Nearly making a bee line for that Blue Moon logo. Thinking ale is beer. What do I know?

This aisle is full of mixers, carbonated beverages and sauces. I was on my way to beer.

Luckily, I was perusing the offerings in the aisle, and found what I sought. Redd's  . . . in all flavors I needed. Right there.

So, I get to checkout. Very friendly clerk. She rang up my purchases, and offered a box for the ale.

Then I showed her my Yelp check-in "prize." Baffled. Said she'd only worked there a month. Called another associate up, who gave me a Crown Royal bag with a keychain inside. Oh, whoopee.

Completed my purchase. Associate asked if I was a member of Randall's Club. No, first time here. So, I joined, but had to fill out a form.

I looked at the poor guy behind me in line and apologized. That's so awkward. He was very kind and said it was OK.

Then the associate who gave me the Crown Royal bag with keychain went into the box again to offer me a different prize: a six-pack of wine glass charms, a better prize for me. So we swapped.

I returned the cart into the store, after using a dang forklift to get the box into my car, said forklift being my arms. It seems not all patrons return their carts into the store.

I LOVE THIS STORE!! If I'm cruising an aisle and there's a store person in said aisle, ABSOLUTELY,  they ask if they can help! Incredibly wonderful, helpful and friendly folks who are just stacking the shelves.

I find this an amazing attribute, and I applaud Schnucks for their training.

Self-check-out aisles have expanded exponentially at this location. Kudos for that!!

Last visit was Monday, December 31. I should have known better. It was massively crowded. I zoomed through as much as I could do. AND I ran into a friend! Holy cow!! We chatted for a few minutes in the yogurt aisle, while shoppers careened around us.

I've eaten at Brio many times . . . mostly for lunch. Always had impeccable service: attentive, but not overbearing. Had beef carpaccio that was fabulous, salmon salad that was delicious (with leftovers), steak (don't know what it's called) with a wedge salad (iceberg, bacon, bleu cheese dressing) that was over-the-top tasting and after I ate the wedge, could just taste the steak (and it lasted for two other meals).

Which speaks to economy. I don't necessarily want mongo portions, but if that what is served, I accommodate. And usually I can make something last two more meals. Generally, that gets ridiculous economy for my pocketbook.

To address the noise issue numerous reviewers have mentioned. I don't know for noise. There have never been problems hearing fellow diners. And we've never been cascaded by other diners' conversations.

Tonight I went for dinner, Thursday. No reservation. Seated immediately. Rightly pleasant hostesses -- three at the podium. Ate with two others. We did not get appetizers. Two were drinking alcohol lightly. Service was -- again -- impeccable.

#1 got the penne mediterranean (and got a doggy bag for the leftovers). It looked delicious, and she said it was.

#2 got mushroom ravioli. It looked delicious, and she said it was.

I got the whole roasted chicken ($18). It came with roasted vegetables and crispy potatoes. I opted for a replacement for the starch and was readily accommodated with spinach ( there were many other non-starch options). This bird comes to your table whole with a knife stuck in the backbone, daring you to cut into it. I complied. It was succulent, delicious with crispy skin and juicy. The roasted vegetables were haricot verts, sweet potatoe planks and onions . . . beautiful and tasty. The spinach was baby spinach (I thought it would be like that frozen stuff.) with a hint of garlic and no soupy sauce.

The meal was incredible. And they packed it beautifully for me to take home, as it was served on a dang platter, and I couldn't have eaten all of it if I'd been an NFL linebacker.

Now, to the bread. The crispy (I guess it's called flatbread.) wafers with all the seeds are wonderful. The other bread served is toothsome and yeasty tasting. You ask for more of bread or butter . . . you get it.

Then dessert. The three of us shared a chocolate lava cake (not really sure what it was named) that was a single-serving round little chocolate-frosted cake topped with a scoop of vanilla ice cream and drizzled with chocolate sauce. The serving bowl edges were sprinkled with cocoa, and three beautiful raspberries were strategically positioned around the cake. I am totally not a dessert-eater. This cake was scrumptious. And sharing it with two others took off a little of the decadent splurge.

On a postnote, one of the specials that especially taunted me was an herb-encrusted salmon.

So now the deal is after 8 p.m., everything is $6.

Recently I got the Greek Quesadilla -- Black olives, tomatoes, red onions, pepperoncinis, cucumbers and feta in a tomato tortilla, served with a side of cucumber feta sauce. This was good-tasting with a fine Greek focus.

Sunday, I did even better (after 8 p.m.) with a $6 Greek Salad -- Black olives, tomatoes, red onions, cucumbers and pepperoncinis, covered with feta, served with Greek dressing.

I had them add steak for $1.70, and the salad was divine. It lasted three meals. All the ingredients were generous, especially the feta. The greens were fresh and crisp -- not an iceberg to be found.

So, three meals for $7.70. I don't think I can do that at home and wash the dishes in hot water -- with soap!

And the queso is still grand!

I've been here so many times since my last review. It's become a staple place, since it's close to Ace Hardware and Target.

My most recent visit was for very specific things. (I guess all grocery-shopping trips should include a list.)

I cruised down the aisles, found what I needed, did self check-out, and was on my way. I don't know what you could want that they don't have.

My girlfriend and I went for the Monday $10 fried chicken blue plate lunch.

We arrived at 11:30 a.m., and got a table right away.

The only thing you have to select is sweetened tea or unsweetened tea. This day it was mango tea. I prefer plain iced tea.

The salad was the same as last time, but a little over-dressed. The quick-pickled vegetables (red onion, cucumber, radish) were so good with the greens and hard-boiled egg slices.

My girlfriend couldn't eat much of her salad, because the dressing was too sweet for her. (It's a medical thing, not a taste thing.) So, I took her salad home with me.

The main meal was one huge starch party. Mashed potatoes, fried chicken with gravy on it, and macaroni and cheese.

We each got two pieces of chicken (leg and thigh). The thigh was boneless, so I ate it with knife and fork because of the gravy. The chicken was not particularly seasoned.

I do not believe the gravy added any flavor.

The mashed potatoes were luscious. The macaroni and cheese was OK.

Our waters were not refilled. And we were asked if we wanted iced tea refills. Well, we were sitting there still eating. So, yes, iced tea refill, please, since we're out of water and tea. Why did she have to ask?

I took a little of everything home.

This past Thursday meeting a co-worker. I arrived a little early (15 minutes early, as it turned out), but was given a table nonetheless and was immediately served water and my beverage of choice.

This place is beautifully appointed with a nice half-wall between dining and bar and spunky copper roosters in three sizes sitting on the half-wall.

As opposed to the Kirkwood Pi, there is plenty of room between tables, so servers can really SERVE, and there seems to be more table room. It's just airier and (I think) allows for private conversation.

Further, servers are friendly and act like they're glad you're there . . . unlike the Kirkwood store.

We both got salad and pie.

I got small pi'oneer ($6) - romaine, Volpi salami, cherry tomatoes,
artichoke hearts and kalamata olives with house-made creamy italian. There was something a little off about the romaine, because I didn't get a lot of leafy greenness. Perhaps I got a lot of core or the inner vaguely green leaves. I don't know, but the salad wasn't GREEN. Overall the taste was terrific. With a combination like that, you can't go wrong. The Volpi salami really made it stand out. All toppings were generous, except the artichoke hearts -- maybe 3.

Dining partner got small K2 ($6) -- field greens, beets, clementines, goat cheese and pine nuts with lemon poppyseed vinaigrette. She said it was over-dressed, and actually had a coughing-choking situation (that lasted a couple minutes) from the acidity (?) in the vinaigrette.

Why . . . I don't know, but we each got a large thin-crust pizza.

I got north beach classico ($20) - Mozzarella, sausage, mushrooms, onions and green peppers. It was quite fine, with LOTS of Berkshire pork sausage. The onions were crunchy.

Dining partner got the hill ($21) - Mozzarella, pepperoni, salami, onions, green bell peppers, kalamata olives and banana peppers. She said it was good.

We both enjoyed our pies, eating one piece, and we both left with mongo to-go vessels.

The service was great and beautifully timed so when the pizzas came, salads were finished. And we were kept well-hydrated throughout.

Thanks, Pi. Fix the Kirkwood store!

My girlfriend and I went for lunch Wednesday. We were SO excited that OSFC is NOW open for lunch.

Parking is tough. It's all street, and the street was full. We persevered.

NOTE that the parking lot that is aside of the OSFC building is NOT for OSFC patrons.

This place is difficult to find. It's one little building amidst a bunch of bigger buildings, some of them warehouses.

It was so cold in this place. There are no soft accoutrements to absorb the cold. So we sat on a hard wood booth. I should have stayed in my coat.

We both ordered the three-piece meal with one side ($12). She got mashed potatoes and gravy. I got macaroni and cheese.

You could get a half chicken (which would be four pieces) for an additional $6. I thought that was ridiculous pricing.

We were early but as time went on, the place filled up. That's a good thing for them.

We didn't want to get the $8 biscuit/cornbread/preserves thing, because we would have filled up with that. And that's way too expensive for a starchy appetizer.

The chicken was fabulous. When it came out, it was so hot -- just out of the fryer. So, we both burned ourselves. NOTE TO SELF!

She liked her mashed potatoes and gravy. I liked my macaroni and cheese. It was soooooo creamy and rich. A couple spoonsful kinda did the trick.

We both ate one drumstick.

This is one large chicken. The thighs and breasts were humungous.

We both had major to-go vessels. I took home two pieces of chicken and 2./3 of my macaroni and cheese.

She ordered some additional sides to take home for dinner.

TAKE WARNING: the salt-baked sweet potato comes with marshmallows and candied pecans. Totally not what I thought a salt-baked sweet potato would be. Certainly not something I would want.

They cover the sweet potato with salt. Bake it. Take off the salt. Then add the accoutrements.

My take-home was good for two more meals. The macaroni and cheese heated up well in the microwave.

My youngest son and I were there early for dinner . . . carryouts. We both got a burrito but there are so many ingredient options, each of ours was unique.

You order at the counter, then walk through the line, as they create your order.

I got a flour tortilla, grilled chicken, three-cheese queso, salsa roja (hot), shredded cheese and sour cream.

He got a flour tortilla, grilled chicken, black beans, three-cheese queso, salsa verde (medium) and shredded cheese.

According to the website, mine had 835 calories (64 carbs). His had 905 calories (83 carbs) .

The biggest difference was: mine lasted three meals.

This was quite a tasty and filling burrito. I'm glad I looked at the menu online with all the helpful nutrition information. It also showed all the ingredient options, as I was rather clueless . . .  this being my first time.

My next burrito will be "naked," and I'll add grilled vegetables to chicken, queso, salsa, cheese and sour cream for 585 calories (17 carbs), and it will probably also last three meals.

It's been open 6 days. Used to be Miller's Crossing. In Hog Hollow on Olive. I went in ~2 p.m. today (July 13) for a late lunch.

I was offered a "soft opening" menu, silverware and napkins upon arrival, once I said I was eating at the bar -- taking a lead from Steven B.

Ordered a half-rack of ribs (~$13). Comes with two sides: I got cottage cheese and green beans. Nice that side offerings were more than the standard ho-hum barbeque sides. But they had cole slaw, baked beans, French fries and other standard sides.

It didn't take long (I was reading and not being attentive to time.) for my hot meal to come out. The ribs were hot, the green beans were hot. The cottage cheese was in its own bowl (which was bountiful) and was cold.

YUM food!

The ribs were sauced, but not heavily, and I think they must have been rubbed, too. Quite tasty and really meaty. Also, cut halfway down, so I didn't have to do a whole bunch of yanking and pulling.

The green beans were crunchy and seasoned so well with I-don't-know-what.

The cottage cheese was -- well, it was cottage cheese -- but so good AND cold AND a generous portion.

I had great service and attentiveness from Pam.

I took half of the meal home.

P.S. I went the next day, too. I like it that much.

My college chum and I met for lunch April 11. We took a great amount of time to catch up. Our waiter was patient. And we were mish-moshing on the menu, as there were so many fabulous options.

She got the Spiro's Wrap: grilled chicken, lettuce, tomato, cucumber, onions, feta and tzatziki.

I thought this was going to be a really lame, small wrap thing. Oh, goodness, no!! This thing was HUGE!! And it looked so beautiful!

I got the chicken special ($13), which came with a salad, rice pilaf and vegetables: broasted/roasted chicken. I opted out of the pilaf and got double vegetables. Holy Smokes -- this was half a chicken, beautifully cooked, crispy skin, tender and juicy.

The salad was fabulous and fresh.

The double vegetables were broccoli and carrots, wonderfully cooked and perfectly seasoned.

She took home half of her wrap.

I took home half of my food, and made a lovely dinner of the salad, adding feta and Kalamatas. 

Then had another meal with the chicken and the vegetables.

First time for dinner . . . all my other visits have been for lunch. And as it turns out, lunch is a bargain compared to dinner!

We had a 5:30 p.m. reservation, and I was the first diner in the place. The hostess offered the dining room or the indoor patio. I selected the patio -- with all the festive Christmas decorations around in the four-story courtyard.

I settled in at the nice, roomy table for two, was served water, rolls and butter, and a beverage, and read my book while waiting for my college chum. I did arrive a tad early.

There wasn't too much happening. There was one couple in the dining room, and that was about it for a while.

We both got the Branica salad ($4.50), which is a lucious combination of greens (no iceberg), mozz, halved cherry tomatoes and onion with house vinaigrette. It was a beautiful presentation of a composed salad. And it tasted fabulous.

For entrees, we both got the Tortilloni de Pollo ($14.95) -- Chicken and prosciutto tortelloni in a thick, rich cream sauce with peas and mushrooms. We both asked for extra mushrooms, and there was a upcharge, of which we were not apprised.

The tortilloni was absolutely grand! Sooo rich, neither one of us could even get through half of it.

We had a Groupon for $30 of food (for which I paid $15), but I thought it was still kinda pricey for a pasta dinner.

We both had huge to-go vessels.

Service from Larry was spot-on!

And the rolls were spectacular!!

I've been here probably five or six times, always for lunch. We make our reservation for 11:30 a.m. And EVERY TIME we've been there, the place packs up about mid-meal.

This little jewel is tucked away in the castle (Le Chateau Village) behind the Frontenac Hilton at Clayton and Lindbergh. You got to know it's there, or it's invisible.

Today we sat on the patio. (It's a patio to me, even if it is indoors.) We had the most delightful server who was so relaxed and friendly. She took drink orders, then told us the specials, so we could consider those while studying the menu. WHAT A GREAT IDEA!! I hate it when a server tells you the specials when you've already decided what you're going to order, and I do believe that's the norm.

The rolls, the rolls, the rolls. Fresh, hot, yeasty. Slather on some butter (or eat them naked -- the rolls, silly, not you!), and you've got a feast. Nuff said!

Today I got the red trout special . . . beautifully baked (?), moist skin-on fish with a savory light lemon-caper sauce, roasted potatoes and broccoli with a touch of tomato. A little wedge of lemon brought a bright burst of citrus that was splendid. I started with the small Branica salad ($3.95), a lucious blend of greens with tomato, onion, mozzarella and house-made dressing. One of my dining partners absolutely loves the spinach salad.

I opted for a third course, because our server raved about it: the corn soup. It's fine. But I'm a soup snob. I didn't finish it, didn't even eat half of it -- maybe three or four spoonsful. It wasn't worth the calories. One of my dining partners tried it and declared it also . . . fine.

I took home enough leftovers to serve as my dinner -- so two meals for the price of one.

My dining partners got:
The chicken special -- light chicken meat prepared with a light tomato sauce (with chunks of tomato) and eggplant, with the potatoes and broccoli.
Fettucine Genovesi at $7.75 for the lunch portion -- with sun-dried tomatoes, mushrooms and pine nuts in a rich cream sauce.

Everybody raved about their meals, including our vegetarian dining partner, who had the large spinach salad and an order of broccoli.

On other visits, I've had and thoroughly enjoyed (and always with the small Branica salad):
Veal Al Limone at $9.95 for the lunch portion -- in light lemon sauce, with shitake mushrooms.
Grilled Salmon at $9.95 for the lunch portion --  topped with lemon butter capers.
Chicken Tortellloni at $7.95 for the lunch portion -- in cream sauce with peas and mushrooms.
Pizza Branica at $8.95 -- chicken. gorgonzola, mushrooms and olive.

One time we were seated inside the restaurant, which is (to me) more formal and old-world, but lovely and rich. The patio seems more festive and casual relaxed -- even if it's not really outside. There are awnings, for goodness sake. Get an imagination!! And no having to duck that pesky sun!!

Trattoria Branica is a hidden treasure that's beautifully appointed. We've always had exceptional service, all glasses (whether water or another beverage) heartily attended to, and we've always felt welcomed and appreciated.








,

Been many times. Recently expanded with coffee stuff, huge deli, huge produce section, wide wine selection, great butcher and seafood sections.

But I was on a mission with the weekly circular. Pasta 16-oz. boxes for $1, Stouffer's dinners 5/$10, Progresso soups 4/$5.

Didn't deviate from my well-appointed list and ended up with a 23% savings! Woo-hoo!

I've been here twice for lunch: August 17 with my girlfriend and October 4 with Big Sis.

With my girlfriend, we both got the special of the day: roasted half-chicken with vegetables and rice pilaf.

I opted out of the pilaf and got double vegetables.

This was an amazing meal. The chicken was perfectly roasted, moist, meaty and flavorful, with lemon-caper sauce. Shoot me with a spoon right now.

The vegetables were carrots, onions and broccoli. Beautifully cooked, crispy (which I like) and tasty.

We both ate some, and took home hefty to-go vessels. I added more capers at home.

October 4 with Big Sis, we both got a large Greek salad $9 (mixed lettuce, red onion, tomato, cucumber, kalamata olive and feta).

We both added gyro meat (+$5), and I asked for extra feta and extra kalamatas.

This was just too totally a fabulous salad. Everything was lovely and blended so well together.

Again, hefty to-go vessels. I added more kalamatas and feta at home.

I got three meals from the roasted chicken, and four meals from the Greek salad.

The flavors kept going on with both.

Yeah, I went back. We'll call this BAB (Brio After Bug). Ironically, we got the same table. I guess it's ours now!

I had my card for the free appetizer, so we selected beef carpaccio ($12.95, but FREE for us!) It was luciously tasting so thinly sliced meat with capers and a mustard aioli -- field greens in the middle (a beautiful presentation) on a HUGE platter!!

With that kind of an app, we both forewent salad and went directly to the entree . . . both selecting the chicken under the brick ($19.25), beautifully cooked chicken in a Marsala wine sauce with mashed potatoes and roasted vegetables. I opted to sub out of the mashed potatoes and got two portions of roasted vegetables. They were really roasted and that brought out such sweet vegetable flavor of the carrots, broccoli, red pepper -- and I can't remember the other vegetables.

Our server Derek was fabulous, and quickly got the flow of our dinner . . . slow, slow, slow, and it lasted 4 hours. I've never had a four-hour meal in a restaurant.

We had lovely to-go vessels.

OK, Brio, you've won me back, but no 5 stars . . . I still remember the bug!

I went for a wine-tasting on a Thursday night in early November. There were 10 in attendance, and our table accounted for three.

Two of the three of us arrived early and got a glass of wine, and we were well attended to, but had to cash out our tab before the wine-tasting, which would be appropriate, since the wine-tasting was put on our friend's credit card when she called in the reservations.

The wine-tasting was in the front room -- really a heated and enclosed patio. It got pretty chilly in there at times, and when the overhead heaters kicked in, it got hot.

We tasted eight wines. I'm certainly not a wine expert. This particular wine-tasting was Figure It Out: Is It from California or Is It Not?

I had no idea on any of them, nor did I like many of them.

But every time the server came to our table, he kept wanting to charge her credit card for the wine-tasting. We all thought it had already been done, and we paid her appropriately.

There were not a lot of snacks available, which I would have expected for a high-end wine-tasting. Some grapes, crackers and cubes of cheese.

I was a little put out with this meager offering, so refused to order an appetizer when the tasting was completed. Both my table-mates ordered an appetizer.

My girlfriend and I returned January 11. We were offered to take any table, so we did.

She got a salad and the Roberto pizza: brown butter, EVOO, roasted Sicilian potato, wild mushroom, pecorino, fontina, goat cheese and toasted pistachio breadcrumbs.

She ordered to take home: seafood pasta --  mussels, clams, whitefish in a tomato broth.

I got a salad and the Papperdelle pasta.

To take home: Gemelli pasta.

The house salad is just plain-old good, like ridiculously good: mixed greens, Italian peppers, mozz, olives (with pits).

We both took home half of our salads. It wasn't because we didn't like them. It was because we had to stop eating to have room for the entrees.

Her pizza came out first, and she offered me a piece. Glory, crazy . . . pizza like I've never had before. Crusty-crunchy-flavorful ultra-thin crust. Toppings were such a fabulous blend of the three cheeses with the wild mushrooms and potato, and crazy-ass pistachio breadcrumbs. I'd get that on a carryout in a New York second.

The Papperdelle was perfect -- categorized as a ribbon pasta, it was so thin and wide, it held sauce perfectly. The sauce was a light tomato sauce with roasted red peppers, pistachios and itty-bitty meatballs that tasted so well of fennel. So tasty.

The Gemelli pasta is a wonderful stretched-out corkscrew that holds and retains sauce, which was a meat-thick tomato sauce. It was a wonderfully balanced dish.

We left with lovely to-go vessels. For $51 (without tax or tip), I got 8 glorious meals.

This is a destination. The only thing NOT here is liposuction!

Just needed a few things and was in the neighborhood. While I was wandering around the incredible produce section trying to find what I needed, I noticed a couple having lunch at a bar and having a glass of wine. WOWEE! Wanted that to be me! Not the whole couple. Not the woman. Just the wine!

But the signage throughout the store was quite helpful (especially in produce). There's so much stuff here. Read Nancy's review to get a good bird's eye view of it all! It's amazing!

I did notice a wacky layout (kind of a maze) going from produce to liquor. Produce is straight, liquor is bent. Hmm! Maybe they've caught onto something!

After checking out, I needed to get some rolls of quarters for my new-at-away-college son, who called this morning about laundry needs! Went to the courtesy desk. This woman didn't bat an eye at my request. I imagined her thinking I'm doin' the slots . . . there are STILL quarter slots, aren't there?!

My college chum and I met for lunch February 10. We had a friendly and delightful host escorting us to a table.

And our server was incredibly friendly and knowledgeable of the menu.

ANOTHER thing our server was incredibly good at: Saganaki -- 
Kasseri cheese, breaded and flamed with brandy. WOWEE, was that a tableside extravaganza!! My college chum ordered it, so I declined having any.

I got the chicken special: 1/2 a chicken beautifully cooked with vegetables and potato. I subbed out the potato for double vegetable, which was broccoli.

Service was spectacular. Food was so good. I forgot what my college chum got for her entree. It was some kind of a sandwich.

The attentiveness of the waitstaff, the wonderfulness of the food -- just made a wonderful lunch for us.

And I got two more meals out of my take-home.

I've been here a few times with my girlfriend who does needlepoint. And has a loom.

And I was in here years and years ago to get my daughter a Raggity Ann doll for her birthday. My daughter is now 27.

The new store is larger, brighter and has much more merchandise.

The new, expanded store is full of so many other things. Gifts, probably many for wedding gifts. Cheese, spread platters. Serving plates, bowls. Gorgeous stuff.

Tervis glasses of many dimensions. MIZZOU stuff, KC stuff.

Jewelry, baby gifts, baby clothes, beautiful picture frames, hand-woven rugs. Solmate socks (http://www.socklady.com/index.php), including those for children with an extra sock. Genius!

An exceptional amount of Easter decorations which looked unique to me. So bright and cheery.

I didn't mess around much in the yarn/thread/pattern area of the store, which is probably half of the store. But there's a lot of stuff there.

My girlfriend brought in some embroideries she'd done for Christmas tree ornaments. You can do the needlework, and have them do the finishing. That was her mission.

I think five people came to review and understand her request. To get it right. Because she's particular about what she wants.

This isn't just a store. It's a philanthropic endeavor: http://www.signofthearrow.com/about-us/

Everyone who works there is a volunteer. Started in 1966, it's a community support organization from the St. Louis Alumnae Club of Pi Beta Phi.

A great place to patronize.

Been here many times. Everything has always been superior. The service is attentive, but not overbearing. The lovely owner meanders through the bar and all the dining rooms to inquire of diners' food and service.

There's a fireplace in the old-world bar, where we ate one night when the dining rooms were packed. It worked just fine. Now, when I say we ate in the bar, we didn't eat AT the bar. There's lots of tables in the bar, and we were appropriately seated at a lovely table very close to the fireplace. And there's a fireplace in the main dining room.

To the exquisite food -- dining partners or I have had and thoroughly enjoyed:
Saganaki -- beer-battered and fried Kasseri cheese
Dolma -- lamb-and-beef stuffed grape leaves with cream sauce
Athenian salad -- lettuce, tomatoes, cucumber,  onion, pepper, Feta
Pastichio -- LONG macaroni with ground sirloin, bechamel sauce and Parmesan
Filet -- there are two sizes, but I always go for the 9 oz. -- ahem, the bigger one!
Top sirloin -- 8 oz.
Shrimp and steak santorini -- broiled scampi and a 6 oz. steak
Steak Krasato -- beef medallion with onion, peppers, mushrooms and red wine

We've even been at least twice on New Year's Eve, which is a verboten dining out night in my book. Yet, at Spiro's, New Year's Eve has been a glorious experience, the food quality and entree offerings didn't suffer, and we weren't HURRIED for the next diners.

In the area, I was planning on visiting this Walmart. I was glad to see it was next to Sam's, which I had also planned to visit. I THOUGHT they were close.

I got the groceries I needed, but also found that Walmart's Great Value brand has Greek yogurt. This is not something available at the Walmart near me.

I'll ask the Walmart near me to offer it.

On self-checkout . . . which I do tend to prefer . . . the woman tending the area was friendly. And she held my cart while I used the facilities.

When I came back, she knew who I was, and she released my cart to me. Kind of important, since I'd already paid for my stuff.

The girlfriends went for "Happy Hour," 5 p.m.-7 p.m., featuring $3 select martinis, $3 select wines, $2 select drafts, $1 arancinis balls, $1 phyllo cigars and 1/2 off flatbreads.

That's a pretty decent offering. We were originally aided by the gracious Wil (yes, just one l), then by Janelle, who was stupendous.

A couple of us got a phyllo cigar, which came with a lovely dipping sauce. It was great.

And we split two great-tasting flatbreads, both just $5 and amazing taste combinations:

the Pan D'olive -- chicken, mushroom, olive, gorgonzola and caramlized onions

the Verdura -- asparagus, roasted tomato, peppers, feta and balsamic onion

Everything contributed to a stupendous evening.

But, dang, I forgot to get an arancini!

Needed some last-minute things for Miss C.'s friend during a weekend visit. Marshall's isn't usually the first place you think of for last-minute and NEED TO DELIVER, because the offerings change daily if not more often.

However, we were in the area, so gave it a try.

Saturday, the offerings came through. Swimsuit and four tops. All ridiculously priced way lower than their labels.

I've been here a few other times and left empty-handed. This trip was BINGO!!

Yeah. We went again.

Fabulous server who had wonderful wine recommendations!

We could not stay away from the ridiculous mushroom and garlic crouquettes, which were totally on par with previous visits. So creamy, crunchy and tasty!

Also got the Ensalada de Jamón y Dátiles -- micro greens, dates, pistachios and sherry vinaigrette wrapped in Serrano ham. This was deliriously delicious! Who knew??

Last was the paella, but we got a different one, the Arroz Negro --  
black rice with lobster, calamari and aioli. Black made black with squid ink. It was lovely-tasting, but not as good as the paella mixta, we agreed.

We had wonderful food, wonderful wine, wonderful server and everything was spaced nicely.

And we had a extra glass of wine for dessert!

Spiro's is an experience. In a glorious way!

I was so sad to hear from Harry that their business has declined with the move of 141. It's happened before, with the strip mall a bit south that houses Hot Wok and Dave's World Famous Bar and Restaurant, among other businesses.

This highway move thing just works a bugger on the businesses in the area. And especially for Spiro's, because they're now relatively on a dead-end road. It's not really dead-end, but quite local.

But just a tad south of Olive at what is now called Woods Mill Road and used to be 141. By the Dierberg's Four Seasons.

The International Supper Club selected Spiro's for its monthly repast. What a fun group.

The food was terrific. Service was spectacular. The company was tremendous.

And Harry came by numerous times as the host-with-the-most to see how we were faring.

I got the lovely house salad (Athenian Salad - $4.75 -- Lettuce, tomatoes, cucumbers, onions, Feta cheese) and Veal Piccata - $18.99 -- Veal cutlet sauteed in garlic, white wine and lemon sauce, served with pasta and white cream sauce.

The veal was perfectly cooked, quite tender and very tasty. The pasta was a perfect accompaniment.

Harry came by at the end of our meal to offer ouzo shots and baklava! What great desserts!

Thanks to Sarah S. and Mallory W. for organizing this fabulous dinner.

And thanks to Sarah S. for the artistic chocolates from RJ Chocolatier!

I had a hefty recyclable to-go vessel of more than half of my entrée.

Next stop on the girlfriend Kirkwood Romp yesterday.

After all our shopping in Kirkwood, we came here for lunch. Sustenance time.

#1 got Salade des Betteraves ($8) -- beets, goat cheese, warm bacon, and a fried egg; and Coquilles St. Jacques ($12) -- scallops in cream sauce.

#2 got Supreme Sandwich ($8) -- chicken breast with Provencal relish, goat cheese and pommes frites -- a whole lot of pommes frites

#3 got Salad Niçoise ($12) -- grilled tuna, greens, hard-boiled egg and vegetables -- potatoes, green beans, cherry tomatoes and other. She subbed salmon for the tuna, and it was a massive piece of salmon.

I got Coquilles St. Jacques. Six scallops in the dish. The scallops did not have a good sear. They were just mostly white. I ate two. First one had some grit. Second one had grit in every bite. I could not continue.

#1, who also got Coquilles St. Jacques, didn't run into grit until her sixth scallop, and she said it was only one grit.

I just asked them to take the dish away, and they didn't ask me to pay for it.

Everybody liked their food for the most part. Salad Niçoise was the winner, IMO.

I've had this place bookmarked for ages, so was incredibly disappointed.

Service was impeccable. Water was refilled readily.

This is a story. Walk with me.

My Niece Nurse Amanda in Texas set up an appointment for me to get my first COVID-19 vaccination on this past Monday. My appointment was scheduled for 10 a.m. today -- Wednesday.

This review should actually be about the Walmart Pharmacy, because I did no shopping in the store.

Everything went swell getting across the Missouri River to St. Charles. Then things went awry. Even with Mapquest, I got lost. And when I saw the Missouri River, I knew I was going in the wrong direction.

I turned around, regrouped and drove west. Found Veterans Memorial Parkway, then the Regency Plaza, which was mentioned in Mapquest, but I couldn't find the address.

I'm sitting in the parking lot of a huge amount of stores, and I can't find any addresses.

I drove around for 15 minutes checking addresses.

FINALLY, I figured out somewhere between Popeye's Chicken and Sam's, there must be this address.

HELLO, Walmart. Who knew! I certainly didn't.

This was my address. I went in, registered with the pharmacist. My appointment was acknowledged. I got my vaccination. I sat for 15 minutes reading a book without incident.

The pharmacist was incredibly friendly and knowledgeable throughout the entire process. And there is a process!

And I got a card validating  that I'd had my first COVID-19 vaccination.

Further, with the pharmacist, we scheduled my next vaccination for four weeks out.

My girlfriend and I lunched January 31. We had a 15-minute wait, but it passed quickly.

Hot, lightly salted chips and salsa were delivered right away. They were perfect.

My girlfriend got a Fahita Quesadilla --  ($9.50)  -- She chose chicken (steak was an option), grilled onions, tomatoes and peppers served with lettuce, tomato and quacamole.

I got the Steak Mexicana -- ($13.99) -- Ribeye with cooked onions and tomatoes --  served with rice, beans, guacamole salad and tortillas.

We both liked our dishes. But kinda, maybe ate too many chips with salsa.

The ribeye was well-cooked to a medium-rare. The onions were caramelized. The tomatoes popped.

The rice was surprisingly tasty, as rice generally tastes like cardboard to me.

The beans were equally flavorful and had a little zing to them.

The guac salad was the crown on the ribeye of this dish. A little onion, a little tomato. Just spectacular.

I took home another two meals. She didn't take anything home.

June 26 UYE to celebrate The Prince of Yelp (or is it king?) -- Steven B. I walked in, and who's sitting at the bar wearing a crown? You guessed it.

We had a fun group for lunch. I met Bonnie and Kay and saw other great Yelp friends I already knew in real-life person.

Service was stupendous. Steven B. seems to be known in this joint. Consequently, our tables got royal service, because he kept wearing the crown.

I got one of the most incredible burgers I've EVER had: ground brisket, bacon, Cheddar, lettuce, tomato, red onion.

I skipped the sesame seed potato roll. And the fries.

The burger was cooked perfectly medium with a little bit of pink. The bacon was thick slab, cooked perfectly crispy (no flabby), the Cheddar was appropriately melted (ask Bobby Flay about that), and the lettuce/tomato/red onion were lovely accoutrements.

I think the brisket is what made this burger stupendous. The burger meat is the foundation. The rest contributes in accordance.

 Thanks, Steven B., for this fun and fabulous outing!!

I've been here plenty since 2016. I like the ribs, green beans, burgers, hummus with vegetables, fried chicken and wings.

January 23, Miss C. and I came for dinner. The place was packed.

Miss C. got the pulled pork sandwich topped with cole slaw. She chose baked beans as her side. She liked the cole slaw on the sandwich, but not so much the pulled pork. And she did not like the baked beans. I couldn't try them, because I don't like baked beans . . . ever.

I got the special ($9) -- filet, green beans and baked potato. I opted for double green beans and skipped the potato. Medium rare on the filet.

The filet was perfectly cooked, well-seasoned, and the green beans were deliriously perfect, al dente and seasoned so well with garlic.

I'm keeping this rating at 4 stars, because I had a great meal. And I have been in the saddle of ordering the wrong thing, so I appreciate and understand Miss C.'s meal was not up to par for her.

We both got to-go vessels. I got two more meals.

They have specials every day of the week. Check them out: http://www.stackhousestl.com/#specials

My college chum and I met for lunch September 12. Jeremy was our knowledgeable server.

My college chum wanted a pasta that wasn't on the "lunch specials" menu, so she got a full-size order.

I ordered from the lunch specials: 1/2 & 1/2 fried artichoke salad and meatball sandwich minus bread.

That fried artichoke salad is just soooo divine and the biggest half-salad I've ever had: some master genius devised it -- fried (but not breaded) artichokes, pistachios, goat cheese, asparagus and spring mix with balsamic vinaigrette.

I ate it all.

Then the meatballs came. Oh, I was full. I ate 1/2 of a meatball. They're meaty, juicy, tender with tomato sauce that is perfectly spiced. And they've got a shave of fresh parm.

So, the 5-1/2 meatballs came home with me for another two meals, and my college chum took home her dinner.

Dang. It's been here since 1913, and I've never been.

My husband took our children every Easter season to pick out a chocolate animal. Invariably, every year, someone came home with a pig. When you can get only one piece of chocolate, you want it to be big, and you want it to be solid (not hollow).

My great friend and I came for lunch today, timing arrival to avoid crowds and lines, part and parcel of Crown Candy Kitchen. And we got a fabulous parking spot.

We arrived at 10:40 a.m. They open at 10:30 a.m. We got a two-person booth right away. Water served immediately. Menus at the booth.

Please note: no separate checks.
 
Tammie was our great server. We needed a few minutes to decide on our order. While discussing and contemplating, a guy in the booth across from us (of course, he heard our conversation), lifted up his BLT to show us the bacon depth. Gads, there must be a pound of bacon on that sandwich. And he showed us the half he hadn't eaten yet.

He got a grilled ham-and-cheese sandwich ($6.99), which comes with chips and a pickle; and a chocolate-banana malted ($5.19).

I got a large chili ($4.99) -- with cheese and onions (+$.99) -- and a hot fudge shake ($5.19).

All their shakes and malts are 24 ounces. You are delivered one of those old-fashioned glass sundae containers with a straw and a spoon. The beverage comes in the metal container used to create your confection.

Their chili is no beans. I like that. The cheese and onions were massive. The chili is sooooo good. Hefty. Spicy, but not hot. Thick and rich. I ate about 1/4 of it. Comes with three packages of oyster crackers.

The hot fudge shake was stellar. So rich, so wonderful, so fudgy. I drank perhaps 1/3 of it.

My great friend ate half of his sandwich. It was so big! And drank half of his malted.

AND, he gave me his pickle . . . which was divine!!

We left with a lot of future meals. And when we walked out, there was a line of diners.

We timed it well.

I was overly fantabulized to find Viviano's out in the vast wastelands. Got some meat and cheeses from the case, spices, garlic-stuffed olives, bleu-cheese stuffed olives, frozen toasted ravs and ordered cannoli for a family get-together at my house the next day.

All in one place.

And they were happy I was there!

I've been searching for gyro meat for a while (for a special recipe), and didn't want to buy it at a restaurant, figuring the price for a pound would be astronomical.

I checked numerous grocery stores. Nobody had it.

Decided to come here today and made a beeline for the deli section. SCORE!! $8.99/lb.

I watched the guy carve the meat off the spit, crisp it up on the griddle and pack it up.

Paid upfront. Incredibly gracious and friendly cashier.

I met three friends for lunch Tuesday. We arrived @11:30 a.m. Already a line out the door. It moved pretty quickly. Stinking hot, so water being available was much appreciated.

A hostess was handing out menus -- great help. Hopefully by the time everybody got to the cashier, they knew what their order would be.

You order and pay at the counter and get your beverage (Pepsi products, tea -- sweetened and plain). Then have a seat. They bring the food out and call your name.

They offer a variety of sandwiches (served with one side), plates (served with two sides), combos (more than one meat and served with two sides), a couple salads, BBQ nachos, 11 sides and various carryout combinations, as well as meat by the pound and sides in pint, quart and gallon sizes.

Too bad they don't have any non-carb sides, except pickles, which I consider to be closer to a condiment.

I got the regular (also available in large) pulled ribs sandwich special -- not on the regular menu ($10.95) with macaroni and cheese.

Ditched the bun. Forked the pulled ribs, which were incredibly tasty and juicy without sauce. And the ribs were pulled. No bones anywhere.

The macaroni and cheese was creamy and cheesy with a little crunch top.

There were five sauces on the table, which you could buy in pint Mason jars for $5 to enhance your home barbeque.

Outdoor covered seating is available.

This location used to be Squeakers Bar & BBQ.

Today after work meeting a girlfriend. Sat in one of the rounded booths that reminded me of the tilt-a-whirl in shape. Fabulous service from Ronnie, who was also manning the front host station.

Got a nice glass of water and a couple brews. Lovely . . . just lovely!

I went today for a matinee. I thought it would cost $10. Nooooo.

Even on the weekend, movies before 5:30 p.m. are $5.

After finding the Big Lots in the Valley closed and gone, I went here.

I was surprised that it didn't look like a warehouse. It's a clean store with good shelving of many different things.

Lots of shelf (meaning non-perishable) food, which was surprising. And brand names.

Kitchen gadgets and small kitchen appliances.

Many, many different storage appliances. Small, medium and large. And special jewelry holders.

Some furniture. Great clearance section. When I went, the clogs and flip-flops were 50% off.

Halloween decorations were coming on the floor.

I went here a long time ago with a girlfriend when they first started selling beer. We enjoyed a couple brews before the movie, and it was fine-and-dandy!

I totally agree with Josh S's assessment on the up-datedness of the theater.

Last couple times here, seating is extremely comfortable (somehow we were in the same theatre both times), and upon theatre exit, there's someone standing there with a platter of sweets -- starlight mints, tootsie roll minis and butterscotch discs. Interesting touch. I guess we're in there getting bad breath!

Very unfortunately last visit, there was a large bucket of popcorn spilled in the lobby that we had to walk around. Could have happened mere seconds prior. Could have happened earlier. But no one was hot-steppin' it to clean it up.

My college chum and I met for lunch and were seated right away at 11:30 a.m.

We opted for a booth. All the doors were open to the patio, so you could hear the traffic on Olive, but it was OK. It wasn't like semi's grumbling down the interstate.

A refreshing, gentle breeze wafted in along with the spectacular aroma of cooking meats from the smoker out front -- some flies came in along with the breeze. They're not stupid; they know where the food is.

There was one man serving the inside, and one woman serving the patio. Another couple hands would have helped. The place filled up pretty quickly, even though we were some of the first patrons to arrive.

Our server was very friendly and quite enthusiastic, and he kept us well-hydrated.

There were four specials today that all sounded pretty good (I forgot one of them.):

their signature chicken salad (only available on Thursdays and sometimes on Fridays) -- and while we were ordering, our server was informed there was just one remaining

blackened salmon salad with poppyseed dressing

a rib sandwich -- meat taken off the ribs, then sautéed with peppers, onions and barbeque sauce, topped with cheese

I would have gotten one of these off-menu offerings, but I had a little problem with each one of them in one way or another -- with either the ingredients or the preparation.

The menu is laminated like a placemat so as soon as you are seated, you have the two-sided menu right in front of you.

We both opted for the Reuben -- comes with one side. She got the homemade chips. I got cottage cheese.

Our server offered a little horseradish on the side, and we both went for that.

The Reubens were wonderfully toasted sandwiches (marble rye). The corned beef was incredibly tender and wonderfully smoky. Swiss and dressing were in good proportion. I would have liked more sauerkraut, but I like heavy on the kraut.

The little cup of horseradish was divine.

Her homemade chips looked beautifully cooked, not paper-thin. Very crunchy.

Ahhh, what do you say about cottage cheese? It was wonderful.

It took a little work to get our check, to-go vessels -- and while he was at our booth, he refreshed our drinks again.

We slugged those down and left with our treasures, including the horseradish.

The patio was full when we were on our way out.

Reserved a little section in a raised area in the back for a retiree happy hour send-off last evening. Didn't know you could do that, but we did about a month prior.

Jay was our server, and he rearranged the tables so we had one long table that seated 12. Hooray!

We ordered a couple brews, along with glasses of water. Jason set menus about the table, along with the wine/beer list.

As folks arrived, we ordered wings (one pound breaded & double dipped in Three Kings' signature sauce -- $8.99). We skipped the double dip and had the sauce served on the side, along with ranch and bleu cheese dressings.

These were huge wings, so crispy and juicy delicious. I ate one plain, and it was divine. Another I dipped in the bleu cheese dressing, which was thick and chunky loveliness.

Another ordered potato skins (stuffed with spinach, artichokes, toasted pine nuts and lemon-spiked Parmesan cream -- $6.49). What a lovely (lighter?) variation from the standard potato skin. The lemon really popped, and all the ingredients blended wonderfully.

Then, creole tuna sliders (three petit blackened tuna steaks with slaw and Cajun remoulade -- $9.99) that had a lovely kick.

Jay was perfectly attentive with beverages and food, not overbearing, but always there smiling. And he alerted us to the end of happy hour, 6 p.m., so those who desired could order another libation.

What a great celebration!

High school friends met after work and we started on the patio. But it got too chilly too quickly, so we asked our delightful server Paul to help us move inside. He was more than gracious to accommodate us!

At the same time our ordered nachos were delivered, and the lovely server took them back to the kitchen to keep them warm until we were ensconced indoors appropriately.

After settling inside, we ordered beverages with Paul's helpful suggestions and had nachos delivered.

Goodness, how full those nachos were of everything!! So nice that it wasn't just the chips on the top that got the good stuff -- smoked flank steak, grilled corn salsa, fresh jalapenos, Cheddar and Monterey Jack cheeses, shredded lettuce and sour cream ($9.95).

Paul served us water without asking . . . which was wonderful! And there were quite a few beverage dilemmas with which Paul helped us!

After wiping the nacho plate clean, we got:

Tempura-fried calamari, which was light and tasty and not overdone, served with rémoulade ($8.95)

Goat cheese artichoke-spinach dip, a lucious different-tasting dip served warm with toast points and tri-colored tortilla chips -- the goat cheese really added a deep, rich additional flavor note to the normally ho-hum pedestrian and well-known dip ($7.95)

Beer-battered chicken tenders that were puffy and light, an incredibly different approach to chicken tenders (which usually makes you think of McDonald's) -- but were so much more like a beer-battered fish -- but well-seasoned chicken that was moist and flavorful served with honey mustard dipping sauce ($6.95)

Paul split our checks quite willingly.

This is a lovely place. The patio is fabulous and beautiful with a flowing water wall. It's well-shaded from summer sun, has plenty of tables and under an awning there are heaters (that we felt as we were moving inside).

As soon as you walk in, you're in the bar, a picture of warm wood and brass.

The hostess station is forward for restaurant and patio seating. When I arrived, I went straight to the patio --  didn't know there was a dining room.

And, yes, you can see the beer-making vats, vessels, pipes and stuff. Fine and well. I believe most of us were drinking Square One's own brews.

I was quite impressed . . . with the food, the service, the ambiance and the total environs. A spectacular evening out!

The Fabulous Fox is always an incredible treat.

A few Saturdays ago was Prairie Home Companion. Amazing.

The Fox foyer is elegant, the lighting fixtures are stupendous, the ticket-takers are generous and friendly.

And the ushers help you find your destination.

Our seats were lower left, but not too far left. We could see everything, with no heads in the way.

The show was great fun, interactive and funny. It was, indeed, a fabulous evening.

My girlfriend and I made a point of visiting Sasha's, since we'd recently been to Sasha's on Shaw.

We sat inside. There were others dining outside but when the rain came, they had to beat a path under a roof, which made a nice communal discussion.

Our server was delightful.

My girlfriend got the same small chopped veggie salad and a Margherita flatbread.

I got the Roast Beef Brisket ($9.99) -- Shaved roast beef brisket on grilled French bread. Au jus came on the side for dipping. It came with a cornichon and a side of potato salad.​ I opted out of a Fontina addition, which cost $2.

My girlfriend shared her salad with me, and it was delightful, full of good flavors and those lovely white cheddar cheese nuggets.

My sandwich was chocked with meat (a good thing) to balance the bread (which was, of course, thick). It soaked well (I still have to get used to that sogging up the bread thing.) in the au jus and tasted fantastic. There was a good deal of smoky flavor to the brisket, and it was tender.

The potato salad was quite tasty and quite a surprise, as the menu doesn't mention it.

The cornichon was tasty and tangy . . . as it should be.

I did taste a piece of my girlfriend's Magherita flatbread, and it was really good. The way they cut it, there is a slice of tomato on every piece.

The atmosphere is good, but incredibly marred by the crates of bottled water and wine sitting under the raised dining area. It makes the whole place look like a warehouse.

There are wine corks on all the restroom doors. And they're working on putting wooden wine crates on the ceiling. A work in progress. It looks good; it's just not finished.

I took half my sandwich home with a nice vessel of au jus and half the potato salad. This served as another meal.

My girlfriend took most of her flatbread home for dinner.

My girlfriend and I went for lunch before a movie.

You go through a cafeteria-style line, and they make your food while you watch, so you can add or subtract ingredients as you go.

My girlfriend got Earmuffs (It's a burrito.): Served with your choice of protein (She chose chicken.), seasoned rice, beans, shredded cheese, pico de gallo and guacamole. She got a basket of chips and got her own salsa of choice from the salsa bar.

I got the Close Talker (It's a salad.): Served with choice of protein (I chose ground beef.),  beans (I skipped those.), pico de gallo, shredded cheese, cucumbers and black olives. I added guacamole, grilled onions and mushrooms and selected chipotle ranch dressing on the side, as I did not know how spicy it would be.

I did skip the taco shell bowl that is available with this salad.

Because I signed up for their online "club," I had a coupon for a free cup of queso. I got a basket of chips, and another basket of chips for the queso. Man, there were a lot of chips at our table.

We shared the queso and ate probably 1/4 of it. It was good stuff.

The mild salsa and medium salsa I selected were both quite good.

My salad was stupendous and huge. The flavors were great. The chipotle ranch dressing was creamy, flavorful and mild.

She could not finish her Earmuffs -- where they get these names, I cannot fathom.

I took all the chips, salsa and queso home, along with half of my salad. My boys liked the chips, salsa and queso. My salad was another meal.

Went with a girlfriend after work to get a little happy hour. We sat at the bar and had the pleasure of Stephanie as our barmistress!! She was attentive, pleasant and generous.

I wasn't sure about my beer selection, so she gave me samples of two, and I selected one of those. It was a wheat beer.

Great HDTVs at the bar.

The place is huge and has outside seating in front along Delmar, as well as in a European-style "alley" between buildings. We sat in the alley for a bit, but it was an incredible wind tunnel. Would have been great with a warmer temperature! Very cozy and intimate!

Back to the bar, I espied all the Three Olives vodka and asked Stephanie to make me something with the cake vodka. She was only limited by her imagination, and she really ran with that!!

Stephanie made a chocolate cake vodka drink. I think the only things in it were the cake vodka and chocolate vodka, way chilled with her snappy shaker skills!! For goodness sake, was this delicious and totally indescribable! Yum-yum!!

After a couple beers, my friend left, and I decided to get some food to take home while enjoying another beer as the food was prepared.

Reuben with sweet potato fries was lucious, tasty and rugged -- full of corned beef. The fries were marvelously flavorful!

Cup of chili (called on the menu "soup of the moment," so it must vary seasonally) was full of meat, not too many beans, spicy and tangy, but not too much! I don't like my food to hurt me.

Gyros sliders were the star (by a tad) of the take-homes. Absolutely FULL of meat with appropriate level of feta and accoutrements. Buns were soft, fresh and yeasty. ONE was a meal for me.

1/2 roasted chicken that came with grilled asparagus spears and Missouri corn risotto. I've never had corn risotto before, and it was so tasty with that nice textural addition of the corn. A large dish. Stephanie apologized that the chicken would take 20-30 minutes to make. NO PROBLEM!!

Now I've got this huge take-home order of food. They packed it all up like champs and nestled everything in a Budwiser bottle case, so I had carrying handles to tote it.

I walked out the front door schlepping this crazy box and walked 2 blocks down Delmar to my car. Not too glamorous, but I was proud and excited.

I got 9 meals out of this food and paid $80 for all of it, which included happy hour consumption and tip.

Thank you, Stephanie!!

My great friend and I came for lunch September 23. We got a table right away, and our server was friendly.

The joint is sooooo loud. Concrete floors, no curtains on the windows offer nothing to absorb sound. And the music was blaring. I had to scream to have a conversation and lean in closely to hear my great friend talk.

He got a combo of two sliders and fries.

I got two sliders (without buns): The All-American (aged Cheddar, garlic aioli and LTPO) and The Classic Reuben.

I know. DON'T tell me -- that was a dumbass thing to do. Go to The Slider House and ditch the buns. But I did. And I'm proud.

He liked his sliders. His fries were ice cold. Not even warm.

My sliders were predictable. Nothing special.

What got this down to one star: when my great friend told our server his fries were cold, she didn't even OFFER to bring fresh, piping hot fries. She left the table and came back saying if we would ask for (such and such a name) next time we come in, they would take care of us (whatever that means).

Yeah. OK. When pigs fly.

So yes, this place is pretty ghetto, and yes, it was kinda slow for being basically fast food, and yes, the prices no longer entirely reflect the not-particularly-savory atmosphere of either the establishment or its immediate surroundings... but the quality was apparent, so I'm happy to give them a pass - and it *is* still a bargain price, even if it was, apparently, cheaper previously. We split a catfish po-boy and a shrimp po-boy, and both were quite fresh and all around delicious - as well as enormous. Both are highly recommended - but take it to go. If you're looking for a classy place to hang out and get food, go somewhere else - but if you're looking for a (relatively) affordable place to get super legit po-boys, this might just be your place. It was certainly ours.

Just noticed I never reviewed this one, when we were in SB last year on a whirlwind wine-tasting tour. Noticed it now because we just drank the bottle of wine we bought when were were here. We were *slightly* inebriated by the time we got to this one, near the end, so I was only like 80% confident that the wine we purchased (a viognier) after tasting it was as good as I remembered, but nope, totally was, it was a great viognier. 

The view is definitely their claim to fame (hanging out with such a great view while slightly inebriated is one of the better things you can do in SB), but judging exclusively on that one viognier, their wine probably isn't half bad either. (We didn't do a full tasting - we had a coupon to taste one specific wine, but we asked if we could use it to taste one wine of our choice instead, a request they would have been silly to reject, since it meant us tasting a wine we'd actually be likely to purchase, which, sure enough, we did. One of the better viogniers I've had, and I quite like viognier.)

I fell for the hype. I'm a big fan of unusual ice cream flavors, and this place advertised tons of them, so on our trip to NOLa, after eating at Commanders, we made the short extra trolley trek out here to try this ice cream, which I thought would be just as impressive as all the various other amazing ice cream shops I've been to. It was... decent ice cream. Pretty good, even. I'd give it 4 stars instead of 3 because it's pretty cheap - but I could also tell the difference in quality between a place like this, and a place that can get away with charging 5 bucks for a cup instead of 3. And they didn't have that many exotic flavors when I was there, either. I don't even remember which flavors I ended up getting, and it's only been a couple weeks. Granted, it's been a *crazy* couple weeks, but still.

I got a sandwich here during a short layover in this terminal. As airport food goes, you could do way worse. It was $9 for a sandwich, and that $9 got me a completely filling lunch. It wasn't a particularly *enjoyable* lunch, but neither was it an unpleasant one. The sandwich was pretty large, and stuffed full of actually pretty quality-tasting meat, it just needed something else - more vegetables, or maybe some hot sauce (to be fair - they probably had hot sauce available, so if I were stuck in this terminal again in the future, given the relative paucity of other choices, there is a high chance I would buy another sandwich here, and just make sure to grab some hot sauce next time.)

This is pretty much the definition of a 3 star review, in or out of an airport - just that if I weren't in an airport, I'd have better options.

IF the staff here was at all nice , ( and I am speaking for the front desk staff alone).. this hotel would possibly earn another star. After calling and asking about availability and being told there was none, I went on Choicehotels.com and mysteriously, there were rooms.. what a miracle ?
