The bellini sparkle was not in a tiny champagne flute, it was in a tumbler and was refreshing. My friend couldn't stop ordering the cucumber, apple, and elderflower cocktail. Be warned, it is very strong! 

I was worried our service would be poor because they only had 2 bartenders for the entire bar, but it wasn't. They were attentive and sure to check up on us and get our orders in. They also have some incredible outdoor seating areas, and enjoying a cocktail on a nice day here is heaven. 

Thanks for the good times Tavern, I can't wait to see you again!

What an interesting market! 

I needed some uncommon dried peppers for a chili I was making, and the local Kroger failed to have the variety of peppers that I needed. Luckily I remembered that K&S carries a wide variety of items and was happy to find an entire wall of dried peppers! Awesome. I quickly picked up my items and browsed the store for a bit. 

The shelves were filled with lots of interesting items and live fish/lobster as well. Yes, there is a unique smell to the place, but that is to be expected for a place with so many different meats, produce, and packaged products. 

Overall, a great place with very affordable prices! I wish I was a better cook so I could really take advantage of what they have to offer.

Almost a perfect experience. So close.

BF and I had an impromptu date night, and I have been wanting to try Moto for a long time! We came in a bit late and were able to snag a nice booth at the front of the restaurant. I absolutely love the ambiance. It's modern and romantic, and they have a gigantic bar that is lovely. 

We ordered a bottle of wine, and I was pleased to see that they offer a variety of options to choose from with different price points. We got a delicious bottle of pinot for $36.00! Excellent. 

For entrees we got an order of wagyu beef meatball, and the prosciutto crostino
with ricotta, thyme, honey. The crostino was amazing but the wagyu beef was a tad bit overcooked. Just a tiny bit. 

Entrees were the blueberry lasagna and the black spaghetti. MMM. Both were outstanding. The blueberry lasagna is a must try if you like mushrooms, it's not sweet, definitely savory and rich. It was unlike anything I've had before and I loved it! I'd highly recommend the black spaghetti as well, it had lobster in the sauce and was out of this world!! 

Since it was date night, we decided to go for dessert and ordered the buttermilk gelato and the white peach mint sorbet. YUM. For only $3 a scoop, it was the perfect end to the meal. 

I am a big fan of Moto and will be back again to hopefully up my review to 5 stars!

I've gotta be honest... the name of this place kinda turned me off. I try to avoid fried and battered things, and I just didn't have much desire to visit this restaurant. BUT I am so glad that I came here with friends who have visited before and recommended it. They didn't lead me wrong. 

We started with the fried pickle chips...YUM! They didn't last long. Then we moved on to drinks and I had a very delicious vodka mule that was served in a copper cup. Perfection! My friends raved about the sushi, and we ordered a roll and the boys had a platter of sushi which was HUGE. 

The sushi was legit. And I probably never would have ordered it had my friends not said it was so good. Who knew they'd have sushi at a place called Batter'd and Fried?! 

Also, they offered great service that was also fast! I'm so glad I stopped in and will give it another try when I'm on the East Side!

For 10 glorious years, Wine on the River has made grey teeth out of us locals, and to the organizers of this event, I love you for that. 

This is hands down my favorite event of the year, and I will continue to make a fool out of myself on the Shelby Street Bridge annually by shamelessly trying to get bigger pours at the wine tents and making new "friends" with other wino attendees. Gotta make it count, right? 

A couple of tips that are MUSTS if you plan on attending the absolute joy that is Wine on the River:

-Buy tickets early. They DO sell out and rather quickly. And nobody wants a DD ticket. 
-EAT something before you go. And I'm not talking fruit and yogurt ladies. You NEED substance. Bacon. Eggs. Breakfast Burrito. These are all acceptable items.
-When the gates open at 3pm, the line on the downtown side is very busy. Go to the East Nashville entrance for quicker lines.

While not all of the wines that are offered are my taste (death to Moscato!) this is a great time to try different varieties and step outside the box. And if you happen to be with people who don't like wine (I hate these people already) they DO offer some select liquors. They also have some food vendors around if you didn't take my advice about the food or just get the drunk munchies. Hey, it happens. 

I will be attending this year, so if you see me and want to say hi, I apologize in advance for my wino behavior.

I was intrigued by this place... part coffee shop, part sandwich shop, part taqueria/fried chicken joint and all housed in a building that feels like a gas station. Despite the lack of ambiance it was tough to decide what to order while browsing the menu and cases which showcased cold salads and hot items like fried chicken. Everything sounded good, but I decided to go the taqueria route and had a chorizo and pastor taco with a side of guacamole. You order to the left side and they had just installed a new ordering system so the lady at the counter had trouble placing my order which resulted in a very long line of people trying to order behind me. They offer a decent amount of seating and the first two orders in our group came out quickly, but I had to pay attention to get it because I didn't get a receipt with a number so I best guessed it. The last two in my party weren't so lucky. They had a significant wait well after us and there were some missed fries and frustration because a sandwich was sitting on the counter but they didn't call out the order loud enough. Once they got busy things seemed pretty chaotic and the pick up counter could use some improvement.
The food was hit or miss. My pastor taco was much better than the chorizo but the guacamole was a highlight. It was fresh and without any brown old patches which is common with pre-made guac. They also offered the classic jalapeno and red sauces that you would find at a taco truck, but unfortunately the green sauce tasted like it had gone bad. The sandwiches were all enjoyed and seemed to be better than my order. We also had the asada fries which were just OK and not recommended. I would definitely come back but would try to call in an order and pick it up. I wouldn't dine in again and think that the sandwiches were better overall. I'll definitely give them a second chance when I am back in the area!

Three Muses was a recommendation from the Yelp Community, so thanks for continuing to lead me on the right path Yelp!! 
I was in NOLA for a Bachelorette Party (I know, but we were not obnoxious I swear!) and I booked an early reservation for us at Three Muses. I love the live music and the vibe here. Sometimes music at a restaurant can be obnoxious and obtrusive, but this band was perfect. At this point we were in NOLA for a few days and ready for something different, and this was absolutely perfect. We ordered the bacon wrapped dates, lamb sliders, and mac and cheese. They were definitely heavy appetizers, but a great way to mix up our dining options. 
The drinks were wonderful and our server gave us free shots to celebrate the bride. Love it! 
Check out Three Muses, but make sure you get a reservation, they are popular and with good reason!

The Turnip Truck is fantastic but pricey. 

I stopped in for dinner at the salad bar, and had 2 days worth of food to enjoy for right under $15.00. Not too bad! The salad fixings are not extensive, but they are very fresh and tasted excellent (I also was there late on a Sunday, so I'm sure time of day had something to do with it). Plus I loved the cold mixed salad items like the couscous, tabouli, and spinach pasta. Try the hot bar too, I snuck a couple bites from my BF and it was excellent! 

The juice/smoothie bar is lovely and overall this is an adorable market for specialty items. However, expect to spend a bit more than what you are used to. Think of it as a designer grocery store!

I was a bit bummed when Phat Bites moved to a new location, but I am pretty sure it's the same distance away from me, so no big loss! However, I drove past it the first time I visited, so keep your eyes peeled. It shares the same space as some nondescript business. 

I'm glad that the space is a lot bigger and they now have plenty of parking, even at peak times. The food, menu, and staff are the same. I came in for lunch a few times recently, and if you go early, you are golden. Anywhere between 11-12:00 you are fine. However, I stopped in around 12:30 and the line was long and order taking a bit annoying. I also waited about 15 minutes for my order, so it's not the quickest lunch option out there. When ordering take out, I like for it to be pretty quick, but expect to be at Phat Bites for at least 30 minutes at peak times. 

I still love the black bean burger that they offer. It's the best one I've had. I also have ordered a few sides. The kale salad is always great, and the hummus is out of this world! Phat Bites is amazing, so check them out!

Small venue with a cool vibe and views of the city. I've never been to a show that was sold out here, most of them have been pretty empty actually. But I love the space, and it definitely has an intimate feel to it. I like that you have to go back through the building and it's somewhat tucked away and hidden. I'd highly recommend seeing a show here!

I came to the "smoking lounge" for a birthday party on a Thursday night, and once I was able to escape from the smoke, I had a lovely time! :)

The upstairs bar is beautiful! The romantic lighting reminded me of a different time period, and I loved that the bartender put on a random 90's lite station on Pandora that had all of us singing along to Mariah Carey, Bryan Adams, and all the great horrible music of the 90's. They also offered 3 appetizers for $21 and house wines that were delicious! The eggplant appetizer was outstanding, and I'd highly recommend it to anyone! A couple partygoers ordered off the menu, and they had a seafood linguine that looked amazing... 

I tried Valentino's quite a few years ago and wasn't overly impressed, but after my lovely night out, I think I need  to give it another go!

All you really need to know is that Jackson's has the best Sangria in town! It's everything you want in a sangria... sweet and tangy with the heavy red wine taste that rounds it all out. I dream of it at night sometimes... plus it's just so darn pretty. I've tried to recreate it at home, and somehow it's just never the same! The French martini is great as well, but anytime I stray from the sangria I wish I'd ordered it instead. It's just so good!! OK, I've got to talk about the food too. 

The Verde Dip aka garlic and spinach dip is unlike any other spinach dip you've tried before. It's my favorite food item at Jacksons! For your meal, the Torrados are great and I haven't had a pasta here that I don't like. 

I've spent many a night on the patio with a sangria in hand having drunken philosophical talks with my friends and I wouldn't take a back a single sip or moment spent here!

I had a decent lunch at Coffee, Lunch. 

I absolutely love the location, building, and set up. It's cute but definitely not large enough for a lot of customers to sit and hang out. And with only one barista, I bet it's pretty slow during rush times in the morning.  

The staff was super friendly and helpful, and we decided on the turkey sandwich, hummus plate, and creamy tomato soup. I had to sample a soy latte, as it is my go-to drink. My hummus plate was very tasty and I enjoyed the soup. I really like that they had a pesto topping on hummus. Delish! My BF wasn't overly impressed with his turkey sandwich, he said it didn't have much flavor and I have to agree. Plus it cost $8.00. Ouch. That's a bit steep to not have a side or anything. 

My latte was good, but they don't have cinnamon powder. This is the first coffee shop I've visited ever who doesn't have cinnamon powder. Isn't that a staple? The barista offered me a cinnamon stick, but it definitely didn't have the same punch that the powder has. 

I had a nice lunch here but do feel the food was a bit overpriced for what you get. Plus I gotta have the cinnamon powder!!!

Hello delicious!

Kien Giang has two limitations that had not allowed me to visit in the past: 

- Cash only
- Closed on Mondays

But alas... I had a $10 bill in my pocket and it was a Wednesday so I planned accordingly and picked out my to-go order. I had the spring rolls and chicken pho. I was a bit puzzled when I looked in the bag because the broth did not have anything in it. But I was relieved to discover they had FILLED a take out box with meat, noodles, and additions. Whew! I was worried for a second! 

The spring rolls were hands down the best I've ever had. Their peanut sauce was simply unreal and the soup was filled with flavor. Outstanding. I didn't even add any hot sauce to my dish since it was so good! 

I'm anxiously awaiting my next non-Monday, non-card visit!

I was bummed when I noticed yet another empty building on Demonbreun that once housed Mirko Pasta, but luckily they just moved spots. Gotta love the Demonbreun curse!

Came here with some coworkers to the new location, it's in a strip shopping area that's kinda in an odd spot... but the space is large and has a good amount of room for large parties. The food was what I remember it being, good pasta and sauce with a nice $8.00 lunch menu. I ordered the tuscan stew which had a variety of seafood in it. I know it was a stew but I was hoping for a tiny bit more broth. But the flavor was good and I was happy with my dish. Just a bit pricey ($14.00) for lunch.

I noticed that they have house wine on the table, which is a nice addition for sure! Glad this spot is in the area, and I will probably visit during work hours but not after.

OK, I've got to downgrade my score a bit after my second experience. 

Came in with a decent sized group after attending wine on the river, so I must admit that parts of this meal are slightly hazy. However, after doing a bit of detective work, I have pieced together my experience. 

What I remember: 
-Ordering a turkey burger and the famous potatoes on the side
-Having one well liquor drink
-The potatoes being extremely soggy and floppy

Fast forward to two days later. This is me checking my credit card statement:

"Holy $*&^ I spent $50 at National Underground?? How did that happen?"

Then the pieces started falling into place. 
-I picked up the tab for my BF (still. TWO burgers and two drinks- a beer and well vodka should not be $50)
-We had to buy BOTTLED water. That cost $2 extra per bottle. 
-There was an up charge for the potatoes that were floppy and not good

Yikes. That's a lot for a drunken meal that I half remember. I had a good experience the first time when I was a bit more coherent, so I'm definitely going to try and be a lot more careful when eating here. If it's late night, I'm choosing Broadway Brewhouse, and next year I think Mexican food is more appropriate for post wine on the river food.

I really enjoyed my visit to Garden Brunch Cafe! I came in around 9:15am on Sunday morning, and it was perfect. There was no wait and we got seated immediately. 

The restaurant is in a very nicely decorated house converted into a restaurant, and we sat in the front room with a fire going next to us. Super cute spot!

They have a great menu, and I had trouble deciding what to order. I love that they offer a variety of different mimosas and also will serve them in a pitcher for a whole table. I had the Germantown eggs Benedict with salmon, capers, caramelized onions and spinach. It was excellent. I'd highly recommend this dish, and it seems to be very popular! My dad had the blackberry french toast and it was also great. It was an entire plate full, and he ate every single bite! I had a side of turkey bacon, and it was probably the best I've ever had!

Service was good, but it took quite a while for our food to come out and they weren't super busy yet. After we finished eating, we went outside and there was a large group waiting, and from other reviews, it looks common to have a crazy wait and slow food delivery. 

To be honest, I wouldn't wait over an hour for brunch here. It is very good, but unless it's early or late, I wouldn't stop in. However, I am not one to wait more than 30 minutes for a table unless I can have a cocktail at the bar or somewhere else to relax. There was a very large group of people were standing outside and there aren't any places to sit down.

Back in the day, I was a kickball player who had games every Sunday, rain or shine off Thompson Lane. Prior to my retirement, I visited this Mexican place a good deal, and remember it being pretty good. 
My job recently moved me from my favorite taco place off Murfreesboro Road, so I found myself here again this week, in dire need of the delicious authentic Mexican tacos that I so craved. It didn't disappoint. 
A few things that I love:
- They take credit card. Yes. 
- That it is a drive-thru. I LOVE this. Super convenient when I want to grab some tacos during a busy day and hit the road. 
- The chorizo tacos. YES. I love that they are cooked very well, with the perfect amount of grease and flavor. 
- The sauces. Make sure to ask for a side of the red sauce, it does not normally come with it, so you need to ask for it in addition to your order. You are welcome. 
A few things I'm not a fan of: 
- Grilled onions cost extra. Look... the tacos are 1.25 each and should come with grilled onions. It's part of the tacos. I don't like that this is an extra charge. 
- I wasn't a huge fan of the carnitas taco. It was OK but didn't taste as fresh as I would have liked. 
Otherwise, I am a fan and will be back. I am a sucker for convenience, and am going to be enjoying this place for a long time to come.

I was impressed with my experience at Salsa!

BUT I think the key to dining here is to realize this is NOT a Mexican restaurant. Also, despite the name, there are no actual "chips and salsa" offerings here, this is a Puerto Rican and LATIN restaurant, so we are talking rice, plantains, beans, meats, etc. Since Nashville has a very limited amount of Latin restaurants, come here looking for a new experience or just go with the perception that you are eating Latin food if you've had it before and you won't be disappointed!  

It's located within view of Mercy Lounge/The Cannery, and would be a perfect spot to get a drink before a show. It's located in an interesting building with a bit of an industrial feel, but I love the way the space is decorated and they also have outdoor seating. 

For dinner, we had the black bean hummus (AMAZING) and Empanadillas de Carne
(Ground Meat Bite size Turnovers) with this heavenly sauce to dip them in....mmmm. Off to a great start! Then (based on the incredible looking Yelp pictures) we ordered the chicken stuffed with plantains, ground beef lasagna with sweet plantains, and sides of yuca and mofongo which is green plantains mashed. Every single thing we had was delicious, unique, and prepared well. The waitress was extremely helpful and explained all the dishes to us and answered our questions.We also had to order the Tres Leches for dessert and it did not disappoint! Food was outstanding all around.

I enjoy the drinks and they are STRONG, but I must say I was slightly disappointed in the mojitos. Since rum is their primary liquor used here, I had hope for a mojito that would knock my socks off, and it fell a bit flat. However, I adore both the passion fruit and red sangria.

Overall, I was very happy with my experience and can't wait to come back!

I have been wanting to try AM@FM for a while now but just haven't made it over to the Farmer's Market to give it a go. Luckily my opportunity came over the weekend! 

I ordered an Asian inspired wrap with chicken and a side of tobasco potato salad. FYI...each sandwich and wrap is a 1/2 so make sure to plan accordingly! It turns out mine was plenty of food and under 10 bucks!! They also offer wine and sangria, and I was sad that they ran out of sangria before I had the opportunity to try it.

There is plenty of seating and a good selection of salads, wraps, and sandwiches. Really enjoyed my first visit and can't wait to stop back by!

Sorry Sylvan Park. I love all of your establishments except this one. The tacos are WAY overpriced for what you get; I've tried everything from lobster tacos (at roughly $4.50 PER taco) to the veggie and chicken ($3ish). Not impressed with any of them. Plus the salsa costs extra (I hate when they do that!). The enchiladas are better than the tacos if you are forced to eat here, but even then they are sub par for what you pay. 

I've had mixed experiences with the drinks; the red sangria was tasty on one trip, the next time I had a pitcher with a friend and it was watered down. The last time I went I had a mojito and it was good, so it varies. 

I wish The Local Taco was good because it is so close to my house. I've given it multiple chances and was disappointed with each experience. I find it sad that a place with "taco" in the name doesn't have good ones! I'll go to a taco truck for my fix!

This Humane Society in West Nashville is awesome!!

I can only speak from cat side, but I have adopted from them twice, and I LOVE that the kittens and adult cats are already spayed and neutered before adoption, no exceptions. That makes things so much easier and helps reduce pet "accidents". They have different cats on special deals, and my adoption fee was $85, but that covered medical evaluation and treatments up until adoption. 

The staff is so friendly and helpful but leave you to browse the cages and figure out what you would like without pressure. Also, the month of June they were running specials for 2 for 1 adoptions. Adopt one kitten, get a second one free! Unfortunately my house would not accommodate two furry friends :). 

They have reasonable prices and even offer low cost vet services. Great location!

As far as sports bars go Sam's is one of the best. Once they converted to a smoke free environment, it was even better! If you are looking for a place to watch a game, Sam's is your place. The location has a great front area with large windows they open on nice days, and they have a private room upstairs that holds 25 people comfortably and you can rent out for $75.00. 

The food is good; your typical salads, wraps, burgers, plus pizza. I can recommend the spicy pepperoni pizza, and you can also build your own for a little bit extra. 

During the weekends and sporting events, Sam's is ALWAYS full of people, so if you plan to see a championship game, head there early! The servers do a good job with how busy the bar is, and stay on top of the tables. 

Sam's is great if you are looking for a casual place to watch a game!

Maybe I'm used to my hole in the wall Greek food, but I thought Taziki's was nothing special after my trip this weekend.

I stopped in with my BF and it was pretty empty on a Saturday afternoon, but has a very nice atmosphere. The restaurant is clean and open with lots of space. I also noticed right away that they offer wine and beer and they have a nice outdoor seating area. 

We ordered the grilled lamb gyro and chicken salad with 2 waters, and it was around $18.00. Maybe I was thrown off by expecting the food and prices of my run of the mill Greek places, but I thought it was a bit steep for what we received. The chicken was bland and the lamb was not shaved in strips like most Greek places. The lamb was just OK and I liked the dill sauce but overall it was lacking. I had the tomato cucumber salad on the side that was my favorite part of the meal because it was seasoned well. I also had potato chips on the side, which I found odd. I would have ordered something else if I had known. 

Overall, I've had better and will go somewhere less glamorous for my Greek food because I feel that you pay for the interior rather than a good meal.

Definitely a nice shopping center in West Nashville that I frequent! 

The stores included are:
Target
Best Buy
Dick's
Marshall's
Ross
World Market (my fav!)
Bath and Body Works
Old Navy
DSW Shoes
NY & Company
Lane Bryant 

Also within a short drive are other stores like Pet Smart, Dollar Tree, and some cell phone stores. The restaurants over here are few, and they also have a Publix close as well. The list above has stores within walking distance, but overall most of the stores are spread out. 

I really enjoy shopping here, and can typically find what I'm looking for!

MMW is a great venue! I love the industrial/factory feel and that it's a good size with two bars! The sound is great, and I love all of the fixtures and set up of the space. It's great! They have a good variety of shows and its an excellent venue. However, the parking definitely blows. The streets are always crowded so if you don't want to pay to park you have to drive quite a bit. Otherwise, lovely place!

Tasty. 

The National Underground did not disappoint. My BF has been raving about their burgers for over a year now, so I stopped in over the weekend to test his taste buds. He did not lead me astray! 

We snagged a table outside and watched as our waitress frantically ran from table to table for a few minutes. After we got our drinks we had to ask about ordering food, but she dashed back over to grab our order after we flagged her down. They do not have printed menus; only food items printed on the wall with chalk. It's a pretty simple menu thankfully, so we didn't have any issue looking it over.  I had the grilled chicken sandwich and my friend had the cheeseburger, and both were excellent! The hamburger tasted homemade and had a regular sized patty; not the thick hunk of meat that often is the star of burger joints. I like that they keep it simple and delicious! My chicken sandwich was filled with flavor which is sometimes rare for chicken at a burger place. 

Apparently the grilled potatoes are amazing, but sadly they were out when we came so we had to stick with kettle chips. Also, no substitutions for other side items. I saw a deviled egg small plate that I must try on my next visit. I'm a sucker for those guys.

My overall first trip was awesome and I understand the hype now. They had a live band playing inside, so I'm not sure how conducive it is for a dinner where you want to talk to your companions, but I will definitely be back!

Over the holiday I double dated it here with some friends one evening for dinner. We were seated at a booth for 8 and told that we might have other diners joining us later. That was a new one for a booth atmosphere, but whatevs. 
We had beer and wine to drink (fine) and ordered the burrata as an appetizer because, you just have to order burrata when it's on a menu cause it is a guaranteed good choice. B&B's didn't disappoint. It was very unique with fennel (which I usually despise but liked in this case), peanuts, and I think it was grapefruit. It was so good and probably my favorite part of the whole meal. I ordered light and had the kale salad. It wasn't the best kale salad that I've had; probably wouldn't order it again. My BF had the burger and it was good, but nothing stand out. The other couple liked their food, but no one was raving. 
I broke the hesitancy and ordered dessert (you're welcome!) and that was a good choice. We had the peanut butter and banana whoopee pie and a panna cotta. We each had a cappuccino as well. Our coffees were delicious and the desserts were very good. The highlights of the meal were definitely the dessert and appetizer, with our main courses leaving us "OK'ed". 
The entire menu looks great so I am very happy to head back and give them another shot. Since they are new I am sure some of this might have fallen in the pitfall of new restaurant growing pains. I love the location, space, and there as enough good to excite me to come back on another night!

It is my mission in life to sample all the authentic taco restaurants and trucks in Nashville and luckily Charlotte Ave is much easier to tackle than Nolensville Pike. Taqueria Azteca is a restaurant across the street from Aldi slightly off Charlotte and I would probably give them a 3.5. The restaurant is small but has about 10 tables or so and I was able to pay with a credit card which is a plus! I ordered the pastor, chorizo, and lengua tacos. Per usual, the pastor tacos were my favorite but I enjoyed the other two also. The tortillas weren't my favorite texture or consistency, but the red sauce was very spicy (yes!) and the green sauce was good but I prefer the creamy jalapeno sauce. 
Overall, the meat was well seasoned and delicious and came with caramelized onions which is a plus in my book. I was pleased with my meal but my search continues for the best taco place in town!

There is a lot of potential at Pearl Diver. The interior is gorgeous and well-themed and the outdoor space makes you feel that you are transported to an island. Plus I love the cabanas and the overall vibe is really cool and interesting. 
However, there were some pretty significant issues. First, you have to order at the bar or window connected to the outdoor space. I definitely had more luck at the bar, but just come here planning to wait to order. That alone isn't a dealbreaker though. I'm fine to wait if I'm getting some interesting drinks and delicious food. Unfortunately Pearl Diver didn't deliver there either. While the port to port cocktail was delicious, it only tasted like fruit juice and was very weak. If I'm paying $12 I want it to taste like an adult beverage. I tried the Paloma later and it was better but also very weak and mostly ice. I was excited about the food but bummed when the mushroom and shishito peppers came out with a laughable amount. There were seriously 5 of them on a skewer and the mushrooms were a huge let down and not worth $9 for these items. Luckily the dumplings and dipping sauce were good so it wasn't a total waste. 
At the end of our night we enjoyed talking to the bartender and sampled a shot of the daiquiri which was delicious and what I should have ordered instead of the other fruit heavy beverages I sampled. The bottom line is that I paid $50 leaving hungry and completely sober which makes me grumpy. Luckily I was hanging out with an awesome group of ladies so it wasn't a total loss but I'm not rushing back, especially since it's the new place to be and super popular. Maybe they know something I don't?

Hemingway's is just the perfect date night spot for a romantic evening or an intimate meal with friends. Trust me on this one! 
After a hectic week I came here for date night on Friday and immediately was impressed with the romantic yet speakeasy vibe. 
We ordered some cocktails which is a bit tricky because instead of giving you the ingredients they give you an author's take on the cocktail so it kinda leaves you guessing. You know the main spirit (whiskey, vodka, rum, etc) but for example they don't tell you that a gin cocktail is really a gin martini. No thanks. So be sure to ask your waiter to describe the drink for you in detail. They also offer a more expensive cocktail menu with premium spirits if that's your thing. 
For dinner we had the risotto to start with walnuts, apple, goat cheese and butternut squash. It was very good but not a large portion which is good before a big meal. I would recommend more than one if you are splitting it amongst a group of 4 or more. 
For entrees I had the roasted duck breast with cranberry stuffing and it was some of the best duck I've had in my life and the best stuffing I've had ever. It was melt in your mouth good and I ate every single morsel. My BF had the Korean fried chicken and it was good but mine just blew his out of the water it was so good!! When I go back I'm going to be hard pressed to not order it again. Heaven. 
Our service was great and they even wrote down the recipe to a cocktail that we enjoyed, I love that! This was a great meal and experience, so go check them out!!

I met a friend for lunch in Brentwood and Chopt was the perfect healthy light lunch in the middle of the week! The space is large and you order at the counter. It was difficult to decide what to order, but when I checked the calories on some of the salads opted for the lighter fare. If you don't want a salad they also offer wraps, but the salads are where they shine. I decided to order the crunchy Asian salad which came with grilled chicken, carrots, broccoli, pickled onion, shallots and cabbage. The dressing was a vinaigrette and they give you the option of it being heavy, regular or lightly dressed. I really liked that extra touch! I went with regular and thought that was the perfect amount. The regular sized bowls are pretty large and I ate it all even though I probably could have been satisfied with eating less. For drinks they offer a ton of healthy options also which I love. Spindriff, la Croix and other water options along with a fountain drink machine. Overall I was very satisfied with my meal and will be back next time I'm in Brentwood!

Super stoked about a Tapas bar in Nashville! Ever since we lost Rumba, I have been pining for an alternative. I'm very glad that Americano has filled that void for me. 

Came with a group on Friday night and had no trouble getting in. I have two gripes... 1. The name. I called this place "Amerigos" more than once and the couple we met had trouble getting here because the GPS kept routing them to Amerigos. 2. The interior is very similar to the old West End Cafe that was here before closing. The atmosphere leaves something to be desired since WEC was a lunch spot. But, let's talk food/drinks.

Their sangria is really really good. Extremely red wine heavy rather than fruit juice heavy which I love! It's actually not very sweet which is right up this dry girl's alley! I really really want to try the margarita/sangria swirl next because it looks fantastic. 

For food, we enjoyed the following:
- Spicy tuna guacamole 
- Hot cauliflower (NOTE, this was too spicy for some but as a spice freak I loved it!)
- Fried manchego cheese
- Chicken and smoked sausage paella 

I'd personally avoid the mushrooms, blistered tomatoes, and mussels. Though I'd get the mussels again just without the mayonnaise on top. I think it was too much for the dish and overpowered the flavors. Otherwise, we had a great experience here! The food came out really quickly, (minus the paella which takes 20 minutes to prepare) and we had a good server as well. 

Overall, I really enjoy this place and want to return soon! Especially on their Tapas Tuesday special once it's here in July!

Everything about The Green Pheasant impressed me. The brass hardware paired with bright teal chairs and elevated ceilings gave an upscale, opulent ambiance that I love and is the perfect setting for a fantastic Friday night meal. We met some friends here for the first time and decided to order a lot of things and share. We ordered cocktails, mine was a lemongrass drink with gin that was delicious and the rest of the table had cold sake. For our cold starter we had the wedges which typically I'm not a big fan of a giant stalk of lettuce as a general rule, but this one was cut up into smaller pieces with a hibachi dressing and crispy onions which were delicious. For the warm courses we ordered two kinds of gyozas, one being the stuffed chicken wings which were unlike anything I've ever had and incredibly interesting. They were warm and flavorful and stuffed with a blend of what I think was shrimp and other seasonings. It's hard to describe, but just get them. We also had the dan dan shishito peppers which I have to order whenever they are on a menu and were very good. I think my favorite dish of the night was the spicy crab noodles. They were good because they were actually spicy for a spice lover, and rich but not too heavy unlike other crab noodles I've had. They were incredible and melted in my mouth. I completely hogged the dish and was not as generous with them as I normally am when ordering shared plates. We also sampled a pork special that was great and had a really good sashimi which I think was the walu on the cold menu. 
The Green Pheasant had it all, ambiance, service and most importantly delicious, interesting food.

It's one thing to come to a restaurant and have a good dish, it's another thing when you go with a group of 10 people and every single dish is outstanding. Tavern accomplished this over the weekend.

It was a Friday night and I feared our large party wouldn't be seated for hours since they don't take reservations and they get so busy at peak times. The hostess told us it would be an hour wait time, and we were expecting that. After about a half an hour, she came back and told us she had a table ready if I could come take a look at it.  Perfect. We were seated and our meal was out of this world.

We opted to try the kale salad, guacamole, and a special appetizer of the night; fried cauliflower. Do yourself a favor and order the kale salad. It's unlike anything you've ever had and is SO good I tried to recreate it over the weekend. Mmmm. But all the appetizers were great, just wished the guac was in a bigger dish :)

For entrees, I sampled the felafel and meat pie. Oh my goodness. I have yet to try something that hasn't blown me away here. I'm glad they have a large menu so I can continue to come back and try it all!

I have been to this location a couple times for lunch, but stopped in for dinner last night for the first time. 

The lunch buffet is ok, I don't remember being blown away or hating it but have never rushed back. For dinner last night my BF and I split the super power builder and it came with a salad, miso soup, crab appetizer, and a very nice healthy portion of mixed sushi rolls and sashimi. For $24.95 we both were stuffed and couldn't finish all of it. THEN it was $10 off for certain bottles of wine, so for both of us we got out of there for $50 total. Now that's a good deal for some sushi and an entire bottle of wine! We both left tipsy and full!

Our waiter was sure to tell us immediately that he'd only been working there a week or so and it definitely showed. He had to run back and ask a bunch of questions, but he at least was quick and kept our drinks full. 

I thought it was good. Yeah, it's not the best sushi out there, but if you are pinching pennies, it satisfied my sushi craving and I was pleased overall! I've definitely had worse sushi for more money.

NOTE: William Collier's is only open on the days that Marathon Music Works has a show, not that I will be returning. 

I never liked William Collier's but found myself here before a show and decided to give it another chance. Unfortunately, it was worse than my other experiences. On my first visit they offered a full cocktail menu and bar fare, and I found it to be sub par but appreciated that they made an effort. 
When I came the other week, they didn't have a drink menu and the bartender was one of the worst I've ever had. She was completely unhelpful when we asked about the changes to the establishment and made me chase her down when I needed the check. I have no reason to return and don't plan to, even with the convenience they offer before a show.

Back in the day I was a West sider and often drove by this large restaurant supply store which quickly became vacant. I remember thinking "it's a shame that this really cool building isn't being used for something like a marketplace or condos." Luckily my musings came to life with L&L Marketplace! They recently gutted the place and have slowly begun opening stores. I stopped in the week of Thanksgiving and there were a decent amount of retailers but still a good amount of construction going on as well as you can see from my photos. Unfortunately the only food option was a milkshake spot, but they were also working on a Thai restaurant right in the main entrance. I will be back for that because Thai food is one of my favorites! I stopped a few shops including a spice store, a local Nashville shop with various treats, apparel, and Nashville based products. Also, local blogger "Living with Landyn" also has a cute store with clothing, gifts, and home goods. Amongst the clothing stores and shops they also have a Cycle Bar, popcorn store, and various other retail spots with plenty of room to add more! I can't wait to come back when they are at full capacity!

After giving it a bit more time, I am now ready to deem Thai Esane the best Thai food in Nashville. Yep, I said it! 

I have dined in only once, usually I call for take out, but everything here is just so good. The flavors are amazing, and take your toughest spice lover here cause they don't mess around with the heat. If you are unsure, just try the mild and build up from there. To give you an idea, I love spicy food and I have to tell them between medium and hot. 

They are a popular place and I think that is largely because they are meeting an ethnic food demand in the area (have ya tried to eat at the Smiling Elephant with a big group?!). Keep that in mind if you want to dine in during prime dinner hours. You're gonna wait a bit. I've had to wait some for my take out order too, but usually not more than 10 minutes and I totally give them a break for that since they are typically slammed when I'm hungry. 

I always thought I was a green curry kind of gal, but they have turned me into a red one. Their red curry with chicken is fantastic. Like noodles? They can make it as a soup too! Want some wide noodles? Try the Malaysian style noodle. Or the Paneang curry is out of this world as well. I will say that their Pad Thai isn't quite my favorite, but I think that is because it's my least favorite Thai dish. 

Their cocktails are also delicious and Thai inspired. The Lychee martini is really good and a nice palate cleanser after you've scarfed down a belly full of spicy food. 

Thai Esane is da bomb guys.

This venue is breathtaking. 

I love everything from the courtyard to the statues, to the unique light fixtures and marble covered interior. This is the perfect place to enjoy a night at the symphony or hear a concert. 

I've noticed that they are trying to incorporate more comedians, popular musicians and discounted tickets to get more people in the doors, and I'm glad that they are making strides to ensure this lovely gem downtown is a success. They have multiple bars in the lobby's so you can enjoy a cocktail for a reasonable price. Put it in a plastic cup and you can bring it inside the auditorium. I love that!

Some people don't dress up, but I would suggest you do. It's just the kind of venue that screams class, sophistication, and the arts.

Delish! 

I finally had a chance to stop in over the weekend, and I'm so glad I did. First of all, I walked from my house (YES) and was blown away with the interior. Seriously. It's gorgeous. They have a large bar and a very unique layout inside. We ended up getting take out, and I'd definitely suggest calling ahead, just to make life easier. While we waited for our order we chatted with Nina who is absolutely lovely. I am so glad they decided to open a Thai place close to the Gulch that isn't the outrageously packed Smiling Elephant. They already were winning in my book. 

We ordered 2 appetizers (Tom Kha, dumplings) and chicken pad thai with the chicken green curry. We didn't love the coconut soup, but the rest of it was very solid, and reasonably priced too! We had to get our staple orders first and are definitely going to be back to branch out and try more of the menu. I am so glad they are here! 

NOTE: if you drive by and it looks closed, go give the door a pull or check the hours. When we came the outdoor tables and chairs were pulled inside and there wasn't an open sign glowing, but they were open.

Solid place for lunch. And a MUCH needed addition to the desert of tasty lunch options that is the industrial park in and surrounding Elm Hill Pike. 

It was quite difficult to find out where the heck this cafe is located due to it being in a business complex jungle with poor signage and addresses. For anyone who is also lost...the building says "2" out front if that helps you. Also, I found it a bit odd that they were located where they were... Being off Elm Hill Pike would have a ton more visibility and convenience for people...but maybe they are just trying to cater to that one specific office complex? 

Once we parked we came inside to see what looked good. I tried the Korean BBQ tacos and the bahn mi pork sandwich with a side of tomato soup. It was a pricy lunch for what I normally spend on the rare occasion I go out but it was a ton of food and I was stuffed. I have to admit that the tacos were a TAD salty and had quite a bit of mayo on them, but the flavor was good and they were huge. I preferred the bahn mi sandwich. The soup was very tasty also, and I grabbed a soy latte for the road before we came back to work. 

All in all, I'm glad this spot is so convenient to me. They offer a half sandwich/soup option that is cheaper and I think I will try next time. Their dessert case is quite extensive as well. Next time I'll have to try one out before I get myself too full!

I have been to the Smiling Elephant 3 times, and the first 2 visits were excellent- they have a great Pad Thai and the Tom Kha soup was outstanding. 

While the decor and building is simply charming, the last time I went it was so busy that we ordered our food to go and one of the dishes was mostly rice with a small amount of meat. It was very disappointing because in the past the food has been excellent despite how busy they were. I would recommend going but with reservations. I won't go back until they get a larger facility or it is at a dead time (3:00 in the afternoon) when there are less customers there.

My BF bought me a gift certificate for Float Nashville a few years ago, and we made it just under the expiration date to sample the services this past weekend. I was able to easily book both of our sessions online, and there's only one option online for a 90 minute float. 
They are open late (until 11pm) and we came in at 5pm on a Saturday. We filled out an iPad with our information and were the only customers there which made for a nice calming experience. The employee was very nice and showed us the tanks. We both opted for the closed tanks for the full experience and I'm glad I did, though they do offer an open tank if you prefer. You start off the float with a lukewarm shower and then enter the tank. Outside the tank they have motion censored lights and once in the tub I had the option to turn on a light but didn't to get the full experience. 
When you get in it is definitely weird at first and difficult to adjust.  I was very tense and the instructions at the beginning were helpful to just focus on your breath and try to loosen any tension in your muscles. The sign on the wall also recommended that you float with your arms over your head. It is definitely weird at first and takes some adjustment. The employee we spoke with said that the first 30 minutes are where your mind races and then you relax into it fully. I didn't find that to be the case for me. I felt it came in waves. I'd have good mediation periods and then go into mind racing anxious "when is this over, how long has it been" thoughts. It felt like the full 90 minutes, (if not longer) and I didn't go to sleep. I had to take a few breaks where I sat up in the tank to reconvene and get my thoughts together. However, overall I would say it was a good experience, just not as easy as I think it was sold to be. It's cool to be floating in a tank but also as weird as it sounds too. 
They play soft music at the end of the session and I was both excited it was over and then a bit sad because it was during one of my meditative periods. 
Make sure you wash your hair afterwards; I made this mistake because I was feeling lazy and my hair was covered in flaky salt afterwards. Wash your hair!! 
I'm docking a star because I feel that it's not quite as easy as advertised, especially if you aren't accustomed to long meditations and also because my BF's tank had clumps of hair that was gross and extremely distracting for him. However, we both felt very relaxed and enjoyed our floats, but it wasn't quite the mind opening experience I felt was sold to be.

Funny Story. 

I attended an opening for Imogene & Willie and they gave us these awesome gift bags with this magical smelling candle. 

When you light this candle, it's as if you are transported to a forest filled with flowers on a warm spring day. Seriously. It's some kind of wonderful. It burns smooth and even and the actual candle is black and unique. It's glorious. 

I'd come home and the candle was lit and I'd tell my boyfriend "Don't light it for no reason! I bet that thing is expensive!" 

My warnings fell on deaf ears and soon, the candle burned down to the bottom and we needed to seek out a replacement. We finally made our way to Imogene and picked up this magical candle. We get to the register and we THINK that the hipster chick says $60! 

Wait wait... That can't be right... "You said $16, correct?"

"No. It's SIXTY dollars." 

After the shock wore off, we looked at each other in dismay and said we couldn't pay that for a candle. So we then asked "Why is it that expensive??"

She said it was "the ingredients" and "from California." 

Whaa??? 

The moral of this story is, they sell candles that are SIXTY freaking dollars. So, I'll have to stick with my ho hum vanilla bean selection from Target and long for better candle days.

I am so happy that my friend was staying at this hotel and we were able to grab drinks at his lovely bar. 

This place is insanely good. I LOVE the decor and all the candles surrounding the bar, tables and lighting up the hotel in general. Add on the forest of herbs and additions sitting on the bar and I felt like I was in a different place altogether!  The bartender Shawn(Sean?) was SO AMAZING. He presented us with a list of nice cocktails that looked great, then told us that he likes to make personalized drinks for customers based on a couple questions he asks customers. We are the adventurous sort and opted to have personalized cocktails. 

Our party had a variety of tastes, so Shawn made us a bloody mary, old fashioned, gin, and vodka drink. I don't even like gin, and the fantastic cocktail was out of this world. I couldn't taste the gin and was trying to steal any bit from my friend that she would allow me to snag. The other drinks were excellent as well; he used chocolate bitters in the old fashioned that gave it a complex and unique flavor.

We sat at the bar for a couple hours and had two drinks each that got me quite tipsy. I wish I had discovered this bar earlier so I could enjoy it more than once!

Guess I need to go back to NOLA soon....

This was my 2nd or 3rd time at the Tomato Arts Festival, and I have a good time coming here!

I like browsing the booths of food, jewelry, art, and other miscellaneous items and stopping in at some of the places of business in and around 5 points. However, I hate that it's just SO crowded and crazy if you try to escape the heat and grab a drink or some food at one of the restaurants nearby. That's the other issue, it is sooo hot! I was hoping with our mild summer it wouldn't be so bad, but alas, it was just as blistering hot as usual. Blerg! 

I still enjoy stopping in at the food booths, while most places have food for sale, you can also sample salsas (my favorite) and other goodies while walking around. Plus this time, we walked around when things were closing up and I managed to snag two pairs of earrings from a vendor for quite cheap since they would rather sell the items than take them home! Score! 

There's plenty to do if you get here early; all kinds of contests and competitions, and some pretty awesome people watching as well! 

Who knew the tomato was THIS popular?

Oh TPAC, you never let me down!

With 3 different auditoriums, TPAC can host popular comedians, broadway shows, smaller theatrical productions, concerts, operas, the ballet, and everything in between! I appreciate the variety of offerings they have, and always enjoy coming to shows here. 

They also allow adult beverages in the show, and will pre-order drinks for you so you can swing by the bar during intermission. So convenient! If you are in Andrew Jackson Hall (the largest one) they recently opened a bar INSIDE the auditorium. That just rules!

You can park for free at the capitol just off Charlotte down the hill a bit, and I always do that to avoid paying to park :) 

My only complaint is that their bathrooms aren't super accessible or convenient, and I feel their signage is small. The restaurants also seem to be crowded no matter when you go. 

I appreciate you TPAC, and am excited to see which shows grace your stage this year!

OK. The Hermitage Cafe is where you need to "end" up after a night on Broadway. Period. After two consecutive weekends singing karaoke and having a fun night on the town, I found myself coming back on two very similar evenings. Roll in late at night and order the biscuits and gravy. JUST DO IT. They come smothered in a delicious white gravy with lots of black pepper. YES. I also tried the grilled cheese and grilled chicken sandwich, and both were fantastic. Prices are very cheap ($4.00 for a sandwich and potatoes) and the place is just an experience overall. Check it out for some awesome drunk food. The only annoyance is that they are cash only!

JJ's is awesome. From the outside, it's rather confusing as to what is within, but after browsing through the shelves of international chocolates, snacks, and beer, you stumble into the coffee shop area where they offer tea, specialty "house" coffee drinks, and the standard java options. 

Sure, the furniture is beaten up to the point of almost falling apart, but there's something  warm and homey about it. And I love the tall ceilings and open windows that let in the sun. I've stopped in with a group of friends and had game nights here, it's a great space to relax, study, conduct a business meeting, or catch up with a group of friends. One of Nashville's greatest treasures! 

My only complaint is they are a bit slowish with making your drinks, so stop in if you are looking for a leisurely visit!

My brother is a big fan of this place, so I was excited when the opportunity arose to come in for a quick dinner and margarita. We ordered a large cheese dip, salsa, and authentic jalapeño and roja sauce that I typically get at taco trucks. 
I always judge a place on their salsa, and theirs was good, but it wasn't my favorite. I can't quite put my finger on it, but it was lacking something. Maybe the batch was just off. However, the cheese dip and other sauces were fantastic. 
I ordered 3 authentic tacos, 2 pastor, 1 chorizo. Our waiter came back to double check which tacos I ordered, but he still got them wrong when I got my food. I ate them anyway and luckily they were really tasty, just 2 chorizo, 1 pastor instead. The corn tortillas were a bit thicker than I prefer, but I admit they were perfect for leftovers and didn't fall apart. I actually think they were better the next day honestly. 
My BF had the enchiladas and they were really good. The refried beans were fantastic, and I know what I'm getting next time around! 
Sadly, they also have the unfortunate Mexican dynamic of having really good food but subpar, premixed margaritas. I ordered the "top shelf" option, and it just tasted like extra tequila. However, it was drinkable and washed down the chips good enough. 
I can see why this place is a staple in Hendersonville. It's a great Mexican option that has authentic dishes with the Americanized ones and I am excited to venture out and experiment with the menu next time!

I've tried to go to the Stillery multiple times, but somehow kept missing opportunities until I finally made it in for some food this weekend. My friend and I were starving and everything on the menu looked enticing! 
To start I ordered the brussels sprouts and my friend ordered the chopped salad. I was disappointed with the sprouts...they were cooked to mush and completely soggy with an awful texture...hello every child's gripe with brussels sprouts and why they've had to make a comeback. I like mine crispy and lightly cooked, not a giant mush ball. Don't order these! My friend's chopped salad was just OK, but didn't seem to be super fresh. Again, I'd steer clear of it. 
However....the pesto pizza was phenomenal! We both devoured that guy and it was a perfect portion for us to share. The crust was even delicious with garlic and butter on top. Yes please!! Highly recommend you give their pizzas a try because ours was PERFECT! 
I almost gave them 3 stars, but I had to dock another star because our server wasn't great. We had to ask for plates as well as cheese and pepper flakes for our pizza which should be provided. It wasn't busy and I felt that we didn't get the service we should have. 
I also had a drink from their specialty cocktail menu but it wasn't strong. Good thing it was affordable at $8, but I'd get something different next time. I think they have potential and I do want to try that hot chicken mac and cheese because it looked spot on! Here's to hoping my next experience will be a much better one!

As a first time home buyer, I had plenty on my plate. Thank goodness for Big League Movers! I was lucky enough that Living Social ran a deal for 2 hours of moving services for $99, so I quickly snatched up the deal and scheduled them to help me move! 

I had to move on a specific weekend and they had Sunday morning available. If you have a specific day you need to move, make sure you call sooner rather than later! There was an additional $40 gas/service fee, and they were about 30 minutes early the morning of the move. The guys were super nice and efficient and moved all of my furniture within 2 hours. Perfect! 

At the end of the services you speak with their supervisor on the phone to make sure everything is good to go. Excellent chance for customer service assurance as well! 

I'd highly recommend this moving company!

There's a subtle charm about the Gold Rush that keeps me coming back. Maybe it's that it's not pretentious, and a good place to get a no-nonsense cocktail or beer before a show or just to hang out with friends. They have an excellent selection of vodka, and it's been a LONG time since I've had the food here. On my most recent visit I eyed the spinach dip which looked quite delicious. 

I enjoy the Gold Rush. It's a dive bar where you need it most. I'll be back again so I can review the food!

NOTE: They allow smoking, so be prepared!

Man, I'm pretty torn about this review... 

I think I should preface by saying I'm not a huge meat eater/lover even though I do eat it and enjoy being a carnivore on occasion. So if you are a meat head and love it... maybe I'm not your best review to read. However, I will continue with that disclaimer! 

This was my first time ever being at a Brazilian steakhouse, but I knew the standard; price fix menu and unlimited supply of food. To be honest, I have never had a desire to eat at one of these restaurants, but as it was someone's birthday I came along for dinner. 

There are two options; full rodizio with unlimited meat and salad bar for $32.99 or salad bar only for $18.99. Multiple people have told me this is a great deal as most Brazilian Steakhouses are around $50 per person. 

After taking a look at the salad bar and seeing all of the food available, I went with the salad bar only and it was PLENTY of food. I enjoyed it; they offered hot dishes and cold ones as well with some hits and misses, but overall pretty decent. I snuck a bite or two of meat from my boyfriend's plate and it was tasty, but I didn't find myself upset that I missed out on it to be honest... some feedback from the table who did partake in the meat selections said that there were some cuts of meat that were amazing, others were a bit tough. They also are pretty good about cutting off big pieces if you want that. 

I did get a bit frustrated having to say "no thanks" over and over again to the gauchos who were bringing by meat. It was better once we told our server that I was only eating the salad bar, but I still had to say "no thanks" again and again. One of them it must have been his first day because he didn't have hardly ANY muscle in cutting the meat and had some difficulty getting pieces off. 

So you see my dilemma... $18.99 is a bit steep in my opinion for a salad/hot bar only, but it was good. It's nice to have the option to opt out of the full experience if you are trying to save some money or have dietary restrictions. I think vegans are a bit screwed....just don't come here if you are vegan period! 

I keep going back and forth between 3 and 4 stars but I think I have to go with my gut and give them a 3.. I can't see myself rushing back unless it is someone else's choice.

NOTE: My BF said he would give them 4 stars if that helps; he had the full meat experience!

This is my favorite Whole Foods in Tennessee! I love shopping here... I just can't afford to every week :( Must.. win.... lottery!

But alas, on the days I can afford to splurge, I come to this location and enjoy my shopping experience! Your first stop needs to be the juice bar to quench your thirst while you shop. My personal fav is apple base, with spinach, kale, and lemon. YUM. But they also have lemonades and smoothies if that's more your thing. Be warned; the juice bar is in high demand, so get your order in and do a bit of shopping then come back, it's worth it!!!

So all that shopping will make you hungry, and after you've browsed the amazing produce, stop at the cooking station with a sit down bar right by the seafood department. They have a delicious menu with a variety of food, plus daily specials. The cooks prepare the food right in front of you, it's like a healthy hibachi but with anything you want! If I'm going to eat at Whole Foods, I eat here and am never disappointed. Also, they have beer and root beer on tap. Hello wonderful!

If you visit on the weekends, they have TONS of samples and stations where you can try a variety of things. And what's great about a store with such excellent customer service is that you ask for something and you'll get it. A sample of a cheese? No problem. What kind of Greek yogurt is best? They'll open a package for you and give you a spoon. I. love. it. Nothing is too difficult here. 

I've got to say, I don't love their giant buffet at the back of the store, it always looks so great but I leave disappointed. But that's OK because they have all kinds of other stuff like pizza, a sushi station, and multiple food bars along the way. I've still got to recommend my cooking station by seafood, I always love the food there! 

Come back and take a cooking class upstairs, those are super fun and very reasonable for what you get. 

Come to Whole Foods and stay all day! I know I could :)

There's a ton to like about the Hutton Hotel, from the obvious tiny touches and finery to the extra care they build into your experience when you set foot inside. It's an easy place to stay by and large, and though I wasn't here for more than a night this go round, I definitely enjoyed my stay. 

It's worth mentioning that I don't count on sleeping well in hotels - one's experience can vary wildly from one place to the next, and even some of the nicer hotels around can't seem to manage the Pillow Conundrum, wherein they furnish rooms with pillows so puffy your head basically sleeps at a ninety degree angle. I digress, but you see my point: little touches like fluffy pillows that are actually comfortable to sleep on rule the day here, and it seems most everyone I met kind bordering on enthusiastic (with the sole exception being one of the housekeeping staff, and in fairness to her, it was about time for me to check out at that point). Still, I'd stay here again in a heartbeat. 

I'm just scratching the surface on Nashville and can't wait for my next trip in. This green hotel is but one of those reasons.

Dark and awesome, it's super sketchy in the best dive bar fashion at Snake and Jake's, the kind of place where you hope no one remembers to open the door lest some light creep in. The joint's bathed in a sort of amber haze, and bellying up and ordering something questionable seems only natural. 

For my part, I tried on a High Life (it fit fine, thanks) and settled into the rhythm that comes from catching the room's vibe, a mash-up teeming with regulars and those of us descending from all parts. It's a great spot for low conversation and easy countenance, and it's not at all unusual to witness a dog wandering around, sort of taking notes, as dogs do. And I'm beginning to think that that hound's been holding out on the rest of us.

A Wednesday night's as good as any when it comes to jazz, which, we were reminded by the band onstage, is one of those gifts bestowed upon the world by Americans. Flag waving aside, these guys were cool as cucumbers as they made their way through some standards, and when a local legend drummer made his way to the stage (looking like he'd just come from the back nine), they ripped off a number of inspiring tracks for a now rollicking crowd. 

It's an interesting setup - to make your way into the main performance room, there's usually a cover (last night it was fifteen), but if you're content to park it at the downstairs bar, they pipe the music in from upstairs and have a tv feed showing the band happening. Oddly, this bar appears to be tilting a little, there are very few straight lines at play here. But if you're in the market for a decent pour and some straight up fab jazz, Snug Harbor's got what it takes.

I was genuinely impressed with Tavern, an unassuming by way of modern restaurant buildout teeming with the local and the hungry on a Sunday morning prior to NFL kickoffs. This clearly is a hopping brunch spot, and they were enjoying enough of a crowd that the wait seemed to be expected among regulars. There was also a little bit of crisp in the air, which made camping outside the patio downright pleasant. 

Eventually though time flies and we opted for a seat outside: the brunch menu was the only one available, and ultimately I opted for a burger, served alongside a very bistro-riffic tiny dipper of fries. Know that the burgers are sizable: I arrived with an appetite and chose to set a little of it aside, which belied its tastiness. They do not, as the saying goes, skimp. 

You'll spend a little here, but won't break the bank. Service was attentive. I'm not in Nashville often these days, but if I were, you can bet I'd be back. Who knows, maybe I will one day anyway.

I wouldn't really call Mena's a palace, per se, but I'm kind of guessing that if it came right down to it and they found themselves cross-examined, they probably wouldn't term it that either. What this place is, definitively, is a local diner, teeming with regulars, and good cheer and some storytelling mixed in for good measure. 

Maybe in that order and just perhaps, maybe not. 

Either way you shake it, I ended up here when another lunch timed out due to a characteristic New Orleans squall, and I soon found myself face first into a plate of fried chicken. They do specials by the bucket load here, and it's pretty likely that you'll encounter a room full of locals. I sat next to a six top that included one gentleman so advanced in years that you could have watched him sit via time lapse photography. This, of course, didn't deter the cheery hostess who knew him by name. That table showed one another lots of photos, told all sorts of stories, and I soaked up what I could. 

Prices a pretty cheap and you're a salt shaker away from the Monteleone, so if you have business there like I did, doesn't take long to get back. In a pinch, a hearty bite I needed.

Family owned and borderline ornate in spots, the Hotel Monteleone proved a welcome respite from the gushing skies of New Orleans this week. Sure, you're right there on the edge of the quarter, but if what you're really after is a few comfortable winks and one of the more unusual hotel bars going, this place has both in spades. 
Be careful where you set things down in the bar: it rotates ("a helluva trick to play on a man," the recent Esquire article said that name-checked this watering hole as one of the US' great bars). 

All in all though, my room was comfy, the amenities cool (if not expansive), and the staff was largely friendly and helpful. Worth noting that if you drive in, parking is thirty bucks a day...but I got such a deal on the room (they've been running a summer special during slow season) that it was easily still worth it to camp here. I'd definitely stay here again.

I definitely enjoyed this place, and to make matters more interesting (well, more interesting than usual, which is pretty interesting), it was the kickoff night of Yelp Drinks Nashville and, as it turns out, the last night of the Preds season. Which didn't keep the place for turning into a verifiable madhouse when the game started. If you've never hit this stop when every heart beats in unison with the red light on top of the net, try it sometime. It's memorable. 

I sipped on a couple of specialty cocktails they were mixing up for the occasion, and washed it down with a Yazoo brew or two (when in Rome), and a pretzel with a side of ground mustard. Ultimately, I likely didn't eat enough (at least this was the message emanating from my skull the next day), but what's not to like about good service, a solid drink selection, and some intense sports with friends in the offing? From where I sit, that's no problem at all.

This is one of those situations where it's probably best that I didn't pop in here with a dining companion...one who no doubt would have had to listen to a semi-tragic rendering of ill-advised Star Wars verses. It's a cool restaurant, though. 

I wandered in during the first half of the first pre-season game the Saints have played since winning the Super Bowl last year, and that must have had some impact on the crowd, as the room was busy but not overly so: the bartenders chatted casually with one another behind the counter as I bellied up, ordered a Schneider Weiss and Steak Frites and settled in. 

My food hit the spot in front of me in a reasonable period of time, and as I'd been too busy to eat well that day, just in time. The service wasn't the friendliest I encountered in the city, but the food was spot on. When you're craving some French Food, you could definitely do worse than here.

Although this oyster bar/restaurant has the name "desire" in it, the oysters here left much to be desired. My boyfriend and I stopped by upon coming across the $1 oysters sign outside. Now having had $1 oysters before, we didn't come with the highest expectations but at least thought the experience would be satisfying. 

We ordered a dozen oysters plus a glass of champagne on the side. The oysters arrived to us looking very...grimy. Each oyster we picked up left remnants of dirt and shells all over our hands meaning they weren't cleaned very well. We tried dunking our oysters in the ice water we got to get rid of some of the dirt but then that just took away all the flavor. Not that these oysters were very flavorful to begin with.

Our waitress was very nice and we felt bad having to ask her if she could take them back to the kitchen for a rinsing. After they were rinsed, we tried to enjoy them but just couldn't as mediocre oysters ran under water doesn't taste much better than mediocre oysters with dirt on them. We ended up leaving without finishing our dozen. At least the champagne was good and bubbly.

While visiting New Orleans, it's good to get away for part of the day to experience something other than hustle and bustle of the city life. Enter: the swamp tour. While some may balk the idea of venturing into a swamp, it's actually a great experience that you won't find in any other place. It's also surprisingly quite clean as well due to the constant moving waters. If you have time for any tour, the swamp tour is the one to take! 

Make sure you set aside about half the day for this particular tour. Pick-up at your hotel is relatively easy and the driver will spend some time gathering the rest of attendees. Along the way, the bus driver may keep you entertained with stories about the city. It was so interesting to see and learn about the remaining effects of Hurricane Katrina as we left New Orleans. When you get to the swamp site, you'll check-in and then wait to be called in groups. Then, you board your designated boat and it's away you go for about an hour and a half. 

The tour itself really gives you an appreciation of the unique landscape the state of Louisiana is situated on. It doesn't get any closer to nature and the tour guide will take you around the marshland, swamp and even the bayou. Of course, we saw plenty of gators swim up to our boat and we were able to get plenty of cool shots as our tour guide fed them marshmallows and hot dogs from a stick. We also saw turtles, ducks and feral pigs as we ventured deeper into the bayou. The land is truly beautiful and the tour guides work hard to show you a good time.

So I didn't think I was going to be using public transportation, since I was visiting a friend with a car.  However, he had to run some errands and I wanted to explore the city, so I told him I would just check out what this city has to offer as far as mass transit.

I must admit, I like it, especially the metrolink.  Coming from Houston, we have awful mass transit.  Their metrolink resembles a mini version of chicago's rail system.  This one is only west and east.  There is a red and a blue line.  It even takes you across the river.

The pricing could be a bit better, they offer a one way, two way, a couple of hours, a day and a week rate.  I know chicago offers a 3? and 5? day pass?  It's good because especially if you're on vacation a whole week might be too much but 1 day is too little.  I went with the one day pass for $7.50.  

The people who rode the rail was very helpful to a tourist like myself.  It was on time and travels fast.

One of the must dos on any trips is a nice dinner.

However, this trip we decided the day of to make reservations of where to go.  What made this even more difficult was our group was 14 people.  Good luck finding a 5 star restaurant who could even take that reservation alone, but only a few hrs before? Slim to no chance.

We were lucky, because Herbsaint was able to accommodate our request.  When we arrived we noticed they had set up our table outside, which wasn't so bad since it was a cool night, and this way our group could be a bit louder.

I started out with the gumbo, it was OK, not the best by any means a friend got the soup of the day which was superb, don't remember what it was (sorry).  

My section of the table decided to start out with a couple of the small plates and share them so we could sample their offerings.  We got the gnocchi, the beef short rib, and the spaghetti with the fried egg.  By far the spaghetti with the fried egg was the best.  It was a bit rich but really satisfying.

As far as entrees went our section were so happy with being able to try so many dishes for appetizers we decided to do something similiar with the main dishes.  The special for this night was lamb neck, yes lamb neck.  This thing was the most amazing piece of meat I had ever tasted.  Another person in the group had the ribeye, which was OK but nothing out of this world, and another person had the pork belly, that was good but the lamb neck had just blown everything else out of the water.

The french fries with pimenton aioli sounded great so we decided to add an order of that too.  It lived up to the description.

Overall, the best dishes were the "specials" of the day.  Fast service and 2 thumbs up for being able to squeeze our large group in.

Besides the Cathedral, this is my 2nd favorite spot along my whole trip to STL.  It's a unique sculpture park, with lots of art, huge green space, and it's completely free.  They have nice paths you can jog or walk upon.

This is one of those not super touristy places, but I feel is a must see while in town.

When you think of New Orleans, you don't think beautiful parks and peaceful sculpture gardens...

Or do you?

Well if you're tired of flashing drunk girls on Bourbin street, or at least something to do during the day, this is the place.

First off, take the trolly out here.  Gives you a chance to experience a true marvel.  Next, bring a camera.  You are in store for some great stuff.

It's so beautiful out here.  Trees, sculptures, benches, fields, if I was a local I would be here everyday working out.

Best experience of my whole trip to NO.

Screw the long lines at Krystal Burger, when you can come to Arby's get a nice cheddar roast beef sandwich, dip it in the juicy Arby's sauce and add in a LARGE Curly fries, and DAMN that's a late night meal.
1.00 gets you a set of their beads. 8.00 and you will be on your ass. 15.00 will get you one without ice and you'll wish you didn't stop by here. Always the way to start any night on Bourbon street.
Walking around Bourbon street and looking for a bar to enter? This place isn't bad, they have a live band, quick service at the bar.

I've heard so many good things about this place and I was afraid if it would live up to the hype.  When you walk into the door you're welcomed and asked if you want to try some of the pralines! Free pralines, I'm already a fan.

I looked around and saw what I had been craving...WHITE CHOCOLATE!!!

I know it's not even real chocolate but who cares it tastes great.  They had a whole section dedicated to my crack!  I got white chocolate reeses, the white chocolate oreos, I got just about the whole white chocolate section.  

Also a friend asked for a king cake and I was not certain about their king cake but if they were as good as the candy I'm sure it was superb.

I don't know what I like more about this place, the name or the actually pizza?

Pi, what a great name for a pizza joint, it's PI-Z-Z-A, so you got that going, then pi similar to pie, which is also known as a pizza pie, and then you can use pir^2 to get the area of the pizza, or the diameter, circumference...the possibilities are endless! My mind was totally blown.

As far as the pizza, this stuff compares to deep dish found in chicago.  Before my trip to chicago I was not a fan of deep dish, because all I had was pizza hut, which does not count haha.

My only complaint with deep dish pizza is the wait, but here it's really not that bad.  They recommended us to split a salad, we opted to try the BLT which has romaine lettuce, red onions, pepperoncini, crispy bacon, cherry tomatoes, parmesan cheese, with peppercorn ranch dressing.  It was very good and light and by the time we were done the pizza was ready.
